fields.headline: Keep off the intellectual property
fields.standfirst: Does the knowledge economy need patent protection?  Simon Caulkin investigates
fields.trailText: Does the knowledge economy need patent protection? Simon Caulkin investigates
fields.body:
Last week Halifax announced it was filing for a patent for its new Internet bank. The move would barely raise an eyebrow in the US, where patenting software and business methods has become common. But it is a significant first for Europe, where no company has yet patented a business process. Indeed, the Financial Times condemned the move as anti-competitive and a brake on innovation.

Unwelcome or not, Halifax's initiative will not be the last. Gone are the days when patents meant widgets and Heath Robinson-type inventors. Patents today are the new business rock'n'roll, one of the hottest commercial battlegrounds - and the fate of the Halifax application will be watched far beyond the banking sector.

Companies are becoming increasingly concerned with intellectual property issues, says Lyn Barkow, a patents specialist at Withers, a City law firm. She predicts a surge of activity on ideas which would not previously have qualified for protection.

Like the cuckoo in spring, the prominent new role of patents is an unmistakable sign that the knowledge economy has arrived. According to the Brookings Institution, intellectual assets, including brands, know-how and patents, now represent more than 70 per cent of the market value of US manufacturing firms. For Internet firms, the proportion can be nearer 100 per cent. Attempts to fence off this valuable real estate to keep out trespassers are bound to become common.

In the physical economy, patents were largely left to gather dust in drawers, dragged out only for defensive purposes - sometimes to spectacular effect. The great patent war over instant photography gained Polaroid nearly $1 billion in damages, and cost Kodak $3bn - probably the most expensive case of intellectual property mismanagement in history.

Most companies, say Kevin Rivette and David Kline in their book, Rembrandts in the Attic: Unlocking the Hidden Value of Patents , start rummaging through that attic only when they are up against it financially. Examples are Texas Instruments, which now makes an estimated $800m a year from licensing deals, and IBM, whose $1.5bn in licensing revenues makes up a fifth of its profits. On the other hand, a new-economy company such as Cambridge-based ARM is a pure intellectual-asset play, its business model based entirely on licensing.

Despite these role-models, US companies have underutilised their patent assets to the tune of a staggering $1 trillion, according to Rivette and Kline. But the pace is picking up as companies become more pro-active. Patent activity has doubled in the US, although in Europe, where protection is harder to get, the pace is still slow.

The Internet has given a hefty shove to the patenting surge, dramatically raising the stakes of success and the intensity of competition. 'When you look at a new business, you ask: what's going to prevent people doing exactly the same and competing the profits to zero?' says Eileen Shapiro, a Boston consultant who helps companies with initial public offerings.

Countering the FT , Shapiro argues that patents benefit customers as well as companies. The Internet offers opportunities to make genuinely better products and services, she reasons, and patents help ensure companies take these opportunities by giving firms incentives to focus on substantial rather than cosmetic improvements.

Shapiro attributes much of the burgeoning patenting activity to the fact that the Internet infrastructure is now advanced enough for non-techies to develop new business methods. To cash in, some of the big consultancies are considering patenting their processes. And taking the idea one step further, entrepreneurs such as Jay Walker have set up 'patents factories' to generate patentable ideas for new firms. One of its patents for reverse auctions formed the basis for Internet firm Priceline, now worth $10bn. Patents marketplaces are inevitably being developed to trade promising ideas.

Should Europe follow the US line on patenting business ideas? In the short term it may have little choice. As the importance of intellectual assets has grown, patenting has become an unacknowledged but potent weapon in the battle for national competitive advantage. It is no coincidence that the US deci sion to allow software and biotechnology patents took place in the early Eighties, when most of the rest of US industry was being hammered by the Japanese.

Likewise, the 1998 court case that established protection for business methods, opening up e-commerce for patenting, has given US firms crucial breathing space.

Barkow of Withers says the European Patents Office (EPO) is, despite previous reservations, likely to be more sympathetic to these applications in future, provided they are properly framed.

Unlike the European system, US patent law does not allow competitors to challenge applications at the investigation stage. However, many fall down when tested in the courts. This may happen to some of the new business patents, Barkow believes. In two eagerly watched cases, Amazon is suing Barnes & Noble for getting too close to its 'one-click' ordering patent, while Priceline is attacking Microsoft on reverse auctions. And in a case which has been hailed by European environmentalists, the EPO upheld objections to the 1994 patenting of a fungicide based on the Indian neem tree on the grounds that the technique adopted by the US applicant had been used by local farmers for years.

In the longer term, many people believe that an intellectual property regime based on physical assets needs to be reassessed to level the global playing field and to stop contentious areas - human genes, for example - from becoming a commercial battleground.

One proposal, apparently supported by Amazon's Jeff Bezos, is to vary the length of protection awarded - 'one-click' hardly deserves the 20-year monopoly accorded to a multi-million pound drug. Shapiro, though, smells hypocrisy. In Internet time, five years is ample to wring all the benefits from a business patent, she says. Besides, who knows where Amazon will be in 20 years time?

webTitle: Tesco Metros close as high rents bite

fields.headline: Tesco Metros close as high rents bite
fields.trailText: Tesco, the biggest UK food retailer, is poised to close up to 10 of its Metro convenience stores, apparently after poor financial performance.
fields.body:
Tesco, the biggest UK food retailer, is poised to close up to 10 of its Metro convenience stores, apparently after poor financial performance.

The supermarket group, run by Terry Leahy, has already ordered the closure of two of the 41 town centre shops, in Leicester and Southend. Its Bristol store is thought to be next in line .

'We close very few stores. It's disappointing for us that those stores didn't hit their targets,' a Tesco spokeswoman said. Adding that all its stores were continually monitored, she refused to rule out further closures.

It is understood that some provincial city centre stores have high rents which cannot be offset by the economies possible at its larger supermarkets. Some of the Metros sell a lot only at lunchtimes and as workers head home.

Competition for the best retail sites - caused partly by the Government's opposition to out-of-town shopping developments, has sparked a near-doubling of shop rents on British high streets in the past five years.

Sainsbury's answer to the Metro, the Local, has also run into trouble. Last year, Sainsbury's launched an assault on the £15 billion convenience store market with plans to 'rapidly develop' 200 of them within three years. So far it has opened only six.

'We can't build out of town, so everyone wants to be on the high street,' Sainsbury's said. 'It's hard finding the right slot at the right price.'

Tesco launched its first Metro seven years ago in London's Covent Garden. That store sells more champagne per square foot than any of its other outlets, the company explained, thanks to the number of advertising agencies in the area. Its other London stores also do well.

There are 20,000 convenience stores in Britain. The market leader is Spar UK, with 2,000 outlets.

Tesco, which has a total of 659 UK stores, has suffered its first year-on-year fall in sales for three years, research house Taylor Nelson Sofres said last week.

Tesco's market share dipped 1.3 per cent to 21.7 per cent, while Sainsbury's slumped six points to 17.1 per cent compared with the same time last year.

This week, Sainsbury's is due to post its first set of figures since the former Prudential boss, Sir Peter Davis, became its chief executive last March.

fields.headline: Handle a job offer
fields.trailText: Don't be too enthusiastic, condsider it for a day or two and get everything in writing
fields.body:
1: Don't let your enthusiasm for shaking the dust off your feet get the better of you. 'The golden rule is to see the offer in writing before handing in your notice,' says Philip Marks of recruitment consultancy Jonathan Wren. You need confirmation of your starting date, salary, any bonuses or other crucial terms, and job title.

2: Look very closely at the bonus arrangements if you are offered them - these are a constant source of misunderstandings between employers and employees. Ask your new company to fax over the terms of the bonus, if necessary - spelling out whether it is guaranteed or not, whether it depends on team or individual performance.

3: Spend a day or two, at least, considering the offer. 'If an employer says they need a response in 24 hours, you'd treat that with a reasonable degree of caution,' says Louise Smith of consultancy JM. 'It's quite legitimate for someone to have one or two weeks to make the decision.'

4: Consider waiting until the company has got references (including medical references) before resigning your current post. Employers are paying more attention to sickness issues, for instance, and may ask a previous employer about your attendance record.

5: Watch out for the major legal traps - agreeing a start date with your new employer that you cannot fulfil because you have to work out your notice. This would put you in breach of contract with the new business. 'Make sure you definitely want the new job,' says James Davies, employment specialist at solicitor Lewis Silkin. 'If your present employer says: "Don't go, we love you, have a pay rise", you'll be in breach of contract if you accept.'

6: Play a straight bat if you have a few competing job offers, says Smith. 'You can say something like: "I've got three offers and one has offered me £5,000 more. Is there anything you can do?" They can only say no. It's quite legitimate to negotiate.' Candidates often improve their salary by 10 or 20 per cent by going this route.

7: Check the credentials of small, new businesses, especially dot.com employers. Recruitment agencies regularly do credit checks and Companies House trawls on new companies.

8: Set down the basic terms in writing in your letter of acceptance, especially if you discussed them over the phone. This is particularly important if, for example, you agreed that you would be exempt from the company's usual requirement that staff wear uniform or work unlimited hours.

fields.headline: How green can you go?
fields.standfirst: Do's and don'ts of energy saving, by Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: UK households waste £6.5 billion a year on energy - £278 per household - according to the Energy Saving Trust. Cutting energy use would not only save you money, it would be good for the environment.
fields.body:
UK households waste £6.5 billion a year on energy - £278 per household - according to the Energy Saving Trust. Cutting energy use would not only save you money, it would be good for the environment. At present the average house emits more harmful carbon dioxide gas than the average car.

Water company Hyder, with the Energy Savings Trust, has suggested a number of ways of improving your home's energy efficiency, cutting bills at the same time:

Loft insulation: Installing loft insulation to a depth of at least 8in (200mm) can cut heating costs by up to 20 per cent.

Glazing: Up to 23 per cent of heat loss from a home can be via windows. Double glazing can cut this loss by up to 50 per cent. Using new energy-efficient glass can cut it by a further 10 per cent.

Cavity wall insulation: Most cavity walls, especially those built after 1930, can be filled. This can reduce heat loss by up to 60 per cent and save up to 35 per cent on fuel bills.

Draughtproofing: Putting this on badly fitting windows and doors can cut heat loss by up to 20 per cent.

Kitchen appliances: Buy an energy-efficient fridge, washing machine and other appliances. Look out for models labelled 'A' on the European Union's energy efficiency scale. They can use less than half the energy of similar models rated 'G', the lowest on the scale. Select the economy setting if possible.

Boilers: If your boiler is more than 15 years old, replace it with a condensing boiler and save 10-15 per cent on bills.

Bathroom: A bath or power shower uses up to 80 litres of water; an ordinary shower uses just 35 litres. A low-volume shower head can save a further five litres compared with a normal shower. If you have a big toilet cistern, ask your water company for a device to reduce the volume of water used per flush - or simply put a brick in it.

Heating controls: Upgrading your controls will help you to avoid overheating your home and water. Turning the thermostat down by 1 C can cut up to 10 per cent off bills.

Lighting: Use energy-saving bulbs and you can save up to £10 per bulb. If every household replaced three conventional bulbs, domestic carbon dioxide emissions would fall by 6.7 per cent.

Garden: Use a hosepipe with a trigger control, have a rain water butt fitted to your gutters and mulch your plants. Throw your sprinkler away.

Rubbish: Most rubbish is taken to landfill sites and generates methane, a 'greenhouse' gas more potent than carbon dioxide, and potentially toxic run-off. Increase the amount of paper, bottles and cans you recycle. Composting food waste could cut your household waste by 50 per cent.

Energy Saving Trust: 0345 277 200/www.est.org.uk

Centre for Alternative Technology: 01654 702400/ www.cat.org.uk.

For a copy of the Hyder guide 'Using Water Wisely', call 0800 052 0138.

fields.headline: How green is your mortgage-lender?
fields.standfirst: Two societies are wooing ecology-conscious borrowers, reports Andrew Bibby
fields.trailText: People keen to do their bit for the environment by improving or renewing an existing property often find that their idea of a sound property purchase does not tally with that of the mainstream mortgage lenders
fields.body:
People keen to do their bit for the environment by improving or renewing an existing property often find that their idea of a sound property purchase does not tally with that of the mainstream mortgage lenders. But two building societies - the Ecology and the Norwich & Peterborough - are lending support and money to borrowers who want to develop environmentally and socially sound homes.

With a single office on the edge of the Yorkshire dales near Skipton, the Ecology building society is well out of the mainstream. Its lending policy is designed to promote sustainable housing and communities. Chief executive Paul Ellis says the society is happy to send away potential customers if they don't meet the criteria: 'If you want to borrow for a holiday home or build a livery stable, you will be turned down out of hand.'

More controversially, the Ecology doesn't lend on conventional houses such as suburban semis. It is often the more unusual properties, turned down by other lenders, that end up on the Ecology's mortgage book. For example, the society is helping Berkshire couple Ken and Carole Neal construct a new home out of clay and straw, using the traditional 'cob' building method once used widely in the South-west. It is also funding a new home in Surrey built partly underground.

The Ecology also offers mortgages for traditional urban houses, such as inner-city terraces and back-to-backs, which it says are by their nature energy-saving. Dilapidated properties at risk of disappearing from the housing stock are also looked on favourably.

Currently the Ecology charges a fairly competitive variable rate of 7.39 per cent, with a 0.5 per cent discount in the first year. Its mortgages can be either interest-only or repayment. Unusually, the society also offers a 0.25 per cent cut in the rate after four years, where borrowers have maintained their mortgage satisfactorily and undertaken promised energy-saving measures.

Borrowers will find that the Ecology's mortgage conditions are likely to include a requirement for adequate insulation and, where appropriate, for windows to be double-glazed. Conventional double-glazing firms will, however, be disappointed. 'There is a requirement that replacement windows are not uPVC. We consider soft or hardwood double-glazed windows best for the environment,' Ellis says.

The Norwich & Peterborough building society is more likely to lend to 'light green' environmentally aware borrowers wanting more conventional property. The society launched its 'green mortgage' package for newly built houses in 1998, and extended this a few months later for existing buildings.

For new builds, the N&P is offering a 1 per cent discount off its variable rate for four years (increasing to 1.25 per cent with compulsory insurance), provided houses meet energy-efficient standards.

For existing properties, N&P's green mortgage discounts drop respectively to 0.75 per cent and 1 per cent, but the society compensates with a free energy survey offer and a £500 cashback payment towards energy-saving home improvements. N&P also offers a favourable first-year discount on further advances to its existing mortgage borrowers, where the extra money is to be spent on energy-saving measures.

Ecology Building Society: 0845 674 5566

Norwich & Peterborough: 01733 362636

webTitle: BA set to take over KLM

fields.headline: BA set to take over KLM
fields.trailText: British Airways is set to take over Dutch national carrier KLM in an audacious move to become the biggest airline in Europe and the fifth-biggest in the world.
fields.body:
British Airways is set to take over Dutch national carrier KLM in an audacious move to become the biggest airline in Europe and the fifth-biggest in the world.

Talks aimed at combining the two airlines are expected to begin soon after BA announces on Tuesday its first annual losses since privatisation - a staggering pre-tax, pre-exceptional loss of almost £300 million, compared with £174m profit it made in 1998-1999.

A senior airline source last week confirmed The Observer's story that BA was seeking to take a stake in KLM and added that a full merger is on the horizon.

fields.headline: A guide to guilt-free investing
fields.standfirst: You can be a capitalist with a conscience, as Helen Pridham discovers in the world of ethical funds.
fields.trailText: How can you get good returns on the stock market without compromising your principles? By choosing an ethical investment fund.
fields.body:
How can you get good returns on the stock market without compromising your principles?

By choosing an ethical investment fund. The investment managers who run these funds not only look for shares which will make profits, they are also guided by ethical criteria. They would not, for example, invest in companies that manufactured arms or promoted gambling.

Investing on an ethical basis is rapidly gaining popularity. A survey by the Co-operative Insurance Society has found that 91 per cent of people feel that companies have a duty towards society and 77 per cent believe businesses should not concentrate solely on profit.

Investors who want to support these beliefs through ethical investment can still get a good return on their money - investments in the average ethical fund have more than doubled in value over the past five years, and most qualify for inclusion in an individual savings account (Isa) so returns are tax free.

But, like most stock market investments, these funds have their ups and downs. This is often due to a tendency to invest in smaller companies.

Simon Baker, manager of Jupiter Ecology, explains: 'These funds were hit two years ago when crises in the Far East and Russia sent stock market investors scurrying for safe blue chip stocks. But over the past 18 months, smaller, growth stocks have returned to favour. What has been the key for many ethical funds is that the market has locked on to technology stocks.

Around 25 per cent of our fund is invested in environmental technology. We bought these stocks on the basis that the companies were offering solutions to green problems. Other investors are now buying because they think they are good financial ideas.'

Baker points to wind power, solar power and fuel cell technology as areas now taking off among mainstream investors.

However, performance may not be the main selection criteria for investors who feel strongly about particular issues. The criteria adopted by the 40-plus ethical funds are all slightly different, and some are more environmentally oriented than others. For example, most, but not all, ban from their portfolios companies involved in producing pornography. However, only a few avoid companies in road construction.

If there are issues which concern you, it is best to discuss the matter with a specialist financial adviser who knows the funds in detail. Ethical Investment Services, a Preston-based firm of independent advisers, recently set up a website (www.ethicalservices.co.uk) which allows investors to specify their ethical priorities. It will then select the Isa funds which most closely meet the priorities specified.

Ethical Investment Services director John Fleetwood says there has been concern in recent months about genetically modified food, but many fund managers are still developing their policy on genetic engineering. However, he adds: 'Apart from animal rights campaigners, most investors are not that discriminatory about the negative criteria. They prefer the fund managers to take a positive approach, investing in companies which are involved in, say, renewable energy, rather than holding shares in banks and telecoms companies just because they happen not to break their criteria.'

Investors concerned about animal welfare will find considerable differences in approach between fund managers. Nearly all state that they avoid companies that use animals for testing cosmetics and household goods, but fewer explicitly exclude testing for pharmaceutical purposes or factory farming.

According to Ethical Investment Services, only three funds - Henderson Ethical, NPI Global Care Growth and Scottish Equitable Ethical - exclude all three and will, for example, avoid investing in supermarkets selling meat and dairy products.

Some fund managers offer investors a choice between funds with very strict negative criteria and those that follow a more pragmatic policy. NPI's Global Care Income fund and Scottish Equitable's Socially Responsible Equity fund are both examples of the latter. As NPI's Toby Belsom explains, this approach is more inclusive: 'It involves looking for companies that are best in their class, such as the supermarket group Iceland, which took a lead on GM food labelling, and also engaging in active dialogue with companies to promote best practice on environmental and ethical issues.'

fields.headline: Going a bundle - or not
fields.trailText: If you are sold on the idea of concentrating your efforts on repaying debt, you don't necessarily have to sign up for a current account mortgage.
fields.body:
If you are sold on the idea of concentrating your efforts on repaying debt, you don't necessarily have to sign up for a current account mortgage.

Patrick Bunton of mortgage broker London & Country, points out that not everyone hates their current bank: 'A lot of people have a good relationship with their bank and don't want to go to an unknown entity.'

But you may be able to benefit from the money management system promoted by the current account product:

 If you have savings on deposit, but don't repay your credit cards in full each month, start by concentrating on paying off card debt.

 If you can afford to save, it may make sense to increase monthly mortgage payments, to shorten the term of the loan, rather than putting savings on deposit. Check for any early payment penalties. Most people want a rainy day fund - equivalent to between three and six months' income - to draw on in emergencies. But after this, debt repayment offers a good, risk-free return.

 Consider a flexible mortgage. These are halfway between current account mortgages and conventional home loans. There are facilities to repay debt without penalty and, sometimes, to take payment breaks. You can also get access, within limits, to the overpayments (which will be stored as equity in your property) if you need to raise capital again. The rate of borrowing should be cheaper than on a conventional personal loan or credit card. They work best if you regularly pay off more than you need, or pay off lump sums. If you never keep a balance on your credit cards and have no overdraft or personal loan, a flexible mortgage and a low-cost current account may be all you need to smarten up your financial management.

Bunton likes the flexible loans available from Yorkshire and Stroud & Swindon building societies.

Yorkshire has a loan at a variable rate of 6.74 per cent discounted by 3 per cent for four months. There are no redemption penalties. Stroud and Swindon has a fixed-rate flexi-loan at 6.29 per cent for two years with no penalties.

Generally, rates on flexi-loans are a little higher than on standard mortgages. So if your priority is debt repayment and not flexibility, you may do as well with a low-cost repayment loan.

Halifax's IF product promises the best of all worlds, but much will depend on the rates it offers on the individual components, says Bunton.

fields.headline: First lessons in joined-up money
fields.standfirst: One account for saving, mortgages and shopping... Is it the next big thing? For Halifax it's a very big IF. Maria Scott reports
fields.trailText: You have shopped around for a better deal on your savings. You made more than one phone call about a mortgage last time you moved house. You have changed to a cheaper credit card deal. You are not doing badly in the financial jungle.
fields.body:
You have shopped around for a better deal on your savings. You made more than one phone call about a mortgage last time you moved house. You have changed to a cheaper credit card deal. You are not doing badly in the financial jungle.

That's what you think. The financial engineers see things rather differently: to them, your methods verge on the prehistoric. What you need now, they say, is a plan that bundles your mortgage with your bank account - the twentyfirst-century way to manage your money.

In July, the Halifax bank will become the latest to launch a product that aims to link your home loans with your savings and current accounts. Even the name of the new product, Intelligent Finance - or IF, as it will be known - implies that all other banking and savings products are for lower forms of financial life.

IF will work on on the basis that for most people it does not make a sense to save in the conventional way. Borrowing is expensive, savings rates are poor, and the margin fattens bankers' profits. Customers who transfer borrowing, saving and banking business to IF will see balances on current accounts and savings deducted from from debts. So savings are, effectively, earning the same rate of interest as the highest rate the customer pays on borrowing. A person who has more savings than borrowings will pay no interest. Those who could benefit are older customers, who may have small mortgages but sizable sums on deposit.

Using notional rates of interest - the real ones will not be confirmed until July - IF has constructed examples to show how savings could stack up. Take someone with a £55,000 mortgage with HSBC charged at 7.64 per cent; an average current account balance of around £200 earning 0.1 per cent; savings of £2,200 earning 5.25 per cent; and £1,500 loan at 15.6 per cent with Marks & Spencer. This customer would have a monthly net interest bill (interest paid, minus interest charged) of £399.88. If they switched all borrowing and saving to IF, this would fall to £332.12 - a saving of £67.76 a month.

There are other products already tilling the same ground as IF already, albeit it with different equipment. Closest to the Halifax product are the Virgin One account and the First Active current account mortgage.

But neither account has signed up more than 25,000 people, mainly because the products are not easily understood. Halifax's product will be a gentler version of what Virgin and First Active offer, but will take advantage of the same basic financial logic.

Since IF aims to have 500,000 new customers in its first year and 2 million by the end of 2004, it could start a minor revolution in the way we manage our money.

Ian Giles of First Active says: 'If Halifax can't educate people on the merits of bundling products, who can?'

The new method of money management works on the basis that debt is expensive, even at today's historically low rate of interest. The problem is that interest rates are low. If you are earning 6.5 per cent on your savings, the return would be 5.2 per cent after basic-rate tax, falling to little more than 5 per cent after inflation.

For higher-rate tax payers, the return after tax and inflation dwindles to less than 4 per cent after tax and inflation. Debt, meanwhile, will cost anything from around 5 per cent, for a low-cost mortgage, to nearly 30 per cent if you use store credit cards.

Current account mortgages encourage you to add consumer debts to your mortgage, transfer the loan to the current account provider and pay everything off at a rate of well under 10 per cent. If you need access to cash later, you can increase your mortgage simply by writing a cheque against the account. Another way of looking at this is to see the savings on the amount you would have paid in interest on loans as a return. For higher-rate taxpayers in particular, the returns make debt repayment perhaps the best risk-free form of investment available.

A 40 per cent taxpayer would have to earn nearly 13 per cent on savings to match the saving achieved by repaying debt on a mortgage at 7.74 per cent. Even in a tax-free Individual Savings Account, it is not possible to achieve such returns at present.

But the new method of money management is not for everyone. The products (explained in more detail below) appear complicated to people accustomed to keeping their mortgages, loans, credit cards and savings separate.

And Graeme Stoner of accountant KPMG points out that where products allow flexibility to increase borrowing, there could be a temptation to borrow excessively against the value of your property: 'The concern I might have is that if your salary is £2,000 a month and your mortgage £750, if you then spend £1,500, you have increased your mortgage, not decreased it.'

Virgin and First Active both say that safeguards built into their products ensure borrowing will not get out of hand. Virgin says that in a recent survey 92 per cent of customers were paying more than necessary on their home loans to ensure their mortgages would be paid off within their pre-agreed terms.

Debt may be a good way to invest spare cash, but it is not necessarily the only way. Stoner says: 'We have clients who feel that having a mortgage is worthwhile because they can make their money work harder elsewhere: in business opportunities, for example, or the stock market.'

But with the Halifax investing heavily in the development of IF, we can all expect to hear more about the benefits of bundling savings with borrowing.

The current account loan is a neat enough idea, but is it right for you?

Look at the questions below. If you answer yes to most of them, you will probably benefit from a current account loan, or from the type of product being promoted by the Halifax's new Intelligent Finance subsidiary:

 Do you have debts on credit cards, store cards, bank overdrafts or personal loans?

 Are these with high street banks (where the rates are generally the highest in the market)?

 Do you have savings on deposit with a high street bank (where deposit rates are low)?

 Is your income irregular because, for example, you are self-employed?

 Do you regularly receive bonus payments in addition to a salary?

 Can you afford to pay off some of your borrowing now?

 Do you expect to have to borrow again in the next few years, maybe for home improvements or to pay for school fees?

 Would it be useful for you to draw on debt you have overpaid, by taking a payment break or paying less into your mortgage in the next few years, during maternity leave, perhaps?

 Are you prepared to monitor your mortgage and spending so that you repay as much borrowing as possible when you can afford to?

All-in-one accounts: pros and cons of the big three providers

Virgin One

This account was the first to combine current account and mortgage and promote the benefits of combining all borrowings and savings. It remains the most radical product of its type, because you must have your salary credited to the account each month.

You move your mortgage and any other borrowings to Virgin, where all will be charged the same rate of interest; rates vary depending on the percentage of property value borrowed. The loan rate starts at 7.1 per cent, rising to 7.7 per cent. This is certainly cheap borrowing compared with mainstream credit cards, but it is not the cheapest mortgage rate in the market, and Virgin does not offer fixed rates or discounts.

You can increase your borrowing after taking out the loan without going back to the lender for fresh permission, taking the loan to a maximum of 95 per cent of the property value.

Each month, your salary goes into the account and reduces the mortgage instantly. Even if the debt rises again, as bills are paid during the month, the customer has saved money, because interest is recalculated daily, rather than annually as with most conventional loans. If you budget to overpay the mortgage on a regular basis, savings can be huge. Virgin calculates that on a £70,000 loan charged at 7.29 per cent, a £50-a-month overpayment will save the borrower more than £19,500 and the mortgage will be repaid five years early.

Virgin One issues a cheque book and credit card, which are all debited to the account. The drawback, according to new competitor IF, is that all borrowing is secured against the account holder's property. And some say the requirement to have a salary paid in each month deters many. The system may also seem daunting since the account - based on the mortgage - is like a permanent overdraft, even though it will get steadily smaller as mortgage payments come off.

Verdict

Full marks for originality, but probably a product ahead of its time. Could be high risk for borrowers who do not monitor their account carefully, but should offer good value in the long term for people who can live within a budget.

First Active Current Account Mortgage

This aims to improve on Virgin One by offering fixed-rate mortgages and discounts. It offers full banking facilities, but customers do not have to have their salaries paid in.

Customers can use the loan as a flexible mortgage if they prefer, making over-payments or underpayments as suits their needs.

Ray Boulger at John Charcol says: 'Virgin insists that you pay your salary into the account but, generally, even though it may make sense, not everyone wants to do that.'

For mortgages up to 75 per cent of the property value, the current rate is 4.49 per cent; rising to 4.74 per cent at 85 per cent of the value and 4.99 per cent for a 95 per cent loan.

Ian Giles at First Active believes the current account mortgage 'makes the deposit account redundant'. Even so, he believes the product will appeal mainly to 'fairly sophisticated individuals' .

Those most likely to benefit are borrowers who have some surplus cash each month to make overpayments on their mortgages.

Verdict

Discounted rates and the option to maintain a separate current account make the product less daunting for nervous borrowers.

It is a lower-risk choice for the spendthrift than Virgin's account, because the current account can be kept separate.

If - Intelligent Finance

Halifax's new baby is not being promoted as a current account mortgage.

But for those who put all their finances into the hands of IF, it aims to achieve the same advantages for borrowers as a current account loan would offer, by offsetting savings against borrowings.

IF chief executive Jim Spowart says that most people are not yet ready for a current account attached to a loan. They prefer, he believes, to operate on the 'jam jar' system, where savings, mortgages, credit cards and loans are all kept separate from one another.

So IF will offer all of these products, via the telephone or Internet, but it will use its sophisticated computer system to deduct balances in current accounts or savings from borrowing before charging interest.

The balances will be taken from the highest-charging borrowing. So £1,000 of saving set against £1,000 of credit card debt means the £1,000 effectively earns whatever rate the card would have charged.

It promises competitive rates of interest, including savings rates on current accounts.

Ray Boulger at John Charcol says borrowers could do almost as well by arranging their own debt repayment programme, but for someone who wants a convenient way to get the best value for their borrowing and saving, it 'could offer good value'.

Verdict

This is a low-risk way to achieve benefits similar to those of a current account mortgage. It is probably easier for most people to understand, and may encourage more savers to question returns on deposit accounts against rates charged for borrowing.

The drawback, according to new competitor IF, is that all borrowing is secured against the account holder's property. And some say the requirement to have a salary paid in each month deters many. The system may also seem daunting since the account - based on the mortgage - is like a permanent overdraft, even though it will get steadily smaller as mortgage payments come off. Verdict Full marks for originality, but probably a product ahead of its time. Could be high risk for borrowers who do not monitor their account carefully, but should offer good value in the long term for people who can live within a budget. First Active Current Account Mortgage This aims to improve on Virgin One by offering fixed-rate mortgages and discounts. It offers full banking facilities, but customers do not have to have their salaries paid in. Customers can use the loan as a flexible mortgage if they prefer, making over-payments or underpayments as suits their needs. Ray Boulger at John Charcol says: 'Virgin insists that you pay your salary into the account but, generally, even though it may make sense, not everyone wants to do that.' For mortgages up to 75 per cent of the property value, the current rate is 4.49 per cent; rising to 4.74 per cent at 85 per cent of the value and 4.99 per cent for a 95 per cent loan. Ian Giles at First Active believes the current account mortgage 'makes the deposit account redundant'. Even so, he believes the product will appeal mainly to 'fairly sophisticated individuals' . Those most likely to benefit are borrowers who have some surplus cash each month to make overpayments on their mortgages. It is a lower-risk choice for the spendthrift than Virgin's account, because the current account can be kept separate. If - Intelligent Finance Halifax's new baby is not being promoted as a current account mortgage. But for those who put all their finances into the hands of IF, it aims to achieve the same advantages for borrowers as a current account loan would offer, by offsetting savings against borrowings. They prefer, he believes, to operate on the 'jam jar' system, where savings, mortgages, credit cards and loans are all kept separate from one another. The balances will be taken from the highest-charging borrowing. It promises competitive rates of interest, including savings rates on current accounts. Ray Boulger at John Charcol says borrowers could do almost as well by arranging their own debt repayment programme, but for someone who wants a convenient way to get the best value for their borrowing and saving, it 'could offer good value'. It is probably easier for most people to understand, and may encourage more savers to question returns on deposit accounts against rates charged for borrowing.

fields.headline: Part-time, but fully funded
fields.standfirst: The European Court gave a retirement boost to thousands who work shorter hours, but Neasa MacErlean finds some may still end up no better off
fields.trailText: The European Court gave a retirement boost to thousands who work shorter hours, but Neasa MacErlean finds some may still end up no better off
fields.body:
If are one of the country's 6 million part-time workers, you are probably rather pleased about last week's European Court of Justice decision strengthening the pension rights of part-timers.

Even if the pension issue does not affect you directly, you can take heart from the improving lot of people who work less than a 35-hour week. Following the ruling, part-timers can get backdated access to company pension schemes - perhaps as far as 1976, but almost certainly for six years.

The judgment underlines the principle that employers cannot discriminate against people just because they work shorter hours. Until last Monday, the legal position in the UK was that part-timers who had been kept out of a pension scheme could be made members retrospectively - but only for a maximum of two years. Final details of the new position will be decided in the next few months by the House of Lords.

The six trade unions which fought the issue to the ECJ estimate that at least 60,000 of their members will benefit. Claims have already been filed on behalf of these workers. But many others could also benefit. An example worked out by the public sector union Unison shows the financial implications. Brian is a part-time library assistant working for a local authority, earning £6,000 for a 17-hour week. When the local government pension scheme decided to let part-timers join in 1986, Brian immediately took up the offer. He had, however, started working at the library in 1976 - so, depending on the Lords' decision, Brian could join the pension scheme retrospectively for those 10 years.

His employer - complying with the terms of the local government scheme - will contribute 10 per of Brian's salary for each of those years. Brian himself will have to make contributions too - set at 6 per cent of his salary. Unison calculate that the extra funds will give him an additional annual pension of £750 and a lump sum on retirement of £2,250. There are some people, however, who may take advantage of the court ruling but find that they are no better off in retirement. The maximum basic state pension is currently £67.50, but under the Minimum Income Guarantee the Government will provide extra money in the form of Income Support to any pensioner whose basic state pension is lower than this or whose total weekly income is less than £78. Legal & General calculates that you need a fund of about £15,000 to pay out about £10.50 a week - the shortfall between the current maximum basic state pension and the Minimum Income Guarantee. So someone who may just build up a fund of £5,000 or £10,000 could discover that they get no extra benefit.

'It will be quite complicated to work out the benefits for each individual,' says a spokeswoman for the National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux. Peter Clinton of the Annuity Bureau says it is not cost-effective for his company to advise someone who has a pension fund of less than £15,000 on what annuity they should buy. 'It is very difficult to add value by building up very small pension funds. I would never discourage people from saving for their retirement - but if the sum is not going to be substantial, you should consider other investments, such as an individual savings account, instead,' he says.

Your first £3,000 of any savings are left out of the means-testing calculation if you are applying for Income Support. The next £5,000 is partly taken into account. Of course, there is no guarantee about what politicians might do in future to the pension system. 'You can't rely on the Minimum Income Guarantee existing in future,' says Charles Levett-Scrivener of financial adviser Towry Law. 'You may be wasting your money building up a small pension fund. But, on the other hand, if the Minimum Income Guarantee is abolished one day, you could be destitute without your own fund.'

There are clearly no easy answers, but individuals should ponder these issues before making their decisions. People who think they may have a claim have various hoops to jump through. They must lodge a claim through an employment tribunal either while they are on their employer's payroll or in the six months after they leave. But some employers will chose to settle with their staff rather than face lots of claims. The GMB and other trade unions are about to start discussing the issue of settlements with employers.

Fair's fair - even at three days a week

Part-time workers stop being second-class citizens on 1 July, when another piece of European legislation, the Part-Time Workers' Regulations, comes into force. The Department of Trade and Industry says the aim is 'to establish a minimum standard of fairness for part-timers so that they will no longer be treated less favourably than the full-timers they work alongside'.

The regulations state that part-timers should:
 Get the same hourly pay rate as comparable full-timers.
 Get the same hourly overtime rate once they have worked more than normal full-time hours.
 Be included in workplace training as though they worked full time.
 Have the same holiday and maternity and parental leave entitlements as full-timers, worked out on a pro-rata basis.

The Low Pay Unit, a London-based pressure group, is enthusiastic about the measures. 'The training provisions, for instance, mean that you won't lose your skills by going part-time,' says its deputy director, Jeff Masters.

But workers cannot assume that all employers will implement it immediately. They may need to remind companies - especially smaller ones - of their new rights. It could take years, and many employment tribunal cases, before the law is fully implemented.

 The Low Pay Unit runs a free helpline on (020) 7713 7583.

fields.headline: Vanguard of mutual defence
fields.standfirst: Heather Connon  on the pros - and pros - of Standard Life status
fields.trailText: Heather Connon on the pros - and pros - of Standard Life status
fields.body:
'Why would our policy-holders want us to demutualise? A new owner would want a profit margin, so why would we want to do it?' That forms the crux of the argument by Standard Life, which is in the midst of a battle against carpetbaggers intent on forcing it to float on the stock market.

The document it sent to its 2.3 million members warned that sharing profits with shareholders would mean lower endowment policy bonuses, smaller pensions or higher premiums. But read the small print and it seems most of these disadvantages would apply only to those taking out policies after Standard went public. Many existing policyholders would be no worse off - indeed they could benefit as they would get shares.

However, the comments at the start of this article were made not by Standard but by Vanguard, one of the largest mutual organisations in the world. It could advise Standard Life on providing benefits of mutual ownership which can be clearly measured.

Vanguard is the only company in the world which does not charge its investors a fixed fee on their policies. Instead, it simply charges them the costs it has incurred, making no profit or loss. The benefits to policyholders are clear. Last year, its average expense ratio - which includes everything from manager's salaries to marketing brochures - was 0.27 per cent of total funds. That is little over a fifth of the average US charge.

The financial benefits of the low charges are impressive. Take an example of an investor putting £1,000 into a fund which produces an 8 per cent return before charges. Over 10 years a Vanguard fund would grow to £2,105; one charging industry average fees would grow to £1,912 - almost 10 per cent less.

'It is a phenomenal advantage, and without any extra risk,' said Brian Mattes at Vanguard. 'It is most evident in things like a bond fund [where capital growth is less of a feature]. That it is like a 100-yard dash where we start at the 50-yard mark.' But Vanguard's costs are not just low, they are reducing. Economies of scale mean it can manage more money without big cost increases. Last year alone, the rate fell from 0.28 per cent to 0.27 per cent; 10 years ago, it was 0.5 per cent.

That belies one criticism of such structures: that companies which simply charge on their costs have no incentive to keep them low. At Vanguard, senior management bonuses are linked to keep costs low and efficiency high. Vanguard has a conservative investment style, but despite that its low costs keep it at the top of the performance tables over five and 10-year periods. Investors are enthusiastic: it has grown from a company with $1.8 billion in funds 25 years ago to become America's second-biggest mutual fund company, with more than $550bn under management.

Vanguard is not strictly comparable with Standard Life. Its mutual funds are more like unit trusts, while Standard has long-term savings contracts such as pensions and endowments, where it has to protect policyholders from the ups and downs of the stock market. And its charges are already low compared with the rest of the industry: the expense to assets ratio is 1.1 per cent, less than half the industry average. But it does charge policyholders fixed fees: simply allocating costs would improve its performance still further.

Standard has £12.1bn of capital in its fund for future appropriations. The company says the capital is needed to invest heavily in equities, where returns are higher than in bonds or property. Only an actuary could judge the appropriate level of capital for a life company, but many have questioned whether Standard really needs that level of reserves.

Standard's financial defence of mutuality is strongest for pension policyholders, who account for less than half its members, but 70 per cent of its new business. About three-quarters of them are either increasing their premiums or making additional single premium payments. And these, says Standard Life, would lose out if it converted to a public company.

Actuarial rules ensure that the benefits of existing policies are not affected by demutualisation, but that guarantee does not apply to those taking out new policies. Standard says even those who just increase their premiums in line with inflation could be affected: Standard does not guarantee to treat the increase as part of the existing policy. A fifth of its pension savers use regular single premiums and each of these is treated as a new policy. It estimates that about 0.75 per cent of the return on a typical pension would have to go to its shareholders. If it is right, a 25-year pension, where £150 contributions are increased in line with inflation, would be worth 9 per cent less if Standard floated.

In two weeks' time, Standard will make a further appeal to policyholders, based more on the less tangible benefits of mutuality: the passing of capital from generation to generation and the importance of retaining the mutual ownership structure.

Will that count for more than the promised windfalls? Savers' heads and hearts may say yes, but will their wallets agree?

fields.headline: Anti-fashionistas demonstrate at Lord's
fields.trailText: Cricket is often praised as an elegant game, but it's fair to say that not since the days of Asif Iqbal and his billowing flares has the game produced any player who could remotely be described as a fashion leader.
fields.body:
Cricket is often praised as an elegant game, but it's fair to say that not since the days of Asif Iqbal and his billowing flares has the game produced any player who could remotely be described as a fashion leader.

These days cricketers do their best to look hip and modern with their shades, baseball caps and tracksuits, but the effect is altogether more Jimmy Savile than Puff Daddy.

It is a brave effort but the players are swimming against a sartorial tidal wave. Because, let's face it, how cool can you be when your job requires you to wear white nylon slacks? If Blue Note had made similar demands of their musicians even Miles Davis would have looked like a dork.

Beyond the boundary it is another matter entirely, of course. Lord's may not have Royal Ascot's hats but it has something just as impressive in its own way, the MCC membership, a body which is to style what Fred Trueman is to futurism.

Every morning at nine the Grace Gates swing open to a rolling mass of strident striped blazers, cerise corduroys and panama hats which look like they have been winter home to a herd of hibernating hedge hogs. Anyone who regards fashion as the repressive construct of a metropolitan elite should worship these people as gods.

From a glance around the impressive Lord's museum it is clear right from the off that the MCC's aims have actually been threefold: playing and staging cricket matches and waging an all-out terror campaign against the running dogs of haute couture.

It all began with the colours. There are two explanations behind the MCC's choice (well, three if you include the rather dull one about the Star & Garter club). One is that the person who came up with them was colour blind; the other that he or she was a wicked prankster.

Personally I lean towards the latter theory. I imagine the joker experimenting with fabrics for years until the perfectly clashing shades of cherry and custard had been produced, then stitching together a tie, holding the finished product aloft and maliciously chuckling: "Now let's see them find an outfit that will match this vile little bugger!"

Impossible, naturally, but such is the anti-fashion verve of the MCC's membership that most don't even bother to attempt it, opting instead to fling it together with the first thing that comes to hand. A pale blue sleeveless safari suit, perhaps, or a Tattersall check shirt buttoned incorrectly (and this is the sort of little detail that transforms an outfit from one that simply affronts the fashionistas to one that slaps them round the chops with a sand-filled sock) so that one half of the collar curls like a stale sandwich.

Or they might plump for a mint green v-necked pullover displaying considerable evidence of past gastronomic indulgence. Just as scientists can uncover ancient weather patterns by studying the rings of fossilised trees, so future archaeolgists will be able to determine trends in middle-class dining habits by carefully scraping away the layers on an MCC member's jumper.

Not, I should say, that the jumper is the product of slovenliness. Far from it. The garment serves an important purpose. The member knows that if ever food supplies run low he has simply to immerse his sweater in boiling water to produce a nutritious broth. It is not so much a pullover as knitted cup-a-soup (quite often complete with crunchy croutons).

Under threat from the ever growing tyranny of style (many members have now abandoned baggy-crotched, straw-coloured corduroy trousers in favour of Blairite chinos) the MCC is now flaunting its colours like never before.

The Lord's catalogue offers everything from button-down plaid shirts to boxer shorts in the characteristic septic-boil combo of yellow and red. There is a whole page of pyjamas and nightshirts. A little superfluous, perhaps, since it is clear from their rumpled appearance that most members sleep fully clothed.

There is also a celebration of the heroic resistance in the museum. In one section on the first floor a little picnic tableau has been arranged.

On the floor a rug is covered with a lavish picnic. Beside it on a fold-out chair sits a perfect waxwork of an elderly, moustachioed MCC member apparently in the act of falling asleep while munching a chicken drumstick.

Well, at least I assume it was a waxwork.

webTitle: Patient Habib sends message to selectors

fields.headline: Patient Habib sends message to selectors
fields.standfirst: Hampshire 229 Leicestershire 212-6
fields.trailText: Hampshire 229 Leicestershire 212-6
fields.body:
When the rain stoppages here and at Lord's did not coincide, Aftab Habib was able to gaze wistfully at the television screen and ponder his own abruptly terminated test career after two matches of restricted impact for England.

His talent is roundly acknowledged at Grace Road. They know his wrists can be eloquent and his strokes prettily fashioned, qualities that have been apt at times to be diminished by technical uncertainties. But these days he is making a strong statistical argument in the attempt to be remembered by the England selectors.

"Show you can also graft" was the advice one imagines he was given in a match repeatedly interrupted by the showers and on a slow pitch with not much scope for bold stroke-making.

Habib is 63 not out in this First Division match. It has taken him nearly five hours, devoid of incident or fallibility, yet worthily composed. He found a willing partner in the big left-hander Jon Dakin, just as he had a week ago against Somerset when they both scored hundreds. After Dakin went, Neil Burns took over; he escaped a chance at the wicket off Shane Warne but anchored conscientiously.

There was little in the pitch to entice Warne. He was less challenging than on the previous day, conceding three boundaries to Dakin in a rare wayward over, though he spun away from both ends to keep warm.

The visitors looked a bowler short. They could have done with Alan Mullally, so familiar with this ground before being ambitiously signed to give Hampshire a new-ball vigour lacking for too long. This was, on present evidence, a misplaced hope. His long-standing hip injury is an increasing concern and now the doctors have ordered him to take a complete break for a month.

This leaves pessimistic expressions back at Southampton. Mullally's continued absence is grim news for the county and especially their club treasurer as he contemplates the worrying financial commitments of the season.

The existing bowling strength did its best. Peter Hartley on occasions beavered away more like a teenager than a 40-year-old, deserving the wicket of Vince Wells. Dimitri Mascarenhas got Ben Smith on the back foot; Warne appeared more fortunate to be given a similar decision against Dakin.

There were six stoppages and only 62 overs possible, as Leicestershire reached 212 for six. In the gloom at the close, the tractor pulling the covers made an unlikely if theatrical entry with headlights blazing.

Earlier, Burns had to be called back after he impetuously made for the pavilion, wrongly assuming one outbreak of showers would stop play. He may have returned to county cricket only this season but clearly had no wish for a wet shirt.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Dominic Ostler of Warwickshire ended his five-year wait for a championship century on another rain-shortened day against Essex in the Second Division match at Edgbaston.
fields.body:
Dominic Ostler of Warwickshire ended his five-year wait for a championship century on another rain-shortened day against Essex in the Second Division match at Edgbaston.

Ostler, 29 and in his benefit season, reached 93 not out on the first day but had to wait almost two days before making it to three figures after rain washed out the entire second day as well as yesterday's morning session.

He needed just seven more balls to move to his 11th first-class century and his first since he made 116 against Essex at Ilford in June 1995.

Ostler finished with 144, adding 83 for the fourth wicket with Trevor Penney (39). Dougie Brown (42) and Neil Smith (68no) then put on 90 in 24 overs as Warwickshire collected maximum batting points for the third consecutive game. Essex reached eight without loss by the close.

Gloucestershire's captain Mark Alleyne finished unbeaten on 122 after a day of showers at Trent Bridge. Resuming on 68, he reached his first championship hundred for two years from 238 balls with 15 fours to help his team move to within three runs of Nottinghamshire's total.

In the third game in the division Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath was another to make his mark despite murky weather on day two against Sussex at Hove.

The Australian pace bowler finished with five for 54 as the hosts closed on 258 all out having resumed on 51 for one, and there were also three wickets for Stuart Lampitt on a day for the seamers.

Worcestershire lost their openers Elliott Wilson and Ryan Driver, both lbw, on their way to 89 for two.

webTitle: MacLaurin calls for check on 'criminal mafia' at top level

fields.headline: MacLaurin calls for check on 'criminal mafia' at top level
fields.trailText: England's top cricket administrator faced up to the horrific possibility yesterday that substantial parts of the international game are in the grip of a criminal mafia.
fields.body:
England's top cricket administrator faced up to the horrific possibility yesterday that substantial parts of the international game are in the grip of a criminal mafia.

Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, will use the next meeting of the International Cricket Council, at Lord's on June 20, to extend the agenda from those players suspected of match-rigging to allegedly corrupt administrators.

"It could be the case that as well as the players it is the administrators who need investigation," MacLaurin said yesterday. "There is a lot of money sloshing around in the game, not just in betting but also in TV deals.

"My fear is that there could be a mafia-type organisation who are involved behind the scenes and that the international players are becoming pawns in the game.

"I know it is an extraordinary idea but it could be the case that criminal mafia are infiltrating areas of cricket and we just don't know how bad the situation is.

"It is possible that our own game in England has problems that we don't know about. Police inquiries are on-going on the match-fixing issue. I would like to think that the game is clean but we have to be vigilant."

The Sussex captain Chris Adams faces an ECB disciplinary investigation after Nasser Hussain, the England captain, lodged an official complaint about his behaviour during a Benson & Hedges Cup tie against Essex at Chelmsford.

Adams will be called before Gerard Elias, chairman of the disciplinary committee, at Lord's on Tuesday week in a season that fast is turning into a personal disaster for him.

Adams has lost his England place after failing to impress on the tour of South Africa last winter, Sussex are bottom of the Second Division of the County Championship, and he has already been involved in two on-field incidents in the first month of the season.

Hussain made a written protest on behalf of his Essex team-mate, Danny Law, who was allegedly manhandled by Adams during an ill-tempered incident in the zonal tie on April 24.

Law, a former Sussex player, was dismissed by a high full toss by the seam bowler, James Kirtley. His protests that the delivery should have been declared a no-ball brought an abusive response from several of the Sussex fielders, at which point Adams became involved.

Adams also ran foul of the umpire David Constant at Hove last week in the championship match against Warwickshire. Angered that Constant had given him out lbw, he burst into the umpires' room to protest but later returned to apologise.

At least he has been spared a second disciplinary hearing. "We are not taking any further action on that," said an ECB spokesman. "He apologised and the matter is closed."

 An effigy of Jagmohan Dalmiya, the chairman of the ICC, was burnt in Calcutta yesterday when a group of around 200 demonstrators gathered to protest about continued allegations of corruption in international cricket.

webTitle: Lehmann takes the spotlight as central casting claims star trio

fields.headline: Lehmann takes the spotlight as central casting claims star trio
fields.standfirst: Derbyshire 303 Yorkshire 216-7
fields.trailText: Derbyshire 303 Yorkshire 216-7
fields.body:
A glance at the scoreboard at Lord's would appear to vindicate the idea of central contracts, but do not mention this when there is a Tyke around.

Although they have completed only two matches Yorkshire, with bonus points from this game, stand top of the First Division. Their total of 39 points from their opening two games, against Derbyshire and Hampshire at Headingley, was only one short of the maximum.

So far so good. But there is a cloud on the horizon apart from the dark cumulus that was responsible for washing out all but 22.3 overs yesterday.

They, like Lancashire, have had three players signed up by the England and Wales Cricket Board. But a look at the fixtures indicates that Yorkshire have fared worse than most when it comes to getting a chance to play their men in matches between tests.

Both their wins were achieved while their three centrally contracted players, Darren Gough, Craig White and Michael Vaughan, were available. But that will happen on only one more occasion this season, when Yorkshire play Durham in June - and then only if the ECB decides to make those players available.

The three should be free next week. But as Yorkshire will be playing Zimbabwe this will hardly help the county's quest for their first championship since 1968. The success of the national side must be placed before more parochial concerns but, if an impressive Yorkshire team do fail to lift the title, they may for once have good reason to grumble.

White, an exile from the Lord's test, arrived here this morning but he may not be fit to play in tomorrow's National League match against Gloucestershire. He has a tender hamstring after pulling up in a warm-up sprint on Thursday morning.

There is one reason, however, why Yorkshire should improve on their sixth place in last year's championship. Darren Lehmann, who played for the county in 1997 and 1998, is back.

Last year, when Lehmann was required for the World Cup, Yorkshire had another Australian, Greg Blewett. By name and by nature: when Blewett left Headingley in mid-August to prepare for Australia's tour of Sri Lanka he had scored only 655 runs from 23 innings, at an average of 31.

Lehmann began the season with 95 against Derbyshire and scored 85 against Hampshire. In this sodden match he is 59 not out and has given ballast to the Yorkshire innings.

Yorkshire resumed yesterday on 171 for six and progressed, damply, to 216 for seven. Gavin Hamilton was caught in the slips to give Matthew Cassar his fourth wicket.

This is such a fast-drying ground that even when there is rain more cricket is never far away. So it was somewhat surprising when play was called off at tea-time. A mercy too. It is cold, wet and windy here. The cricket season is stillborn.

webTitle: Hinds maiden test century puts Pakistan on the back foot

fields.headline: Hinds maiden test century puts Pakistan on the back foot
fields.standfirst: Pakistan 253 West Indies 184-3
fields.trailText: Pakistan 253 West Indies 184-3
fields.body:
The young left-hander Wavell Hinds has put West Indies in a strong position in Barbados with his maiden test century. At tea in the second of three tests they were 69 runs adrift of Pakistan with seven wickets standing.

Pakistan, who had made 253 in their first innings, achieved the first breakthrough when Adrian Griffith edged the ball into the gloves of Moin Khan off the first ball of Waqar Younis's second over to have West Indies on 11 for one.

Hinds then took the crease and the first six of the match came when Sherwin Campbell smashed Waqar over the square-leg boundary. In a punishing mood, Campbell hit Waqar for a four to third man and another six followed when Campbell hooked Wasim Akram over the fence.

The ball landed on the corrugated iron roof and Pakistan's bowlers must have sensed they were in for a long day in the field.

Mushtaq Ahmed, the leg spinner, replaced Waqar and was at once hit to the midwicket boundary by a confident Hinds before Pakistan missed a chance they were to regret when Hinds tried to hit Abdur Razzaq out of the ground, mistimed the shot and the ball dropped between two fielders in the mid-on region.

A sparkling cover drive by Hinds off Abdur Razzaq bought up the 50-run stand between Campbell and Hinds.

In the next over, Hinds drove Mushtaq Ahmed straight for a boundary. It was enthralling cricket. The ball was inspected by the umpires repeatedly. The quality appeared to be poor, and it was changed in the 17th over, with the West Indies score at 70.

Pakistan missed another chance when a shot off Mushtaq Ahmed could not be held by Razzaq at square-leg. Pakistan's fielding was not up to its normal high standard.

Campbell drove Razzaq for what should have been a single but ended up with six runs as a result of an over-throw. The two batsmen ran all six runs to provide one of the days' funniest moments. The Pakistan fielders were not laughing, though.

webTitle: Hick stamps his mark on old country

fields.headline: Hick stamps his mark on old country
fields.standfirst: England keep the pressure on Zimbabwe between the showers
fields.trailText: England keep the pressure on Zimbabwe between the showers
fields.body:
The name of Graeme Hick has been written all over this match, and Duncan Fletcher has done much of the writing. The England coach has a long-standing and unwavering belief in his former team-mate's ability.

The soft southern African accent may still be there, but as the visiting coach Andy Pycroft says, Hick is English through and through now. Born and bred in Zimbabwe, and a member of their World Cup side at the age of 17 (when Fletcher was captain) his desire to succeed in this of all games must be overwhelming.

The rain showers, occasionally mixed with hail, that blustered in from the north throughout the day and restricted play to just over three hours ensured that there were more entrances and exits than in a French farce. But by the time stumps were drawn at seven o'clock Hick was well down the path to his own personal nirvana and England on 175 for three - 92 runs ahead - to a position of dominance in this first Cornhill test.

If the weather allows sufficient time, they have the match sewn up already. Hick will resume this morning on 62, an innings that in 2 hours has blossomed from a stuttering start, like a car warming up on a winter's morning, to one of increasing fluency as the ball soaked and softened and the bowling ran out of ideas.

So far he has hit eight boundaries, only the last one remotely streaky, and at times, particularly when the left-arm medium pace of Bryan Strang was slanting across him, he was pummelling the ball into the covers relentlessly, leaving fielders wringing their hands. Shortly before the close, when 55, he was missed at the wicket by Andy Flower (who dropped Mark Ramprakash on the first day) off the bowling of Neil Johnson.

It was a bad error by the Zimbabwean captain and Hick will need no second bidding. The prospect is there now that after he reaches his hundred (and surely this is a question of when rather than if) he will flippin' murder them.

Michael Atherton had his eye firmly on a hundred as well. He has 13 to his name in a career stretching to 96 matches but never one at Lord's in 22 attempts, so no name on the honours board in the dressing room.

He came close against Australia seven years ago, within a few feet in fact, stumbling, slipping and then falling on all fours when trying to complete the run that would have taken him to three figures.

But a half-century yesterday, the 53rd time that he has passed 50 in tests, and the seventh occasion at Lord's, was followed by an lbw decision as the ball jagged back at him that brought an oath muttered under his breath, the merest shake of the head and a wistful smile, the closest Atherton comes now to emotion since his run-ins with match referees a few years ago.

Replays - the benefit of which are not given to umpires of course when adjudicating on lbw decisions - showed that the ball had cannoned on to his pad from the inside edge of his bat. The game of cricket, as he freely acknowledges, has its smooth side and its rough. He and Hick had added 64 for the third wicket.

It was an unfortunate end to an accomplished innings, con structed in textbook fashion as if he had spent the rain breaks in the MCC library thumbing through the section on opening.

Except for the occasions when he was being turned around square by the away swing of Pommie Mbangwa, his defence was solid, the ball seen early and played wickedly late.

Allowed a fraction of leeway outside off stump and the ball, if a fraction short, was put away square off the back foot with that Boycottian elbow-high flourish. Err on the side of fullness and his timing through the covers off the front foot was razor sharp. One drive off Mbangwa, down the slope to the Mound stand, sounded like pistol shot and has not been bettered this match.

The Zimbabweans persevered but were limited, relying heavily on Heath Streak for any penetration and on the medium-fast bowling of Mbangwa and Strang for containment. There was no searing pace to hammer the ball into Hick's ribs to unsettle him or to spear it on to his toes as the great fast bowlers have done.

webTitle: Bittersweet revenge for Bulawayo murder victim

fields.headline: Bittersweet revenge for Bulawayo murder victim
fields.trailText: For David Lloyd, a victory at Lord's would begin to soothe the resentment that has lingered ever since his involvement as England coach during a tour of Zimbabwe in 1996 which has gone down as one of the most lamentable in England's history.
fields.body:
Some of you may be under the naive impression that this match is entitled the first Cornhill test. You would be sadly misguided. It should properly be termed "Bumble's Revenge". And so far it is all going entirely to plan.

For David Lloyd, a victory at Lord's would begin to soothe the resentment that has lingered ever since his involvement as England coach during a tour of Zimbabwe in 1996 which has gone down as one of the most lamentable in England's history.

Zimbabwe have the same effect on Lloyd as Inspector Clouseau had on Chief Inspector Dreyfus. Both men wish nothing more than complete annihilation of their quarry, Lloyd most famously when he uttered the immortal phrase after a drawn Bulawayo test: "We flippin' murdered 'em."

If the Lord's rain showers become more prolonged, and Zimbabwe somehow contrive to save a game in which they have been thoroughly outplayed, Lloyd may develop a nasty case of Dreyfus Eye. His autobiography, Anything But Mur der, the publication of which coincides with the first test between these countries since Bulawayo, leaves no one in doubt how much he loathes the place.

Tell it like it is, Bumble. Harare, according to Lloyd, "is the pits". Its people are "inhospitable", the capital city "dangerous and tacky". Some of its cricketers are little better, being guilty in Bulawayo, when they bowled wide and got away with it, of a "shameful negativity".

Zimbabwe's cricketing public are also pilloried. Harare Sports Club, writes Lloyd, "is home to a faction who represent the worst excesses of the old colonial empire. Their barstool conversation is frequently anti-English, harking back to UDI and the 1970s".

His disgust is most pronounced for the beer-swilling spectators in the "outdated Colonial Club", where he witnessed "the demeaning process of black waiters having to pick up empty beer bottles thrown down by white spectators... like some long-forgotten racist ceremony".

To his everlasting annoyance, it was Lloyd who received a dressing-down. The England and Wales Cricket Board took exception to his attitude, with Tim Lamb, the chief executive of the ECB, flying out to condemn him as abusive, undiplomatic, unsociable, ungracious and a figure of ridicule.

Even now, as England bat themselves into an invincible position, Lloyd's triumph is not absolute. England owe their batting dominance to Graeme Hick, a Zimbabwean, whose test career might yet reach fulfilment under Lloyd's replacement as coach: none other than Duncan Fletcher, another Zimbabwean.

How much more satisfying it would have been for Lloyd yesterday had England's standard been raised by a fellow Lancastrian. But Michael Atherton fell leg-before for 55 - and he got a nick on it, too. He has still to make a hundred in a Lord's test, and will never have a better opportunity. He will not need Lloyd to tell him that.
