fields.headline: Cool hand Luca
fields.standfirst: The heat is on Chelsea's Italian coach as his season's quest for silverware goes to the final day
fields.trailText: It is reassuring to know they have got their priorities right at Chelsea. Journalists arriving for the club's Cup final week press day, dressed in the standard fashion-free manner of the profession, were all handed a pack marked "Giorgio Armani". In it were photographs of the squad wearing the Wembley outfits the Italian tailor had designed for them, three-button single-breasted suits in charcoal-grey wool, worn, according to the blurb, "with light grey tone on tone shirt and tie combination".
fields.body:
It is reassuring to know they have got their priorities right at Chelsea. Journalists arriving for the club's Cup final week press day, dressed in the standard fashion-free manner of the profession, were all handed a pack marked "Giorgio Armani". In it were photographs of the squad wearing the Wembley outfits the Italian tailor had designed for them, three-button single-breasted suits in charcoal-grey wool, worn, according to the blurb, "with light grey tone on tone shirt and tie combination".

Despite the best efforts of Graeme Le Saux, Frank Leboeuf and George Weah, no one wears the ensemble as well as the manager Gianluca Vialli. In one snap he is pictured in the dugout at Stamford Bridge with Dennis Wise and Armani himself (who, surprisingly for a designer reckoned to define the epicentre of cool, appears to be wearing a shellsuit). As Vialli grins through the promotional necessities of the modern football manager, he has his hand on Wise's knee, not exactly the traditional image of a manager facing a make-or-break crisis.

Yet that is how today's match is being presented in sections of the press. Vialli, it is said, having spent the amount he has and with the squad at his disposal, simply must win. Not just to have a trophy to show for all his investment but to put his club back in the money-spinning business of serious European competition next season.

Lose to Villa and his expensive collection of internationals will be obliged to reassemble immediately after Euro 2000 and begin the long haul of qualification through the Intertoto Cup. An outcome, the whispers have it, which could well mark an end to Vialli's 27 months in charge at Stamford Bridge.

Vialli, of course, is keen that such talk should not become received opinion. Asked at the press day (where he had swapped Armani for Umbro) if defeat this afternoon would render his entire season a failure, he was quick to snap back. "I will not answer that question," he said, his gaze significantly more steely than in those humble after-match appearances on television in his lucky Frank Spencer grey v-neck suggest. "Whatever happens it is something to be proud of, to reach the last match of a long season and still have something to play for."

Anglophile

Vialli has consistently challenged received opinion since he first came to England, signed by Ruud Gullit from Juventus in 1996. Back then it looked as if he would conform to the Carlos Kickaball model of the foreign player which obtained at the time: come to England just as your Italian career is beginning to fade, fill your boots with cash, then disappear after a season in search of the next big pay cheque complaining of Third World conditions; the path taken by his former strike partner in Turin, Fabrizio Ravanelli.

But Vialli was not like that. From the moment he arrived, everything he did suggested he was in for the long haul. Far from being the fancy-dan foreigner found wanting when the weather turned or the opposition were keen to tattoo their initials on expensive shins, this most elegant of men seemed to take perverse pleasure in a good kicking. Chelsea fans remember the two goals he scored in six inches of comedy Norwegian snow against Tromso which kept the club in the Cup Winner's Cup two seasons ago; the brace in a January downpour at Oldham to maintain an FA Cup challenge; the relentless way he led the line in another Cup tie at Oxford. Even when Gullit gave him ample opportunity for a flounce by regularly humiliating him on the substitutes' bench (two minutes on the pitch is all he got the last time Chelsea were in the Cup final) he kept his counsel.

His commitment was aided by the fact that, off the field, he loved living in London. He is a genuine anglophile. Perhaps as a consequence of his wealthy northern Italian background (his father, a leading industrialist, owns Castello Belgioioso, a 60-room pile outside Cremona) he has a penchant for the Sloanier, Barbour-clad elements of the English lifestyle. He has an apartment in a stucco-fronted terrace in Eaton Square rather than the footballer's standard-issue neo-Georgian mansion in Wentworth. He drives a Jaguar, not a Ferrari. He has such a playful affection for the English language that he likes to slip a new idiomatic phrase into every press conference. For some old-fashioned reason he considers us a nation of gentlemen. And he likes to behave like one, even to journalists.

Maybe Ken Bates saw all this in him when he made Vialli manager after Gullit was summarily sacked in January 1998. Maybe Bates reckoned the personable, generous, popular Italian would defrost the glacial dressing-room atmosphere Gullit had engendered. To the watching world, however, it looked as if Chelsea had appointed a figurehead attracting old mates such as Pierluigi Casiraghi to come and play while Graham Rix got down to the tactical work. But if that ever was the plan, it was derailed by Rix's prison sentence. Vialli was alone in charge, and once more set about proving assumptions wrong.

Despite his protests to the contrary the Italian is hard-pressed to deny that his year will ultimately be assessed on what happens today. As Gullit loftily put it this week, "he has won nothing yet this season". Watching Vialli's players train, the three World Cup winners, the former world player of the year, a classy Catalan here, a majestic Italian there, it is hard not to conclude that they will have under-achieved massively if they fail against Villa. Only Chris Sutton looks ill at ease in the company, shruggingly apologising when a group game of keepy-uppy ends with the ball scudding off his shin.

Desire

There are hints in Vialli's recent pronouncements that, after enjoying the annual family holiday at the castello , he is preparing to change things in the close season. In his first few months he followed the Italian team-building model that Gullit had set in train: like a shopper on a spree in Emporio Armani, he bought quality off the peg: Casiraghi, Marcel Desailly, Albert Ferrer. A Cup Winners' Cup and League Cup had been won with the team Gullit built, but Vialli wanted more. In the Premiership his team were found wanting. Manchester United won the title because, unlike all their nearest challengers, they did not forget to win at Bradford. Chelsea lost not only at Valley Parade but at Watford too, the latter defeat between two draws with Milan.

"When we go to places like Sheffield Wednesday and Leicester we have to show more desire," Vialli admitted this week. So was it a desire deficit which had cost his club the title?

"When you play 60 matches in a year, subconsciously you prepare better for big matches," he said. "It is not something you do on purpose, players try to be at their best all the time."

Make of that what you will. Certainly there are clues at Stamford Bridge that he wants to develop his own talent rather than buying Armani-style. The club, he says, will return to a British core, perhaps led by the nine youth-system products who have been given a first-team run-out this season. Several of the club's thirtysomething stalwarts seem to have read the runes, acknowledging that this afternoon at Wembley may be a last hurrah. While Gianfranco Zola smilingly tried to deflect questions about his future, Leboeuf revealed that "everyone is eager to come back in the summer - but whether it's Luca's choice is a different matter".

And Vialli seems to be gearing himself up for tough decisions. He has, after all, recently returned to a significant smoking habit. It will be hard. Until 18 months ago he was one of them, a team-mate of the lads who wore T-shirts saying "Cheer up Luca" when he was ignored by Gullit. Now he will have to say goodbye.

"I find it difficult not to have personal feelings," he said of the need to communicate bad news. "But I find it easy to do what is right."

The irony is that his biggest signing, the one he hoped would signal a younger, more British Chelsea, has been a resounding flop. Poor Chris Sutton. When a pressman tried to lighten his Eeyore countenance by suggesting the Cup final was his chance for vindication ("Look at Teddy Sheringham last year!"), he shrugged and muttered: "I don't know if I'm starting yet. It's highly unlikely at the moment."

In the end, Chelsea fans will be hoping that Sutton is just one of the "mistakes" Vialli refreshingly admits to making and not the kind of albatross that Stan Collymore, for instance, became for Brian Little at Aston Villa. While most Blues supporters would accept that a change of faces at Stamford Bridge is inevitable, it is Vialli they desperately want to be the man administering it.

"He is massively popular, particularly after Gullit who seemed to take delight in dropping crowd favourites," Jeremy Leslie, a Stamford Bridge regular, said. "Bates knows it would be mad to get rid of him and I think that's why he made him do a lap of honour at the last home game, to show us he's behind him. People understand he's still learning, we are prepared to let him learn. After all, look how long it took Alex Ferguson to get it right."

It is often forgotten that the manager is only 35, two years older than Wise, not someone to whom the adjective mature is often applied. He has never been afraid to admit he has much to learn. But learning on the job is rarely a luxury afforded to football managers.

However relaxed the smiles this week, Gianluca Vialli knows that a few royal blue ribbons hanging from the FA Cup at five o'clock this afternoon will be the best guarantee he has of another course of lessons.

webTitle: When a £15 footballer had his day in the sun

fields.headline: When a £15 footballer had his day in the sun
fields.trailText: Johnny Dixon, Aston Villa's 1957 Cup winning hero talks to Ian Mallin.
fields.body:
Six of Aston Villa's seven FA Cup triumphs belong to a sepia-tinted age but their last, in 1957, was captured on scratchy monochrome. And Johnny Dixon sits bare-chested in the Wembley dressing room speaking into the microphone of a fresh-faced David Coleman.

"I never thought it was possible but we had the run of the ball and it's turned our way. Possibly it's Manchester United's turn next year," says the affable, teetotal, non-smoking Geordie before showing off the cup to the BBC camera.

"Never mind, we'll be back to do it next year," United's captain Roger Byrne agrees later. They turned out to be tragically ironic words. Nine months later Byrne's life and those of seven of his team-mates on that sunny May day were cruelly snuffed out on a day of steady snow in Munich.

As this year, Aston Villa were the underdogs in 1957. The 10th-placed team in the First Division were meeting the newly crowned champions, which meant that the Busby Babes at Wembley were aiming for the first double of the 20th century. United were packed with players fast becoming household names even outside Manchester: Bobby Charlton, Duncan Edwards, Tommy Taylor, Eddie Coleman.

In his history of the FA Cup, Geoffrey Green says: "Already champions of the league, all Manchester United had to do, it seemed, was to take the field, give one little puff at Aston Villa and the double was theirs."

Forty-three years on from that cloudless afternoon, distant austere days when the Suez canal had just been opened again to shipping and Britain was still gripped by petrol rationing, the 76-year-old Dixon, who lives in Sutton Coldfield, remembers: "United were a great side all right, there's no doubt about that, and we had just avoided relegation the season before. But we were playing with the confidence that winning can instil in a team.

"Eric Houghton was the manager and Bill Moore his assistant. Bill was a real taskmaster on the training ground but he knew when to use the stick and when to use the carrot.

"We weren't afraid of United but they were obviously going to be mightily difficult to beat. Then we had a team talk before we went down to Wembley and Bill says to us, 'Lads, there's one thing we've got to work out for Saturday and that's who's going to carry Johnny on their shoulders when he carries the cup around the stadium'. That eased the tension and we sensed that this was going to be our year."

Peter McParland, the robust left-winger from the granite town of Newry, County Down, scored the goals that forged Villa's 2-1 victory but only after his early collision with Ray Wood, when the United goalkeeper's jaw was broken in a sickening crunch against the side of the Irishman's head.

The legality of the challenge was the topic of many a saloon-bar conversation in Birmingham and Manchester for years afterwards but what cannot be denied is the shimmering brilliance of Villa's second-half goals.

The first saw the inside-left Dixon swap wings and curl over a teasing right-foot cross that would make David Beckham proud and McParland steamed in to power the ball past the stand-in goalkeeper Jackie Blanchflower with a header from near the penalty spot.

But in the 1946-47 season, when Villa paid a then-massive £9,500 for Swansea's Wales centre-forward Trevor Ford, Newcastle let Villa have Dixon for £15.

Those were the days before the abolition of the maximum wage. Dixon and his team-mates may have played to colossal crowds, banks of Park Drive-puffing men in flat caps, but he says: "The most I got was £24 a week and £22 in the summer. Dixon still has his and he will be at Wembley today as a Villa guest in his new jacket to relive sunlit memories.

"The thing that stays in my mind was a moment a couple of minutes before the end when the ball had gone out of play. I looked up at the royal box where the cup gleamed in the sunlight. Minutes later I was climbing those 39 steps. At that moment I was on top of the world."

webTitle: Villa's iron man on his mettle

fields.headline: Villa's iron man on his mettle
fields.standfirst: If the day is to be decided in midfield, Dutchman George Boateng has the steel to settle it
fields.trailText: George Boateng, Aston Villa's Iron Man, talks about his FA Cup dream.
fields.body:
George Boateng has been christened the Iron Man by his Aston Villa team-mates and, as Paul Gascoigne can testify, the Dutch midfielder is not a man to collide with. If John Gregory is to be believed, Boateng could be his key player today at Wembley.

Few foreign players have adapted to the hustle and bustle of Premiership life with as much relish as Villa's combative No6. A Dutchman with an English mentality, says Gregory. "Nah," counters Boateng, "I don't like fish and chips."

Culinary tastes aside, as Boateng relaxed in the Holte suite at Villa Park this week it was clear the Brummie way of life has been to his liking now that the acrimony surrounding his £4.5m defection from Coventry last year has subsided.

After a few teething problems the 25-year-old has emerged as Villa's most consistent performer since the turn of the year, to the point that some Dutch papers have been clamouring for his inclusion in Frank Rijkaard's Euro 2000 squad.

For the time being, however, Boateng says he has more pressing matters of concern. Only time will tell whether he leaves Wembley this evening with a medal but, as someone whose tackling can be every bit as tough as his talking, he can bank on heading up the M1 with a fair few bruises on his shins.

"Dennis Wise is good at getting backwards and forwards but I'm not so sure about Didier Deschamps," he volunteers. "He is getting old now. Can he keep up with Ian Taylor or myself?" At least there was a backhanded compliment squirreled away for Wise. "He has improved," says Boateng. "Two years ago all I knew of him was the red cards, the yellow cards, the fighting, the provocation and the taxi stuff."

Overlooking the unwritten rule that Wise and taxis should not be mentioned in the same breath is one thing. But dismissing Deschamps, World Cup winner et al, as past his sell-by date? Well, as Frank Leboeuf might say, time to get your medals out.

If Chelsea's midfielders are already sharpening their studs, however, it is a safe bet that Boateng will give as good as he gets. He says his combative instincts come from growing up in Spijkensee, a run-down area just outside Rotterdam.

Mean streets

His friends became embroiled in a life of drugs and petty crime and the district had such a reputation that the local taxi drivers refused to stop in his street. "I had bad friends," he says. "They were involved in all sorts of trouble. It was a tough area and people had to survive."

Boateng went on to play in the same Feyenoord team as Chelsea's Ed de Goey for three years and captained the Dutch Under-21s at a time when Ruud van Nistelrooy was good enough only for a place on the bench.

Although he has no regrets about leaving the Netherlands for the Midlands - "Coventry was the place where I found myself," he declares - he believes his season with a "relegation team in England" has been an influential factor behind his conspicuous lack of international caps.

Nevertheless he has no intentions of returning to the Netherlands. "Coming to England was the best thing I have done. We used to watch the FA Cup final every year in Holland and we were so jealous. All the drama, the tears - you don't get that anywhere else.

"The culture is so different but I like it here, I love it. When Wimbledon were relegated and I saw the pictures on television of ladies crying and boys with streaming red eyes it reminded me how much I would miss that emotion back in Holland."

Boateng's emergence has coincided with Villa's renaissance over the last five months and it is a measure of his stature that he is virtually assured of his part in the cast today, the supporting role going to either Taylor or Lee Hendrie.

He predicts that the team which "wins midfield will definitely win the match" and so presumably he will be hoping the ageing Deschamps plays. And as he does for every game, Boateng will say a quiet prayer before leaving the dressing room.

"People have asked me if there is a danger of being too nervous to play, but I have faith that God will guide me through. Being religious has made me mentally stronger and taught me how to cope.

"With the final coming up, I have been praying even more than usual. But being religious does not make me any different. People talk about footballers having problems and, without talking about anyone in particular, I'm sure if they believed in Christ they would not have suffered from gambling, drinking and so on."

A message there, perhaps, for Villa's player of the year, the periodically reformed Paul Merson, or maybe even the self-destructive Gascoigne. Boateng, of course, was the player inadvertently involved in one of those infamous Gazza moments, his forehead getting in the way of a forearm smash from the occasional Middlesbrough midfielder during Villa's game at the Riverside stadium in February.

"He has been a big factor behind our revival," says Gregory. "When he arrived I played him on the right and asked him to do things that maybe he couldn't. But since he has gone into the centre he has hardly looked back. When he plays well the whole team tends to play well." Over to you, Didier.

fields.headline: Trophy in danger - classic required
fields.standfirst: Chelsea and Villa can stage a match to restore a bruised reputation
fields.trailText: David Lacey argues that Chelsea and Villa can stage a match to restore a bruised reputation.
fields.body:
And so to the forgotten final. Well, perhaps not forgotten and certainly not by the supporters of Chelsea and Aston Villa who will flock to Wembley this afternoon, but hardly an object of the heady media hype to which this occasion has long since been accustomed.

All season the world's oldest football competition has struggled for attention. The withdrawal of Manchester United in order to compete in the Fifa World Club Championship, which clashed with the fourth round, dealt the Cup a body blow from which it has not recovered. Without the holders the tournament lost much kudos.

The Football Association compounded the Cup's misery by bringing the third round forward from the new year to early December, overlooking, in its desire to ease fixture congestion, the significance of this round in the public psyche. The third round of the FA Cup normally gives a season its second wind.

The future of the Cup is still a cause for concern. Already this season one of the semi- finals has had to be settled by penalties without a replay and if ever a final were decided this way it would surely be the ultimate ignominy.

There is one encouraging thought for today. By convention the more a Cup final is built up as a classic waiting to happen, the bigger the let-down is likely to be. If the opposite applies, therefore, Chelsea and Villa will produce a match worthy of Wembley's last FA Cup final before the demolition men move in.

Certainly the ingredients are there for a game of intriguing contrasts: Chelsea's studious chess players against Aston Villa's breezy, pragmatic draughts men. The respective managers are of opposite types: a cultured Italian, Gianluca Vialli, and a down-to-earth Englishman, John Gregory.

In a sense the teams themselves have arrived at Wembley from the opposite ends of the spectrum. Though both need to win the Cup to gain a place in the Uefa Cup, Chelsea would regard success today as a consolation whereas Villa might rejoice at such tangible evidence of having turned their season around.

When winning the Cup offers less satisfaction than finishing second or third in the league, football has indeed become a strange arena. Yet this is now the reality, with Champions League places worth considerably more than a handshake from the mayor.

Chelsea had hoped for so much more from their season. Reaching the quarter-finals of the Champions League was no mean achievement but from the start Vialli's side frittered away too many Premiership points to produce a serious challenge for the title.

Villa, on the other hand, spoiled a promising start - they lay second for most of August - by going nine league games without a win between September 18 and December 18, a decline which prompted considerable speculation about Gregory's future as manager, given his chairman Doug Ellis's trigger-happy habits.

Perhaps Deadly Doug has mellowed in his later years. At all events he refused to be panicked into sacking Gregory and has since been rewarded by a resurgence from Villa, who will arrive at Wembley on the back of only three defeats in their past 28 games.

Maybe the name of Aston Villa is on the Cup this time. After all, they began their run by being drawn against a side-effect of Manchester United's non-appearance, Darlington, who had been knocked out by Gillingham in the second round but survived as the "Axa lucky losers".

Omens can be false. Something similar was said about Villa in the Worthington Cup after West Ham, having beaten them on penalties, were ordered to replay their quarter-final - they had fielded a cup-tied player - and lost. Villa, however, failed to exploit their good fortune, losing their semi-final to Leicester as Gregory complained that his team had "choked".

Memories of this, along with Villa's spiritless performance against Bolton Wanderers in their FA Cup semi-final at Wembley, prompt the thought that Chelsea, who are nothing if not a team for the big occasion, will win this afternoon. If Villa needed penalties to beat Bolton after a goalless two hours then what price their chances against opponents who on their day can pass and move better than anyone?

If Villa can reproduce the strength of character that saw them come back to defeat Leeds United in the fifth round with a hat-trick from Benito Carbone, including one goal audaciously struck from a huge distance, then perhaps the Cup will return to Villa Park for the first time since 1957. So much depends on how good a start Gregory's team get. Villa can become trapped by their own caution.

There are many ways Chelsea might win, all of them involving Gianfranco Zola, Tore Andre Flo, Dennis Wise or Gustavo Poyet. Against that Paul Merson is the Villain most likely to open up one of the Premiership's tightest defences, and if this happens Dion Dublin and Carbone will surely punish Chelsea from air and ground.

A forecast? Chelsea to win 2-1 but with Dublin the man most likely to prove this false.

webTitle: Fallout from TV sparks radio activity

fields.headline: Fallout from TV sparks radio activity
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner looks at the TV aspect of the final.
fields.body:
Special. That was the word that used to be scattered around the TV schedules on Cup final day. And special it was, blanket coverage on BBC and ITV, with both broadcasters engaged in a comical battle to grab the audience early: children's TV favourites dressed in club colours playing silly games before you had even had your Weetabix. Cup final day. Cancel all arrangements.

It was almost more fun than being there, what with all that special telly: It's A Cup Final Knockout versus Cup Final Winner Takes All. Where are the Tarbucks of yesteryear?

The specialness of the FA Cup has been dwindling for years - ever since they stopped doing the draw on a Monday lunchtime, and started playing matches on Sunday - and it was never likely to survive the shameful withdrawal of the holders; but did the BBC have to rub it in by taking off Grandstand and replacing it with My Fair Lady? And Herbie Rides Again, not even the original Love Bug movie but a sequel?

The screen battle will be fought out between ITV and Sky. Both sides will have the same anodyne player interviews and chats with celebrity supporters; Richard Attenborough is clearly going to be busy.

The real ratings fight may shift to radio. Now that the Cup final has become just another take-it-or-leave-it live televised match, there is less chance the family outing to Ikea or the seaside will be cancelled in its favour, so more of us than usual may be following the action from the driver's seat. And this year the BBC has a rival.

Whereas Radio 5 Live kicks off at its normal time of 1pm, Talksport, making its Cup final debut, goes boffo. Coverage starts at 7am with a four-hour show presented by the Sun's Brian Woolnough. For those who feel four hours with Brian is scarcely adequate to cover the subject, Gary Newbon steps in at 11 with a Cup final forum giving former players the chance to have their say with journalists and fanzine editors, after which Alvin Martin and Kerry Dixon join Alan Parry in the commentary box.

This is followed by a Cup final phone-in with John Fashanu. In between times Talksport will be meeting a "host of celebrities".

Talksport is running a trail saying: "The match lasts 90 minutes but the talking goes on for 24 hours." I very much fear this may be the case.

There will not be much talking on the internet today, though, at least not in the way of commentary. The clubs are jealously guarding their online rights, the final money-making frontier. So old technology will have to do for the millions of us no longer pinioned to our sofas by a national festival of television; or as they used to say in the early days of wireless football, back to square one.

webTitle: Dreaming of one last white horse final

fields.headline: Dreaming of one last white horse final
fields.trailText: If this really is the last FA Cup final played at Wembley before the old stadium is knocked down then surely it is not asking too much for Chelsea and Aston Villa to provide a match that will be remembered for something more than the result, the fate of so many of its 71 predecessors.
fields.body:
If this really is the last FA Cup final played at Wembley before the old stadium is knocked down then surely it is not asking too much for Chelsea and Aston Villa to provide a match that will be remembered for something more than the result, the fate of so many of its 71 predecessors.

Time and again the Cup final has failed to live up to the grandeur of the occasion. Before substitutes were allowed injuries were the problem, reducing one or other finalist to 10 men and upsetting the balance of the contest. From 1952 to 1960 five out of nine finals were affected in this way.

Then there were Cup final nerves. Frank Buckley's fine young Wolves side, weaned on monkey-gland tablets, were overwhelming favourites in 1939 but when they autographed a ball before kick-off their shaky signatures were barely legible. Portsmouth won 4-1.

With finals increasingly dominated by big-occasion teams such as Manchester United, Liverpool and Arsenal, pre-match nerves have become less of a problem. Yet still the Football Association's showpiece has resolutely refused to combine memorable football with a contest of such drama that the crowd has gone home with its heart racing.

Even the most famous Wembley final of all, the game in 1953 when Stan Mortensen and Stanley Matthews, supplied by Ernie Taylor's passes, inspired Blackpool to a 4-3 victory over Bolton Wanderers after they had been 3-1 down with 20 minutes to go, was a case of bad football redeemed by outstanding individualism.

Nine years later Tottenham defeated Burnley 3-1 in the most aesthetically pleasing of the Wembley finals but it was a relatively passionless game for all that. Asked whether he had enjoyed the match, Bill Nicholson, the Spurs manager, replied, "No, it wasn't hard enough," and you could see what he meant.

The final which more than any has combined conflict and art to best effect remains the 1948 encounter between Manchester United and Blackpool when Matt Busby's first great United side came from behind to win 4-2.

Those were less cynical times. Both teams were rich in players who just wanted to demonstrate their trade as attractively as possible: Johnny Carey, Johnny Morris, Jimmy Delaney and Charlie Mitten for United, Harry Johnston, Matthews and Mortensen for Blackpool. This afternoon's final, in prospect at least, has something of those qualities about it. Gianfranco Zola, Gustavo Poyet, Didier Deschamps and, yes, Dennis Wise are each capable of bringing the finest of football's arts to Chelsea's performance, and Paul Merson, Benito Carbone, Dion Dublin and Gareth Southgate can do the same for Aston Villa.

By no means all of the finals of the 90s were bad - although it seemed to take Arsenal and Sheffield Wednesday four years rather than four hours to settle the replayed final of 1993 - but none was outstanding.

The most enduring images of the past decade will be of a tear-stricken Paul Gascoigne being carried off the field in 1991 and, the previous May, Ian Wright leaping off the Crystal Palace bench to score twice and take Manchester United to a second game.

The 80s produced the most recent final that combined a sense of the dramatic with a genuine surprise. Who will forget the diving header by Coventry Keith Houchen to take Tottenham, who had led twice, into extra-time, the Cup eventually going to Highfield Road? Wimbledon's victory over Liverpool the following season may have been the greater shock but it was not the better match.

That decade was a vintage period for Wembley finals. The 1981 replay and Spurs' 3-2 triumph over Manchester City was an absorbing, fluctuating affair won by Ricky Villa's famous dribble through the City defence, which upstaged one of the best goals scored in a Wembley final, Steve MacKenzie's wonderful volley for City.

Wembley FA Cup finals have never seen more heart-warming scenes than when Sunderland, lying halfway in the old Second Division, beat Don Revie's Leeds United in 1973. Or a less likely hero than Mike Trebilcock, whose two goals turned the 1966 final around for Everton against Sheffield Wednesday.

Yet the most tumultuous final at Wembley remains the first, in 1923, when the new stadium was engulfed by a tide of humanity that saw the game between Bolton and West Ham witnessed, unofficially, by a crowd of more than 200,000. PC George Scorey and his white horse Billy became lasting symbols of English football's sense of order and discipline even amid scenes of the utmost chaos. What a long-lost world that seems now.

webTitle: Debutant Sarwan gives Windies upper hand

fields.headline: Debutant Sarwan gives Windies upper hand
fields.trailText: Ramnaresh Sarwan could not complete a maiden Test century on his debut but had the satisfaction of leading West Indies to a 145-run first-innings lead over Pakistan on the third day of the second Test in Bridgetown.
fields.body:
Ramnaresh Sarwan could not complete a maiden Test century on his debut but had the satisfaction of leading West Indies to a 145-run first-innings lead over Pakistan on the third day of the second Test in Bridgetown.

Sarwan, aged just 19, was unbeaten on 84 as West Indies were bowled out for 398 about 25 minutes prior to the scheduled tea break as they replied to Pakistan's 253.

Sarwan batted impressively for 10 minutes short of three-and-a-half hours, during which time he faced 222 balls and struck eight boundaries.

He had to share the honours with off-spinner Saqlain Mushtaq, who captured the last two wickets of Reon King and Courtney Walsh to end with five victims in a Test innings for the 10th time.

But Saqlain did have to suffer the indignity of being clouted for two leg-side sixes by last man Courtney Walsh, whose 22 in 51 minutes off 31 balls also contained two fours and helped build the West Indies' lead.

fields.headline: Palme d'Or contenders
fields.trailText:
Dancer In The Dark
It's got great songs, great dance scenes and, er, an execution too. Lars Von Trier's emotionally pummelling musical starring Bjork will cause a row if it wins or loses. Critics have rarely been so divided over a film.
fields.body:
Dancer In The Dark
It's got great songs, great dance scenes and, er, an execution too. Lars Von Trier's emotionally pummelling musical starring Bjork will cause a row if it wins or loses. Critics have rarely been so divided over a film.

The Yards
James Gray's solid New York story of graft and family ties starring Mark Wahlberg and James Caan has been compared to On the Waterfront. A safe, if uninspired, bet, it would ensure Hollywood returned in droves next year.

Eureka
Japanese, three hours and 40 minutes long, and about the trauma of a bus driver who survives a bloody hijack, it doesn't sound terribly promising but critics were bewitched.

Yi Yi
The most superior of family soap operas from the prolific Taiwanese director Edward Yang. Beautiful, subtle storytelling may not be enough, however.

Nurse Betty
Neil LeBute's misanthropic and very funny comedy about a TV soap addict whose fantasies about a heart-throb star come true in the most unexpected way. Will make Rene Zellweger an even bigger star. Comedies, however, seldom win prizes.

Song From The Second Floor
Roy Anderrson, who hasn't made a feature film for 25 years, returns with a brilliant oddity. Benn Anderson of Abba fame wrote the score. A dark horse that might just nip in at the finish.

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.standfirst:
Kids' New York
Kids' London
(Dorling Kindersley, £4.99)
fields.trailText: Kids' New York/London
fields.body:
Did you know that in 1653, the Dutch built a wooden wall along the top of New Amsterdam to keep out the British and the Native Americans? Welcome to Wall Street (nearest McDonald's: 160 Broadway).

Now, when we get to the Children's Museum of Manhattan, I want you to track down a) the dog that writes poetry b) the first drafts of Dr Seuss's books c) some dead skin cells. No squabbling, please, or we don't go to Coney Island tomorrow ("coney" means "rabbit", incidentally).

DK's new series of guides "for kids who know where they're going" kicks off with New York and London (did you know that the "front" of Buckingham Palace is really the back?).

Each is packed with amazing facts and handy tips (look out for MPs being interviewed on Parliament Green - you might even get on television).

There are treasure hunts at most locations and any number of tasks, games, lists and quizzes. But above all, there are the pictures - the gem-like cut-outs that turn each glossy page into a glittering kaleidoscope. Kids will be kept fully occupied guarding these guides from grasping adults.

fields.headline: Douglas Adams never travels without...
fields.trailText: PowerBook | Hartmann briefcase | Navajo bracelet
fields.body:
A necessity: I cannot do without my PowerBook. My entire life's work is on it - everything I have ever written - all seven novels, every speech, every article. It includes videos of my five-year-old daughter and my diary and address book. Plus it gives me access to the web and my e-mail. People often complain about mobile communications, saying how nice it is to be out of touch. I am the exact opposite.

A luxury: I am extremely fond of my briefcase - a Hartmann made of the sort of leather that used to be used for driving big machines - rough and tough rather than smooth and Italian. I got a new one last year, and I suspect it will the last one I will ever need. I hope so because it cost around $1,000.

A memento: A few years ago, I bought a chunky Navajo silver bracelet in a shop in Sante Fe, New Mexico, one of my favourite places. I have worn it every day since. It is my comfort blanket. Sante Fe is one of those places where you feel there is a sense of deep history - even if you don't know what it is.

If only: I wish that everywhere in the world had the same power supply and telephone connection (see my first answer).

 www.h2g2.com - the online version of The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy - is now open and waiting for contributions.

fields.headline: On the verge of collapse
fields.standfirst: www.deckchair.com
fields.trailText: www.deckchair.com
fields.body:
What can I do here?
Very little. Last year, I mentioned deckchair.com and received an earful on Monday morning from a frustrated reader. Still, founder Sir Bob Geldof relaunched it last week, so I gave it another try. According to the PR puff, Deckchair now has a bigger choice of flights and links to 140,000 hand-picked websites.

What went wrong?
First of all, Sir Bob told me to register before I could search for anything. He took my email address and didn't bother to tell me whether he'd send junk mail. Undaunted, I searched for a flight to Moscow. Five minutes later, Deckchair was scouring the database. Goa? Ten minutes later, it was still plodding away. Amsterdam? As for a hotel in Rome, the top suggestion was in Honduras.

Surely the links were worth a look?
Surfing in Cornwall and trekking in Nepal were easy to research, but sailing around the Greek islands, health advice for Oman and obtaining a Russian visa all drew a blank. In other words, Altavista is likely to be more effective.

Were there any redeeming features?
Deckchair takes four traveller types - girls, blokes, culture vultures and weekenders - and suggests activities in NY, Barcelona, Prague and Paris.

This site is for...
Former rock stars thinking about launching an internet start-up. It's sagging. It's on the verge of collapse. Throw the deckchair away and start again, Sir Bob.

fields.headline: Heavyweights dish out painful beating
fields.trailText: For all but about an hour of this compelling day England were nigh unrecognisable from the team that turned in the dismal performance against New Zealand just nine months ago. The batting looked solid, runs came quickly enough to suggest a commanding total - and with it the luxury of a declaration well before the close. But England wouldn't be England without a collapse, and the resumption of normal service was sparked by the departure of Nick Knight.
fields.body:
For all but about an hour of this compelling day England were nigh unrecognisable from the team that turned in the dismal performance against New Zealand just nine months ago. The batting looked solid, runs came quickly enough to suggest a commanding total - and with it the luxury of a declaration well before the close. But England wouldn't be England without a collapse, and the resumption of normal service was sparked by the departure of Nick Knight.

He and Stewart had put on 114 for the fifth wicket and, at 376 for 5, the stage could not have been better set for a Flintoff cameo. But in forgiveable haste, he and his less celebrated understudies picked up last year's script. The final six wickets added just 39 runs: plus ça change.

Or so it seemed. Today things really were different. Even this apparent setback rebounded to England's advantage. Gerald Ratner could not have found a silver lining as sparkling or lustrous as this, with time - aided by the gloomy weather that is forecast for Sunday - Zimbabwe's only possible lifeline. The England collapse deftly removed from Nasser Hussain's reach any temptation to bat on into the evening.

The upshot was that Zimbabwe had a theoretical 48 minutes - just right for Gough and Caddick to work up a terrifying head of steam - to survive in failing light. They were not up to the task. For all but the most partisan England supporters, it was a painful sight, like watching a flyweight inadvertently in the same ring as a heavyweight. And it's some time since England resembled anything other than a flyweight themselves.

The dramatic conclusion to the evening session eclipsed other encouraging indicators too. For the first time in 15 Tests, England had two centurions and two century partnerships in an innings. Last summer, they could not manage either of these in a four-match series. There is of course a large health warning to give out. Lest optimists get too excited, it must be underlined that this was at the expense of an attack - Heath Streak a wholehearted exception - that would be of zero interest to the selectors of any other Test nation.

One thing though is sure: on this evidence England are a long way from the bottom of the Test ladder.

Hugh Chevallier is managing editor of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack

fields.headline: Trekking poles
fields.trailText: Adjustable aluminium walking sticks with wrist loops and hardened metal tips. Most have in-built shock absorbers you can switch on and off.
fields.body:
What are they?
Adjustable aluminium walking sticks with wrist loops and hardened metal tips. Most have in-built shock absorbers you can switch on and off.

Why use them?
Four legs good, two legs bad: a single pole can take a third of the weight off your hips, knees and ankles.

And the bad points?
A few people get blisters on their hands, your arms ache as well as your legs, but that's about it. Hardened curmudgeons convert overnight.

Come on, there must be something.
Oh, all right: the craze started in Germany. And they're noisy - the average mountain pass in midsummer sounds like an international wheel-tappers' convention.

How do they work?
Adjust them so your elbows are at right angles, put your hand upwards through the loop - watch that, it's counter-intuitive - and away you go: three points of contact with the ground all the time.

One stick or two?
Two are better, so you're balanced. When it's really rough or steep, put one away - they're telescopic - so you've got a spare hand for the rock.

What do they cost?
Between £15 and £35 each. Makers include Brasher, Gabel and Leki (purveyors of the Wanderfreund). The best (and priciest) have handles tilted forward to spare your wrist and some have walking-stick tops for that "country gent" image. A few can be used as monopods for cameras.

Won't I look a nerd?
Yes. But that's less painful than hip or knee replacement. And everyone has daft kit these days.

fields.headline: Wings of desire
fields.standfirst: You can really get away from it all - three months on a deserted island with a handful of like-minded people and thousands of birds for company.  John Quinn  did it and shares his experiences
fields.trailText: You can really get away from it all - three months on a deserted island with a handful of like-minded people and thousands of birds for company. John Quinn did it and shares his experiences
fields.body:
A ride really is paradise: a lush emerald island surrounded by powdery white beaches, set in azure-blue clear waters and populated by a handful of people, a million sea birds and all sorts of exotic creatures. It is perhaps the finest example in the Indian Ocean, easily accessible yet unspoilt.

As a volunteer warden on the nature reserve of Aride Island, the only problem was finding time to do nothing after taking care of the wildlife, the visitors and ourselves.

Wildlife

There are birds everywhere. Sooty terns mill in their thousands. Washing in the morning, you can watch white-tailed tropicbirds feed their ravenous chicks. Evening dinner on the veranda is often rudely interrupted by a confused Audubon's shearwater crash-landing into the rice pan. Seychelles blue pigeons coo from the tree tops. At night you are lulled to sleep by chattering noddies in the heavily-scented trees.

Getting up in the mornings from our humble chalets by the beach was effortless. We - that's me and five fellow biologists - knew the skies would be blue and the temperature a comfortable 30C.

Our first duty of the day was to search the beach for telltale tracks of nesting hawksbill or green turtles. Sometimes we were lucky and found one laying her clutch of more than 100 eggs above the crest of the beach. Awkward on land, turtles in the water are swift and graceful. To see a 50kg green turtle munching away on coral rock is unforgettable and not rare when snorkelling in the Seychelles.

In any one year, more than a million sea birds from 10 species nest on Aride. Trying to count and see how well they breed is challenging - counting noddy chicks in their seaweed nests high in the trees was a pain in the neck. The nocturnal shearwaters posed other problems - nesting in burrows.

The sustained contact with the birds was the most rewarding aspect of island life. But it could also be harrowing. Scores of young and adult birds became entangled in the sticky seeds of the pisonia tree - leading to their deaths. Precarious fairy tern eggs fell off branches. In some years, most of the island's sea birds fail to raise young because there are too few fish. As a biologist, I knew it should have been of consolation that this was (usually) only natural.

Victuals

Watching hungry chicks being fed was usually enough to send us in search of our own lunch. Once a week, we took the inflatable to Praslin, 10km away, to get supplies. My shopping list became smaller as I learned to use the island's natural produce. Most Seychellois are expert fishermen - my colleagues were no exception. Barracuda, bonito or jackfish were trawled from a fast-moving boat or baited bamboo traps were left beyond the reef. On one occasion it took steady nerves to remove a 4ft moray eel from among the catch. Fresh barbecued swordfish, jackfish or tuna in a chilli, garlic and ginger marinade is exquisite. The Seychellois look exceptionally healthy, no doubt because they eat fish daily.

There were plenty of fruits and vegetables to use on the island, as the fruit bats hanging in the trees knew well. One day, I caught a blue pigeon tottering on a branch, after it had become drunk from eating over-ripe papaya. He took two days and large quantities of water to recover.

Try this recipe: fry grated papaya (unripe) with onion, ginger and garlic until soft, and season.

Citrus fruits grew in abundance. I'm convinced limes were originally planted on Aride so that gin and tonics could be sipped on the beach while watching the sunset. Wading into the marsh to gather the spinach-like bred le mar was well worth the soaking. The coco yam made delicious deep-fried chips. Milk from grated coconut flesh took forever to extract but the fish curry that followed was worth it the effort.

On our desert island, everything took a long time. Our only mod cons were solar-powered fridges, lights and gas cookers. Water had to be taken from a well and boiled before drinking, and a bucket improvised as a shower. But somehow this grafting to provide the bare necessities was enormously satisfying.

Visitors

There was always excitement when tourists arrived. It took all six of us to launch the rubber boat we used to collect visitors from the boats moored beyond the reef. During the south-easterly trade winds from April to October, it can be too rough to land.

My Seychellois colleagues take pride in pointing out plants found nowhere else in the world. The piratical frigatebirds who steal fish from sooty terns are also a favourite.

You learn of the island's colonial history and see excavations where occupants searched for treasure rumoured to have been stashed by pirates such as Long John Avery and Captain Kidd. There is a memorial to Christopher Cadbury, of the chocolate family, who bought Aride in the 1970s on the advice of his friend, Sir Peter Scott, thereby safeguarding its future.

After the tour, we would enjoy a delicious barbecue before the visitors went snorkelling on the reef. The huge diversity of fish can lead to serious sensory overload. In 20 minutes on Aride's coral reef, you can easily see more than 100 fish species of a dazzling variety - blue-lipped sweetlips, boxfish, emperors and angelfish.

Elsewhere

You can stay overnight on other nature reserve islands such as Cousine and Bird Island, although these are expensive. But there are many other places to visit.

Hike up Morne Seychellois on Mahé for spectacular views of the islands. Visit the prehistoric forests in Vallée de Mai on Praslin to see the mystical coco de mer tree fern. Relish the cuisine and befriend the locals, most of whom are of African or Asian origin. Nearly all islands have idyllic, practically deserted beaches, but those on sleepy La Digue, where that Bounty Bar ad was filmed, are probably the best.

The practicals

To volunteer for three months on Aride, write to Aride Information, The Wildlife Trusts, The Kiln, Waterside, Mather Road, Newark NG24 1WT. Tourists cannot stay over night, but day trips between October and April cost about £40 from nearby Praslin. Yachts can also land at Aride (£10 per person); contact the island by radio or phone (00248 321600). Flights to the Seychelles start at £550.Contact Alignspeed (01293 596660), Seychelles Travel (01258 450983) or the Seychelles Tourist Board (020 7224 1670). Travel between and on islands is easy and inexpensive. Other useful websites: www.odci.gov/cia/publications/factbook/se.html, www.sey.net and www.seychelles-travel.co.uk.

fields.headline: Le shopping
fields.standfirst: Retail therapy in the French capital is a serious business.  Anna Rockall guides you through it
fields.trailText: Retail therapy in the French capital is a serious business. Anna Rockall guides you through it
fields.body:
A plan of attack was needed. I collected advice, studied maps, made lists and drew up a plan that was supposed to lead me seamlessly from one shop to another. I learnt that most of the good shops fitted into two areas that allowed you to see a respectable portion of Paris, including a few of the tourist sights.

Day 1
Starting point: Arc de Triomphe

It was unfortunate that the first thing I picked up was the cheese because it smelt but no cheese lover could resist the delights of Androuet, tucked just off the Champs Elysées near the Arc de Triomphe (6, Rue Arsene Houssaye). It's one of the best cheese shops in Paris; the cheeses are matured in cellars on the premises, and you can try the cheesy menu in the restaurant. After much rapturous sniffing, I settled on a selection including a beautiful Reblochon and a ripe Pont-l'év que.

Next were the celebrated wine cellars of Taillevent, (199 Rue de Faubourg St Honoré). If you go back to the Arc de Triomphe, and walk up Avenue Hoche, it will take you to the right part of this very long road. Les Caves Taillevent stock thousands of wines from all over France, and sommeliers are on hand to help out. The room is decorated with empty bottles drunk by luminaries - a 1953 Fourcaud-Laussac drunk by Salvador Dali in 1976, a 1934 Grand Vin de Léoville drunk by Richard Nixon in 1986, and a 1934 Chateau Haut-Brion drunk by Charles de Gaulle in 1961. After a tour of the large cellars, I took the sommelier's word for it and chose Taillevent's selection of Bordeaux, which was then thankfully delivered to where I was staying.

On the long walk east down Rue St Honoré, which runs parallel to the Champs Elysées, I passed a lot of top clothes shops and big labels, including Façonnable - stylish casual shirts for FFr600-800 (there are around 10.8 francs to the pound) - and Hermès, home of the classic silk scarf at FFr1,460. With the current strong pound this works out at almost a bargain, around £23 cheaper than the London price of £160. But I pressed on to my slightly less glam destination, Au Nain Bleu, (406 Rue St Honoré), the toy shop to end toy shops. They sell the kind of toys that grown-ups prefer to have littered around their living rooms- smart painted wooden toys and games. My niece was soon sorted out with some beautiful doll's house furniture, and I carried on towards Place de la Madeleine.

Place de la Madeleine is more famous for its food shops than it is for its grand classical temple, La Madeleine. Paris's most lavish delicatessens guard the square, offering goodies for the extravagant gourmet. I was put off the truffles at the Maison de la Truffe by the inflated price of FFr290-496 for a mere 25g, but for a wider range of products - the widest - Fauchon is unmissable. It will sell you anything from raspberry pepper sweets (FFr39) to Roquefort mustard (FFr25) or Earl Grey jelly (FFr35); there are hundreds of products you didn't even know existed, let alone know you wanted.

By this stage, I'd been looking at food all morning without eating a thing, so went next door to the Salon de Thé Fauchon, for a terribly refined late morning morsel. From the selection of patisseries, I chose a Traviata Framboise. It was a raspberry and almond cream delight that tasted like it had fallen from an angel's table. Washed down with tea chosen from an array of special blends and infusions (caramel tea anyone? Or green apple?) it made for a luxurious elevenses.

Feeling the urge for a little peace and greenery, I wandered down to the Place de la Concorde and through the long avenues of the Jardin des Tuileries towards the Louvre before turning off towards the busy high street shopping area of Les Halles. This is a fun place, with crowds of young faces, buskers and street performers and a buzzing atmosphere, but the shops turned out to be disappointingly like shops on any good high street in England. It was clearly a foodie day, because heading east along Rue de la Verrerie, I came across A l'Olivier (23 Rue de Rivoli) near metro St Paul, where they stock an impressive range of olive oils: peanut, corn, chilli, tarragon and truffle. The thoroughbred of oils is the unfiltered extra virgin olive oil from the Vallée du Paillon at FFr95 for 50cl, but I came away with a small selection of fennel, lemon, and herb.

Tired and footsore, I headed towards the elegant lawns and shady benches of the Place des Vosges; I'd seen the Arc de Triomphe, the Champs Elysées, the Madeleine, the Jardin des Tuileries, Les Halles and the Place des Vosges, as well as some of Paris' finest shops. I took the metro back west for a sundowner at Le Totem, the bar restaurant in the Palais de Chaillot that looks across the river at the Eiffel Tower. Not as touristy as you might think, this terrace at the top of the Trocadéro gardens turned out to be the perfect place for a cold beer at the end of a hard day.

Day 2
Starting point: Boulevard St Germain

Having explored the Right Bank, it was time for the Rive Gauche. I took the metro to Solférino, at the eastern end of Boulevard St Germain, so that I could work my way down without doubling back on myself. I soon discovered, though, that as with the Champs Elysées, the best places were actually off the famous road. Apart, that is, from Richart (258 Bvd St Germain, by Solférino metro), which sells astonishingly artistic chocolates.

I had promised myself this wouldn't be a foodie day, but a box of these miniature works of art was a perfect house gift for my host. They have a very distinctive style, in particular the square chocolates hand painted with patterns and delicate pictures (FFr105 for 16). I chose a box with each chocolate decorated differently with little people - too beautiful to eat.

Walking west down Boulevard St Germain, I turned right on to Rue St Peres - a good move for the fashion conscious. Capucine Puerai (62 Rue St Peres) sells a small but elegant range of dresses and suits with simple, clean lines at FFr800-1,800. I escaped from the shop with one little white dress only to be sucked in by its neighbour and sartorial opposite, the decadent and glamorous Shadé. The main stock was in accessories - fantastic glam jewellery from FFr500-1,000, jewelled chokers and gaudy rings, wonderful scarves and mad hats. I settled on a sparkling choker for those dressier nights out.

Ask any chic Parisian where to go for lingerie, and she will say Sabbia Rosa, where you can find silk underwear of every form and colour, from the demure to the outrageous. Fortunately, it is just down the road from Shadé, still on Rue St Peres, so I popped in to admire the great armfuls of softest silk on display. A short camisole goes for FFr1,200, but it's not the same if you buy it yourself.

Just down the road, at the junction with Rue de Grenelle, you can find Prada, YSL and other top labels for those with astronomical budgets. This is the Latin Quarter, and it is a good place to come to buy presents - the Galeries D'Amon on Rue St Sulpice sells beautiful blown glass bottles and vases from FFr450 up, and at Cir, a few doors down, you can buy candles of every shape, size and style, including a gold replica of the Eiffel Tower which was too kitsch to be missed. There is something around every corner, so it's worth taking time to explore.

On my second day, I had managed to explore a fair chunk of the Left Bank, my bank account was empty, my shopping bags full, and my head spinning. It had got to the stage where all judgment had been lost and I had gone credit-card crazy.

But temptation was not far away, in the shape of one of Paris' trendier restaurants, Spoon. Here they have broken down the traditional style of menu into its component parts, and leave it up to you how you want to reassemble it. You choose the basic elements you want - say, cod - and then which of the available ways you want it done - say, roast with citrus jam. Every element of the menu is presented with a range of possibilities. If you are feeling daring, you could start with dessert, or have your hors d'oeuvre with chips.

Everything's on offer, and what you pick is entirely up to you. Just like shopping, only easier on the feet.

Anna's bag

Androuet: large Reblochon (490g) FFr69, a whole Pont-l'év que (400g) FFr46.

Taillevent: a boxed selection of six Bordeaux FFr420, plus FFr60 for local delivery.

Au Nain Bleu: Living-room set for dolls' house, FFr200.

Salon de Thé Fauchon: Patisserie FFr45, tea FFr40.

A l'Olivier: three flavoured olive oils at FFr37 each.

Richart: FFr105 for a box of 16 chocolates.

Capucine Puerai: dress FFr1,200.

Shadé: choker FFr550.

Cir: Eiffel tower candle, FFr55.

Total: FFr2,901 (£268.61)

 A strike that has led to ATM machines in France being empty of money continued this week. Stores have lowered their credit-card minimum purchase and official advice is to take more French francs with you for incidentals.

Just down the road, at the junction with Rue de Grenelle, you can find Prada, YSL and other top labels for those with astronomical budgets. This is the Latin Quarter, and it is a good place to come to buy presents - the Galeries D'Amon on Rue St Sulpice sells beautiful blown glass bottles and vases from FFr450 up, and at Cir, a few doors down, you can buy candles of every shape, size and style, including a gold replica of the Eiffel Tower which was too kitsch to be missed. There is something around every corner, so it's worth taking time to explore. On my second day, I had managed to explore a fair chunk of the Left Bank, my bank account was empty, my shopping bags full, and my head spinning. It had got to the stage where all judgment had been lost and I had gone credit-card crazy. But temptation was not far away, in the shape of one of Paris' trendier restaurants, Spoon. Here they have broken down the traditional style of menu into its component parts, and leave it up to you how you want to reassemble it. You choose the basic elements you want - say, cod - and then which of the available ways you want it done - say, roast with citrus jam. Every element of the menu is presented with a range of possibilities. If you are feeling daring, you could start with dessert, or have your hors d'oeuvre with chips. Everything's on offer, and what you pick is entirely up to you. Just like shopping, only easier on the feet. Anna's bag Androuet: large Reblochon (490g) FFr69, a whole Pont-l'év que (400g) FFr46. Taillevent: a boxed selection of six Bordeaux FFr420, plus FFr60 for local delivery. Au Nain Bleu: Living-room set for dolls' house, FFr200. Salon de Thé Fauchon: Patisserie FFr45, tea FFr40. A l'Olivier: three flavoured olive oils at FFr37 each. Richart: FFr105 for a box of 16 chocolates. Capucine Puerai: dress FFr1,200. Shadé: choker FFr550. Cir: Eiffel tower candle, FFr55. Total: FFr2,901 (£268.61)  A strike that has led to ATM machines in France being empty of money continued this week. Stores have lowered their credit-card minimum purchase and official advice is to take more French francs with you for incidentals.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.standfirst: Allison Davies asked for tips and recommendations for two nights' accommodation when travelling though France from Calais to Spain.
fields.trailText: Allison Davies asked for tips and recommendations for two nights' accommodation when travelling though France from Calais to Spain.
fields.body:
We made the same journey last year. Two days is ambitious - allow three if possible. Best driving tip - in smaller towns, overhead traffic lights are easily missed - so look out for them at junctions. Best value accommodation - look for (often very small) "Chambre d'hote" signs in rural areas. These are often akin to chateaux with fabulous accommodation and in gorgeous locations. No need to book - you're often the only people there.
Janet Conroy

For a very cheap, clean, place to stay, I recommend Formule 1 - there's at least one of this chain of hotels on the outskirts of most towns and cities. You get bed and breakfast with shared toilet and shower; payment is automatic (if you've pre-booked) by credit card - and instructions are in English. With regard to driving, I advise always having in mind the next town you're heading towards as French road numbers aren't as well signposted as British ones and often just "change" for no apparent reason.
Ian Andrews

If you have kids, I would get a fly-drive package to say Barcelona - skip the overnight stops, the long and, for the kids, boring journey and spend more time enjoying things. Mind you, driving in Spain is a bit hairy at times.
David Hall, Horley

Whenever travelling through France we always use the Gites De France Bed & Breakfast Guide (English title French Country Welcome). We've stayed in a huge variety of places, usually rooms in a private house that have been converted to provide en suite accommodation. They are nearly all in small villages. Some of them will do an evening meal. Around £25pp a night for bed breakfast and evening meal would be on the expensive side.

If you can't find a current guide, the address to get one from is: Maison des Gites de France, 35 rue Godot-de- Mauroy, 75439, Parish Cedex 09. Tel: (1) 49 70 75 75.
David and Hilary Thomas, Stretford

D Heath wanted advice on how he and his family, with a nine and a 14-year-old, could experience Cuba, meet the locals and have fun.

I suggest you avoid hotels and stay in casas particulares (private houses that rent out rooms and usually provide meals). You will eat far better than in hotels and see day-to-day Cuban family life. If you don't speak Spanish, it is well worth the effort to learn even some basics.

Safety is not a problem, assuming you take normal precautions - Cuba is one of the safest countries you can visit, certainly far safer than the UK. You have thousands of beaches to choose from, most of them deserted. If you want a beach resort near Havana then there are a number on the north coast within 60km - avoid Varadero. You can increase your options by hiring a car, which is relatively cheap.

Get a good guide book - Lonely Planet or Travellers Survival Guide are the most detailed - and spend some time in Havana.
Tim Ferguson

We are an association of casas particulares . You can stay in one of our houses. You can share the house with a family with or without children or you can stay in an apartment on your own. It can be in old Havana, Vedado or anywhere around the island. Check the website at www.geocities.com/casaparticular
Carlos & Daniel

We have just returned from a tour organised by Havanatour. We stayed in hotels at Las Terrazas (a rural area west of Havana), Havana and Trinidad. Safety was never an issue in our wanderings around both Havana and Trinidad.

Four-star hotels will give you all the physical comfort you could wish for, and the beach near Trinidad is a dream. You cannot help but meet Cubans. You will be incessantly hailed with "Where you from?", so you need some basic Spanish. They will be very friendly and intensely curious about you, even inviting you to their homes, but often after a dollar handout as well.

Avoid 100% tourist areas like Varadero. I can give more details if the questioner wants to contact me direct.
Brian Light
brilight@dial.pipex.com

Clare Monk wanted to know what the weather was like in Thailand in August and September.

The rainy season starts in July with things getting gradually more wet as the year progresses. As a rule, the south of Thailand is generally wetter than the north. On the basis of this, it's probably reasonable to assume you will be seeing some showers during your trip.

However, Thailand has (along with the rest of the planet) been experiencing what can only be described as "weird weather", ie things are just not happening when they should! I was in Thailand in March this year and met some travellers in Chiang Rai who had abandoned the Phuket area to travel north because the weather was so awful down south - March is supposed to be "rain-free" according to the books.
Julia Knight

<bthis week's questions

I am a 21-year-old woman and I will be travelling to Africa this summer for a seven-day safari to the Vic Falls. However, the first two days of my holiday will be spent in Johannesburg. I have heard a lot about the safety problem there and I would like to get some information from other people who have been there about where I should stay, what I should and should not do etc.
M Gerritsen

Can anyone give us advice (especially do's and don'ts) about hiring a campervan in Canada, travelling in the Canadian Rockies with a campervan, using campsites in the Canadian Rockies, travelling by train between Calgary and Vancouver, walking in the Canadian Rockies and flights to Canada (Rockies). Is it cheaper to fly to the US and hire a camper there for travel in Canada?
Heather Skaife

 If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller @theguardian.com. We will publish the answers as soon as we can. We cannot answer questions we do not publish.
