webTitle: Power play - how the City of Angels gets its kicks

fields.headline: Power play - how the City of Angels gets its kicks
fields.standfirst: Some may think London the sporting capital of the world because it hosts today's FA Cup Final and next month's Wimbledon. But Los Angeles is a major-league player, too.  Andy Pietrasik enjoys a weekend lost in the action
fields.trailText: Some may think London the sporting capital of the world because it hosts today's FA Cup Final and next month's Wimbledon. But Los Angeles is a major-league player, too. Andy Pietrasik enjoys a weekend lost in the action
fields.body:
'I've always called LA the world capital of sport," says Tommy Lasorda, senior vice-president of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who won two world baseball series when he was the team' manager from 1976 to 1998. That's world series, mind, even though only American and Canadian teams compete.

The Hall of Famer and "baseball's most popular ambassador" may very wellhave a case for championing his city over the likes of London or New York for the world sporting crown, though. For when Angelenos are not worshipping at the outdoor altar of health and fitness - flinging their bronzed bodies about a beach volleyball court, say, in Santa Monica, or surfing the breaks at Zuma, rollerblading along Venice's Ocean Front Walk or maybe pumping up their pneumatic pecs at Muscle Beach - they like nothing better than to cheer on others in the pursuit of athletic excellence.

The conditions are, of course, perfect for competitors and spectators alike: great weather, glorious west-coast setting and stadia that are out of this world.

In the land of plenty, LA can be seen toenjoy an embarrassment of riches. The Dodgers outgrew their birthplace of Brooklyn and moved west for richer pickings in 1958. The LA Lakers relocated from Minnesota in 1960, have since won six basketball world championships, and in Magic Johnson had one of the greatest players in NBA history. The LA Kings have yet to lift ice hockey's Stanley Cup, but the team had Wayne Gretzky, known as The Great One, from the late 80s to early 90s. And, in a country where the car is still king, there's the Long Beach Grand Prix to keep the petrol heads happy. Each of these is a blockbuster franchise with Hollywood production values, budgets and box-office stars to match.

Sports addicts who time it right can drift from one field of dreams to another over the space of a long weekend. In early April, the Lakers were putting the finishing touches to their West Conference-winning season before entering the play-offs for the NBA championships; the Dodgers were pitching their first home series of the millennium against the Cincinnati Reds; and Long Beach was waving the chequered flag on its 26th Grand Prix. Sadly, I couldn't stick around to catch the Kings' opening home play-off game against the Detroit Redwings. But ow there's an excuse to go back next April.

The hoops
Friday 7.30pm: LA Lakers versus Sacramento Kings

The setting for tonight's hoop dreams is a $375 million, futuristic-lookingstadium in downtown LA, which opened last October. "Uniquely LA" is how Dan Meis, of architects NBBJ, describes his company's all-glass and metal creation. From the outside, it looks like a giant, glowing hockey puck at full til (it is also home to the KIngs as well as the Clippers, LA's other NBA franchise). Inside, the seating presses down on the varnished wooden court, making it appear way too small a stage for the world's tallest athletes. Even from a distance, you feel close to the action. But not as close as those who, like Jack Nicholson, pay $1,150 to be on top of it in thefloorside seats.

"Welcome to the Staples Center, the sports and entertainment centre of the world," says the public announcer.

The world capital. The world champions. The world's biggest. Out of this world. There's reallyno place left to go from here, other than the centre of the universe. Americans are not ones for selling themselves short, but they sureknow how to put on a good show. Especially in Tinseltown.

Before the action starts, there's the singing of the Star-Spangled Banner, the last time the 18,997-seater venue will stand still for the next two-and-a-half hours. The teams enter to strobe lights and disco music; the all-dancing Laker Girls distract the crowd between time-outs; vendors walk between the aisles handing out peanuts, burgers, hot dogs and even Pizza Hut boxes; the man sitting in the lucky seat number wins a year's subscription to Cigar Aficionado; "When I say Lakers, you say go!"

On court, in the land of the giants, there is aa Goliath whodominates the game and the eye. "A great physical specimen," is how film director Spike Lee describes Shaquille O'Neal in his basketball book, Best Seat in the House. At 7ft 1in and weighing 22 1/2 stone, the Lakers centre is a massive talent, dwarfing the other players who attempt to pirouette and fly past him. While the 6ft somethings circling the basket have tomake at least a token leap when they plop their shots through the hoop, Shaq's size 21 sneakers barely leave the ground as he twists and nonchalantly flicks the ball up and over the rim.

Basketball is a fast and graceful game, even if Shaq appears to lumber unhurriedly between defence and attack. At the end,the Lakers run out winners by 121 points to 114 (Shaq has scored 41 of them). That's a lot of baskets for your average $40 seat price - and, in between, we've had an indoor fireworks display, break-dancing and a rapper singing "We can get it on".

Celebrity spots: Pete Sampras and Garry Shandling.
Price of a huge flame-grilled burger: $7.50.
Price of a beer: $5.
Price of a replica Shaq shirt, number 34: $150.
Regular basketball season: runs from November to April.
Regular ticket prices: $10-$150.
Where: Staples Center, 1111 South Figueroa.
Box office tel: (213) 742 7340710, www.staplescenter.com

The ball game
Saturday 5.15pm: LA Dodgers versus Cincinatti Reds

Sports fans arriving at Dodgers Stadium must feel as though they have just died andarrived in heaven. Address: Elysian Park Avenue. Setting: on a hill overlooking downtown LA to the south, tree-lined Elysian hills to the north and east and the San Gabriel mountains beyond. Overhead: puffy white clouds in a cobalt-blue sky. There are even a couple of palm trees at the pavilion end, for Pete's sake. Or did I just dream that along with the chorus of angels?

I didn't imagine that hallowed diamond, though. Pure manicured magic, all 100,000sq ft of the dazzling Bermuda grass and sand.

If you build it, they will come.In the late 1950s, Brooklyn Dodgers owner Walter O'Malley had a dream to build a more modernball park for his Brooklyn Dodgers. New York couldn't come up with a site, so he moved them to LA. Simple economics. By 1962, the LA Dodgers had a 56,000-seater home, where they beat theCincinatti Reds 6-2 in their opening game on April 10.

Thirty-eight years later almost to the day, the Dodgers are onceagain pitted against the Reds in their opening home series at Dodgers Stadiu. (They win the first game 8-1, but willlose this one 5-4). In the close season, the fifth oldes venue in baseballhas had a $50-million facelift, adding 35 luxury suites at $125,000 to $300,000 a season and nine rows of padded seats behind the home plate ($195-$250) to cater for the Hollywood set. More than half the seats in the stadium, though, are still available for $6.

Since 1962, players' wages have gone through the roof,of course, and there have been ugly strikes and shut-outs down the year. But much about the game has reassuringly staye the same: the rules, the old-fashioned looking uniforms, the tradition of the seventh-inning stretch - when everybody stands up and sings "Take me out to the ball game . . ." - and the vendors holding up cotton candy and boxes of Crackerjack popcorn.

Baseball is about as downhomey as it gets, a completecontrast to the rap-influenced, tattooed, blazinginner-city world of basketball. Shoot, some of the ball players still chew Red Man tobacco.

It's also amurderously difficult gameto master, and thus one of the most beguiling. Curve balls and sliders wing from the pitcher's arm at 90mph towards a batsman armed only with a slim, round shaft of wood for defenc. Strike one. Bases loaded. Pinch-hitters and sluggers. RBIs and ABs. When they connect and clear the outfield for a home run, you cannot fail to be at once relieved and exhilarated.

But ven if allthe stats and percentages leave you either bamboozled orcold, there is no nice way to while away a sunny southern Californian afternoon than at the top of Elysian Park Avenue.

Celebrity spots: a day earlier, Carole King was singing the Star-Spangled Banner; Tom Cruise; Goldie Hawn and John Cusack.
Price of hot dog: $3.75.
Price of a beer: $5.
Price of a baseball hat: $12.99.
The regular baseball season: runs from April to October.
Regular ticket prices: $6-$38.
Where: Dodgers Stadium, 1000 Elysian Park Avenue, Echo Park.
Box office tel: 001 (323) 2241448, www.dodgers.com

The race
Sunday 1pm: Long Beach Grand Prix

An hour from downtown LA on the Metro Blue Line or, more fittingly, a 40-minute drive south down the coast, is what the publicity machine for the seaside resort ofLong Beach likes torefers to as "the world's fastest beach party". This three-day festival of sunshine, sound and speed, including the Toyota Grand Prix, is part of the 20-race CART FedEx Championship series. Fittingly, cenes from the movie Speed were filmed along Shoreline Drive where today's race is taking place.

Monaco-style, 1.9 miles of Long Beach's palm-lined streets just up from the Pacific shoreare turned into a circuit, along which the racing cars chase for 82 laps. That's around 155 miles, pretty much going round in circlesat an average speed of 80-odd mph and topspeeds of more than 100mph.

Californians love racing's playboy image and itsmovie-style setting - Hollywood legendPaul Newman is part-owner of the Newman-Haas racing team, which has two cars in the field, driven by Michael Andretti and Christian Fittipaldi. More than 200,000 turn out on a blisteringly hot day, many of them in nothing more than halterneck or bikini tops and cut-off jeans. Dedicated male fans sport multi-coloured Valvoline-labelled race shirts, smoke $7 Fittipaldi Premium cigars and eat from Fat Boy's Diner BBQ and King Taco stands. The group in the grandstand row in front of us appear to have eaten little and drunk a lot. They're having a roaring good time.

Hollywood kicks in again before the race. Former allAmerican football star John Elway throws footballs into the crowd. After the prayer for the drivers, there is a fly-over by US Navy F-18 jets and the Elite Frog Parachute Jump Team deliver the American Flag by "airmail". There's a rendition of the Star-Spangled Banner, again, before those famous words: "Gentleman, start your engines".

The roar of the engine, it has to be said, is more of a whine, a shrill one with back-firing explosions that set the pulse racing. At this point, health-conscious Californians jam in their earplugs - which would seem to defeat half the exercise of being here, given that it's not much of a spectacle to see the cars for fractions of a second every 70 seconds or s.

Large screens above the pits doshow the race in full, however,as well as views from cockpit cameras, and the race commentator does his best to inject somemore drama into the proceedings by likening these images to scenes from the Mortal Combat arcade game. The real drama comes in the crashes and thespin-offs though- as long as no one is too badly hurt, of course - and there are many over the course of this race. Only nine of the original 25 drivers finish, and Christian Fittipaldi's car bursts into flames during a pit stop directlyopposite the grandstand.

Canadian Paul "Goin' to the wall" Tracy takes the chequered flag, and we take the freeway back to LA . . . and get stuck in traffic.

Celebrity spots: George Lucas.
Price of a taco: $1.60
Price of a beer: $5
Where: Long Beach Grand Prix, April 14-16. www.longbeachgp.com
Ticket prices: $45 for three days, $35 for one day.
Box office tel: (562) 436-9953

Sports fans on tour

June 4
Motor Racing: Monaco, Monte Carlo Grand Prix.
Page & Moy (0116 250 7007) offers from three-night packages by coach, inc B&B and race tickets, for £269pp, one-day flight deals for £349pp to 10-night packages for £5,500.

June 15-22
Rugby: England tour of South Africa.
Gullivers Sports Travel (01684 293175) offers a package from June 15-22 taking in the matches at Pretoria and Cape Town for £1,119 based on sharing a twin room.

July 1-23
Cycling: Tour de France.
Graham Baxter Tours (0113 2843617) offers 12 different packages, ranging from a weekend to two weeks following the tour on cycles, and with prices from £159pp to £699pp respectively.

August
Football: The Italian and Spanish leagues kick off in the last week of August.
Fanfare Events (0161-437 0002) offer tailor-made packages taking in a major game. Two-night packages typically cost from £325pp, inc flights, hotel B&B and match tickets.

September
Olympic Games: Sydney. September 15-October 1.
Sportsworld (01235 550904) is the official ticket and tour operator for the UK. Tours start at £1,895pp for six nights' motel accommodation, inc flights excl tickets. Tickets available from £10 for the baseball or hockey, up to £600 for the closing ceremony. Availability is becoming limited. Details of the paralympics October 18-October 28 are also available from Sportsworld.

October
Horse racing: Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, Hippodrome de Longchamps, Paris, Sunday October 1.
One-day trips start at £159pp, weekends at £229pp from Horse Racing Abroad (01444 441661), which also offerstrips to other major race meetings.

November-December
Cricket: England tour of Pakistan and Sri Lanka.
Pakistan Tests: Lahore (Nov 15-19), Faisalabad (Nov 22-Dec 3), Karachi (Dec 7-Dec 11); Sri Lanka Tests: Galle (Feb 22-26), Kandy (March 7-11), Colombo (March 15-19).
Jon Snow Sports Travel (01293 440440) is offering packages to the Test matches but had not finalised prices or details at the time of going to press. If you call, they will take your details and send final itineraries.

Places to eat

Breakfast

1 The Original Pantry 877 S Figueroa St. Breakfast of champions 24-hours-a-day for around $5 in vintage American diner.

Lunch

2 Sky Box Staples Center Affordable and filling before the game, though steer clear of the parmesan-coated fries: 1/2 lb burger $7.95, All-Madden Team Chop $14.95, Goin' Deep Cappuccino Pie $12

Dinner

3 Ca' del Sol 4100 Cahuenga Boulevard. Nice courtyard; usual Italian suspects of risotto, pasta, veal etc and a good selection of Californian wine. Dinner with wine around $35 a head.

4 Tammy Tang's 7313 Melrose Avenue Typical Thai menu - red curries, soft shell crab etc, and good vegetarian choice. Meal plus wine around $25-£30 a head. (Lunch $20 a head plus drink.)

Places to drink

1 Sky Box - The Sport's Fans Bar & Grill Staples Center. See Shaquille O'Neal's framed size 21 sneakers and grab another ball game on one of the many giant screens over a $6 beer.

2 Grand Avenue Sports Bar Regal Biltmore Hotel, 506 South Grand Avenue. Good for sports buffs with its 11 satellite feeds, but also worth a wander around afterwards for its restored 20s elegance. Birthplace of the Oscar statue, host of numerous Academy Awards, and scene of countless movies, this is where west coast society came to be seen. $4.50-$6 for a brandy.

3 Top of Five Westin Bonaventure Hotel, 404 Figueroa St. Ride outside in a glass elevator to the top of this revolving bar for a panoramic view of the city. $6.50 for a Cosmopolitan cocktail (see recipe below).

4 Ye Olde King's Head 116 Santa Monica Boulevard. Novelty value only to see the Californian take on the English boozer, though it's the best place around to watch European soccer.

"Welcome to the Staples Center, the sports and entertainment centre of the world," says the public announcer. The world capital. The world champions. The world's biggest. Out of this world. There's reallyno place left to go from here, other than the centre of the universe. Americans are not ones for selling themselves short, but they sureknow how to put on a good show. Especially in Tinseltown. Before the action starts, there's the singing of the Star-Spangled Banner, the last time the 18,997-seater venue will stand still for the next two-and-a-half hours. The teams enter to strobe lights and disco music; the all-dancing Laker Girls distract the crowd between time-outs; vendors walk between the aisles handing out peanuts, burgers, hot dogs and even Pizza Hut boxes; the man sitting in the lucky seat number wins a year's subscription to Cigar Aficionado; "When I say Lakers, you say go!" On court, in the land of the giants, there is aa Goliath whodominates the game and the eye. "A great physical specimen," is how film director Spike Lee describes Shaquille O'Neal in his basketball book, Best Seat in the House. At 7ft 1in and weighing 22 1/2 stone, the Lakers centre is a massive talent, dwarfing the other players who attempt to pirouette and fly past him. While the 6ft somethings circling the basket have tomake at least a token leap when they plop their shots through the hoop, Shaq's size 21 sneakers barely leave the ground as he twists and nonchalantly flicks the ball up and over the rim. Basketball is a fast and graceful game, even if Shaq appears to lumber unhurriedly between defence and attack. At the end,the Lakers run out winners by 121 points to 114 (Shaq has scored 41 of them). That's a lot of baskets for your average $40 seat price - and, in between, we've had an indoor fireworks display, break-dancing and a rapper singing "We can get it on". Celebrity spots: Pete Sampras and Garry Shandling. Price of a huge flame-grilled burger: $7.50. Price of a beer: $5. Price of a replica Shaq shirt, number 34: $150. Regular basketball season: runs from November to April. Regular ticket prices: $10-$150. Where: Staples Center, 1111 South Figueroa. Box office tel: (213) 742 7340710, www.staplescenter.com The ball game Saturday 5.15pm: LA Dodgers versus Cincinatti Reds Sports fans arriving at Dodgers Stadium must feel as though they have just died andarrived in heaven. Address: Elysian Park Avenue. Setting: on a hill overlooking downtown LA to the south, tree-lined Elysian hills to the north and east and the San Gabriel mountains beyond. Overhead: puffy white clouds in a cobalt-blue sky. There are even a couple of palm trees at the pavilion end, for Pete's sake. Or did I just dream that along with the chorus of angels? I didn't imagine that hallowed diamond, though. Pure manicured magic, all 100,000sq ft of the dazzling Bermuda grass and sand. If you build it, they will come.In the late 1950s, Brooklyn Dodgers owner Walter O'Malley had a dream to build a more modernball park for his Brooklyn Dodgers. New York couldn't come up with a site, so he moved them to LA. Simple economics. By 1962, the LA Dodgers had a 56,000-seater home, where they beat theCincinatti Reds 6-2 in their opening game on April 10. Thirty-eight years later almost to the day, the Dodgers are onceagain pitted against the Reds in their opening home series at Dodgers Stadiu. (They win the first game 8-1, but willlose this one 5-4). In the close season, the fifth oldes venue in baseballhas had a $50-million facelift, adding 35 luxury suites at $125,000 to $300,000 a season and nine rows of padded seats behind the home plate ($195-$250) to cater for the Hollywood set. More than half the seats in the stadium, though, are still available for $6. Since 1962, players' wages have gone through the roof,of course, and there have been ugly strikes and shut-outs down the year. But much about the game has reassuringly staye the same: the rules, the old-fashioned looking uniforms, the tradition of the seventh-inning stretch - when everybody stands up and sings "Take me out to the ball game . . ." - and the vendors holding up cotton candy and boxes of Crackerjack popcorn. Baseball is about as downhomey as it gets, a completecontrast to the rap-influenced, tattooed, blazinginner-city world of basketball. Shoot, some of the ball players still chew Red Man tobacco. It's also amurderously difficult gameto master, and thus one of the most beguiling. Curve balls and sliders wing from the pitcher's arm at 90mph towards a batsman armed only with a slim, round shaft of wood for defenc. Strike one. Bases loaded. Pinch-hitters and sluggers. RBIs and ABs. When they connect and clear the outfield for a home run, you cannot fail to be at once relieved and exhilarated. But ven if allthe stats and percentages leave you either bamboozled orcold, there is no nice way to while away a sunny southern Californian afternoon than at the top of Elysian Park Avenue. Celebrity spots: a day earlier, Carole King was singing the Star-Spangled Banner; Tom Cruise; Goldie Hawn and John Cusack. Price of hot dog: $3.75. Price of a beer: $5. Price of a baseball hat: $12.99. The regular baseball season: runs from April to October. Regular ticket prices: $6-$38. Where: Dodgers Stadium, 1000 Elysian Park Avenue, Echo Park. Box office tel: 001 (323) 2241448, www.dodgers.com The race Sunday 1pm: Long Beach Grand Prix An hour from downtown LA on the Metro Blue Line or, more fittingly, a 40-minute drive south down the coast, is what the publicity machine for the seaside resort ofLong Beach likes torefers to as "the world's fastest beach party". This three-day festival of sunshine, sound and speed, including the Toyota Grand Prix, is part of the 20-race CART FedEx Championship series. Fittingly, cenes from the movie Speed were filmed along Shoreline Drive where today's race is taking place. Monaco-style, 1.9 miles of Long Beach's palm-lined streets just up from the Pacific shoreare turned into a circuit, along which the racing cars chase for 82 laps. That's around 155 miles, pretty much going round in circlesat an average speed of 80-odd mph and topspeeds of more than 100mph. Californians love racing's playboy image and itsmovie-style setting - Hollywood legendPaul Newman is part-owner of the Newman-Haas racing team, which has two cars in the field, driven by Michael Andretti and Christian Fittipaldi. More than 200,000 turn out on a blisteringly hot day, many of them in nothing more than halterneck or bikini tops and cut-off jeans. Dedicated male fans sport multi-coloured Valvoline-labelled race shirts, smoke $7 Fittipaldi Premium cigars and eat from Fat Boy's Diner BBQ and King Taco stands. The group in the grandstand row in front of us appear to have eaten little and drunk a lot. They're having a roaring good time. Hollywood kicks in again before the race. Former allAmerican football star John Elway throws footballs into the crowd. After the prayer for the drivers, there is a fly-over by US Navy F-18 jets and the Elite Frog Parachute Jump Team deliver the American Flag by "airmail". There's a rendition of the Star-Spangled Banner, again, before those famous words: "Gentleman, start your engines". The roar of the engine, it has to be said, is more of a whine, a shrill one with back-firing explosions that set the pulse racing. At this point, health-conscious Californians jam in their earplugs - which would seem to defeat half the exercise of being here, given that it's not much of a spectacle to see the cars for fractions of a second every 70 seconds or s. Large screens above the pits doshow the race in full, however,as well as views from cockpit cameras, and the race commentator does his best to inject somemore drama into the proceedings by likening these images to scenes from the Mortal Combat arcade game. The real drama comes in the crashes and thespin-offs though- as long as no one is too badly hurt, of course - and there are many over the course of this race. Only nine of the original 25 drivers finish, and Christian Fittipaldi's car bursts into flames during a pit stop directlyopposite the grandstand. Canadian Paul "Goin' to the wall" Tracy takes the chequered flag, and we take the freeway back to LA . . . and get stuck in traffic. Celebrity spots: George Lucas. Price of a taco: $1.60 Price of a beer: $5 Where: Long Beach Grand Prix, April 14-16. www.longbeachgp.com Ticket prices: $45 for three days, $35 for one day. Box office tel: (562) 436-9953 Sports fans on tour June 4 Motor Racing: Monaco, Monte Carlo Grand Prix. Page & Moy (0116 250 7007) offers from three-night packages by coach, inc B&B and race tickets, for £269pp, one-day flight deals for £349pp to 10-night packages for £5,500. June 15-22 Rugby: England tour of South Africa. Gullivers Sports Travel (01684 293175) offers a package from June 15-22 taking in the matches at Pretoria and Cape Town for £1,119 based on sharing a twin room. July 1-23 Cycling: Tour de France. Graham Baxter Tours (0113 2843617) offers 12 different packages, ranging from a weekend to two weeks following the tour on cycles, and with prices from £159pp to £699pp respectively. August Football: The Italian and Spanish leagues kick off in the last week of August. Fanfare Events (0161-437 0002) offer tailor-made packages taking in a major game. Two-night packages typically cost from £325pp, inc flights, hotel B&B and match tickets. September Olympic Games: Sydney. September 15-October 1. Sportsworld (01235 550904) is the official ticket and tour operator for the UK. Tours start at £1,895pp for six nights' motel accommodation, inc flights excl tickets. Tickets available from £10 for the baseball or hockey, up to £600 for the closing ceremony. Availability is becoming limited. Details of the paralympics October 18-October 28 are also available from Sportsworld. October Horse racing: Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, Hippodrome de Longchamps, Paris, Sunday October 1. One-day trips start at £159pp, weekends at £229pp from Horse Racing Abroad (01444 441661), which also offerstrips to other major race meetings. November-December Cricket: England tour of Pakistan and Sri Lanka. Pakistan Tests: Lahore (Nov 15-19), Faisalabad (Nov 22-Dec 3), Karachi (Dec 7-Dec 11); Sri Lanka Tests: Galle (Feb 22-26), Kandy (March 7-11), Colombo (March 15-19). Jon Snow Sports Travel (01293 440440) is offering packages to the Test matches but had not finalised prices or details at the time of going to press. If you call, they will take your details and send final itineraries. Places to eat Breakfast 1 The Original Pantry 877 S Figueroa St. Breakfast of champions 24-hours-a-day for around $5 in vintage American diner. Lunch 2 Sky Box Staples Center Affordable and filling before the game, though steer clear of the parmesan-coated fries: 1/2 lb burger $7.95, All-Madden Team Chop $14.95, Goin' Deep Cappuccino Pie $12 Dinner 3 Ca' del Sol 4100 Cahuenga Boulevard. Nice courtyard; usual Italian suspects of risotto, pasta, veal etc and a good selection of Californian wine. Dinner with wine around $35 a head. 4 Tammy Tang's 7313 Melrose Avenue Typical Thai menu - red curries, soft shell crab etc, and good vegetarian choice. Meal plus wine around $25-£30 a head. (Lunch $20 a head plus drink.) Places to drink 1 Sky Box - The Sport's Fans Bar & Grill Staples Center. See Shaquille O'Neal's framed size 21 sneakers and grab another ball game on one of the many giant screens over a $6 beer. 2 Grand Avenue Sports Bar Regal Biltmore Hotel, 506 South Grand Avenue. Good for sports buffs with its 11 satellite feeds, but also worth a wander around afterwards for its restored 20s elegance. Birthplace of the Oscar statue, host of numerous Academy Awards, and scene of countless movies, this is where west coast society came to be seen. $4.50-$6 for a brandy. 3 Top of Five Westin Bonaventure Hotel, 404 Figueroa St. Ride outside in a glass elevator to the top of this revolving bar for a panoramic view of the city. $6.50 for a Cosmopolitan cocktail (see recipe below). 4 Ye Olde King's Head 116 Santa Monica Boulevard. Novelty value only to see the Californian take on the English boozer, though it's the best place around to watch European soccer.

webTitle: I lost my heart in... Barbados

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... Barbados
fields.standfirst: Hunter Davies
fields.trailText: Hunter Davies
fields.body:
Why: Barbados was the first West Indian island I visited. This was on January 7, 1986, my 50th birthday. For the first 18 years of my life, I'd woken up on my birthday to a freezing cold bedroom on a council estate in Carlisle. I promised myself that if and when I got to 50, I'd wake up to palm trees, white sand and warm sea.

We went on Concorde and booked into Cobblers Cove. I ran straight into the sea on arrival - and ran straight out again, screaming in agony. I'd stepped on a sea urchin.

I started exploring that wonderful West Coast beach, walking the coves, swimming in that silken sea, and I found four words coming into my head: The Med is dead - I tend to think in headlines. We have been back to the West Indies every January since to the same hotel, my favourite on the planet; quiet, luxurious, but ever so relaxed.

What's the best thing: I love the people in Barbados, the landscape, the climate. My perfect day - well, three perfect days - is walking that West Coast beach, stopping, swimming and having drinks, then getting the bus back. Next day, I take the bus to where I got to the day before. In three days, I've covered all 10 miles or so.

My advice: Barbados is perfect for first-timers to the Caribbean - then I'd recommend island hopping, perhaps to Bequia or Domenica.

How do I get there? Airtours (08701 577775) offers 14 nights' self-catering, departing Gatwick June 5, for £449pp inc tax. The Destination Group (020-7400 7045) offers seven days' self-catering in Homar Rentals apartments, travelling out on Tues and Thurs in June for £399pp inc tax - both offers based on two people sharing. BA offers flight-only out of Gatwick from £339pp (before June 22).

 A Walk Around the West Indies, by Hunter Davies, is published by Weidenfeld and Nicolson at £18.99.

fields.headline: Spears of destiny
fields.standfirst: Chris Arnot visits the one place in England to take full advantage the asparagus season
fields.trailText: Chris Arnot visits the one place in England to take full advantage the asparagus season
fields.body:
In the Vale of Evesham right now, the roadsides are frothing with cow parsley. Outside the pubs and hotels, meanwhile, are blackboards advertising locally-grown asparagus.

Sparrow-grass, as it's known in these parts, has become largely a local speciality - very different from the days just after the second world war when tons of the delicately-flavoured shoots would be despatched by train to London. Cheaper imports have taken their toll.

"People want to eat sparrow-grass and strawberries at Christmas these days," I was told by one disgruntled grower with a weatherbeaten face the colour of red clay. "But they don't taste of nothing." The 240 acres of the Vale once devoted to the commercial production of asparagus has dwindled dramatically. Luckily for visitors, though, there are still enough under cultivation to meet demand during the comparatively short English season.

A week tomorrow, carefully-tethered bundles will be piled high on a long trestle table in the yard of the Fleece Inn, Bretforton, as the annual asparagus auction gets under way. Proceeds will go to the village band. There's another auction on the next Sunday (June 4) on behalf of the local church fund. The auction usually finds the chef from the prestigious Lygon Arms at Broadway rubbing shoulders with the landlord of the Round o' Gras' and various market traders from Birmingham.

Owned by the National Trust, the 15th-century Fleece Inn is one of an endangered species in rural England - an unspoilt village local. Enthusiastic visitors tuck into gammon and asparagus in flagstoned side rooms while regulars stand at the bar, supping Piddle in the Wind, an ale brewed across the Vale at Wyre Piddle.

It would be nice to report that the Round o' Gras' at nearby Badsey was equally unspoilt. After all, it is the best-known asparagus pub of all, as its name suggests.

Unfortunately, the interior has been the victim of rather too many refurbishments, to the point where the decor has become vaguely reminiscent of a Beefeater Steakhouse. All rather different from the pub's heyday under Buster Mustow, the bewhiskered and florid-faced former landlord who built up the trade here from the mid-1960s. At a time when exclusive restaurants were offering small bundles of asparagus at big prices, he offered what he called "proper country portions". Word spread. Between 1967 and his retirement in 1987, Buster shifted 20 tons of sparrow-grass in as many years.

"In Buster's time, about 70% of the village earned their livings through the market gardens," local blacksmith Dave Caswell told me. Now 60, Dave has been making asparagus-cutting knives here for 45 years.

Dave led the way out of the back of the forge, past a pile of rusting horse shoes into a surprisingly long garden. At the bottom was a sizeable patch devoted entirely to sparrow-grass. The blacksmith made a swift incision into a ridge, sliced through the root and extracted a perfect specimen - purple at the tip, white at the stem. "You should boil asparagus with a sprig of mint and serve it with melted butter or a bit of gammon fat," he said, salivating at the thought.

Bearing this in mind, I set off back towards the M5. But you shouldn't leave the Vale without calling in at Pershore, a country town with a fine medieval abbey, elegant Georgian streets, expansive water meadows and ancient footbridges over the River Avon. Rumour has it that this is the real-life Borchester in The Archers, though don't bother trying to find the equivalent of Underwood's department store or the sink estate to which the Grundys have been banished since their eviction from Ambridge.

Pershore is famous throughout the Midlands for the quality of its plums. Every year it stages a festival dedicated to the fruit in one of the main streets.

Being in the Vale of Evesham makes you conscious that fruit and veg was once a seasonal business in England.

For now, the product demanding attention is asparagus. Tuck in and enjoy while you can.

Asparagus recipe

Steam or boil the aspargus while at the same time frying one or two eggs per person in a generous mixture of olive oil and butter. When the egg yolks are still soft, take them out of the frying pan and, when the asparagus is cooked, frizzle them in the oil and butter. Serve with the oil and butter poured over. Shave parmesan over the top and serve with chunky bread.

The practicals

Asparagus auctions are held outside the Fleece at Bretforton (01386 831 173) on May 28 and June 4, starting 6.30pm. The Pershore Plum Festival is on August 28. The Angel Inn and Posting House (01386 552 046) in Pershore offers two-night weekend breaks for £100 for two people, B&B. For other hotels and B&BS, contact the Heart of England Tourism Board (01905 763 463) or the Wychaven District Council tourism office (01386 565 373).

fields.headline: Travelogue
fields.trailText: Lone rangers | Easy riders | Lure of the liner
fields.body:
Lone rangers
A new guide to help lone parents and their children go on holiday has been published by the National Council for One Parent Families. Holiday 2000 lists groups that organise specialist holidays and gives ideas for affordable holidays, where to look and what to watch out for.

There are sections on insurance, taking the kids out of school and how to make a complaint if something goes wrong. House swaps, farm holidays and day trips are also covered. There is an index of organisations that can help.

The guide is free to lone parents who call 0800 0185026.

Easy riders
The Millennium Festival of Cycling, coordinated by the Cyclists' Touring Club, is running from June 17 -25. The festival includes a variety of cycle rides throughout the UK, including Bike to Work day, an MPs' bike ride and hundreds of local events. The week coincides with the opening of the first 5,000 miles of the National Cycle Network. Details on www.cyclingfestival.org.uk or 09068 995577 (premium rate).

Lure of the liner
Over 800,000 UK residents took a cruise last year, more than four times the number at the start of the 90s. The most popular destinations were the Mediterranean (279,000), the Caribbean (143,000), short cruises from Cyprus to Israel and Egypt (91,000) and the Atlantic Islands (67,000). Alaska drew 15,000.

A quarter of all cruise passengers were aged between 45 and 54, but it is the baby boomers generation that has shown the biggest increase in cruise holidays in the past five years. The average age of people taking cruises is now 54, down from 59 10 years ago.

Long-haul hike
Leisure travellers have benefited from the deregulation of the European airline industry, but long-haul business fares have continued to rise, according to a study carried out by American Express. Premium fares from Europe to North America have risen by more than 40%. Holiday fares have gone down by between 6% and 9% while business fares in Europe are up by an average 25%.

Ulster rising
For the first time, the annual number of British visitors to Northern Ireland has topped one million. This figure, for last year, is a 20% increase on the 1998 total, according to the Northern Ireland Tourist Board. The Republic of Ireland has also experienced growth, with 384,000 visitors recorded in 1999, an increase of 7% over 1998.

fields.headline: Gough leaves Zimbabwe in tatters
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 83 and 39 for 5
England 415
fields.trailText: It's been another excellent day for England in the first Test against Zimbabwe at Lord's. First they totalled 415 in reply to Zimbabwe's 83, with Graeme Hick (101) and Alec Stewart (124*) hitting centuries. Then Zimbabwe lost five wickets for 36 - four of them to Darren Gough - in the evening gloom and closed on 39 for 5, still 293 runs in arrears. Only the weather can save them now.

First they totalled 415 in reply to Zimbabwe's 83, with Graeme Hick (101) and Alec Stewart (124*) hitting centuries. Play resumed this morning under sunny skies and with England all smiles on 175 for 3. Runs were hard to come by against the tight off-stump line of Heath Streak, but Hick and Stewart found life easier when the other bowlers were on, and brought up the 100 partnership with few alarms.

Hick was in particularly destructive form, and moved to 99 with two lazy, easy lofts over midwicket for four off Pommie Mbangwa. He was then made to wait 20 minutes for his century by another searching spell from Streak, but got to his sixth Test ton with a push for two on the on-side. The celebrations were cut short, however, when Streak dismissed Hick next ball, lbw for 101 to make it 269 for 4.

After lunch Stewart, uneasy at first, began to open up, and creamed three fours in three balls - two through the covers, one past mid-on - against Streak as England raced past 300. He then followed Hick to a hundred, but almost ran out Nick Knight in the process as he scampered a quick two. It was Stewart's 13th Test century and his third at Lord's.

Knight had started slowly too, but was just threatening to cut loose (one back-foot cover-drive for four off Mbangwa was the shot of the day) when he slapped Guy Whittall straight to Neil Johnson at point for 44 to signal tea at 376 for 5. He and Stewart had added 107 for the fourth wicket.

But England made a hash of things after the interval as they went in search of quick runs. Andy Flintoff was caught at mid-off for 1 as he tried to lift Whittall into the pavilion (378 for 6), then Chris Schofield, on debut, chased a wide one three balls later and was snapped up at second slip by Johnson for 0 (378 for 7). Suddenly Whittall had taken three wickets in 12 balls.

Andy Caddick then tried to cut a ball from Streak that was too close to him and was caught behind for 13 (398 for 8), before Darren Gough, overexcited by a cover-drive of sheer perfection for four off Streak, tried to mow legspinner Bryan Murphy on the legside and got a top edge which was comfortably held by Alistair Campbell, running round from slip. With Gough out for 5, England were 407 for 9. Ed Giddins unleashed one glorious offside slash for four but gave Streak his sixth wicket of the innings as he slogged to midwicket for 7. England had lost their last six wickets for just 39, but with a first-innings lead of 332, it didn't really matter. Alec Stewart was left undefeated on 124, to take his Test record at Lord's to 1240 runs at 56.36.

Zimbabwe were left with an awkward 50 minutes to see out the day. But Gough had other ideas. Charging in from the pavilion end, he trapped Grant Flower lbw for 2 (2 for 1), with the final ball of the first over, had Trevor Gripper taken by Nick Knight at third slip for 5 to make it 7 for 2 (although replays suggested the ball might have bounced just before Knight caught it), and then pinned Alistair Campbell leg before for 4 to leave Zimbabwe tottering at 18 for 3. Then, after Andy Caddick had won the plumbest of leg before shouts against Murray Goodwin (out for 11 to make it 33 for 4), Gough picked up his third lbw victim, Andy Flower, and Zimbabwe were 36 for 5.

Nasser Hussain even claimed the extra half hour as England tried for an improbable three-day victory. Now when was an England captain last able to do that?

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: A gentler summit
fields.standfirst: When he's not risking his life on the world's toughest mountains,  Stephen Venables enjoys a stroll with his family up Solsbury Hill
fields.trailText: When he's not risking his life on the world's toughest mountains, Stephen Venables enjoys a stroll with his family up Solsbury Hill.
fields.body:
The world's great peaks and wildernesses are thousands of miles away. Just across the valley at the southern end of the Cotswolds is Little Solsbury Hill, a 500ft bulge whose most dramatic feature is an Iron Age fort. Which would you choose?

Stephen Venables often chooses the former, even after 20 years of mountaineering which include brushes with death and the loss of many friends. He's just crossed the glaciers of South Georgia and will climb the Matterhorn for a TV film in September.

But more often he chooses the latter, especially since his wife and two young sons can come with him. "You can feel intimidated by the harshness and sterility of the high mountains," he says. "This is the antithesis - a lush, green and gentle landscape, but with enough hills to make it interesting.

"I'm quite lazy about walking and impatient to get to the steep, exciting bits - walking is a means to an end, so I'm not a great walker with a capital W. Solsbury Hill is appealing because it's short and local, and it's a way of getting into the country very quickly."

He and his family leave their house in the Bath suburbs by bike or by car and head towards the flat-topped dome of Solsbury with its horizontal bands of fields, hedgerows and woodland. The walk starts beyond a new bypass at Bailbrook, where the river Avon is pushed westward by the barrier of hills.

They take a gap in the hedge, cross an ancient lane and slant across a steep field - sledging territory, if ever there's snow - to a stile: "It's magical once you cross it, because you suddenly enter a much wilder landscape and you can hardly hear the bypass," says Venables. "You feel very isolated in these thickets, even though you're just above Bath."

He likes it, especially in the autumn when the cold man's beard is tangled among the red and crimson of hips and haws, with sloes and blackberries adding a touch of brilliance. Next comes a low limestone escarpment and a final push to the summit and the concrete triangulation point: the two boys, aged seven and nine, usually want to stand on it.

"You emerge into clean air and the wind, and in the winter the clouds scud in from the Atlantic," says Venables. "The top is an extraordinary flat expanse, like a huge green table, and in the summer there are silvery thistles with magnificent purple flowerheads.

"It's great for flying kites and for running around, especially for children like ours who are growing up in a terraced house with a narrow garden. And you can see the complicated layout of Bath on its seven hills, with the Avon coming in from Bradford and making a sharp bend. "We normally run all the way down. Because there's a spring in a field where the cows graze, it's often like Passchendaele, so it involves slithering and falling over and getting completely coated with mud. So the way we do it, it's not a walk for people who want to stay clean."

The practicals For a free brochure and accomodation list for Bath, call 01225 477101. For mail order of leaflets on walking in and around the city, call 01225 477708. Also visit www.thisisbath.com. OS Landranger map (1 inch to 1 mile) 172, (Bristol, Bath), price £ 5.25. Explorer map (2 inches to 1 mile), 155 (Bristol, Bath) £5.50. Bath is the southern end of the Cotswald Way, the newest National Trail; guides include The Cotswald Way, by Mark Richards (Reardon Press, £3.95), and The Cotswald Way, by Anthony Burton (Aurum, £10.99).

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Day out for Thomas | Bath time | Stately car boot
fields.body:
Day out for Thomas
The official replica of Thomas the Tank Engine will preside over two days at Severn Valley Railway.

 Departs Kidderminster May 20/21, every half hour 9.15am - 4.30pm, last train back from Bridgnorth 5.50pm. £9/£7 OAP, £4.50 over-twos. Comberton Hill, Kidderminster (01299 403816). Further fun days: 0870 2412532.

Bath time
There's still room at the Bath International Music Festival - Opening Concert in the Assembly Rooms (11am today), the Organ spectacular in Bath Abbey (4.30pm tomorrow) and Zimbabwe's "Black Umfolosi" at The Forum (7.30pm Sun). The children's dance in Royal Victoria Park (2pm Sat) is free.

 (01225 463362), ends June 4.

Stately car boot
More than 100 Red Cross supporters will be bringing choice rural items to a car boot sale at Elton Hall in Cambridgeshire.

 Sun 10am-5pm. £3. Elton Hall, Elton, Nr Peterborough (01832 280468).

Games preview
A Science of Sport exhibition at Manchester's Museum of Science and Industry gives a taster of 2002's Commonwealth Games.

 Exhibition: 12.30pm-2pm Sat/Sun. Open daily 10am-5pm. £6.50/under 18s free. Liverpool Road, Castlefield, Manchester (0161-832 1830).

Kew jump
A ticket for the Kew Explorer, which makes 40-minute circuits of the Royal Gardens, allows you to hop on and off all day.

 Open daily 9.30am-4.30pm. £5/£2.50 (under 5s free). Richmond, Surrey (020-8332 5622).

Dingle Dell
Millennium Forest Festival Week in Scotland has created woodland events, such as a Wood Walk at Dalkeith Country Park.

 Begins tomorrow 10am. Dalkeith (0131-654 1666). Millennium Forest for Scotland Trust, 91 Mitchell Street, Glasgow (0141-229 5780).

Ahoy there!
At the pirate's party at Lydford Gorge in Devon, children can swing over a mini galleon, hunt for chocolate treasure and float model ships down the river.

 Open Sat/Sun 10am-5.50pm, £3.50/child reduction. The Stables, Lydford, Nr Okehampton, Devon (020-8315 1111).

Horsing around
Wiltshire's long-distance White Horse walking trail linking eight chalk horses can be tackled as seven separate one-day walks.

 White Horse Trail Pack (£6) from Wiltshire Walking and Cycling Hotline (01980 623255).

Artspace 2000
More than 50 artists exhibit their work in 18th-century Oxfordshire barns and gardens until June 4.

 Barn Galleries, Aston, Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire (01491 577786).

fields.headline: Hanging on in the Himalayas
fields.trailText: Climber Stephen Venables on his latest book, A Slender Thread: Escaping Disaster in the Himalayas.
fields.body:
Stephen Venables' worst moment as a climber came when a steel peg pinged out of the rock and he dropped backwards into the Himalayan night, bouncing nearly 300ft down the flank of Panch Chuli V until his three companions held him on the rope.

His latest book describes how he then summoned the courage to take off a mitten and examine his legs ("always useful for getting off mountains"). Under his right knee he found a lump of bone sticking out of a warm, sticky hole; his left ankle was broken less badly.

He waited in a tent for four days with a makeshift splint on his leg and infection setting in. Then, two courageous Indian helicopter pilots hooked one skid on to the snowfield, and Venables was plucked to safety.

Woven into his rescue story is an attempt to explain why the "oddballs and misfits" of the climbing world insist on going to remote places to swing around on pitons at 20,000ft.

You spend months dreaming about your latest expedition, and when you abandon your pregnant wife and get to the mountain, you spend most of the time wanting to get the hell out.

But then there are what climbers call the "moments", which seem to consist either of breathtaking beauty or cocking a snook at death. Venables describes, for example, the sudden rush of delight as the clouds clear to reveal the peak against a peach-coloured dawn.

He suggests that the dangers of mountaineering are perhaps just an extension, to a higher level, of the risks everyone faces from the moment of birth: "For all the richness of 'normal', everyday life, it is good sometimes to trespass high in the sky and live life with uncommon intensity, experiencing something that gets close to the sublime."

· A Slender Thread: Escaping Disaster in the Himalayas, by Stephen Venables, is published by Hutchinson at £17.99.

fields.headline: The A-Z of B&Bs
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor recommends caution when tracking down the best B&Bs on the net
fields.body:
Don't underestimate the importance of finding a good bed and breakfast establishment. Even the most uninspiring of hotels will maintain a polite distance, but at a B&B you may end up eating breakfast with the hosts, admiring their pets and being woken by their children.

Gleaning information in advance is vital, and skimming the tourist board brochure is not necessarily the best way to go about it.

Some sites set out to recommend the very best places to stay, others function more like a directory. In either case, star ratings and objective information may not be apparent, so ask yourself questions - such as, is the bathroom shared? - as you might query an estate agent's brochure.

LeisureHunt
B&B owners register with this international accommodation directory. A search for B&Bs around Tewkesbury returned plenty of results, but the information is minimal.

Bed & Breakfast
More than a thousand recommended British and French B&Bs are listed here. The authors have considerable experience of the trade and their own (somewhat obscure) set of symbols to rate the accommodation. Try www.bed-breakfast-france.com for more ideas.

Special places to stay
Leave plenty of time to explore this revamped site from Alastair Sawday. Listings include hotels and B&Bs across Ireland and several other countries as well as in-depth coverage of the UK and France. An enthralling guide.

KGP
KGP lists more than 650 B&Bs in buildings of special interest such as vicarages, houses with a literary association, and Georgian properties.

Go Ireland
Ireland's national tourist board has details of more than 4,500 B&Bs in both Eire and the North.

webTitle: Traders 'blame it on Boo' as markets fall

fields.headline: Traders 'blame it on Boo' as markets fall
fields.standfirst:
US trade gap and dot.com doubts play on traders' nerves

Boo
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A record US trade deficit and fears that Britain's internet bubble has finally burst sent share prices on both sides of the Atlantic plunging yesterday.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
A record US trade deficit and fears that Britain's internet bubble has finally burst sent share prices on both sides of the Atlantic plunging yesterday.

The prospect of higher borrowing costs and concerns that further dot.com casualties are likely to follow Thursday's high-profile collapse of Boo.com unnerved investors who raced to dump hi-tech stocks. "It seems that nobody has kept a head when all about are are losing theirs, and blaming it on Boo," one trader said.

Yesterday's sell-off wiped more than £42bn off the value of London shares and sent the FTSE 100 index tumbling 187 points, 3% of its value, to 6,045.4. The hi-tech sector was particularly hard hit, with the Techmark index ending down 291 points, 8.7%, at 3,052.

In New York, traders were unnerved by news that the gap between US exports and imports widened to a record $30.2bn (£20.3bn) in March as a record foreign oil bill overwhelmed a rebound in exports of farm products and motor vehicles. Analysts said the ballooning trade deficit was a sign that the Federal Reserve has not done enough to cool the red-hot US economy.

Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, said the market was finally waking up to the impact of higher inflation. "I think the market is in denial over the full implications of what the Fed is up to." He expects the Fed to raise rates to 7% by the end of the summer because of continued signs of an overheating economy.

At lunchtime in New York, the Dow Jones industrial average was down more than 140 points to 10,635 while the Nasdaq composite index had fallen more than 120 points, almost 3%, to 3,410.

Cisco, the networking group, was particularly hard hit with a 5% decline to just under $53. In the past six weeks the company has erased the 50% run-up in its stock market value made this year. Its decline prompted speculation on some websites yesterday that John Chambers, the company's chief executive, was about to step down - a rumour vehemently denied by the company.

The decline also knocked Cisco from its slot as the world's most highly valued technology company. Intel, the semiconductor maker, was worth about $38bn more than Cisco by lunchtime.

European stock markets were caught up in the hi-tech sell-off. In Germany the Neuer Markt closed at 6,489.72, down 307.78 points, a fall of 4.5%, while in Paris the Nouveau Marché closed down 284.94 points, 6.1%, at 4,275.23.

Internet startups which have yet to make money are particularly vulnerable to interest rate worries because analysts downgrade their estimates of the current value of future earnings streams.

Among the hardest hit was the IT services sector where the market is worried that consolidation is slowing. Commenting on the sector, Nomura analyst Sean Maher said: "It seems we've gone from mindless euphoria to angst and despair."

Nomura yesterday downgraded the whole of the IT services sector on valuation grounds, saying that no company seemed to be taking a clear lead by restructuring.

Simon Strong, technology analyst at West LB Panmure, said: "Sentiments are getting worse and technology stocks are in danger of being oversold."

The decline also knocked Cisco from its slot as the world's most highly valued technology company. Intel, the semiconductor maker, was worth about $38bn more than Cisco by lunchtime. European stock markets were caught up in the hi-tech sell-off. In Germany the Neuer Markt closed at 6,489.72, down 307.78 points, a fall of 4.5%, while in Paris the Nouveau Marché closed down 284.94 points, 6.1%, at 4,275.23. Internet startups which have yet to make money are particularly vulnerable to interest rate worries because analysts downgrade their estimates of the current value of future earnings streams. Among the hardest hit was the IT services sector where the market is worried that consolidation is slowing. Commenting on the sector, Nomura analyst Sean Maher said: "It seems we've gone from mindless euphoria to angst and despair." Nomura yesterday downgraded the whole of the IT services sector on valuation grounds, saying that no company seemed to be taking a clear lead by restructuring. Simon Strong, technology analyst at West LB Panmure, said: "Sentiments are getting worse and technology stocks are in danger of being oversold."

fields.headline: Gray arias
fields.standfirst: Alasdair Gray's The Book of Prefaces does exactly what it says on the cover
fields.trailText: Alasdair Gray's The Book of Prefaces does exactly what it says on the cover
fields.body:
The Book of Prefaces
Alasdair Gray
Bloomsbury, £35, 640pp,

You could probably read every book review in this week's papers and never be made aware that what you are reading about are books. Tree flakes. Not disembodied voices, not wise sayings, not people, not ideas, not issues, or themes, not emotions. Books are things: inert, fungible, and violable.

We should therefore judge them by their covers. We should judge them also by the width of their margins, by the quality of their illustrations, by their publisher's logos and blurbs, and by the quality of their binding and typefaces. And most of them will of course be found wanting.

Most books, like most things, are horribly ugly, and most writers seem not to care. There are of course exceptions - Joyce had Ulysses published in "Greek blue", Nabokov designed his own covers - but most writers seem happy to allow anyone with a rudimentary grasp of some crude desk-top publishing program to do with their words what they will. This may be because they do not believe in their books as books.

Alasdair Gray believes in books, and he writes books that defy every bogus standard established by contemporary Western publishing. He began his magnum opus, Lanark, when he was 18, and it took him more than 25 years to complete. This is unusual. He illustrates his own books. Equally unusual. He also mocks and belittles them. Almost unheard-of.

His plots, like his career, defy logic and expectation. Lanark, for example, begins with Book Three and then progresses to its Prologue, before regressing to Book One. In his follow-ups he has dabbled with crude sexual fantasy and pornography (1982 Janine, The Fall of Kelvin Walker, Something Leather), historical fiction (Poor Things), and short stories (Ten Tales Tall and True, Unlikely Stories, Mostly). He has plundered all the great and obvious sources, from the Odyssey to Moby-Dick to Frankenstein and Kafka, he uses footnotes and marginal notes, and is prone to old-fashioned reader-romancing and twinkliness (his last page always contains a quirky illustrated "Goodbye!").

Like all his other books, The Book of Prefaces is distinguished from the ordinary. It has almost nothing in common with any book written by any living author. Its affiliations are with the tradition of the commonplace book, with the 18th-century dictionary makers, with the Victorian encyclopaedists, with the Everymans, the Observers, and with H G Wells's The Outline of History. It is egalitarian in ambition and aristocratic in execution. It should be bought and fondled by anyone who is tired of of the tasteless swill, the cheap hype, the hustling, the glad-handing, the chit-chat, the back-scratching, second-guessing groupthink that sometimes goes by the name of Contemporary British Literature.

The Book of Prefaces is perverse. It is exactly what its title claims: a book of prefaces, proceeding chronologically from Caedmon's poem on the Book of Genesis (c.675) to Wilfred Owen's scrawled introductions to his own Poems (1920). Unconsidered trifles include John Clare's unstopped intro to "The Parish" (1827) - "THIS POEM was begun & finished under the pressure of heavy distress with embittered feelings under a state of anxiety and oppression almost amounting to slavery". In addition, there are prefaces to these prefaces, glosses and introductions, and not all of them written by Gray (the book makes strange bedfellows, among others, of James Kelman and Roger Scruton).

What, one wonders, could be more foolish than compiling an anthology of such a kind? Unless, of course, one were to be of the opinion that reading might be a variation of writing. Or that it were important to answer the kind of questions which Gray believes his prefaces might assist us to answer: "Who am I? How did I come here? What should I do? Where am I going?" Or unless one can agree with Gray's characteristically fierce and righteous conclusion: "I consider this anthology a memorial to the kind of education British governments now think useless, especially for British working-class children. But it has been my education, so I am bound to believe it one of the best in the world." The Book of Prefaces is completely useless, like anything worthwhile. It's only a book; above all, it's a book.

fields.headline: Saddington Fair
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: My mother rang me this morning and asked if I would give her driving lessons. I laughed for quite a long time
fields.body:
Saturday, May 6, Ashby-de-la-Zouch, Leicestershire

My mother rang me this morning and asked if I would give her driving lessons. I laughed for quite a long time. Eventually, she said, "Yes or no?" I said, "It would be disastrous, you can't even tell left from right." I asked her if she had requested that her new husband teach her. She said, "Ivan reckons that there are enough cars on the road already." I advised her to use public transport. She said that there was no public transport to the crme de la crme of boot-fairs at Saddington in the middle of the Leicestershire countryside.

"Why won't Ivan take you to Saddington?" I asked.

"Ivan gets nervous seeing so many cash transactions taking place between untrained amateurs," she said.

Ivan used to be the chief accountant at a dairy until the cold winds of change knocked the milk bottles off the steps of time and replaced them with the cardboard carton in the supermarket chill cabinet.

My mother was still blathering on: "The last time we went to a boot-fair, Ivan completely ruined my pleasure by moaning about the lack of regulations. He said that both the buyers and the sellers were anarchists, and should be made to pay tax and VAT. He has even asked Pandora to bring in an act of parliament: The Boot Fair Regulation Act.

When she mentioned that there were Abba LPs and memorabilia for sale, I offered to take her one Sunday.

Monday, May 8

My father continues to deteriorate in hospital. He has now contracted a virus (the one caused by privatised cleaning) and is in an isolation ward. His new wife, Tania, is in almost permanent attendance. She is taking advantage of his weakened state to read Great Literature at him. She is currently halfway through Moby Dick. When she went out to go to the toilet, I asked my father how he was enjoying Melville's extraordinary allegorical seafaring tales. "I am not enjoying it," he whined " I don't like fishing."

I noticed that Tania had placed a copy of Silas Marner: The Weaver Of Raveloe on the bedside trolley. It was obviously to be the next literary read-aloud treat. I wondered if I should mention to her that my father has a violent antipathy to books, films and TV dramas about children. (Something had once happened to him in a cinema during the showing of a Shirley Temple film - I don't know what but a gabardine mac was involved).

Tania would be on firmer ground if she stuck to Raymond Chandler or the earlier Dick Francis.

Friday, May 12

Pamela Pigg called round to say that she's found me a small town house overlooking a canal basin in Leicester. The present occupant, a Mrs Wormington, is an OAP. She is in hospital, but is nil by mouth, so Pamela reckons I can probably move in in a couple of weeks. I said, "Is she nil by mouth so as to free up the country's housing stock?"

Pamela said, "She is occupying a three-bedroom house and she is 97-years-old."

I said, "Pamela, I don't want Mrs Wormington killed so that I can enjoy watching the narrow boats pass by my living-room window." I asked which hospital Mrs Wormington was in. She told me that it was the same one as my father, Pankhurst Ward - which was sort of appropriate. Though Mrs Pankhurst chose to be nil by mouth.

Sunday, May 14

Mrs Wormington is nil by mouth because she has had a stroke and can't swallow properly. She has no family or friends: "They've all died off, lad," she told me. I used a cotton bud dipped in water to moisten her mouth. "I don't like to bother the nurses," she croaked.

Are pensioners to be my albatross? I can already feel her liver-spotted hand around my neck.

fields.headline: Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea
fields.trailText:
Aston Villa: James, Delaney, Ehiogu, Southgate, Barry, Wright, Boateng, Merson, Taylor, Carbone, Dublin.
Substitutes: Joachim, Hendrie, Stone, Samuel, Enckelman.
fields.body:
Aston Villa: James, Delaney, Ehiogu, Southgate, Barry, Wright, Boateng, Merson, Taylor, Carbone, Dublin.
Substitutes: Joachim, Hendrie, Stone, Samuel, Enckelman.

Chelsea: de Goey, Melchiot, Desailly, Leboeuf, Babayaro, Poyet, Wise, Deschamps, Di Matteo, Zola, Weah.
Substitutes: Flo, Morris, Cudicini, Terry, Harley.

Referee: G Poll (Tring)

No Flo for Chelsea as Weah gets the nod after his exertions on the train ground this week. Carbone and Merson will look to provide the creative vibe for a Villa side that may edge this final due to the intense pressure on their opponents. Will this be the dream final for Dublin, who broke his neck in December?

1 min A sunny Wembley hosts the season's showpiece finale - these two teams should provide a good spectacle.
3 Early exchanges in midfield results in Villa possession as Carbone's guile overcomes Wise's industry.
7 Chelsea are getting hold of the ball more as Deschamps starts to win more tackles in midfield. A smooth move down the right from Zola produces a cross that is cleared as far as Wise on the right of the area. His first-time volley is well hit but straight at James.
12 First real test for de Goey as Wright hooks in a cross from the left. He comes and claims in confident fashion - it's going to take something special to get the better of him today.
15 Barry cuts off the rampant Melchiot in his prime, just as the Chelsea right wing back was accelerating onto a loose ball. The first booking of the match goes to the Villa man.
18 Melchiot returns the favour by barging Barry to the ground after a sloppy defensive header. The Chelsea defender is booked. The set piece is cleared by Babayaro for a corner.
20 Nothing comes from the centre, and Babayaro can take his time over clearing upfield. Merson needs more time on the ball to create things for Villa, as the Birmingham side look a little short of attacking ideas at the moment.
24 Villa are pressing forward as Chelsea are having trouble getting their collective foot on the ball. No Chelsea attack for five minutes now. Carbone has been notable in his absence thus far.
26 Leboeuf clears a Wright centre with a strong header out, but Merson, from fully 25 yards, drives a looping, curling effort just wide of the top corner. Referee Poll has spotted an earlier infringement by Wise on Boateng. The Chelsea skipper becomes the third name in the book.
28 James almost hands Chelsea a goal on a plate as he comes for a regular centre from the right, he jumps majestically and spills the catch pathetically. Luckily for Villa no Chelsea man foresaw the keeper's clumsiness and James was able to scramble and gather the ball, albeit with a sheepish look on his face.
31 Poyet hassles Ehiogu into conceding a corner from the left.
32 Gus Poyet is wearing Ian Taylor like a shirt. The cross is to the near post and James gathers well.
35 Not much to choose from the two teams thus far. A lot of effort and endeavour, but little quality. Looks like the match may be settled by the one goal. Again, another Chelsea attack breaks down in front of a resolute Villa defence.
37 Carbone loses the ball in the left midfield and goes bonkers at referee Poll for not giving the free kick. The challenge was very physical, but probably just this side of fair.
39 A free kick in a central position 35 yards out for Chelsea. Zola flicks the ball over a static Villa defense, aiming for Poyet, but Ian Taylor does enough to ensure that the Uruguayan makes no contact.
40 An error by Boateng almost lets in Weah. The Liberian is forced wide left, and then his cross is not what one would expect from a former World Player of the Year. Weah, like many players on both sides, is yet to rise to this occasion.
42 Wright, Carbone and Merson combine well on the left. Only a poor pass from Wright to Merson allows the move to break down and lets Chelsea regain possession. Merson looks furious with Wright.
44 A Zola free kick from the right causes some consternation in the Villa area. The unflappable Barry is able to deal with the joint threat of Weah and Desailly to head clear.
45 Leboeuf, timing his challenge on Dublin poorly, is paid back by Dion with a shove on the back of the head that leaves him, curiously, writhing on the floor clutching his buttocks. A quick wipe of the magic sponge later and the French defender is restored to health.
46 A quiet and dull first half comes to an end. The ref's whistle gets the loudest cheer of the day so far. No real chances, no real incident. Just like all the other recent Cup Finals then.

45 Right then - let's hope that Messrs. Vialli and Gregory have told their teams to shelve the tripe and start serving up football caviar for 300 million people watching this garbage worldwide. No changes on either side for the start of the second half.
47 Chelsea give up possession in their won half and are almost punished for it. Wright picks up the ball on the left and swings in a pacy cross that Taylor meets with a firm header. His effort flashes in front of de Goey and goes out of play. Goal kick. A sloppy start by the London side.
49 Merson's industry wins a corner on the left. The deep centre is met by Southgate at the far post. He connects well with the header but the effort sails over the Chelsea crossbar. Again, Chelsea's marking looked slack.
50 Zola on the centre right, flicks a ball through to Weah, who looks up and sees James stuck in no-man's land. His shot beats James but edges just wide of the Villa keeper's right-hand upright. Chelsea's best chance so far.
52 Poyet rants and raves at the referee long enough to earn a booking. The set piece, from the right, is overhit and de Goey collects with ease at the far post. This half is looking up though.
55 Di Matteo looks like he's running through custard with flippers on. How can a pro be so slow? From a through on the left, Poyet shoots at James, who spills the drive at the feet of Wise, who slots the ball home. Cue crazy celebrations - but no-one's noticed the linesman, who has his flag up. Eventually Wise stops cartwheeling around long enough to embark on a lengthy spell of swearing. After all that it's still nil-nil and James is the luckiest keeper on the planet.
57 Corner to Villa on the right. It's a case of too many legs spoil the clearance, as the ball gets stuck in the area. Eventually Leboeuf hoofs the ball upfield, but Boateng collects and just as he is about to unwind a netbuster, Wise slides in with a last-ditch blockage that takes man and ball at the same time.
61 All of Chelsea holds its collective hands on its collective head as Weah glides in to the far post to connect with a Poyet centre. All the cliches in the world don't do justice to a miss where it was harder to do what the Liberian did (slice the ball into Row Q) than to bury the ball in the goal. Maybe this just isn't Chelsea's day.
64 A clever flick from Zola releases Weah. James senses the danger early and is all over Weah like a fat kid on a burger. Chelsea are beginning to turn the screw, but are the Fates against them on this day of days?
66 Balding ex-England winger Steve Stone is warming up, so one of the Villa playmakers may have to make way. If Gregory substitutes Beni during the Cup Final he'll throw a wobbly that the guys on Mir could see.
70 A Villa free kick seeks out Southgate at the far post. He heads the ball back to Dublin, but the Villa striker cannot generate any power or direction into his header and de Goey can watch the ball sail out of play.
72 A nice Cruyff turn by Melchiot on the left foxes Delaney, who responds with a foul.
73 GOAL! Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea Zola's free kick is whipped into the area. James comes, gathers and spills at the feet of Roberto di Matteo, who simply swings his leg and starts celebrating. Unsurprisingly, Southgate et al look really deflated.
75 Beni Carbone almost finds the perfect reply to Chelsea's goal. Leboeuf clears off his own line next to the post with de Goey well beaten.
78 Villa substitution: Stone for Taylor; Carbone for Joachim. Gregory brings on the cavalry, but it seems too little too late.
81 Villa are still game, chasing every ball, but Chelsea have talent in reserve and are content to hold the ball and sit back. Villa seem to have the vigour but not the verve to wrestle control of this game from Chelsea's hands.
84 Villa try and regain the initiative with a free kick. The ball in is aimed at Dublin, but Leboeuf is able to clear. Villa seem short of ideas.
88 Villa substitution: Hendrie for Wright.
89 Chelsea substitution: Flo for Weah.
90 Three extra minutes for Villa to make a change to the scoreline.
92 Gareth Barry tries, tries and tries again from the left to deliver a cross. Eventually his centre is successful and finds Ehiogu unmarked at the far post. His header is poorly directed and loops over the crossbar.
93 Chelsea substitution: Morris for Zola. There's an Englishman on the pitch... they think it's all over...
94 Full time: Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea. Chelsea win the FA Cup and qualify for the UEFA Cup for season 2000 - 2001.
