The set piece, from the right, is overhit and de Goey collects with ease at the far post. This half is looking up though. 55 Di Matteo looks like he's running through custard with flippers on. How can a pro be so slow? From a through on the left, Poyet shoots at James, who spills the drive at the feet of Wise, who slots the ball home. Cue crazy celebrations - but no-one's noticed the linesman, who has his flag up. Eventually Wise stops cartwheeling around long enough to embark on a lengthy spell of swearing. After all that it's still nil-nil and James is the luckiest keeper on the planet. 57 Corner to Villa on the right. It's a case of too many legs spoil the clearance, as the ball gets stuck in the area. Eventually Leboeuf hoofs the ball upfield, but Boateng collects and just as he is about to unwind a netbuster, Wise slides in with a last-ditch blockage that takes man and ball at the same time. 61 All of Chelsea holds its collective hands on its collective head as Weah glides in to the far post to connect with a Poyet centre. All the cliches in the world don't do justice to a miss where it was harder to do what the Liberian did (slice the ball into Row Q) than to bury the ball in the goal. Maybe this just isn't Chelsea's day. 64 A clever flick from Zola releases Weah. James senses the danger early and is all over Weah like a fat kid on a burger. Chelsea are beginning to turn the screw, but are the Fates against them on this day of days? 66 Balding ex-England winger Steve Stone is warming up, so one of the Villa playmakers may have to make way. If Gregory substitutes Beni during the Cup Final he'll throw a wobbly that the guys on Mir could see. 70 A Villa free kick seeks out Southgate at the far post. He heads the ball back to Dublin, but the Villa striker cannot generate any power or direction into his header and de Goey can watch the ball sail out of play. 72 A nice Cruyff turn by Melchiot on the left foxes Delaney, who responds with a foul. 73 GOAL! Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea Zola's free kick is whipped into the area. James comes, gathers and spills at the feet of Roberto di Matteo, who simply swings his leg and starts celebrating. Unsurprisingly, Southgate et al look really deflated. 75 Beni Carbone almost finds the perfect reply to Chelsea's goal. Leboeuf clears off his own line next to the post with de Goey well beaten. 78 Villa substitution: Stone for Taylor; Carbone for Joachim. Gregory brings on the cavalry, but it seems too little too late. 81 Villa are still game, chasing every ball, but Chelsea have talent in reserve and are content to hold the ball and sit back. Villa seem to have the vigour but not the verve to wrestle control of this game from Chelsea's hands. 84 Villa try and regain the initiative with a free kick. The ball in is aimed at Dublin, but Leboeuf is able to clear. Villa seem short of ideas. 88 Villa substitution: Hendrie for Wright. 89 Chelsea substitution: Flo for Weah. 90 Three extra minutes for Villa to make a change to the scoreline. 92 Gareth Barry tries, tries and tries again from the left to deliver a cross. Eventually his centre is successful and finds Ehiogu unmarked at the far post. His header is poorly directed and loops over the crossbar. 93 Chelsea substitution: Morris for Zola. There's an Englishman on the pitch... they think it's all over... 94 Full time: Aston Villa 0 - 1 Chelsea. Chelsea win the FA Cup and qualify for the UEFA Cup for season 2000 - 2001.

fields.headline: Ewan, Alessandro Raho (1999)
fields.trailText: · View the 2001 version of the work online
fields.body:
· View the 2001 version of the work online

Artist: Alessandro Raho, born 1971, who makes consciously old-fashioned paintings in such traditional genres as the portrait and the landscape.

Subject: Ewan Gibbs, artist, one of Raho's closest friends since they were at Goldsmith's together, and a maker of intimate, emotionally compressed drawings.

Distinguishing features: This guy is fashion-conscious, urban. Everything about him is contemporary, the Fred Perry shirt, the slightly unshaven look, the haircut, the tear in his eye - the tear? The face we're looking at, a face we might meet in the street, is isolated in front of a white screen. The white is poppy and cool. Ewan is poppy and cool, except for the lump in his throat. At first you think he's supremely self-confident, but then you realise he's fight ing to control his feelings.

Raho believes this is his 16th portrait of Ewan Gibbs. They are both artists, both prominent on the London art scene, yet Raho denies that this is a painting of an artist, or an in-group piece of mututal promotion. Ewan is simply a friend, he says, and a sympathetic sitter. He always paints his friends. Ewan might be anyone of his age, his generation, his place. He could be Jamie Oliver. It has a sense of style, beauty, pleasure, a sense of the city. But it also has a quality of inwardness. Ewan seems to feel more than he says. He is framed by white space, is marked out as an individual, and while he's adept in the modern world, he's hurt by it too.

The portrait is such a ludicrously unfashionable and unmodern kind of art - the modernist critic Clement Greenberg sneered at it as a genre of "homeless representation" with no place in serious culture - that today it is revived by young artists as a kind of joke, a self-consciously effete exercise.

So today you get two kinds of portrait. There are ones painted by members of portrait societies with "royal" in their names. Then there are knowing ones by young artists such as Jason Brooks and Elizabeth Peyton, where you can't really look at the subject of the picture because it says so loudly, with such acute self-consciousness, "Look at me! I'm painting a portrait! Isn't that cute?"

This portrait succumbs to neither of these dead ends. It's chic pop art, but it is sincere chic pop art. It resembles a passport photograph or police mugshot - which both Duchamp and Warhol used in portraiture - with its brutal cropping and fixing of identity.

This painting has the pose of an official mugshot yet the opposite meaning. While a mugshot fixes who you are, this painting queries Ewan's identity. What appears to be defined is in fact uncertain what is Ewan feeling and thinking? What do we know about him from this painting? Far less than we imagine.

Did he like it? "It's weird because I've got to the point where I don't look at it as being myself," says Ewan Gibbs. "I look at it as a painting. It feels like it is a figure looking back at you it's as natural as a photograph without being photographic."

Where is it? Asprey Jacques, 4 Clifford Street, London W1 (020-7287 7675) until July 1.

fields.headline: How did you get on?
fields.trailText:
Mostly 'a's:

You'd dearly love to be a great team player, wouldn't you? Sadly, you're a sheep. The problem is that you're trying too hard to be liked, but contributing nothing. In a good team, everyone supports each other by building on individuals' ideas. You won't be valued or respected unless you make suggestions that move the team forward.
fields.body:
Mostly 'a's:

You'd dearly love to be a great team player, wouldn't you? Sadly, you're a sheep. The problem is that you're trying too hard to be liked, but contributing nothing. In a good team, everyone supports each other by building on individuals' ideas. You won't be valued or respected unless you make suggestions that move the team forward.

Mostly 'b's:

You may think people like you. In reality, they're scared of you. You're a gossip, untrustworthy and out for yourself. You say a lot, but contribute little. Grow up.

Mostly 'c's:

Congratulations! You're a great team player, an asset to any organisation. You're adaptable, try to get on with everyone, put the team's interests before your own and readily offer information that may help the team goals. You make sure everyone is contributing as much as they can. But remember - when time is tight, an issue is of low priority or requires a specialist's decision - working as a team may not always be the answer.

Mostly 'd's:

Mr Livingstone, I presume? Like the new mayor of London, you're happy to use a team when it suits you but you'll go out on a limb if things don't go your way. Face it, you're far too egotistical to ever be a good team player. You do, however, have a lot to offer: you're conscientious, have a sharp, creative mind and unconventional ideas. Do yourself - and your company - a favour... become self-employed.

 With thanks to Philip Wilson, senior occupational psychologist at the London Fire Service.

fields.headline: Sir Larry Lamb
fields.standfirst:
Newspaper editor who made the Sun shine and gave Britain the page three girl
Read the news report here
fields.trailText: Sir Larry Lamb, who has died aged 70, was a classic example of that tradition in which the editors of very popular newspapers are expected, even encouraged, to be very unpopular. He worked to that rule: he was overbearing, over-critical and, often, over the top.
fields.body:
Sir Larry Lamb, who has died aged 70, was a classic example of that tradition in which the editors of very popular newspapers are expected, even encouraged, to be very unpopular. He worked to that rule: he was overbearing, over-critical and, often, over the top.

As justification for his domineering style, he could point to his undoubted success. He was appointed editor of the Sun at the time of its rebirth under Rupert Murdoch in 1969, and was responsible for transforming what had been a declining paper, selling 650,000, into one that sold more than 4m in nine years.

In so doing, it became Britain's highest circulation daily, providing Lamb with especial pleasure by surpassing his former paper, the Daily Mirror. Indeed, his approach to running the Sun drew on his experiences as a sub-editor at the Daily Mirror, where the exercise of autocratic power by Hugh Cudlipp and Jack Nener - themselves influenced by the grumpy style of a famous former editor, HG Bartholomew - was considered synonymous with success.

That was not all that Lamb learned during his 10 years with the Mirror. Confident of his talents and frustrated at being overlooked for high office, he wanted to prove Cudlipp and his cohorts wrong.

Proving people wrong was the making and the breaking of Lamb. He was born Albert Lamb, in the Yorkshire mining village of Fitzwilliam, but thought he had been given the wrong name, and soon adopted "Larry", after a character in Toytown, on BBC Radio's Children's Hour. After leaving grammar school, he tried - but failed - to get a job as a journalist, and was forced to take a post in the town hall, where he became known as a left-wing trade unionist.

He eventually used a position on the Nalgo union paper to obtain a cub reporter's job on the weekly Brighouse Echo, swiftly moving on to daily papers in the north-east. One of his bosses at the Newcastle Journal, the late Norman Baitey (himself renowned for his wicked tongue), told me he knew Lamb would "make it" one day because he was the only sub-editor who ever challenged one of his headlines. "He told me it was wrong, and he would only send it to the printers if I ordered him," Baitey said.

Brief periods on the subs desks of the London Evening Standard and the Daily Mail followed before Lamb joined the Daily Mirror in 1958. So frustrated was he that he took the risk of becoming northern editor of the Daily Mail in Manchester in 1968, a job many regarded as a backwater for Fleet Street executives.

He gave me a chance there as a sub and I, too, suffered from his brutal teaching methods. All my colleagues were struck by his half-suppressed anger. His reputation brought him to Murdoch's attention when he bought the Sun. Both set out to prove the cynics wrong by stealing the Mirror's clothes - its anti-establishment irreverence - and many of its best journalists.

Lamb soon troubled the Mirror, reworking their formula with a fresh panache. Within six months, he more than doubled the Sun's circulation, with editorial content that was saucy rather than salty, reflecting the permissiveness of the early 70s. He serialised sex manuals and, eventually, introduced the nation to the page three girl.

Politically, Lamb kept the paper pro-Labour, at least until Murdoch's internal fights with the print unions, and Margaret Thatcher's accession to the Tory leadership, convinced him, and a significant proportion of the working class, to vote Conservative. For this, he was knighted in 1980 - within a year of the Tory election triumph.

I joined him at the Sun, but my own growing trade-union militancy coincided with his shift to the right. Although we fought, and I lacked any sympathy for his leadership methods, I never lost my respect for him as a newspaperman.

By the early 80s, his misplaced confidence that his success stemmed entirely from his own defiant character led him to think everyone else, even including Murdoch, was wrong. He was particularly upset at Murdoch not giving him the editorship of the Times. Circulation at the Sun began to slide when Lamb failed to respond properly to the Daily Star, another tabloid even further downmarket than his own. In 1981, Murdoch decided it was time for his once-prized asset to go.

Two years later, he gave Lamb a second chance by making him editor-in-chief of the Australian, but that lasted barely nine months. "Larry just couldn't help himself," a News Corporation executive told me. "He had megalomaniac tendencies and kept clashing with Rupert." By then, his authoritarian personality had clouded his once-sure journalistic touch and he failed to stem the decline of the Daily Express during his three years as editor (1983-86).

Sir Larry later tried to distance himself from Kelvin Mackenzie's bonk-busting Sun, even reflecting in his book, Sunrise (1989), that his introduction of page three might have been a mistake. Ironically, it may be his chief claim to fame, apart from a grateful line or two in Mrs Thatcher's eventual memoirs.

He is survived by his wife Joan, two sons and a daughter.

Albert 'Larry' Lamb, journalist, born July 15 1929; died May 18 2000

webTitle: Should the UN get out of Sierra Leone?

fields.headline: Should the UN get out of Sierra Leone?
fields.standfirst:
Yes: Christopher Clapham, professor of politics
No: Alex Ramsbotham, United Nations Association
fields.trailText:
Yes: Christopher Clapham, professor of politics

No: Alex Ramsbotham, United Nations Association
fields.body:
Dear Alex,
The Sierra Leone fiasco reinforces a lesson the UN should have learned years ago but is still shamefully reluctant to accept: if there isn't a peace, you can't keep it - and the attempt to keep non-existent peaces is not merely a waste of time, but carries a huge risk of exacerbating the very conflicts the peacekeepers were meant to help resolve.

There is a place for UN monitoring, where the parties to a conflict have reached a genuine settlement, backed by their dispositions on the ground, which the intervening force can help guarantee. Sierra Leone had no more than a bogus settlement, reminiscent of Angola in 1991-92, or worse, Rwanda in 1993-94: paper agreements between bitterly hostile adversaries. UN peacekeepers were sent in, though neither side had disarmed, and one side had accepted the agreement mostly to gain a breathing space in which to strengthen its position.

Providing such a space only makes things worse. In Rwanda, the Arusha accords gave hardliners in the government the opportunity to organise genocide. Sierra Leone is similar: the Lomé agreement of May 1999, into which the Kabbah government was pressured by the UN and others, ostensibly established a coalition between an ineffectual elected government and a ruthless armed opposition with a record of reneging on agreements. The peacekeepers sent in to police it were so poorly armed that hundreds could be rounded up as soon as the war resumed.

It is open to the UN to send real fighting forces into situations like Sierra Leone, to kill and be killed, if the states concerned allow it. That would be a very hazardous enterprise, and unlikely to lead to the reconstruction of Sierra Leone. But at least the UN would have some idea of what it was supposed to be doing. Peacekeeping as seen in recent conflicts is a farce fuelled by wishful thinking. We'd be better off without it.
Yours sincerely,
Christopher Clapham,

Professor of politics and international relations,
Lancaster University

Dear Christopher,
I acknowledge your reservations about fragile peace agreements: the Lomé agreement was seriously flawed. But the UK and US were primary influences in initiating Lomé; the UN was fully aware of its weaknesses. Traditional peace-keeping is often inapplicable to internal wars, but the UN has been trying to develop appropriate responses to such emergencies. It is the unwillingness of the more powerful UN member states, not least the five permanent members of the Security Council, to provide sufficient resources for an operation's effectiveness that is the problem.

Perhaps a lesson can be learned from East Timor last year, where the May agreement providing for a referendum to decide the province's future status was deeply flawed: the Indonesian authorities insisted upon guaranteeing security. It was inadequate UN involvement that allowed gross human rights abuses against the East Timorese people before, and especially after, the vote. Only then was the international community convinced to provide a proper input. No one can pretend that the referendum process was an unqualified success, nor that UN involvement has been smooth. But there at least appears to have been progress, which could not have occurred without the UN.

Peace processes are delicate, dynamic and risky. It is difficult to persuade the international community to prepare effective contingencies until it is too late. Meanwhile, people continue to live (or die) in misery while the international community prevaricates. The responsibility lies with UN member states, particularly those in the Security Council, to provide operations with sufficient resources to reduce the risks, including strengthening peace agreements in the first place.
Yours sincerely,
Alex Ramsbotham,
Head, UN and conflict unit,
United Nations Association-UK

Dear Alex,
I do not agree the failings of the UN can be separated from those of its member states, least of all the permanent members of the Security Council. The UN is an assembly of states; its strengths and weaknesses are reflected in those of its leading members. Their reluctance to provide resources for peacekeeping, most of all to risk troops, is a reality derived from bitter experience, notably that of the US in Somalia.

I do not believe that many conflicts can be resolved through external intervention. East Timor, like Namibia a decade earlier, was a crisis to which a clear, acceptable solution could be found, through the simple mechanism of independence validated by an internationally supervised election. Crises like those in Somalia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone or Congo are not like that. These are fundamentally internal wars which can only be resolved internally: either by one combatant securing supremacy, or through a compromise in which each party recognises a settlement.

Bodged settlements only delay, and often prevent, this resolution. Either the force brought in to monitor them packs up at the first sign of trouble, or it gets dragged into a long-term commitment in which its own role is compromised, and its costs escalate - not least in lives. The UN must acknowledge its limitations, and avoid getting dragged into conflicts it cannot resolve and in which its involvement can only damage its credibility and the welfare of those it is trying to help.
Yours sincerely,
Christopher

Dear Christopher,
I cannot agree that external intervention is inappropriate to internal wars; nor are they ever really internal for very long. It cannot be assumed that a lack of intervention will accelerate resolution. In Sudan, a highly destructive war has been continuing despite international involvement being limited to diplomacy, non-military humanitarian aid and development assistance; Somalia, since the UN's withdrawal, is no nearer stability. Military victory does not guarantee peace: in Afghanistan, the Taliban is not renowned for respecting human rights.

This does not assume that forcible military intervention is desirable: it is costly in human and financial terms and ineffective. Some of the UN's best (but least public) achievements have been through preventive action, such as the pre-emptive deployment in Macedonia. I accept that bodged peace agreements are unsatisfactory and urge the international community to increase preventive efforts, especially through the UN. But where military intervention is necessary to protect life and promote stability, it must be undertaken, even if it requires a long-term commitment by the international community.
Yours sincerely,
Alex

Dear Alex,
I feel we are on similar ground: we both recognise and support the obligation of the international community, acting through the UN, to do what it can to resolve conflicts in which internal and external elements are often impossible to distinguish. There is a role for peacekeeping forces and preventive action.

But we differ over something more important. You believe that the world is ultimately controllable: that the UN, backed by the leading members of the Security Council, can, with sufficient goodwill and determination, police an international system in which viable states are maintained, governments are stabilised, and basic respect for human rights is assured. Sadly, I cannot agree, and the cases that you cite - including Afghanistan and Somalia - make it clear why not.

The long-term commitment by the international community would involve the imposition of a new colonialism enforced by the armies of industrial states. It would also be impossible: no amount of commitment (which in practice translates into "no number of dead soldiers") is going to protect life and promote stability. It can only promote further instability, as it did when the Russians intervened in Afghanistan and the Americans in Somalia.

No matter how tragic the loss of life, and how appalling the abuse of rights, the UN and its leading states must recognise the limitations on their capacities, and come to terms as best they can with a world that they cannot control. They must resist the temptation to send peacekeepers into situations where they add to the number of victims of the UN's naivety and overambition.
Sincerely, Christopher

Dear Christopher,

I'm pleased we agree on the need for increasing the focus on preventive action. But the fact that conflict prevention is at present so inadequate suggests there are situations where more emergency measures are required. I think we can distinguish between the neo-imperialist imposition of western ideals and the obligations of richer, more stable countries to uphold their responsibilities to poorer or less stable states, whose predicament we have often had a significant role in creating. One would hope local people would lead the way in designing models for governance.

I agree that attempts by the UN, or anyone else, to intervene in evidently unsuitable circumstances are likely to be counterproductive. The UN has been very cautious in its approach to the Congo, although much greater (not necessarily military) international assistance might help to ameliorate the situation. In Sierra Leone, much more could have been done much earlier to address the grotesque behaviour of the RUF and improve the circumstances surrounding Lomé. But while acknowledging the input of UN peacekeepers, the improved circumstances since the arrival of highly efficient, well-resourced British troops demonstrates the effect such support can have.

It's precisely the uncontrollable nature of the world that warrants some forum for global management, not only in security terms. The UN was established in the wake of two world wars to counter the massive destruction that accompanied such inter-state conflicts. The changing nature of war can be seen as a consequence of some success in the UN's original raison d' tre. The problems that it is experiencing with internal conflict is a reason to make stronger efforts rather than to disengage.
Sincerely, Alex
fields.bodyText: Dear Alex, The Sierra Leone fiasco reinforces a lesson the UN should have learned years ago but is still shamefully reluctant to accept: if there isn't a peace, you can't keep it - and the attempt to keep non-existent peaces is not merely a waste of time, but carries a huge risk of exacerbating the very conflicts the peacekeepers were meant to help resolve. There is a place for UN monitoring, where the parties to a conflict have reached a genuine settlement, backed by their dispositions on the ground, which the intervening force can help guarantee. Sierra Leone had no more than a bogus settlement, reminiscent of Angola in 1991-92, or worse, Rwanda in 1993-94: paper agreements between bitterly hostile adversaries. UN peacekeepers were sent in, though neither side had disarmed, and one side had accepted the agreement mostly to gain a breathing space in which to strengthen its position. Providing such a space only makes things worse. In Rwanda, the Arusha accords gave hardliners in the government the opportunity to organise genocide. Sierra Leone is similar: the Lomé agreement of May 1999, into which the Kabbah government was pressured by the UN and others, ostensibly established a coalition between an ineffectual elected government and a ruthless armed opposition with a record of reneging on agreements. The peacekeepers sent in to police it were so poorly armed that hundreds could be rounded up as soon as the war resumed. It is open to the UN to send real fighting forces into situations like Sierra Leone, to kill and be killed, if the states concerned allow it. That would be a very hazardous enterprise, and unlikely to lead to the reconstruction of Sierra Leone. But at least the UN would have some idea of what it was supposed to be doing. Peacekeeping as seen in recent conflicts is a farce fuelled by wishful thinking. We'd be better off without it. Yours sincerely, Christopher Clapham, Professor of politics and international relations, Lancaster University Dear Christopher, I acknowledge your reservations about fragile peace agreements: the Lomé agreement was seriously flawed. But the UK and US were primary influences in initiating Lomé; the UN was fully aware of its weaknesses. Traditional peace-keeping is often inapplicable to internal wars, but the UN has been trying to develop appropriate responses to such emergencies. It is the unwillingness of the more powerful UN member states, not least the five permanent members of the Security Council, to provide sufficient resources for an operation's effectiveness that is the problem. Perhaps a lesson can be learned from East Timor last year, where the May agreement providing for a referendum to decide the province's future status was deeply flawed: the Indonesian authorities insisted upon guaranteeing security. It was inadequate UN involvement that allowed gross human rights abuses against the East Timorese people before, and especially after, the vote. Only then was the international community convinced to provide a proper input. No one can pretend that the referendum process was an unqualified success, nor that UN involvement has been smooth. But there at least appears to have been progress, which could not have occurred without the UN. Peace processes are delicate, dynamic and risky. It is difficult to persuade the international community to prepare effective contingencies until it is too late. Meanwhile, people continue to live (or die) in misery while the international community prevaricates. The responsibility lies with UN member states, particularly those in the Security Council, to provide operations with sufficient resources to reduce the risks, including strengthening peace agreements in the first place. Yours sincerely, Alex Ramsbotham, Head, UN and conflict unit, United Nations Association-UK Dear Alex, I do not agree the failings of the UN can be separated from those of its member states, least of all the permanent members of the Security Council. The UN is an assembly of states; its strengths and weaknesses are reflected in those of its leading members. Their reluctance to provide resources for peacekeeping, most of all to risk troops, is a reality derived from bitter experience, notably that of the US in Somalia. I do not believe that many conflicts can be resolved through external intervention. East Timor, like Namibia a decade earlier, was a crisis to which a clear, acceptable solution could be found, through the simple mechanism of independence validated by an internationally supervised election. Crises like those in Somalia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone or Congo are not like that. These are fundamentally internal wars which can only be resolved internally: either by one combatant securing supremacy, or through a compromise in which each party recognises a settlement. Bodged settlements only delay, and often prevent, this resolution. Either the force brought in to monitor them packs up at the first sign of trouble, or it gets dragged into a long-term commitment in which its own role is compromised, and its costs escalate - not least in lives. The UN must acknowledge its limitations, and avoid getting dragged into conflicts it cannot resolve and in which its involvement can only damage its credibility and the welfare of those it is trying to help. Yours sincerely, Christopher Dear Christopher, I cannot agree that external intervention is inappropriate to internal wars; nor are they ever really internal for very long. It cannot be assumed that a lack of intervention will accelerate resolution. In Sudan, a highly destructive war has been continuing despite international involvement being limited to diplomacy, non-military humanitarian aid and development assistance; Somalia, since the UN's withdrawal, is no nearer stability. Military victory does not guarantee peace: in Afghanistan, the Taliban is not renowned for respecting human rights. This does not assume that forcible military intervention is desirable: it is costly in human and financial terms and ineffective. Some of the UN's best (but least public) achievements have been through preventive action, such as the pre-emptive deployment in Macedonia. I accept that bodged peace agreements are unsatisfactory and urge the international community to increase preventive efforts, especially through the UN. But where military intervention is necessary to protect life and promote stability, it must be undertaken, even if it requires a long-term commitment by the international community. Yours sincerely, Alex Dear Alex, I feel we are on similar ground: we both recognise and support the obligation of the international community, acting through the UN, to do what it can to resolve conflicts in which internal and external elements are often impossible to distinguish. There is a role for peacekeeping forces and preventive action. But we differ over something more important. You believe that the world is ultimately controllable: that the UN, backed by the leading members of the Security Council, can, with sufficient goodwill and determination, police an international system in which viable states are maintained, governments are stabilised, and basic respect for human rights is assured. Sadly, I cannot agree, and the cases that you cite - including Afghanistan and Somalia - make it clear why not. The long-term commitment by the international community would involve the imposition of a new colonialism enforced by the armies of industrial states. It would also be impossible: no amount of commitment (which in practice translates into "no number of dead soldiers") is going to protect life and promote stability. It can only promote further instability, as it did when the Russians intervened in Afghanistan and the Americans in Somalia. No matter how tragic the loss of life, and how appalling the abuse of rights, the UN and its leading states must recognise the limitations on their capacities, and come to terms as best they can with a world that they cannot control. They must resist the temptation to send peacekeepers into situations where they add to the number of victims of the UN's naivety and overambition. Sincerely, Christopher Dear Christopher, I'm pleased we agree on the need for increasing the focus on preventive action. But the fact that conflict prevention is at present so inadequate suggests there are situations where more emergency measures are required. I think we can distinguish between the neo-imperialist imposition of western ideals and the obligations of richer, more stable countries to uphold their responsibilities to poorer or less stable states, whose predicament we have often had a significant role in creating. One would hope local people would lead the way in designing models for governance. I agree that attempts by the UN, or anyone else, to intervene in evidently unsuitable circumstances are likely to be counterproductive. The UN has been very cautious in its approach to the Congo, although much greater (not necessarily military) international assistance might help to ameliorate the situation. In Sierra Leone, much more could have been done much earlier to address the grotesque behaviour of the RUF and improve the circumstances surrounding Lomé. But while acknowledging the input of UN peacekeepers, the improved circumstances since the arrival of highly efficient, well-resourced British troops demonstrates the effect such support can have. It's precisely the uncontrollable nature of the world that warrants some forum for global management, not only in security terms. The UN was established in the wake of two world wars to counter the massive destruction that accompanied such inter-state conflicts. The changing nature of war can be seen as a consequence of some success in the UN's original raison d' tre. The problems that it is experiencing with internal conflict is a reason to make stronger efforts rather than to disengage. Sincerely, Alex

fields.headline: Ristorante Abruzzi, Rome
fields.standfirst: Matthew Fort finds it impossible not to stuff his face. After all, when in Rome...
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort finds it impossible not to stuff his face. After all, when in Rome...
fields.body:
Every now and then, you come across a classic restaurant - somewhere that does what it does supremely well, that goes about its business with unobtrusive authority. Ristorante Abruzzi in the via del Vaccaro in Rome is one of these rare treasures.

Eating out in Rome has changed a bit in recent years. The old-fashioned pizzerias are giving way to fast-food joints, old-fashioned trattorie are being replaced by snazzy, new-style ones, traditional dishes are being subjected to a Ground Force-style makeover into la cucina nuova . Perhaps that's inevitable. Even in the Eternal City things must change a little. Trouble is, if you do away with the old completely, you lose sight of where you came from. And you might lose Ristorante Abruzzi, which, in spite of its name, is an old-fashioned trattoria.

The list of its virtues begins with its position, just off the Corso, not far from Piazza Venezia, and a minute's walk from one of the most exquisite squares in Rome, the perfectly symmetrical Piazza S. Iganazio. Its entrance is unobtrusive and unremarkable. The inside is unobtrusive and unremarkable, too - two rooms with crazy-paving marble floors, white walls dotted with large prints of Roman views, and comfortable, sturdy chairs and tables. The service is brisk but polite. Energy is not wasted on irrelevancies. It has the elegance of purpose.

Wine? We will bring you wine. The house wines, just red and white, are admirable. They are wines made to go with food, not too heavy, not too light, wines of distinct character, but not in-your-face, up-your-nose, grab-you-by-the-tonsils wine. They are sensible wines. You can get more expensive wines, maybe better wines, but why bother? The menu, however, is long: antipasti, paste asciutte, zuppe, piatti pronti per giorno (main courses), piatti da fassi espressi (quick dishes), cacciagone (game), pesce (fish), verdure (vegetables), not to mention cheese, puddings and fruit. That's 70 dishes, all told, and all of them traditional - far too many for a restaurant to produce to any reasonable consistency under normal circumstances. But Ristorante Abruzzi is supra-normal, and I don't suppose that the menu has changed much in 40 years. That's enough time to get things properly sorted.

Take my six-year-old nephew James's main course, tortellini in brodo. It's a classic Italian dish and, as is so often the way with classics, much abused in the hands of lesser chefs, who take short cuts or who feel obliged to add the imprint of their own creativity. The perfection of tortellini in brodo lies in its simplicity - good chicken broth, fine pasta stuffed with good meat, cooked to where it just holds its own against the pressure of the teeth. Just like James's helping, in fact. No wonder he scoffed it down. Another nephew, Lawrence, had fettuccine ai funghi porcini. You could argue that the porcini were well out of season, so perhaps they were sott'olio (kept in oil), or perhaps they were flown in from South Africa. No matter - they were plentiful, and the pasta firm against their soft slipperiness.

The grown-ups, meanwhile, opted for antipasti from the cold, help-yourself counter. I helped myself to: a triangle of fritatta, a braised artichoke, onion roasted with a slice of tomato on top, a slice of grilled aubergine, a dollop of aubergines in oil, ditto peppers, marinated fresh anchovies, courgettes baked with tomato purée, courgettes baked with Parmesan, fried courgettes, a heap of spinach and a few olives. I think that was it, but I did not exhaust what was on offer. The anchovies aside, it was a masterpiece of vegetarian cooking, except, of course, I never thought of it as such: it was just fabulous cooking.

We moved on to straccetti di manzo con rughetta, a quick-fry of shards of beef and rocket, sauced with the meat juices and oil in which it was cooked and a dash of lemon. A fantastically simple dish that is fantastically good, as long as your beef and rocket taste as clearly as they did here. My main course was even simpler, bracciolette di abbacchio scottadito, or roasted lamb chops. That's all it was. Two lamb chops on a plate. No sauce. No veg. No garnish. No gravy. It was what you might call pure food. The chops were pure in flavour, too - a crisp pale amber to the eye, firm to the tooth, plaything to the tastebud. My brother and his wife spoke in similar cheerful tones of their bistecca di manzo alla griglia. Vegetables were served separately - artichokes for them, cold spinach dressed with oil and lemon for me.

It would be unreasonable to expect puddings to maintain this exalted level, and they didn't. But, ice cream and zabaglione apart, they do not play as major a part in the culinary passions of Italy as they do here. Crème caramel passed muster; monte bianco was a monument to artificiality; tiramisu was too sweet. Still, that's a small matter in the scale of things. And the scale of things wound out through the afternoon.

Coffees came. Bottles of digestivi were left on the table for us to help ourselves. This was not a cunning trick to sock us with an enormous bill - they were free, on the house, and we made free with them. The bill? A princely L221,000, or just under £70 for four-and-a-half people. Make that five. James is a person in his own right

webTitle: Three things you didn't know about Wisden

fields.headline: Three things you didn't know about Wisden
fields.standfirst: The last thing Simon Briggs wrote for Wisden before he left for The Daily Telegraph contains some surprising revelations about the magazine which this month celebrates its 21st birthday
fields.trailText: Four years ago I lucked into one of the world's great jobs, an editorial post at Wisden, by impressing Matthew Engel with my knowledge of Test history. My passion for cricket, I told him, dated back to England's 5-0 victory in the 1985 Ashes.
fields.body:
Four years ago I lucked into one of the world's great jobs, an editorial post at Wisden, by impressing Matthew Engel with my knowledge of Test history. My passion for cricket, I told him, dated back to England's 5-0 victory in the 1985 Ashes.

Now, almost inconceivably, I am giving it up. But as I defect to the daily press, I thought I'd let you in on a few trade secrets about the company.

1 WCM is run by a bunch of reformed glue-sniffers.

When I joined, WCM was probably the last magazine in the western world to be laid out with scissors and glue. Apart from The Lady, perhaps. Our petroleum derivative of choice was cowgum, a highly addictive adhesive that could only be bought from the local artists' suppliers, where it was stored in a flameproof safe.

Cowgum's chief advantage was that it didn't stick quite as well as Pritt; if Imran Khan's masterly analysis of the Pakistani tourists was refusing to fit on a page and a half, you could just rip it off and start again. It's chief disadvantage was its Houdini-esque ability to find its way out of any container. I once left a tin in a plastic bag in the editor's hallway, and it fell over and leaked all over his rug. Sportingly, he said he'd never liked that rug much anyway.

Since 1997, and the move to John Brown Publishing, we've produced the magazine on Apple Macs, but WCM's managing editor Steven Lynch has yet to break his solvent habit. Every morning he cowgums the day's cricket stories into an aromatic WH Smith scrapbook.

2 The most indispensable employee of the Wisden Almanack is a woman.

Almanack editors come, go, and take sabbaticals. But one thing that hasn't changed since 1990 is the identity of the deputy editor. Harriet Monkhouse, a classics graduate from Oxford, was working for a computer magazine when Graeme Wright hired her; now she uses email to co-ordinate a worldwide web of statisticians, scorers and record-compilers. If Harriet took a year off, so would Wisden.

It might surprise some readers of the Almanack to hear that between 1990 and 1998, the three-man team that produced it actually consisted of one man (first Graeme Wright and then Matthew Engel) and two women (Harriet and production editor Christine Forrest). For seven of those years, of course, women weren't even allowed in the Lord's Pavilion.

3 Now you can send questions to WCM over the internet.

This won't be news to regular readers of wisden.com, but every Thursday our managing editor ungums himself for long enough to answer the notes and queries submitted to his online column, AskSteven (send questions to asksteven@theguardian.com ). Which is not to say that the rest of us resent the public-service status assumed by some telephone callers, only that enquiries can be dealt with more fully on the web.

The television companies haven't quite caught on to this yet. They're still hauling us onto phantom stations like BBC News 24 to explain why overseas players are good, and the benefit system is baaad. I even made two appearances on terrestrial TV during my Wisden career - both mercifully buried in remote parts of the schedule.

At 7.30am on August 24, 1999, I could be seen perching uncomfortably on a loo seat in The Big Breakfast's bathroom while Ed Hall quizzed me about the sad state of English cricket. ("Toilet," according to one urbane cameraman.) I was rather more optimistic on Channel 5's Live and Dangerous in 1997, after Hussain had put Warne and McGrath to the sword at Edgbaston. "Only two teams have ever come from behind to win the Ashes," I said, confidently. I should have added: "England and Australia."

And here's one more thing for free - something you've probably guessed by now. Wisden is a great place to work. I'm going to miss it in so many ways, and not just for the smell of cowgum in the morning.

You can now read Simon Briggs almost every day in the Daily Telegraph, where is he deputy cricket correspondent

webTitle: Save the last laugh for me

fields.headline: Save the last laugh for me
fields.standfirst: Woody Allen tells  Kurt Jacobsen  why, with his two new films, he's sticking to what he does best
fields.trailText: Woody Allen tells Kurt Jacobsen why, with his two new films, he's sticking to what he does best
fields.body:
On a muggy spring day the tower bells of the stately Rockefeller Chapel chime "New York, New York" in mischievous homage to the renowned arch-neurotic Woody Allen. No one ever had a bigger crush on the Big Apple. ("I have a weak spot for New York City and I fantasised about it as I grew up," Allen confesses. "A New York of penthouses and white telephones that never really existed anywhere except on film.") But this is the cerebral stronghold of the University of Chicago, where a long queue for a free sneak preview of Woody Allen's annual flick - his 33rd in 34 years - spills outside an ornate Gothic hall.

Small Time Crooks, co-starring Tracey Ullman as low-life thief Allen's entrepreneurial wife and Elaine May as their ditzy accomplice, is a sure thing, laced with wonderfully funny lines and saturnine plot twists. It's the kind of film that those vulture-like fans in Stardust Memories demanded that the harried artist churn out: Hey, don't make pretentious dramas (Interiors) that don't work, make pretentious comedies that do.

Despite the heat Allen wears light brown corduroys, a green pullover, brown shoes and those black-rimmed glasses without which he says he feels existentially naked ("like Groucho Marx minus the moustache"). Although he complains about a hearing loss, you want to tell him that hypochondria and neuroses as comic stigmata must agree with him because he looks great and you can't believe he is 64. Allen speaks genially and lengthily about scriptwriting, the decline of comedy, the blight of "factory-made" films and theatre, and his deceptively varied body of film work ("I'm always seen as doing the same thing. It's like Chinese food - many different dishes but it's all Chinese food.")

Once again, in Small Time Crooks, Allen plays a dim-witted hustler surrounded by a motley crew of low-IQ louts and lasses. Why the attraction? "There are two things that I can play, apart from a sperm and an ant. I can play an intellectual. I get credit for appearing to be an intellectual because I wear big dark glasses. But I'm closer to the dimwit in Small Time Crooks. You should see me at home. I'm not hunched over a copy of Heiddeger making marginal notes. I'm sitting with a beer in my hand watching the Knicks. I can play dim-witted characters because that's who I grew up around. I can play Broadway Danny Rose, and the character in Take the Money and Run and I can play this character. I have an affinity for them."

So why does Allen seem so sadly condemned to comedy? "I wish that I had been born with the talent to be serious. My favourite artists are Chekhov, Tennessee Williams, Ibsen, Eugene O'Neill, Arthur Miller. Ingmar Bergman in film. These are the people I idolised. I just don't have what it takes to be that kind of artist. So I struggle and I try to make that work every now and then. But I sweat and huff and puff and maybe sometimes it's OK and sometimes maybe it embarrasses me. Whereas when I'm working in comedy it comes very gracefully for me. It's just an accidental fate that I was born with that kind of gift.

"People at the box office line up for what I call the neanderthal style. In Small Time Crooks I liked the notion that people want to rob a bank and that their cookie business - that they use to rob the bank - takes off and makes them rich. That element of wit is what attracted me to it. But many contemporary comedies come out with relentless toilet jokes because there's a big market for it."

So are audiences today dumber than they used to be? "I never believed in the dumbing down of the country. It can't be that - because every generation has got to feel that their generation was the cultivated and sensitive one, and the new generation is Philistine. Culture has gotten more informal and more relaxed. The time I saw A Streetcar Named Desire it was clear that Blanche was the heroine and Stanley was the nefarious, sinister, unruly brute. But after you look at it over the years you start to feel that, you know, she's crazy. She comes into his house and she's stiff and she's formal - and the world has gotten more informal and so now we understand Stanley's position more.

Now you have a more American sensibility that's expressed in a general loosening up of the culture and it is reflected in films. In comedy, though, the films got more - I don't know - infantile. The big test for me is : Does the film go any place? All the writers I know have a million good ideas that don't go places. When I wrote Purple Rose of Cairo, the guy coming off the screen was a funny idea but it didn't go anywhere. I got 50 pages out and the thing drops dead. I put it in the drawer. But six months later it occurs to me that if the actor in Hollywood comes into this small town and then the guy comes off the screen and falls in love with a girl who has to choose between fantasy and reality - and she chooses reality and it hurts her - well, I knew I had something.

"Same thing with Bullets Over Broadway. The idea of the gangster as a playwright who really did have talent was a funny idea. But it dropped dead halfway through. Only when the idea occurs to me that the gangster realises that the actress is screwing up his dialogue and he kills her, did I realise I had someplace to go with the movie. With Small Time Crooks. The fact that they rent this cookie store next to the bank and the cookie store hits it big - that's a nice idea. Only when I had the idea that money changes them and they start putting on airs and becoming pretentious did I really have something.

"Comic ideas are cheap but ideas that flower, that develop into something are not so easy to find. It's laborious to plot out things; when you get that idea you tend to rush ahead too rapidly and you force the ending. There is no shortage of film companies that will see a funny idea and they won't care that it doesn't go any place. They'll give it to a movie star who will do it because they see themselves getting a lot of laughs but never realising it isn't going any place and then they find it is a disaster."

Why did he not try his hand more at theatre than films? "I wanted to be a playwright originally. When I was a young man the theatre was much more significant than film. What happened was the influx of these great foreign films started to wake American film-makers up. Suddenly American movies improved and grew up a little bit. Coupled with that the American theatre got more and more into these factory-made spectacles and got away from the great things it had. I wish the theatre was thriving as I knew it in New York when I grew up."

The experience of helplessly watching his first script, What's New Pussycat?, undergo a severe mangling was traumatic and inspiring: "I stood there with no clout whatever because it was my first job. Peter O'Toole and Peter Sellers were nice people but it was a film that was motor-powered by studios. So I decided I would never work in film again if I could not be the director." I write on a yellow pad and I type it up myself. You get used to things, you know, and that is part of my particular personality, which is desperately resistant to change. I see change as symbolic of approaching death. I resist change in any form."

fields.headline: From the top
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The escape by three British officers from captivity in Sierra Leone is a tribute to the new thinking on leadership, teamwork and innovation in the services.
fields.body:
The escape by three British officers from captivity in Sierra Leone is a tribute to the new thinking on leadership, teamwork and innovation in the services.

Leadership and management training in the forces have been transformed over the last 30 years. Training priorities have moved away from building inflexible and rigid hierarchies to developing flexible people with the ability to take independent action. The soldiers' escape demonstrated their ability to cope without help from a command centre.

This is important to all types of organisation. Most British enterprises want results but fail to invest the time and resources needed to produce the outcomes. UK managers are the worst educated in the industrially developed world. They leave school earlier, are less likely to have degrees and spend less time on training than their European, North American or Asian rivals.

For a short time in the 90s, people like Sir Bob Reid and Michael Heseltine inspired a real effort to tackle these problems. Business, the CBI and government put the quality of management high up the policy agenda. But hardly a week goes by without evidence that the quality of UK management remains inadequate. Management failings are at the root of the difficulties at BNFL, Rover, the Dome, British Airways and the Paddington rail crash. Despite this, many policy makers seem to believe that large organisations should solve their own problems while public resources should be concentrated on support for small or micro businesses.

This argument is dangerous. First, healthy small firms - especially in manufacturing - are dependent on large businesses. A collapse at Rover would have destroyed more jobs in small manufacturing firms that all the policy initiatives of the last decade have created.

Second, micro businesses make virtually no contribution to the economy except as substitutes for unemployment. Their contribution occurs as they grow, employ more people, innovate and compete internationally.

The UK's success rate in building growing businesses is dismal. For much of the last decade the number of start-up businesses per 1,000 of the population has been among the highest in the developed world. But we perform miserably in international comparisons of numbers growing to employ 10, 50 or 100 people. We are squandering the opportunities created by our advantages in language and access to finance and markets. Take-up of training vividly illustrates the difficulty, with more than 10 times as many managers completing management National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs) than small firm NVQs, with the gap widening in the face of little demand.

The officers escaping in Sierra Leone showed many traits of successful entrepreneurs. They spotted their opportunity and worked as a team. They understood their environment and employed the terrain to their advantage. Use of technology was critical when Major Ashby called his wife on his satellite telephone. This success was not the result of luck. Officer training at the Royal Military Academy Sandhurst is built around Thomas Edison's view that "the harder I work, the luckier I get". They know that leadership and management training are vital parts of building long-term capability.

This explains why a US army review described the British army as "best trained". The observation that it was also the worst equipped takes us back to the need for management training across UK industry.

 Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive, the Management Charter Initiative

fields.headline: It's a boy
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's new son is to be named Leo after the prime minister's father.
fields.body:
Tony and Cherie Blair's new son is to be named Leo after the prime minister's father. Baby Leo, who was born at the Chelsea and Westminster hospital at 12.25am this morning, weighed in at 6lbs 12oz.

Mr Blair, who was present at the birth, praised the doctors and midwives who looked after his wife. "They were absolutely fantastic. The birth was straightforward and Cherie and I were very, very grateful."

The prime minister said Mrs Blair was very tired after a long labour but "very happy... Cherie and the baby are absolutely fine. He's a gorgeous little boy."

The birth was a natural one, rather than the Caesarean section that many had expected. "[Cherie Blair] and the prime minister are looking forward to a quiet weekend spending time with their new son and their other children, who are delighted," said a Downing Street spokesman.

The baby is the first to be born to a serving British prime minister in 150 years, and a fourth child for the couple.

Mr Blair spoke to his father this morning to tell him of the baby's arrival. Mrs Blair's father, the actor Tony Booth, declared himself "absolutely thrilled and delighted" at the news that he had another grandson. "I know both his parents and brothers and sister are completely besotted with him."

Flowers and congratulations began arriving at Downing Street this morning, including bouquets from the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh and Tory leader William Hague, as well as family, friends, and well-wishers.

Mr Hague said: "Ffion and I were delighted to hear of the birth of Tony and Cherie's baby son and we send our congratulations to them and their children.

"This is a wonderful day for them and a happy day for the country as a whole. We send them all our best wishes for the future."

fields.headline: The Grand, Brighton
fields.trailText: Elegant, striking, white-fronted building by the beach with uniformed doorman and concierge. A friendly reception amid the Victorian grandeur.
fields.body:
Address: King's Road, Brighton, East Sussex BN1 2FW.
Tel: 01273 224300
Web address: www.grandbrighton.co.uk

First impressions
Elegant, striking, white-fronted building by the beach with uniformed doorman and concierge. Friendly reception amid the Victorian grandeur. A small plaque commemorates the hotel's reopening in 1986, after the IRA bomb.

What are the rooms like?
Ours was spacious and well-appointed with a balcony and a tremendous view over the pebble beach and Brighton's piers.

The bed test
In our case, a four poster. Not too hard, not too soft.

The bathroom test
Large, full of mirrors and free soaps. Bath good and deep; shower good and strong.

Restaurant
The King's Restaurant (£30 for a four-course table d'hote dinner) is a little long on the tradition of silver service and short on the benefits of modern British cuisine. Plus points for breakfast - a monumental buffet.

The lounge
A comfortable, airy piano bar, mainly for the oldies. Younger guests head for the hotel's Midnight Blues Nightclub. Or, much better, go to town.

Other facilities
Hairdressing salon, massage, facial, manicure, sauna, sunbed, indoor pool, gym.

What is there to see within walking distance?
The beach, the Palace Pier and dilapidated West Pier, the Royal Pavilion, Brighton Museum and Art Gallery, the Lanes shopping district, the Sea Life centre.

What is there to see within 10-minute drive?
The pretty hilltop town of Lewes and the rolling South Downs. Glyndebourne opera house is very close. Gatwick airport is 20-30 minutes away.

How much a night?
Our deluxe double with sea view: £300 per night. Regular doubles start at £210 per night; singles £155.

Would you go back?
On a very special occasion, yes.

fields.headline: The ideal crisp sandwich recipe
fields.trailText: There's no point in trying to be sophisticated about this: the crisp sarnie was part of most people's youthful gastronomic delinquency, and is one of the great communal eating experiences
fields.body:
There's no point in trying to be sophisticated about this: the crisp sarnie was part of most people's youthful gastronomic delinquency, and is one of the great communal eating experiences.

Still, there are rules that should ensure an above-average result. One, only soft white bread of the Mother's Pride variety will do - the textural contrast between the two primary elements is crucial to the success of the finished item. Two, the cheaper the crisp the better - the higher tensile qualities of hand-turned chips are not suited to the evanescent fragility of this delicacy. Third, there is the matter of additives, by which I mean butter or mayo spread on the bread, not to mention the inclusion of other vegetal matter - eg, cucumber, cheese, thinly sliced Mars Bar, etc. Here, I think, personal values have to play their part. I've experimented with peanut butter (horrid), Marmite (heaven) and caviar (bliss).

fields.headline: Fiji's leaders held hostage in 'ethnic' coup
fields.trailText: Seven masked gunmen were last night holding the prime minister of Fiji, Mahendra Choudhry, and up to 50 cabinet ministers and MPs hostage in parliament, after staging a coup the aggressors said was conducted on behalf of indigenous Fijians.
fields.body:
Seven masked gunmen were last night holding the prime minister of Fiji, Mahendra Choudhry, and up to 50 cabinet ministers and MPs hostage in parliament, after staging a coup the aggressors said was conducted on behalf of indigenous Fijians.

To the delight of mobs who looted and burned Indian-owned shops in the capital, Suva , ethnic Fijian nationalist George Speight declared himself interim president, suspending the constitution and appointing an opposition MP and political novice, Ratu Timoci Silatolu, as interim prime minister.

The coup leader was described yesterday as a former computer salesman with a taste for the flamboyant gestures but with hitherto little public support.

However, it was unclear last night whether the ethnic Fijian-dominated armed forces would back Mr Speight. Both the coup leader and the president of Fiji, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, claimed yesterday that they had the loyalty of the military.

Mr Speight said:"I am asserting control, I am asserting executive power over Fiji as I speak. All executive power currently resides in my hands."

He also claimed that the armed forces were at his "beck and call". Sir Kamisese, whose daughter, Adi Koila Mara, was among the ministers being held hostage, has declared a state of emergency. He gave himself the power to command the military, and appealed to the hostage-takers to release the MPs. He also urged the army and police to restore the rule of law.

"I regret to say what is happening today is not in accordance with the constitution and is therefore unlawful," Sir Kamisese said.

The bloodless coup was instantly condemned by Commonwealth leaders, who warned that the South Pacific nation could face suspension.

The Commonwealth's secretary general, Don McKinnon, said he was "sad and angry" over the attack on Fiji's elected government. "I have been in touch with the president of Fiji Islands, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, to offer my full support for his efforts to restore constitutional rule," he said. Australia's prime minister, John Howard said: "I'm horrified that such an act should be carried out against a democratically elected leader."

The storming of parliament came as about 5,000 people demonstrated against Mr Chaudhry on the anniversary of his election. Police imposed a curfew as a pall of smoke hung over Suva's many burnt stores and 300 troops fanned out across the city. Two military battalions were also deployed around the country to help police curb the violence.

But there was no indication that soldiers were intervening to end the hostage drama.

Mr Chaudhry, Fiji's first ethnic Indian prime minister, angered the Pacific island state by packing his administration with Indo-Fijians.

Last night there were reports that Fiji's Indian community, who make up 44% of the 800,000 population of the islands, were already trying to flee overseas as thousands had done after two coups in 1987 reinforced Fijian control of parliament.

The arrival of seven masked armed men in parliament ends weeks of speculation that Mr Chaudhry, whose rainbow coalition won power in a landslide exactly a year ago, would be deposed. A joint statement of Fijian political parties issued just before the coup said that civil unrest would continue until the government and the 1997 multi racial constitution under which it had been elected were removed.

"No right-thinking Fijian will allow this government, which has been manifestly anti-Fijian in both direction and intent, to continue to violate the desires and aspirations of the indigenous Fijian people," it said. Land rights have remained a volatile issue on the islands since the first coups.

More than 90% of the land is owned by the ethnic Fijians but is leased to the Fijian Indians, who were first brought over 100 years ago as indentured labourers, to run sugar cane farms as tenants.

Salesman makes an unlikely rebel

George Speight is not your typical coup leader. The burly, balding leader of seven gunmen who took the Fijian cabinet hostage yesterday is a charismatic businessman with family links to the opposition but no military background.

A former computer salesman with a taste for the flamboyant, Mr Speight is a marketeer by training. His father is Fijian of European extraction which makes him an unlikely champion of the ethnic Fijian cause.

"He is a theatrical kind of person. Loves being at centre stage," Professor Brij Lal of the Australian National University said.

Centre stage was exactly where Mr Speight was yesterday as he and six other masked gunmen stormed parliament and took the prime minister and his cabinet hostage before declaring that he had dissolved Fiji's constitution.

Mr Speight owes much of his career to his father, Sam Speight, who was a high-ranking member of the former government. The younger Speight is a commerce graduate from an Australian university and was sponsored by his father's SVT party to do postgraduate studies in the US.

Mr Speight had excellent contacts with the SVT government. While his father was in power, the government made him chairman of Fiji Pine and Fiji Hardwood Corporation, two local companies involved in managing Fiji's lucrative timber trade. The country has the world's richest mahogany resources.

But when the current prime minister took power, Mr Speight was was sacked from both companies. Indigenous Fijians have accused the prime minister, an ethnic Indian, of benefiting the Indian community.

Mr Speight claimed yesterday to be representing ethnic Fijians, many of whom are dissatisfied with the Indian-dominated ruling coalition.

But observers believe his support is far more limited. "I don't think he represents any constituency except a group of disgruntled Fijians. He is a person who is politically naive, personally ambitious and eager for some limelight," Mr Lal said.

Mr Speight did not appear to have the support of Fiji's army.

He was also fired last year by the insurance brokering firm Heath Fiji where he was local managing director. He was blamed for alleged financial irregularities at the company.
Alex Bellos and agencies

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Scotland | Vietnam | New England
fields.body:
Europe

Scotland: Golf-break to the Open, July 21-22, in St Andrews, staying in Glasgow at the Carrick Hotel with transfers to St Andrews and two all-day passes. Goldenrail Hotel Breaks (0990 992993).

Spain: Seven-day self-drive birdwatching, botanical and wildlife tour of Picos de Europa, based in Soto de Cangas and Espinama. Tour costs £595pp inc day flights from Heathrow, hotel and detailed bird and mammal lists and car rental. Wildlife Worldwide (020-8667 9158).

Asia

Vietnam: A 19-day trip, with 10 days moderate cycle touring. Dates start in September. Price from £1,860. World Expeditions (020-8870 2600).

India: A 19-day holiday in Ladakh, "Little Tibet" departing Delhi July 16. Trip includes trek to Markha Valley, coinciding with the full moon and the Hemis monastery's annual summer Buddhist festival. Tour cost is £1,240 but does not include international flights, which are available. Peregrine (01728 862222).

North America

New England: On the trail of the whale, from Gatwick or Heathrow to Boston, between July 22 and August 7. An eight-night holiday is £1,395 per person, including return flights, B&B (based on two sharing) in Rockport, a half-day tour of Cape Ann and whale trips. Discover the World (01737 218800).

Canada: Twelve-day self- drive motorhome from Vancouver or Calgary. Cost from £720pp including flights, first night hotel and 10-day motorhome rental and 160km per day allowance. Lakes and Mountain Holidays (01329 844 405).

Australia

Sydney: Celebrate the next New Year on a boat in the harbour then visit the vineyards of the Hunter, Barossa, McClaren and Clare on a wine tour. Lynette Arblaster and Tim Clarke act as tour manager and wine guide. Departing UK December 27, back January 9. Price is £2,999pp inc flights, meals and wines. Details from Arblaster and Clarke Wine Tours (01730 893344)

Middle East

Syria: Why make do with the guide book when you can take the author? An eight- day journey focusing on Bronze Age sites in Northern Syria is accompanied by Jonathan Tubb, curator of the British Museum's Syria-Palestine department. Departure is October 10 and costs £1,395 including flights and half-board. British Museum Traveller (020-7323 8895).

fields.headline: Fiji's leaders held hostage in 'ethnic' coup
fields.trailText: May 19 2000: On this day gunmen stormed the Fijian parliament and held the prime minister and members hostage. This is how the Guardian reported the events.

fields.headline: A selector for the future
fields.standfirst: Zak Stinchcombe is a keen cricket fan who has just started training with his local team. Oh, and he's seven years old. Here he tells the England selectors how they should have done their job for the first Test against Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Last week the England selectors picked their team to take on Zimbabwe in the first Test at Lord's. I know that there have been injuries, but even so they chose the wrong team. If everyone had been fit, my England squad would have been
fields.body:
Last week the England selectors picked their team to take on Zimbabwe in the first Test at Lord's. I know that there have been injuries, but even so they chose the wrong team. If everyone had been fit, my England squad would have been

1 Ramprakash
2 Knight
3 Hick
4 Thorpe
5 Hussain
6 Flintoff
7 Read
8 Tudor
9 Gough
10 Caddick
11 Mullally
12 Swann

I chose Nick Knight to open because he is a left-handed batsman - like me - and a left-right opening pair always upsets the bowlers. Also he adds on runs so quickly - especially important if the other opener is Mark Ramprakash. We do need to keep the board ticking over.

My middle order would have been Graeme Hick, Graham Thorpe, and Nasser Hussain - right, left, right. Hick is the best batsman we've got, Thorpe has done well for England before and scored a century in his first Test match (114* v Australia at Trent Bridge in 1993), and Hussain seems to be the best captain we've had since Mike Brearley.

The allrounder just had to be Andy Flintoff. He bats like Botham and can bowl quite well when he's on form.

My keeper would have been Chris Read, altough I would have Jack Russell if he was young enough. Alec Stewart is past his best and we need to look forward. I would have Stewart as coach for Read.

Alex Tudor was my number eight. For a tailender he bats magnificently and averages about 55 in Tests. His bowling is rapid, but he needs to have more control of the ball. Let Bob Willis sort him out.

Goughie picked himself, as did Andy Caddick. The final spot should have been between Alan Mullally and Graeme Swann depending on the wicket and whether it will swing or turn.

Although the bowling is a little weak, the team might break England's best score of 903 for seven declared, made at The Oval against Australia in 1938.

webTitle: Relight your fire if the thrill is gone

fields.headline: Relight your fire if the thrill is gone
fields.standfirst: What to do when your glittering career has turned into a boring job
fields.trailText: What to do when your glittering career has turned into a boring job
fields.body:
It may be that landing a great account just doesn't provide the same rush any more. Or that your eyes glaze over when reading those once-riveting sales projections. Or that you're aimlessly web surfing when you should be multi-tasking.

Professionally speaking, the thrill may not be entirely gone. But it certainly isn't what it used to be. What happened to that driving sense of focus?

Some reach this point and immediately press the panic button: Did I chose the wrong career? Should I start over again? Have I been living a lie?

But, in most cases, that's an unnecessarily extreme reaction. It's quite normal to realise that, on many days, a career is a job rather than a heart-pounding adventure.

The key? Keeping distractions to a minimum and maintaining focus on the work-related tasks at hand. Here's how:

1. Invent a challenge.

A lack of focus often emerges because what once was exciting - landing a top client, nailing down a tricky quarterly forecast, etc. - has now become old hat.

This isn't a bad thing, really. It just means you've become good at what you do. You've adapted highly efficient ways to get it done quickly. Still, that means you have some extra time on your hands.

Career coach Laura Berman Fortgang, author of Take Yourself to the Top (Thorsons), suggests finding your own source of spark.

"Sleuth out a flaw in the company that is costing the company money and create a proposal for how you can fix it. That will re-energise you and re-engage you in the game," she suggests.

"Go to your boss and ask them to challenge you more or give you a big project to handle," she adds. "Find a 'secret mission' within your job. Redesign the job for ultimate satisfaction.

"Think of what skills and talents you'd like to be using and what part of the business you would like to impact."

2. Face reality - quality work isn't easy.

Yes, solutions to complex work tasks require careful research and analysis. Still, too many employees seek the easy way out. When they meet a roadblock, their interest wanes.

One solution is to break off an intimidating project into incremental portions of accomplishment. Let success be defined by mini-victories that build upon each other.

Have a list of them and tick them off when you've achieved each one and give yourself a moment to celebrate.

Maybe go for pizza and a pint with some friends (after working hours, of course) but quickly move forward to the next challenge.

3. Tech tools should help, not hinder, productivity.

There's your work email account. Then a personal email account that you call up on the web. Then mobile phones. Not to mention pagers...

When do we get a chance to disconnect and zero in on the job at hand? Evaluate which tech tools are really essential and cut back on what isn't. Do you really need to check that personal email five times a day? Try doing it once in the morning and once at the end of the day.

Can you survive by logging off the work email and (shudder!) turning off your pager for an hour to focus on a deadline? Good. Do it. And you don't have to grab those voice mail messages every time that annoying blinking light goes on. Cover up the light with a piece of paper for an hour or two. (Out of sight, out of mind.) Then, clean up the voice mail once you've gotten a good chunk of today's 'to do' list taken care of.

If you're finding yourself too readily distracted by non-work related web wandering, it may not require an all-out moratorium. But try setting a limit. Say, a half hour during the lunch break.

Often times, non-work related web surfing and other distractions are pursued when workers are anxious about a task at hand and seek avoidance.

4. It could very well be the job, not you.

It's not uncommon, especially in today's 'here today, gone tomorrow' workforce mentality. Job jumping doesn't have the same negative stigma these days that it did in generations past.

The trick is to leave before you're getting pushed out. It's much easier to find a job when you're not hitting a desperation period.

Or that you're aimlessly web surfing when you should be multi-tasking. Professionally speaking, the thrill may not be entirely gone. But it certainly isn't what it used to be. What happened to that driving sense of focus? Some reach this point and immediately press the panic button: Did I chose the wrong career? Should I start over again? Have I been living a lie? But, in most cases, that's an unnecessarily extreme reaction. It's quite normal to realise that, on many days, a career is a job rather than a heart-pounding adventure. The key? Keeping distractions to a minimum and maintaining focus on the work-related tasks at hand. Here's how: 1. Invent a challenge. A lack of focus often emerges because what once was exciting - landing a top client, nailing down a tricky quarterly forecast, etc. - has now become old hat. This isn't a bad thing, really. It just means you've become good at what you do. You've adapted highly efficient ways to get it done quickly. Still, that means you have some extra time on your hands. Career coach Laura Berman Fortgang, author of Take Yourself to the Top (Thorsons), suggests finding your own source of spark. "Sleuth out a flaw in the company that is costing the company money and create a proposal for how you can fix it. That will re-energise you and re-engage you in the game," she suggests. "Go to your boss and ask them to challenge you more or give you a big project to handle," she adds. "Find a 'secret mission' within your job. Redesign the job for ultimate satisfaction. "Think of what skills and talents you'd like to be using and what part of the business you would like to impact." 2. Face reality - quality work isn't easy.
