fields.headline: Cool companies
fields.standfirst: No 33 Miller Group
fields.trailText: No 33 Miller Group
fields.body:
Stop drooling - it has no link with the Miller Brewing company of Milwaukee producing that smooth Lite beer. This Miller Group is the UK's largest privately owned property development, house building and construction services company with a history that stretches back to the 30s. It provides diverse career opportunities, from building and construction to civil engineering and mining.

The company says its success is solely attributed to the excellence of its people. This is not a glib soundbite as the firm and all its operating divisions have achieved the coveted investor in people (IiP) status.

The Miller Group adopts an ethical approach to business and is renowned for its creativity, innovation and environment-friendly credentials. For example, its civil engineering arm is currently participating in Yorkshire Water's £120m Coastal Care Programme, with the help of "Alison", an 80-ton tunnelling machine (left). The project will clean bathing waters in Scarborough, Whitby, Filey and Bridlington, ending sewage disposal to sea.

Miller Homes, its house building business, has a well established and award-winning reputation for quality-built family houses throughout the central belt of Scotland, the North of England and the Midlands. Properties range from one bedroom flats to five bedroom executive family homes.

In its approach to urban and community regeneration, the division also has an unrivalled reputation for imaginative and cost effective solutions to the challenges facing urban Britain. Take its project in Islington, north London, where it is the master builder in a massive urban regeneration programme to construct a retail and leisure complex. The 200,000 sq ft development comprises a nine screen Warner Village multiplex cinema, together with various ground floor retail units and first floor bars and restaurants.

The Miller Group recognises the need to continually grow and expand its professional and managerial capability. It operates an undergraduate work placement scheme and encourages progression to its graduate training programme at a future date. This lasts for at least two years, with every candidate supported by a mentor backed by regular formal reviews and feedback on performance. Plus there are opportunities for further study through the Miller management development programme.

Graduate intake is dependent on the needs of the business. Technical and business degrees including construction, quantity surveying and civil engineering would normally meet its requirements.

Speculative employment enquiries should be made to: Human resources manager, The Miller Group, Miller House, 18 South Groathill Avenue, Edinburgh EH4 2LW. All current vacancies are advertised online at www.miller.co.uk

webTitle: Are you really a good team player?

fields.headline: Are you really a good team player?
fields.standfirst: Try this quiz and discover the truth about yourself
fields.trailText: Try this quiz and discover the truth about yourself
fields.body:
Asked to list your best qualities at an interview, chances are you'll claim you're a great team player. But is it true or just wishful thinking? Try our quiz to discover the truth. And be honest.

1) Think back to your school days. How did you feel when teams were picked?

a) Horror. You were always the last and still have nightmares about it.

b) Proud. You knew you'd be picked first or second - the team captains were your best mates.

c) It didn't bother you. You knew you'd be picked eventually and, whichever team you joined, you did your best to help them win.

d) Did that really happen? You must have had a sick note/been smoking behind the bike sheds every session.

2) You've been invited to join a team to develop a hot new product. Do you:

a) Turn the offer down flat. You've got nothing to contribute.

b) Check out who's on the team first. There's no way you'd work with that idiot in marketing.

c) Jump at the chance. You're excited at the prospect of working with a great bunch of people.

d) Turn the offer down. You're far too busy working on your own projects.

3) This morning, a colleague suggested a particularly unhelpful idea. Do you:

a) Ignore them for the rest of the week.

b) Say nothing, then gossip about your stupid colleague with the others.

c) Keep your feelings to yourself and patiently explain why you think the idea wouldn't work.

d) Ha ha ha ha... What a moron!

4) One member of your team is much quieter than the rest and is overlooked or ignored, despite having great ideas. Do you:

a) Ignore them. It's a dog eat dog world.

b) Listen to their ideas and then - in a louder voice - put them forward as your own.

c) Encourage them to contribute whenever you can.

d) Suggest that they don't really contribute and might want to leave the team.

5) A source has given you information which will help your team make an important decision. Do you:

a) Tell no one. You can't be sure it's true.

b) Release the information in dribs and drabs, so no one except you has the full picture.

c) Freely present the information for the good of your team and organisation.

d) Milk it. Hold on to the information for as long as you can... then tell the others at a time that is most beneficial to you.

6) A bright spark in your team has come up with a solution to a long-standing problem. Do you:

a) Go along with it. You can't be bothered to argue.

b) Support the idea - then steal it.

c) Support the idea. With a little improvement and effort from the rest of the team, it's workable.

d) Criticise a minor aspect of the suggestion and say it's therefore unworkable.

7) Two members of your team continuously argue about trivial matters. Do you:

a) Ignore them and hope they'll resolve their differences without bloodshed.

b) Encourage the conflict by siding with each party behind the other's back. Then distribute negative information about them to the rest of the team.

c) Mediate. Discuss the issues with the individuals concerned and try to resolve the conflict.

d) Leave a few innocent, but potentially dangerous, objects (Stanley knife, heavy phone, stapler) in strategic places. Your office could do with a little excitement.

8) You're in a relatively new team and the members are still very cautious and excessively polite with one another. Do you:

a) Stick to the status quo, sir. It's safer and much less effort, if you please. Thank you.

b) Take everyone down the pub and suggest a few drinking games. If everyone gets sozzled, they'll lose their inhibitions.

c) Suggest a regular night out/team weekend away so people can get to know each other.
d) Make lewd jokes and call everyone "mate" at the next meeting. It will lighten the atmosphere.

9) Someone new has joined your team. Do you:

a) Ignore them. You're not the office Mother Teresa.

b) Go on a mission to make them your best mate. That way, they'll support everything you say and do.

c) Be friendly but not over-bearing and offer to bring them up to date on what's been going on, so they'll settle into the team naturally.

d) Look bemused. Has someone new joined? You thought one of your colleagues had had their hair done. You still don't know everyone's names anyway.

10) What do your colleagues think of you?

a) Everyone likes you but they never take up any of your suggestions.

b) If they had a popularity contest you'd win hands down.

c) You're friendly, patient, supportive, a good listener and have great ideas.

d) It's unprintable. Who cares? What matters is getting the job done.

Now count how many 'a's, 'b's, 'c's and 'd's you circled and click here to discover how you got on.

webTitle: How to cope when you're working with a slacker

fields.headline: How to cope when you're working with a slacker
fields.standfirst: Employees who take things easy at work can cause problems for their colleagues, but there is usually a good reason for their behaviour
fields.trailText: Employees who take things easy at work can cause problems for their colleagues, but there is usually a good reason for their behaviour
fields.body:
If there's one thing I can't stand it's laziness," says Sara Barker, team manager in a direct mail advertising firm. "It just makes me see red. I have one guy, Martin, in my team who just works as if he's got his handbrake on - it takes him twice as long to do things, he never finishes a job properly.

"I seem to spend my life having a go at him, sending work back, asking him to do things again - and it just never makes any difference."

The first thing to define is what is causing the person to behave in this way - whether it is caused by a specific problem with the job that can be solved, or whether it is a product of more general disaffection with office life.

"Usually there is a good reason if someone is slacking," says Jane Weightman, author of Managing People . "Often it's a 'gap' problem - where expectations and reality don't meet. It may be that the person may not have had the job explained thoroughly, may not have had sufficient training or feels undervalued."

Barker admits she's not dealing with the problem, but finds it hard to control her annoyance. "I know that ticking him off in public is a bad idea and I suppose I should take him into my office and talk it through, but I feel that I don't have anything solid to have a go at him about. He's not actually causing the department a problem - he does the work that's necessary - he just never bothers to put the effort in and do anything extra."

According to Dr Stuart Metcalfe, senior lecturer in business studies at the South Bank Business School, the idea of 'having a go' is coming at the problem from the wrong angle. "The best way to deal with this sort of situation is take the person to one side and have a quiet chat," he says.

"These kind of conversations can be awkward, but you can take the sting out of it by asking what they don't like about the company, or the job. Make it clear that you are willing to consider that the fault may be on the company's side, as well as theirs.

"And never, ever, tick someone off in front of their colleagues - it only causes resentment and is incredibly demotivational."

Jane Weightman agrees: "Have the conversation in private and be prepared to listen and take on board whatever the person has to say. Sometimes it may be as simple as the fact their car has failed its MOT and that's why they're late to work. Or it could be something work-related - but once you have the reason for their seeming disinterest, then you're half way to solving the problem."

Nine times out of ten a chat will solve the problem - but sometimes it isn't that simple. "I had a woman in my team recently, Monica, who just wasn't working properly - she'd come in late, take whole afternoons off for medical appointments," says Ian Stevenson, who heads up a team of market researchers.

"I suspected that she was going for interviews - and so I brought her into my office for a chat, but she denied anything was wrong."

In the end Stevenson's suspicions turned out to be correct - when Monica handed in her notice. "I felt really stupid," he admits.

"My instincts were correct but I didn't have the confidence to deal with the situation. When her performance didn't pick up after we spoke, I should have sent her a note or a memo, but I just wasn't quite sure how to do it."

"As a manager you have to decide where the lines are drawn," says Dr Metcalfe. "If someone still isn't pulling their weight after you have spoken to them, then send them a memo. It keeps the matter confidential - which is hugely important - but lets them know that you are still unhappy with their performance. Again, don't make it confrontational but simply outline what the perceived problems are - timekeeping, attitude, whatever.

"If the situation still doesn't improve, you then have to confront it - but at least you have written proof that you have followed correct procedures."

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

"It's astonishing what people will tell you if you show interest," says Jane Weightman. There may be a perfectly good reason why someone isn't working to their true potential. You'll never know unless you ask.

fields.headline: Help: No one appreciates me!
fields.trailText: How can you succeed when your definition of success might be radically different from that of your employer?
fields.body:
I work for an organisation that seems to punish rather than reward achievement. Whenever I have a major success with clients, I'm moved on to new work rather than allowed to capitalise on the relationships and systems I've created.
Cameron C, conference organiser, London

There are two possible explanations for this. The first is that you're unaware of the effect you have on others and have misinterpreted the situation. The second is that what you and your clients regard as success is viewed differently by your employer.

It is confusing when those you regard as customers are reeling with delight at the level of care you provide whilst your employer responds with disapproval. But the explanation is simple - individual excellence causes problems in organisations run by plodders for plodders.

Be honest, which is the more likely scenario in your case? If you're not sure, find out from whoever is making the decision to keep you on the move. Ask if they have a problem with your work and the reason for your reassignments. If they talk about staff morale, the necessity for team work, they're plodders. If they try to be kind and spare your feelings, it's your perceptions that are flawed.

Exceptional ability can cause the average employer a headache. Word about who's good spreads quickly and everybody wants a share. If your work is of a higher standard than those around you it throws their shortcomings into sharp focus. The best solution is to find yourself an above average employer or become your own master. If you have something people are willing to pay for it's an opportunity worth exploiting.

fields.headline: Top rung/Bottom rung
fields.trailText: Two employees of Barclays Stockbrokers give their views on working life from either end of the career ladder
fields.body:
Hilary Cook
Aged 41
Investment management director Barclays Stockbrokers

Bringing on young talent gives Hilary Cook the buzz in her job. "Running a team gives you a great opportunity," she says, "to create the environment where they can flourish and watch how fast they can develop."

Hilary entered stockbroking after an academic career - including Oxford and Edinburgh - which saw her heading for an economics PhD. "But when I saw my investment analyst friends being well paid for doing similar research, I decided it was the financial world for me."

CV? She moved into her present post with Barclays Stockbrokers following spells in private client banking. The company, with a staff of 1,550, manages assets of £10.7bn for clients.

"We are investing real money and seeing our views on the performance of companies being borne out - or not. It's a big responsibility because our decisions affect people's livelihoods."

Key decision? "To invest heavily in Marks & Spencer in the 80s and, more recently, to sell the shares again."

Must-have qualities: "We look for lively graduates from any degree background who are numerate, can reason logically and write clearly. We need all-rounders as assessing the unknown is not a science."

Tom Collyer
Aged 24
Investment analyst trainee Barclays Stockbrokers Tom Collyer got into banking at the last minute. By the time he graduated from University College London (geography) in 1997 he admits that he had failed to send out a single job application. "But by the end of the summer I was one of the last to be taken on in the Barclays Management Scheme."

He was one of 100 graduates to join the two to three year programme which involves a series of work placements and study for an external qualification. Tom has so far worked in high street banking, loan applications, small business and offshore banking. His current placing in investment management began earlier this year.

"What I like about the training is that it gives you a broad-based flavour of financial services."

Tom recently sat investment management exams. Each trainee has a £2,000 personal development budget to spend on courses of their choice. Performance contract targets are set out on each attachment.

"Barclays provides an amazing opportunity for graduates. A lot of resources and support are available."

Next move? "I think it will take me a few more years to learn fully the investment side of banking."

fields.bodyText: Hilary Cook Aged 41 Investment management director Barclays Stockbrokers Bringing on young talent gives Hilary Cook the buzz in her job. "Running a team gives you a great opportunity," she says, "to create the environment where they can flourish and watch how fast they can develop." Hilary entered stockbroking after an academic career - including Oxford and Edinburgh - which saw her heading for an economics PhD. "But when I saw my investment analyst friends being well paid for doing similar research, I decided it was the financial world for me." CV? She moved into her present post with Barclays Stockbrokers following spells in private client banking. The company, with a staff of 1,550, manages assets of £10.7bn for clients. "We are investing real money and seeing our views on the performance of companies being borne out - or not. It's a big responsibility because our decisions affect people's livelihoods." Key decision? "To invest heavily in Marks & Spencer in the 80s and, more recently, to sell the shares again." Must-have qualities: "We look for lively graduates from any degree background who are numerate, can reason logically and write clearly. We need all-rounders as assessing the unknown is not a science." Tom Collyer Aged 24 Investment analyst trainee Barclays Stockbrokers Tom Collyer got into banking at the last minute. By the time he graduated from University College London (geography) in 1997 he admits that he had failed to send out a single job application. "But by the end of the summer I was one of the last to be taken on in the Barclays Management Scheme." He was one of 100 graduates to join the two to three year programme which involves a series of work placements and study for an external qualification. Tom has so far worked in high street banking, loan applications, small business and offshore banking. His current placing in investment management began earlier this year. "What I like about the training is that it gives you a broad-based flavour of financial services." Tom recently sat investment management exams. fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to choosing between a busy or easy life
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to choosing between a busy or easy life
fields.body:
A. Wrap up well

Efficiency and time management experts frequently preach the folly of indulging in busy work - unimportant or routine jobs someone else could do for you. But there's comfort value in activities that keep you occupied without taking a lot of effort. The idea that you should always scorn the easy options and pursue new challenges is dangerous. There is nothing wrong with a bit of ease and a lot wrong with frenetic activity and a constant desire to do better.

B. Honourable retreat

Undemanding activities are an effective way to boost confidence and energy levels. The more challenging your normal pursuits, the more essential it is to find trivial but satisfying tasks to retreat to every now and then. Choose jobs with no prospect of generating extra work and where success is guaranteed. If you're short of ideas try clearing out e-mails, reorganising your address book or updating old presentations. As well as offering instant gratification this has value in terms of organising your resources.

C. Comfort zones

Periods of relaxation disguised as activity are safer than obvious time out. Absorption in an apparently acceptable task deflects unwelcome attention from those with extra work to assign. Unfortunately, as with many pleasant pursuits, you need to ration yourself. Used sparingly, sessions inside your comfort zone are revitalising enough to help you tackle the more difficult bits of life.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: The latest from the world of graduate recruitment
fields.body:
No time to revise: Looking for an excuse should you flop at your finals? According to a poll by freefund.com, an internet database of student scholarships and bursaries, three out of five students have part-time jobs and more than 40% of them admit that their employment is having a detrimental effect on their studies and overall grades.

Big in the US: Huge salaries, share options, executive toys and even sky diving are being offered to graduates as firms scramble to recruit in America's booming economy. Some companies are promising signing-on bonuses of £3,000, but mountain bikes, laptops and DVD players are being used just to tempt students to campus presentations.

Not a mouse in the house: The next generation of laptops could be closer to your lap then you'd imagine. British company Electrotextiles is working on a keyboard made out of a 'smart fabric' which could be sewn into your trousers or skirt and a necktie that functions as a mouse.

It's a work thing: In its never- ending quest to win you the best jobs, The Guardian is creating an online recruitment service which will go live in the summer and aims to advertise opportunities across all sectors. Called workthing.com, it will "provide an information exchange, advice and recruitment service for everyone involved in the world of work".

Book of the week: Motivation is much more than just a few words of praise. It is an essential skill which anyone can learn, and with which you can have an indelible positive impact on yourself and on others. So says Max Landsberg, whose book The Tao of Motivation can be ordered for the special price of £5.99 (plus p&p) from our Cultureshop on 0800 316 6102.

Not so smart: Got an annoying colleague who knows less than anyone, yet thinks they know it all? Research by psychologists at Cornell University in the US suggests that incompetence actually robs people of their ability to recognise it. As a result they will often forego the training that they need or ignore second opinions which might correct their mistakes.

Tip of the Week

Appearances matter: When it comes to judging job offers, Professor Maura Belliveau, who teaches at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business, has some advice. "Don't just look at where people work. Watch how they work - simple things like how a receptionist greets strangers can be illuminating," she says. "Organisations convey something about themselves in their selection of frontline staff. Companies with strong cultures stand out from the moment you walk on to the premises. And every company has stories - anecdotes that employees share with outsiders. What are the stories about? Big wins? Great service? Political battles? The stories that people inside a company share tell you a lot about the company itself."

fields.headline: Giuliani to quit Senate race
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: The United States was robbed of its most riveting election in years last night when sources close to Hillary Clinton's rival made it clear he was to withdraw from the Senate race.
fields.body:
The United States was robbed of its most riveting election in years last night when sources close to Hillary Clinton's rival made it clear he was to withdraw from the Senate race.

Mayor Rudy Giuliani, one of the Republican's biggest stars, left the party casting around for a new candidate to take on Mrs Clinton only 11 days before its nominating convention.

"The mayor will announce today that he will drop out," said the source. Mr Giuliani had spent the morning making clear his intentions by calling party leaders and telling them that he could not devote his full attention to the election.

This is a euphemism for the last three weeks, when the wheels came off the campaign of a man who had previously appeared to be in control of everything in New York, from the police to the hot dog vendors. First Mr Giuliani, aged 55, said he had prostate cancer; barely a week later he announced that he was splitting from his wife of 16 years - apparently without telling her in advance.

But perhaps the most damage to his prospects was done when his wife, Donna Hanover, a television personality and film actor, alleged that he had an affair three years earlier with his press secretary.

"The mayor's campaign was over the moment Donna Hanover said that," said Kevin McAuliffe, a former Giuliani speech-writer and the editor of The Sayings of Generalissimo Giuliani.

The affair was denied but seemed to imply that the mayor had breached the line he had previously drawn between his private and public lives. The departure of the mayor, who in seven years has presided over a cut in crime in the city of more than 60%, appeared on the face of it to be a huge fillip for the Democrats.

Polls had shown that four out of five New Yorkers cared nothing for Mr Giuliani's private life - and that Mrs Clinton had failed to build a lead over him.

She limited her reaction to saying: "I have absolutely no control or say over what happens on the other side."

Previously unpublished poll figures show that, up against any one of six Republicans, crucial voting blocs in New York state are against her. They say that 41.3% of Jewish voters, 52.7% of whites and 55.9% of suburban voterswould not back her under any circumstances.

Some believe that, deprived of one of the two polarising candidates, the November election will become all about Mrs Clinton, who is ritually abused by many as a self-seeking outsider.

Rick Lazio, a fresh-faced congressman from Long Island, is the hot favourite to step in and make a late start against Mrs Clinton, who has been campaigning for the better part of a year.

Mr Lazio, who is to the right of Mr Giuliani, showed an interest in challenging the mayor for the Republican nomination until he was warned off by the party leadership.

Peter King, the Sinn Fein-supporting, novel-writing maverick from Nassau County, said that he too would like to run.

But he angered the party's establishment by enthusiastically backing Senator John McCain against George W Bush for the presidential nomination.

webTitle: Cherie Blair in hospital as birth appears imminent

fields.headline: Cherie Blair in hospital as birth appears imminent
fields.standfirst: Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Speculation grew last night that the much-heralded Blair baby may arrive this morning, after Cherie Blair, the prime minister's wife, checked into London's Chelsea and Westminster hospital amid a fever of media excitement.
fields.body:
Speculation grew last night that the much-heralded Blair baby may arrive this morning, after Cherie Blair, the prime minister's wife, checked into London's Chelsea and Westminster hospital amid a fever of media excitement.

Mrs Blair, whose official due date is next Wednesday, made her way from Downing Street to the hospital yesterday morning in a silver Ford Galaxy which was later driven away, prompting the conclusion that she had been admitted ready for the birth.

No 10 sources were reduced to insisting they had no plans "to give a running commentary on the birth" as pressure for information on the imminent arrival mounted.

Six months after news of the pregnancy leaked out, the focus on the new addition to the first family - an unexpected fourth child for Tony and Cherie Blair - has reached fever pitch, with presents and cards beginning to pile up in Downing Street.

Reporters and photographers have kept vigil at the hospital all week, particularly since Mrs Blair, 45, visited briefly late on Wednesday evening after experiencing "some discomfort", according to No 10 sources.

Mrs Blair set off for the hospital from a Downing Street side entrance shortly after 11am in a journey officials initially claimed was not connected to the birth of the baby. She arrived at the hospital avoiding waiting photographers and reporters, and was escorted to the maternity unit on the third floor.

Mr Blair, meanwhile, arrived at the hospital at 8.42pm after working at Downing Street during the day.

There was speculation last night that Mrs Blair would have a caesarean section this morning. Earlier this year, the fertility expert and Labour peer Lord Winston disclosed the hospital the Blairs had chosen and suggested the baby would be born by caesarean.

The baby will swiftly be exposed to the full glare of publicity previouly encountered only by royal offspring.

The Blairs, who make a point of their desire to preserve the privacy of their children Euan, 16, Nicky, 14 and Kathryn, 12, have said there will be only one official photo opportunity to record the arrival of their son or daughter.

However, while the family has in the past invoked the press watchdog or even court injunctions to prevent media intrusion, there is no doubt that the infant will also provide a welcome political boost for a prime minister suddenly struggling in the opinion polls.

Mr Blair referred to the baby during question time in the Commons for the first time last week, in answer to a question on parenting, and it is certain the child will feature in the media as the next general election approaches.

Mrs Blair, who earlier this week appeared in the high court to represent the TUC in a court challenge to the government on parental leave regulations, will also face scrutiny over every decision, from whether she sticks by her plan to use real nappies rather than disposables to the childcare arrangements she makes and how soon she returns to work.

The baby will make Mr Blair the first prime minister for 150 years to have fathered a child while in office. The last was the whig Lord John Russell whose son George Gilbert William Russell was born in 1848 during the first of his father's two periods as prime minister. The last prime minister to have children as young as the Blairs' was Herbert Asquith, who had an 11-year-old daughter and five-year-old son when he became prime minister in 1908.

Downing Street and the hospital yesterday refused to confirm that Mrs Blair was inside but a well-planned police operation gave the game away when they began erecting barricades at both entrances of the hospital.

On the third floor, security was tight. A man who had been visiting his daughter in the maternity unit said Special Branch officers were checking visitors as they went in and out.

fields.headline: The Goldman show
fields.standfirst: William Goldman is the ultimate Hollywood screenwriter, and he has a theory to explain every aspect of movie-making, too. If only his own life had followed the script... Suzie Mackenzie plays out a reel or two with him
fields.trailText: William Goldman is the ultimate Hollywood screenwriter, and he has a theory to explain every aspect of movie-making, too. If only his own life had followed the script... Suzie Mackenzie plays out a reel or two with him
fields.body:
Every Hollywood script will possess a number of what are known as "character scenes", scenes that propel the action through revelation of character. (Of course, any dramatic work will necessarily include these - only in Hollywood are they given their own special name.) These scenes are immensely useful, being both dramatic and economic. The scene in Thelma & Louise, where Thelma shoots the guy in the parking lot, is a classic "character scene" - it spins the action in a new direction, tells us a lot about Thelma and hints at something dark and pervasive in her past. Ditto Kathy Bates's infamous ankle-breaking scene in William Goldman's screen adapt-ation of Stephen King's Misery. If we hadn't worked it out before, we now know that James Caan's character is in deep shit.

But character scenes don't have to be violent, they can be fleeting, subtle, point to something, some particular obsession, say, that you're going to need to pick up elsewhere in the script. What follows is a "character scene" from my meeting with William Goldman in his baronial penthouse apartment in New York. The apartment is the former home of the late Clare Boothe Luce, playwright and editor and wife of publishing magnate Henry Luce, the founder and owner of Time, Fortune, Life, etc, and at one time one of the richest and most powerful men in America. So when I say baronial, I say it conservatively.

The meeting had been fun. Goldman had allotted me two hours in his busy schedule which, for anyone connected with Hollywood, is generous. And Goldman is a wonderful raconteur, gossipy, irreverent to just the right degree, plus he picks his targets well. I had really enjoyed the 10-minute treatise against Andrew Lloyd Webber, the man who "singlehandedly" destroyed Broadway with that "mock-opera shit he wrote". "But now that he's dead, I mean creatively dead, I really do believe Broadway may come back. Is that silly and sentimental of me?" He wanted to write a piece entitled The Death Of Andrew Lloyd Webber. "Not that I don't hope he lives another 50 years, makes more money, gets more acclaim... But creatively, he is finished. There may be a comeback but I doubt it. Even Cameron Mackintosh, one of the great producers of all time, can't save him now."

Goldman loves these big sweeping statements. His "theories". As in, "Let me give you my theory on..." According to his Lloyd Webber theory, all the talented kids who should have been writing for theatre were so disillusioned by "all that horseshit he put out for 15 years, from 1971-1986 when he was so powerful", that they went elsewhere, mostly into the movies. Which dovetails neatly into his theory on why movies are destroying culture. Bleeding all the talent from elsewhere while not providing any diversity of entertainment. "If you think of human experience as a pie, then the wedge Hollywood is reflecting now is getting smaller and smaller."

Sure this slightly contradicts his "big theory" - but who's to quibble? A good theory, like a good story well told, can run and run. "My big theory is this. We don't know why, but we know talent clusters. There were a lot of talented guys around in Russia at the turn of the 19th century; a lot of guys around Shakespeare; and in sixth-century Athens. It's always true, and in all the arts. When one guy's terrific, there will be a lot of other terrific guys around. And this last decade, the 90s, has been a period of very low talent."

This is great stuff, vintage Goldman. Unassailably correct, and delivered with that glibness that he has turned almost into a poetic art. "Hitchcock was not a great director, he was a great entertainer, and acknowledged as such until those French idiot auteurs like Truffaut came along looking to plump their own lives, looking for directors who had been ignored." It's his story, and he'll tell it the way he pleases, which is, to keep it simple, attend to the timing, edit out what he doesn't need.

Not for nothing is Goldman the highest paid script doctor in Hollywood, a reputed $1 million for four weeks' work. Doctoring, editing, working out how to make the story work, is his talent. And it is not a small talent. So I sat listening to his stories. Most of which I'd read before - in his book Adventures In The Screen Trade - or was about to read in his new book, More Adventures In The Screen Trade. Not that this spoils the stories. If a story's worth telling once, it's worth telling a hundred times.

And then this happened. Goldman suddenly, mid-sentence, mid-laugh, looked down at his Rolex, looked up at me and said in a crisp tone: "Fifteen minutes to go." Just that. Fair enough, he is a busy man, he'd been generous with his time and his knowledge. He then carried on jokily as if time were no imperative at all. Five minutes to go, he got up (I know this because I now looked at my watch), walked over to his desk, picked up two books, signed them, handed them to me and walked with me down the long corridor in the apartment that leads to his lift. Two minutes to go. Let's say, 20 seconds to walk to the lift, less than a minute for it to arrive and say a jolly goodbye, 10 seconds for me to get down. He's still a good 30 seconds within his schedule. And pacing it - frame by frame by frame.

Then, half way to the lift, the phone rings. And now he has a problem, because the phone is on the desk, 10 seconds there, 10 seconds back. Plus the conversation... he's way out of time. This is not in the script. What does he do? Look, he's a screenwriter and, as he so often has said, "In movie terms, that makes you the lowest creature on the food chain. And they don't look down there, not unless they want something." It could be Ridley Scott on the phone, it could be Spielberg. He has to answer that phone. If he's clever, jiggles about a bit, he can probably fit it in. He walks briskly back, picks up the phone, listens. Says, "No", and then "Yes". Puts down the phone. We get to the lift, it arrives... He's made it. On time and to budget.

It's a good scene and, to steal from Peter Sellers, if I were scripting it I wouldn't change a thing ...except maybe to have the lead played by Russell Crowe. No, it's a perfect scene. It reveals something that we have to know about this character to make sense of him. That he is, to quite an absurd degree, obsessed with time. I'd realised that he is an obsessive earlier when he showed me his walk-in closet with his laundered shirts tidied in piles according to colour. Think wardrobe department. And his kitchen, sparkling clean. Not surprisingly. In all the years he has lived here - "never been used." He's got the set, but he is not the cook. Sure enough, coffee is ordered in.

But now I know something else and it's crucial. He doesn't like to go outside the script. Remember the final frame of Butch Cassidy And The Sundance Kid, where the camera holds them, suspended in that moment before death, as if somehow this story, these characters, cannot end. We can't see them die because, if the movie works, we've fallen in love with these affable rascals. Their killing is not real killing - we don't care how many Bolivian peasants go up in smoke. In this script, Goldman's version, reality is conveniently out of shot.

Yep. It's all beginning to fit his story - in my version.

Why does someone become a writer? Out of need, Goldman says, "to get outside yourself." "To balance the playground see-saw." "Because I had the standard horse-shit upbringing." "Because I want someone to look at me and say, 'He's okay,' though I don't believe it." "I write out of revenge." Take your pick. And take it from him, he was not a born writer. When he was young he was a lousy writer, couldn't even get his stuff printed in the Oberlin College magazine. "And I was the fiction editor."

In 1953, aged 21, he got into Columbia University. "Through pull. I knew someone who worked there. My grades weren't good enough. I was a C-plus student." The self-deprecation is not phoney. He loves this idea of the underdog coming up trumps. The ugly duckling who turns into the swan. Bernstein and Woodward taking on the biggest power on the planet and winning. Come to think of it, he ends that story early also, mid-way through Watergate. The audience supplies the ending.

He started writing for the theatre, "three flops in two years", and fantasising about writing "The Great American Novel". It never occurred to him to write for movies. First, he didn't know there was such a thing as a screenwriter. "I thought the actors made up their lines." And, "Coming from where I came from, the Midwest, in the era I was born, the 30s, movies were glorious fun - Bette Davis dying or whatever. But whatever they were, they were not serious." Not art - and he was going to be an artist. Incidentally, he still maintains that it is generically impossible for a Hollywood movie to be art. "Inconceivable because a Hollywood movie is by definition expensive, $75 million on average, so they go for the lowest common denominator. To try to make a movie that people may actually go and see."

There followed the usual writer's trajectory. Failure, a bit of success when he was hired to write a screenplay of Flowers For Algernon, more failure when he was fired from that. "It was a shock, I'd never been fired before." He had never had a job before to be fired from. He is very endearing in this way. Loves his failures. "My successes I don't believe. I'll tell you my success theory one day."

There was a bit of teaching at Princeton, but he couldn't stand living outside New York so he moved his wife Ilene and two daughters back. And somewhere around this time, in between the firing and the publication of his "big" novel, Boys And Girls Together - the review in the New York Times said: "A child of nine could understand this book before he could lift it" - he had a really unusual bit of luck. In 1966, Paul Newman said yes to Harper, Goldman's screen adaptation of Ross Macdonald's detective thriller The Moving Target. It was a hit. So when Newman got hold of another Goldman script, then called The Sundance Kid And Butch Cassidy, he didn't says yes, but he did say: "If you ever rewrite this I'd like to take another look."

Every studio in Hollywood turned it down - you can imagine how Goldman loves this bit of the story. His agent, trying to be kind, told him he didn't want to send it out again "in the shape it's in". So it was auctioned. But by now, with not a word changed, it had undergone that mythic transformation from duckling to swan. It was sold for $400,000 - in the mid-60s this was three times the former record for a script. It made Goldman a legend and an object of envy and vilification overnight.

And so was conceived Goldman's other big theory. No one in Hollywood knows anything. Everything in Hollywood is fabrication, he says, with one single exception. "Word of mouth. Studios would love to be able to fabricate word of mouth, but so far they haven't found a way. They came pretty close with The Blair Witch Project. Don't believe that horseshit that it wasn't a Hollywood movie. Sometimes a movie is so well sold that they convince you it's not Hollywood. Easy Rider was another. You're supposed to believe it was made by these guys with love in their hearts. Total shit. That was a Hollywood movie."

Anyway, since nobody knows anything of what will work from one day to the next, "Hollywood is a pretty edgy place." Full of actors who don't know why they are famous. "Most of the time they are famous because they took a part that someone else turned down and the movie was unpredictably a hit." Full of studio executives who expect to be fired. "Two mistakes at $75 million and you are out. You enter your leper period. So they make stars they can pay a lot of money to because they think maybe stars will help them save their jobs." And full of directors who are scared. Mike Nichols has just directed "a monumental disaster". His previous movie didn't do well. "It's kind of a rule that directors lose it by 60 - rich, not listening anymore. Nichols is 68. And though I don't know the man, I guarantee you he is scared."

But it's not always performance related. "Here we enter the world of sex. Sometimes a studio will ordain some beautiful young man a star whether their record deserves it or not. Brad Pitt has been in flop after flop. Same as Gibson. Gere, for all his disasters, keeps getting work." But what's interesting is it doesn't work this way with female stars. "Take Rene Russo. Lethal Weapon 3. In The Line Of Fire. Get Shorty. All of them hits. Then she gets the lead in Buddy and it doesn't work. No more vehicle parts for her." Which, on reflection, suggests he's either forgotten The Thomas Crown Affair, or doesn't consider it a "vehicle".

His favourite Hollywood line is not one of his own but was told him by a studio head some years ago. (Actually I think Goldman is indulging in a bit of Hollywood fabrication here. That's a Goldman line if ever I heard one.)

If we hadn't worked it out before, we now know that James Caan's character is in deep shit. webTitle: It's just a boys club, says quitting Labour MP

fields.headline: It's just a boys club, says quitting Labour MP
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The failure of Tony Blair's administration to act on pledges to reform House of Commons hours was highlighted last night when one of the record new intake of female MPs announced she was standing down at the next election.
fields.body:
The failure of Tony Blair's administration to act on pledges to reform House of Commons hours was highlighted last night when one of the record new intake of female MPs announced she was standing down at the next election.

Tess Kingham last night confirmed to party members in her Gloucester constituency that she would not seek reselection after becoming disillusioned with parliamentary life in her three years as an MP.

She said: "I wish to work in a modern parliament that enables me to deliver the best for the people of Gloucester. I do not want to work in a gentleman's club.

"The practices and culture of parliament are suited to a 19th century institution when well-heeled men did a day job then popped along to the Commons to do a bit of politics and enjoy the restaurants and bars.

"The job of an MP in the 21st century is totally different. Constituents demand more from their representatives."

Although she said her decision had not been influenced by the birth in January of her twins Karl and Natasha, the lack of facilities at Westminster clearly played a part.

"The lack of child care facilities does make life difficult for any MP with children, as it does for the thousands of staff at Westminster," she said. "But it is not the main reason I intend to leave parliament."

The Palace of Westminster has no creche, no allocated place to feed babies and no dedicated facilities for the children of MPs or staff.

Ms Kingham, who also has a four-year-old daughter, Rosa, recently joined the Swindon South MP Julia Drown to call for childcare in parliament

She said: "I do not mind working long hours and sitting in debates all night if they are a worthwhile contribution to democracy. To debate the minimum wage, Kosovo, trade union rights or other important matters of genuine political disagreement is stimulating and worthwhile.

"That is what MPs are there for. Unfortunately, much of the late night debating in parliament is not worthwhile. I am not willing to sit up all night for schoolboy politics.

"The little boys who indulge in this may think it is 'a laugh', but to me it is insulting to my constituents and no way to govern in the 21st century."

Her case highlights a growing number of MPs at Westminster who have attacked the hours and conditions in the Commons amid growing disappointment at the unwillingness of senior party figures to push for real reform.

In yesterday's Guardian, the Labour MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, Oona King, warned that her colleague's decision to stand down should not be read as "proof that women with young children can't cope with Westminster". She wrote: "In fact, it highlights the more significant point that Westminster can't cope with well-balanced human beings."

The Labour backbencher Harriet Harman argues that the Commons could start sitting early in the day and finish at 7pm or even earlier without losing business time.

The argument against such rescheduling holds that it is supported only by London MPs who can then go home in the evenings.

The Labour chief whip, Ann Taylor, and the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, are widely seen by disenchanted party colleagues as key forces blocking reform, but both claim that moves to change the Commons timetabling on Thursdays for an early start and finish must bed down before further reform can be considered.

"The lack of child care facilities does make life difficult for any MP with children, as it does for the thousands of staff at Westminster," she said. "But it is not the main reason I intend to leave parliament." The Palace of Westminster has no creche, no allocated place to feed babies and no dedicated facilities for the children of MPs or staff. Ms Kingham, who also has a four-year-old daughter, Rosa, recently joined the Swindon South MP Julia Drown to call for childcare in parliament She said: "I do not mind working long hours and sitting in debates all night if they are a worthwhile contribution to democracy. To debate the minimum wage, Kosovo, trade union rights or other important matters of genuine political disagreement is stimulating and worthwhile. "That is what MPs are there for. Unfortunately, much of the late night debating in parliament is not worthwhile. I am not willing to sit up all night for schoolboy politics. "The little boys who indulge in this may think it is 'a laugh', but to me it is insulting to my constituents and no way to govern in the 21st century." Her case highlights a growing number of MPs at Westminster who have attacked the hours and conditions in the Commons amid growing disappointment at the unwillingness of senior party figures to push for real reform. In yesterday's Guardian, the Labour MP for Bethnal Green and Bow, Oona King, warned that her colleague's decision to stand down should not be read as "proof that women with young children can't cope with Westminster". She wrote: "In fact, it highlights the more significant point that Westminster can't cope with well-balanced human beings." The Labour backbencher Harriet Harman argues that the Commons could start sitting early in the day and finish at 7pm or even earlier without losing business time. The argument against such rescheduling holds that it is supported only by London MPs who can then go home in the evenings. The Labour chief whip, Ann Taylor, and the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, are widely seen by disenchanted party colleagues as key forces blocking reform, but both claim that moves to change the Commons timetabling on Thursdays for an early start and finish must bed down before further reform can be considered.

fields.headline: Homo rapiens
fields.standfirst:
Charles's adviser spells out the prince's philosophy and warns off the scientists

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: So what does the word "sacred" do for you? Does it induce a nice warm glow, or bring on an instant fit of apoplectic rage? To a man, it's the rage that seized the great and the good of the UK's scientific establishment when Prince Charles chose to organise his contribution to the Reith Lectures around the simple notion of rediscovering a "sense of the sacred".
fields.body:
So what does the word "sacred" do for you? Does it induce a nice warm glow, or bring on an instant fit of apoplectic rage? To a man, it's the rage that seized the great and the good of the UK's scientific establishment when Prince Charles chose to organise his contribution to the Reith Lectures around the simple notion of rediscovering a "sense of the sacred".

Richard Dawkins dismissed this as "mumbo-jumbo". Lewis Wolpert saw it as nothing more than an outbreak of New Age superstition. Walter Bodmer likened Prince Charles to a Dalek: "This sort of comment reminds me of how the Daleks from Dr Who, when they were confronted with rationality, burned up".

Such personal insults and intellectually vapid outrage are nothing new. From its inception in the early 1970s, the modern environment movement has always had an influential spiritual dimension to it, which has been deeply suspect in the eyes of most scientists.

There have always been two parts to this. The first is deeply pragmatic. Given that we go on destroying the world even though we now know for a fact that we're destroying it, the politics of "enlightened self-interest" (ie protect the environment in order to protect ourselves) has clearly been found wanting. We must therefore dig deeper into the human psyche, tap into those value systems which tell us this is either an affront to our own humanity (for those who don't actually believe in God) or an affront to God (for those who do).

The second part is more a journey of interdenominational discovery. Every one of the world's major religions or faiths has within it what might be described as "an environmental ethic", based either on the notion of a creator God or the inherently sacred nature of all life on earth. Add to that a wide diversity of less formal spiritual sensibilities (on the part of those who are not adherents of any major religion, but who still seek a deeper meaning in life than that provided by scientific materialism), and you end up with a very rich tapestry indeed. That does not make environmentalism "a new religion"; it simply encourages us to re-examine our traditional belief systems to draw out that environmental ethic from each.

Yet far from seeing such concepts as a creator God, or our "sacred trust" in acting as stewards of creation, as relatively orthodox aspects of the core teaching of Christianity and other faiths, many leading scientists have branded Prince Charles's Reith Lecture as an expression of neo-paganism or "extreme mysticism". So when Pope John Paul II declared (as he did in 1990 in Peace With God The Creator, Peace With All Creation) that "Christians in particular realise that their responsibility within creation and their duty towards nature and the Creator are an essential part of their faith", did that reveal him as some tree-hugging spiritualist? When the eminent Islamic scholar, Seyyed Hossein Nasr, reminds us that "it is not only human beings who sing the praise of God - everything has its own tongue with which it praises him, everything sings the praise of God by virtue of its very existence", does that brand him as a New Age mystic?

There is a world of difference between pantheism (in which the divine is seen to reside in nature itself, leading some people to "worship" nature in the form of forests or mountains) and panentheism in which it is God that is seen to reside in nature, to be revealed through every twist and turn of evolution. If Prince Charles was a pantheist (which he is not), then Chief Rabbi Jonathan Sacks and other religious leaders would find it hard to leap to his defence as they have done.

But as John Durant (professor of public understanding of science at Imperial College) rightly points out, Prince Charles went further in implicitly arguing that a religious/spiritual approach to the natural world (based on "a greater respect for the genius of nature's designs, rigorously tested and refined over millions of years") must automatically entail a rejection of genetic engineering and other technologies which threaten to transform nature irreversibly. Many take issue with him on this point, arguing that we have always intervened in nature, often irreversibly, and that without those interventions (agricultural, medical, industrial), life would be a lot nastier than it is today.

If managed and regulated properly, they argue, there is no reason why GM crops should not bring as great a range of benefits to humankind as the selectively bred crop types on which all farmers (including organic farmers like Prince Charles!) currently depend. This is a debate which will run and run. But what is so disturbing is that so many of his scientific critics seem to challenge the very notion that there is an ethical/spiritual aspect to the debate at all.

As we march off boldly into a genetically engineered future, the moral and ethical issues will get more and more pressing. The "hard lines" between different organisms and species are beginning to melt away; we can now pick and choose individual genes from one organism to introduce into a totally different and unrelated organism, crossing all biological boundaries, in combinations that nature never could and never would bring together. As Jeremy Rifkin points out in The Biotech Century, "living things are no longer perceived as birds and bees, foxes and hens, but as bundles of genetic information. There is no longer any question of sacredness or specialness. How could there be, when there are no longer any recognisable boundaries to respect? How can any living thing be deemed sacred when it is just a pattern of information?"

That's what lies at the heart of Prince Charles's concerns about both genetic engineering and modern science in general. In his Reith Lecture he quotes from the philosopher Philip Sherrard, who argued that the crisis we face today is not in essence an ecological one, but a crisis in the way we think. We treat Planet Earth in this destructive, godforsaken way because we see things in a destructive, godforsaken way. And we see things that way because that's how scientists have taught us to see ourselves: as random, purposeless bipeds, with an inherently destructive nature arising from our genetic inheritance.

Having systematically "desacralised" ourselves (ie ceased to think of ourselves as sacred beings), we have had little difficulty desacralising the world around us, evolving a world view that strips the earth and its creatures of any sacred significance, reducing our natural inheritance to a bank of exploitable assets uniquely available to Homo rapiens.

Which must surely make for a worthy contribution to a series of lectures about sustainable development, as Prince Charles has just demonstrated. But how sad that all our scientific gurus can come up with is invective and arrogant scorn.

Jonathon Porritt is a programme director of Forum for the Future; his book Playing Safe: Science and the Environment, will be published on May 29 by Thames & Hudson (£6.95)

fields.headline: No surrender - please
fields.standfirst:
It seems Unionists fear the IRA has gone too far in demonstrating that the war is over

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Because David Trimble appears to be slightly less unreasonable than others in his party, he has acquired a reputation for tremendous statesmanship. It is imagined that he has made a hugely difficult step in sitting down with men of violence.
fields.body:
Because David Trimble appears to be slightly less unreasonable than others in his party, he has acquired a reputation for tremendous statesmanship. It is imagined that he has made a hugely difficult step in sitting down with men of violence.

And yet he had no problem sitting down with the mass murderer Billy Wright. Conversely, he has never even sent his condolences to Desmond and Jessica Hamill, whose son Robert was kicked to death for being a Roman Catholic in 1997. Mr and Mrs Hamill are supporters of the SDLP, which we are forever told is "moderate". So they would fall into the category of non-threatening Catholics; but perhaps it is too much to expect their MP to show any interest in their son's murder.

Ken Maginnis, Trimble's blustering sidekick, is the parliamentary spokesman of the Northern Ireland Police Federation. He describes Robert as a "republican propaganda case". Asked on Radio 5 in January about the decision by the director of public prosecutions not to press charges against officers who had threatened the late Rosemary Nelson, Maginnis immediately changed the subject to speak about "a man called Hamill who was beaten to death by a mob in Portadown - or who was injured and subsequently died".

It would appear that, in Maginnis's book, leaving someone fatally injured must be distinguished from finishing them off there and then. Or perhaps we are to infer that Robert's refusal to die for 12 days was politically motivated. Anyway, Maginnis went on to allege that Rosemary, who represented the Hamill family, had for some reason scuppered the murder inquiry by silencing witnesses from "the republican side" (Catholic bystanders). Clarification of Maginnis's interpretation of the act of murder came when he addressed students in north London a few weeks ago. Fortunately, his ramblings were caught on video, but an effort to interest Channel 4 News in the story failed and the family decided their best bet was to give the tape to the Irish News in Belfast, which ran the story last weekend. Either Maginnis has taken a blurred peek at the coroner's report or his sponsoring union gave him their own misreading of it, but he saw fit to accuse the medical staff who fought to save Robert of misdiagnosis.

In fact, the only misdiagnosis that took place was that, until the autopsy, it could not have been known that he hadn't a chance of surviving. Clearly, health service money was wasted.

Maginnis does not like seeing public money spent on Robert Hamill; he has complained about the cost to the Northern Ireland Office of answering MPs' questions about the murder. Maginnis, who claims to have produced a report on the case, vindicating the four RUC officers who were 20 yards from Robert during a prolonged and savage beating, says that "a bone behind his eye caused a brain haemorrhage and he died".

What the post mortem says is that a skull fracture ended behind the eye where the bone is relatively thin. Anyone wanting to absolve police officers will seize on something like that as a way of blaming the victim.

Unfortunately for Maginnis, everyone's skull is like that. As for his claim that Robert was sitting up in bed chatting until this mysterious haemorrhage that the coroner must have missed, all the hospital staff who have testified that Robert never regained consciousness must be republican troublemakers.

You might think it pointless to bang on about Ulster Unionists' behaviour but my point is that Trimble and Maginnis are supposed to be the ones we can do business with. The whole peace process has descended into a battle by Britain to keep at the head of their party the two members of it who are considered to be bordering on sanity.

It is hoped that they are genuine in at least wanting the peace to have a chance of holding. The rejectionists want the agreement to fail at all costs. This might be because the thought of sharing power with any nationalist is as repugnant to them now as it was at the time of Sunningdale. It might be because a state of war serves a rightwing ideology that has nothing to offer working class protestants. Or it might be that the IRA has gone too far in demonstrating that the war is over. If Unionists think it's surrendered, there's no need to concede anything.

Such people are so scary that the British government is disbanding the Patten report to swing support behind Trimble. Now, it has been announced that no officers will be disciplined for making threats against Rosemary. We have yet to hear about disciplinary action in Robert's case.

The government has said that there can be no public inquiry in either case until all proceedings are completed. But the real reason is that justice is hostage to the political careers of David Trimble and Ken Maginnis.

webTitle: Nothing's new in the world of art

fields.headline: Nothing's new in the world of art
fields.standfirst: Today's hand-me-down culture is sheer laziness. Try original, Damien
fields.trailText: Like the works of art they describe, critical adjectives have their time. "Controversial" was over-worked in the liberating 60s and 70s, "wry" in the ironic 80s, "confessional" in the tell-all decade of the 90s. But one particular word of praise lies rusted at the bottom of the reviewer's tool bag.
fields.body:
Like the works of art they describe, critical adjectives have their time. "Controversial" was over-worked in the liberating 60s and 70s, "wry" in the ironic 80s, "confessional" in the tell-all decade of the 90s. But one particular word of praise lies rusted at the bottom of the reviewer's tool bag.

"Original" is almost a sin for modern critics whose work is to provide a check-list of references, to elucidate the experience of déjà vu. To what extent does Gladiator improve on the earlier Roman epics, Ben Hur and Spartacus? In borrowing wholesale the plot of Noel Coward's Private Lives for her novel Honeymoon, will Amy Jenkins match the commercial success of Bridget Jones's Diary, the main inspiration for its prose style? Hearts And Bones wants to be the BBC's answer to ITV's Cold Feet - is it?

The view that there is no interest in - or possibility of - originality in the arts was further encouraged this week. Damien Hirst has made contributions to charity to settle legal action by the makers of a children's toy which inspired Hymn, a sculpture he sold for £1m. And the chair of the judges of the Betty Trask Award, a literary prize for young writers, complained that the bulk of the entries were merely opportunistic imitations of previous successes, including Bridget Jones's Diary.

Some academics are charitable towards these cultural hand-me-downs. Making standard tactical reference to Shakespeare's use of borrowed plots, they argue that the millions of creative minds so far born have exhausted all the possible forms and contents. Being an artist in the 21st century is like living in a listed building. You can only make minor changes because the original features are what people want to see. Where Shakespeare created his own Troilus, Ridley Scott offers us his take on Ben Hur.

Recent technology makes this excuse more persuasive. Familiarity with the achievements of the past is almost inevitably greater in the creatives of today. A movie director starting out in the 40s or 50s would have required a private income and a long illness to have seen his five favourite movies 100 times each. But video has made it almost routine for a young film-maker to turn up clutching his stack of cherished cassettes fizzing at the edges from serial replay. Writers are similarly more sensitive to history because the internet makes available a dismaying weight of the novels, plays and poems of the past. It is therefore the opposite of dishonesty to acknowledge this by quotation, sampling, homage.

An allied defence - especially for artists such as Hirst - is the artistic history of the use of found objects. In this sense, his only mistake was to fail to realise the difference between a shark and something designed and copyrighted by another artist. Most cultural borrowings, though, are the result not of artistic subtlety but commercial cynicism. The increasing pressure of the market - particularly in television, cinema and book publishing - reduces the tolerance of risk and failure.

This bias towards the recycled idea is intensified by the way most major movies, television shows and commercial novels are now commissioned. The "pitch" is a Hollywood tradition in which an idea is described in a few lines, with inevitable reference to recognisable predecessors. It's Harry Met Sally but she's an alien. It's Brief Encounter but they're gay.

Internet booksellers include a device headed "If you like that, you'll like this". But, without admitting the trick to customers, the majority of mainstream culture now operates on the same system.

And yet originality remains possible. Spike Jonze's movie Being John Malkovich and Mary Harron's American Psycho never remind you of anyone else's. Their approach and tone is their own. Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides (released this week) looks like a lot of other movies but the 1993 novel on which it was based - by Jeffrey Eugenides - had no obvious literary paternity, even finding a technical device (group narration in the first person plural) which read-all critics found fresh. At the new Tate Modern last week, the single work attracting most attention was Juan Munios's Towards the Corner: a group of old men on terraced benches, laughing at an unseen event. It is a genuinely fresh image although one which, in the modern way of things, will be rapidly borrowed by advertisers and other artists with or without attribution.

Martin Amis's memoir Experience - though acknowledging a debt to Nabokov's Speak, Memory - is, in structure and expression, a genuinely original book, despite edging dangerously late on to the groaning shelf marked Confession. Both Martin Amis and his father Kingsley drew on a tradition of comic writing but built extensions to the house, did their own decorations and renovations. But much of what calls itself creativity today is simply squatting in someone else's construction. The authorities - whether the actual Arts Council or a metaphorical one - should kick them out. Artists should know the past of their form without being paralysed by ideas already had. It's merely laziness to say that no modern work can be beyond compare.

Sofia Coppola's The Virgin Suicides (released this week) looks like a lot of other movies but the 1993 novel on which it was based - by Jeffrey Eugenides - had no obvious literary paternity, even finding a technical device (group narration in the first person plural) which read-all critics found fresh. At the new Tate Modern last week, the single work attracting most attention was Juan Munios's Towards the Corner: a group of old men on terraced benches, laughing at an unseen event. It is a genuinely fresh image although one which, in the modern way of things, will be rapidly borrowed by advertisers and other artists with or without attribution. Martin Amis's memoir Experience - though acknowledging a debt to Nabokov's Speak, Memory - is, in structure and expression, a genuinely original book, despite edging dangerously late on to the groaning shelf marked Confession. Both Martin Amis and his father Kingsley drew on a tradition of comic writing but built extensions to the house, did their own decorations and renovations. But much of what calls itself creativity today is simply squatting in someone else's construction. The authorities - whether the actual Arts Council or a metaphorical one - should kick them out. Artists should know the past of their form without being paralysed by ideas already had. It's merely laziness to say that no modern work can be beyond compare. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: MPs want to test critical views in public

fields.headline: MPs want to test critical views in public
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: MPs are set to invite the Prince of Wales to explain his highly critical views on genetic modification to a Commons select committee, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
MPs are set to invite the Prince of Wales to explain his highly critical views on genetic modification to a Commons select committee, it emerged yesterday.

In a rare step, members of the all-party science and technology committee agreed to issue the invitation after the prince spoke out in favour of working "with the grain of nature" rather than manipulating it.

One Labour MP insisted the prince should answer the committee's call to explain the "green mysticism" he claimed lay behind the prince's views. Nigel Beard, a member of the committee until recently, argued that Prince Charles should not be permitted to make controversial statements and then hide behind a cloak of privilege when MPs sought to hold him to account.

However, St James's palace yesterday played down the prospect that the prince would accept the invitation, saying it would be unprecedented for a member of the royal family to appear before a select committee.

In the Commons, committee sources suggested that the MPs would have no power to compel the prince to appear. While committees can summon some witnesses, a string of categories of people are exempt, including members of the Lords and Commons, foreign nationals and members of the royal family.

As with much Commons procedure, such issues rely more on precedent than formal rules, but the source said: "As far as I am aware, nothing can compel him to come."

Ian Gibson, the Labour MP for Norwich North, also told Radio 4's World at One programme that the committee had resolved to invite the prince to speak to it.

"Prince Charles has for some time now been taking an interest in public affairs which is indeed welcome, particularly in GM crops," he said. He should now give evidence to the committee.

Asked whether he thought the prince was adopting an "anti-science line", Dr Gibson replied: "Yes, I certainly do."

The committee's request coincides with growing outrage over the disclosure that hundreds of farms have been planted with oil-seed rape containing GM seeds.

Labour backbencher Alan Simpson - a leading voice in questioning the advance of GM technology - yesterday joined calls on the government to destroy the crops.

Ministers are resisting pressure, with officials suggesting the government does not have the power to order crop destruction since there is no risk to human health or the countryside.

webTitle: One day he will be king. But what does he really believe in?

fields.headline: One day he will be king. But what does he really believe in?
fields.standfirst:
Prince's luxury lifestyle conflicts with image of ascetic and reluctant royal

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince Charles spent the days leading up to his latest diatribe against "scientific rationalism" in suitably ancient, low-tech, ascetic surroundings: the remote Greek Orthodox complex of monasteries on Mount Athos, where he slept in a dormitory and read by the light of an oil lamp.
fields.body:
Prince Charles spent the days leading up to his latest diatribe against "scientific rationalism" in suitably ancient, low-tech, ascetic surroundings: the remote Greek Orthodox complex of monasteries on Mount Athos, where he slept in a dormitory and read by the light of an oil lamp.

He arrived there in very different style - on board the third biggest luxury yacht in the world, the Alexander, plaything of his friend, the elderly Greek shipping tycoon John Latsis. The Alexander comes equipped with ballroom, two speedboats and a helicopter. For a man as concerned as Prince Charles with sustainable development - the theme of his controversial BBC lecture this week - this emblem of conspicuous consumption seemed to jar with his heartfelt plea for mankind to "work with the grain of nature".

What does the future Charles III believe? Is there a coherence to his views on science, tradition, the sacred, architecture, education, or is he simply a confused individual, struggling to reconcile his sense of royal majesty, his material desires and his apparent yearning for a life of solitary spiritual contemplation?

"I don't think he's quite sure where he is," said one Anglican cleric who knows the prince. "He's struggling to discover the roots of his spirituality and where it's going to lead him, and struggling as well to place spirituality and faith alongside his public and private life."

The prince caused uproar among the scientific community this week when he launched a broad attack on modern rationalist society, saying the "sacred trust between mankind and the creator" for man's "duty of stewardship of the earth" was being "smothered by almost impenetrable layers of scientific rationalism".

In fact, the theme was one Prince Charles has been publicly preoccupied with since 1982, when he chided the British Medical Association for modern medicine's obsession with cells and molecules at the expense of "traditional", holistic medicine.

More obnoxious to mainstream scientists was his 1996 accusation that science had tried to assume a "tyranny over our understanding". Perhaps most disturbing of all for the rationalists was his 1993 speech at the Oxford Centre for Islamic Studies, when he effectively accused his own faith of surrendering the world to science at the time of the Renaissance.

"At the core of Christianity there still lies an integral view of the sanctity of the world, and a clear sense of the trusteeship and responsibility given to us for our natural surroundings," he said. "But the west gradually lost this integrated vision of the world with Copernicus and Descartes and the coming of the scientific revolution."

Despite his wish to be known as "defender of faith" rather than defender of the Anglican faith on inheriting the throne, the prince loyally attends Anglican services. But he has compared main stream British Christianity and humanism unfavourably with more "traditionalist" religions like Islam, Buddhism, Hinduism and Jainism.

Friends and acquaintances deny that he is anti-science. "Remember, he also patronises quite a lot of scientific or quasi-scientific technical organisations," said one of his biographers, Jonathan Dimbleby. "I think what he has is a healthy disrespect for what he sees as scientific arrogance."

Many environmentalists have embraced the prince's message, and his calls to respect tradition and ancient wisdom, in architecture as well as in agriculture and medicine, have struck a chord with a British public, left, right or green, inherently suspicious of scientists.

What remains a mystery is the prince's beliefs about his own role in the world, as future hereditary head of state.

He is often portrayed by friends as a reluctant royal, one who would prefer to retreat from the world to live the life of a philosopher, quietly reading, gardening and painting. Yet all the intellectual ideas of his speeches - the importance of tradition, respect for ancient wisdom, a God-given natural order - are arguments used by monarchs for centuries to justify their own privileged place in the social order.

"He's traditional partly because of who and what he is, and also his traditional feelings about religion are because of who and what he is," said another biographer, Penny Junor.

But others say that the contradictions between his message and lifestyle bother him less and less. "I think there are tensions within the same person which are more resolved now than they were say 10 years ago," said one observer close to the prince. "The urge I'm sure he's had from time to time to escape from it all is now well under control, now more than ever."
