fields.headline: Nature's champion
fields.standfirst:
From folk healers to controlled explosions

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Through the centuries, healing has been practised by folk healers who are guided by traditional wisdom... No one could be stupid enough to deny the enormous benefits which the advances of medical science in this century have conferred... the fact remains that contemporary medicine as a whole tends to be fascinated by the objective, statistical, computerised approach to the healing of the sick.
fields.body:
Through the centuries, healing has been practised by folk healers who are guided by traditional wisdom... No one could be stupid enough to deny the enormous benefits which the advances of medical science in this century have conferred... the fact remains that contemporary medicine as a whole tends to be fascinated by the objective, statistical, computerised approach to the healing of the sick.

- speech marking 150th anniversary of the British Medical Association, 1982

At the core of Christianity there still lies an integral view of the sanctity of the world, and a clear sense of the trusteeship and responsibility given to us for our natural surroundings. But the west gradually lost this integrated vision of the world with Copernicus and Descartes and the coming of the scientific revolution.

- speech at Oxford Centre for Islamic Studies, 1993

It is as if tradition represented the enemy of man's lofty ambition; the "primitive" force which acts as an unwelcome reminder, deep in our subconscious, of the ultimate folly of believing that the purpose and meaning of life on this earth lie in creating a material form of utopia - a world in which technology becomes a "virtual reality" god; the arbiter of virtual reality ethics - and thus the eventual murderer of the soul of mankind.

Tradition reflects the timeless order, and yet disorder, of the cosmos and anchors us into a harmonious relationship with the great mysteries of the universe. Some scientists claim to have discovered the origins of the universe and explain it all quite confidently in terms of a big bang.

If it was a big bang, then I suggest it was a controlled explosion.

- speech to InvestCorp dinner, July 1996

During the last three centuries, in the western world at least, a dangerous division has come into being in the way we perceive the world around us. Science has tried to assume a monopoly - even a tyranny - over our understanding. Religion and science have become separated... Science has attempted to take over the natural world from God.

- speech on building bridges between Islam and the west, December 1996

We should show greater respect for the genius of nature's designs... refined over millions of years. This means being careful to use science to understand how nature works, not to change what nature is, as we do when genetic manipulation seeks to transform the process of biological evolution into something altogether different.

- BBC lecture, 2000

webTitle: Boyfriend of Ashia Hansen arrested over 'race attack'

fields.headline: Boyfriend of Ashia Hansen arrested over 'race attack'
fields.trailText: The boyfriend of the black international athlete Ashia Hansen was yesterday arrested in connection with an alleged racial attack in which he was stabbed in the back and slashed across the forehead.
fields.body:
The boyfriend of the black international athlete Ashia Hansen was yesterday arrested in connection with an alleged racial attack in which he was stabbed in the back and slashed across the forehead.

Chris Cotter, 28, whose girlfriend is a gold medal prospect at this summer's Olympic Games in Sydney, told police that he was attacked by at least four men near her Birmingham home in March. He said they told him: "We warned you not to mix with niggers."

Mr Cotter, who is white, was arrested along with two other men yesterday by West Midlands police who said they were no longer treating the incident, which prompted a public outcry and a review of safety procedures for black athletes, as racially motivated. The men were expected to be held overnight.

A police spokesman said: "We can confirm that we have today arrested three people in connection with the attack on Mr Cotter. Detectives are currently interviewing them in relation to this serious matter."

Mr Cotter, an insurance worker and former triple jumper, told how, on March 21, he was approached by a man in a duffle coat and black woollen hat who was joined by other men after he had made racist remarks. He said: "They were swearing at me, calling me a nigger lover. It was only when I saw the blood that I realised I had been stabbed."

Two days after the attack, Ms Hansen received a letter from a racist group telling her she was "lucky". Three prominent black male athletics internationals were also sent hate mail demanding that they withdrew from the Olympics.

At the beginning of April, Ms Hansen's car was broken into and her belongings were scattered across nearby streets.

Ms Hansen's agent, Sue Barrett, said last night: "Ashia is not willing to talk to anyone about this incident. She may be releasing a statement after the weekend."

fields.headline: Rebels target British troops
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: Rebels in Sierra Leone are targeting British troops for attack in the belief that causing casualties among the 800-strong UK contingent there will force it to withdraw, according to military officials.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Freetown and  Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
Rebels in Sierra Leone are targeting British troops for attack in the belief that causing casualties among the 800-strong UK contingent there will force it to withdraw, according to military officials.

The inhabitants of several villages in the Port Loko area, where the parachute regiment is deployed, have been interrogated by Revolutionary United Front patrols demanding to know the whereabouts and movements of British troops. Rebels have told villagers that they wanted to kill or capture British soldiers.

While defence sources in London yesterday claimed that the rebels were being driven "well back" into the country, intelligence reports reaching Freetown estimate that as many as 1,000 RUF fighters are moving around in territory to the west and south of Port Loko, which is about 40 miles north-east of the capital.

"The RUF are on the back foot and we believe they are desperate to get us out of here," said a senior military source in Freetown. "There is very strong information indicating that is what they are now trying to do."

He added that the RUF strategy was based on the 1994 intervention in Somalia, where US troops pulled out after the death of 18 soldiers and television pictures of American servicemen being beaten and dragged through the streets of Mogadishu undermined public support for the action.

Ministers must now decide whether to pull out or allow British forces to be sucked into the civil war.

The army is not keen to discuss the threat officially, fearing it could complicate the mission in Sierra Leone. But a British military spokesman, Lieutenant Commander Tony Cramp, said they were aware of the danger.

"Every soldier here knows there is a risk," he said. "We're not going to back down if we get a couple of casualties and we would hope that the British public would support us."

Had it not been for British intervention, it is likely that the UN mission would have collapsed and the rebels would have seized power. Defence sources in London insisted that "prudent precautions" had been taken against an RUF attack.

British troops reinforced their positions yesterday by flying in light artillery from one of the eight British ships off the coast and dispatching the frigate HMS Chatham seven miles up river toward Port Loko. HMS Chatham was described as "rehearsing for future operations" but its presence on the river will not have gone unnoticed by the RUF. Harrier bombers also flew over the area yesterday.

British forces are not particularly vulnerable where they are dug in and have hacked away large areas of bush but it may be difficult to protect British soldiers on patrol.

And during the attack on British troops at Lungi Lol earlier this week in which four RUF fighters were killed, the first rebel to approach the fortifications was able to disguise himself by wearing a UN beret.

Although the army is officially steering clear of combat, the parachute regiment and SAS have made regular forays toward the front. Yesterday, at least three British army jeeps accompanied a Sierra Leonean commander to a newly seized bridge south of Port Loko.

Another problem is that RUF fighters are often indistinguishable from the ordinary Sierra Leoneans. Drug use is widespread among the rebels and many are beyond reason and unafraid of death when they go into battle.

Nigerian soldiers, who have long battled the RUF and who have frequently been singled out by the rebels for particularly brutal treatment, have described how some rebels threw themselves suicidally at their guns.

The Sierra Leone cabinet met yesterday to decide what to do about the captured rebel leader, Foday Sankoh. The government is under considerable pressure at home and abroad to put him on trial for murder.

But it is also keeping open the possibility of negotiations with the RUF by laying out terms for a ceasefire. Britain yesterday placed its hope in negotiation and the build up of UN reinforcements. The conditions for talks include the release of all UN hostages held by the RUF, an end to attacks on pro-government forces and speedy disarmament.

The Sierra Leonean information minister, Julius Spencer, said many of his colleagues favoured putting Mr Sankoh on trial and keeping up the military pressure on the RUF. But he added: "We have to consider what support we get from the international community because we can't go it alone".

The RUF has threatened to continue the war unless Mr Sankoh is released. "If they put our leadership on trial, we are not going to sit back and watch that for a second time. We will answer force with force and dialogue with dialogue," Jibril Massaquoi, a rebel spokesman, said at the RUF headquarters in Makeni.

webTitle: Chemists to sell morning after pill

fields.headline: Chemists to sell morning after pill
fields.trailText: Women may be able to obtain the morning after pill over the counter at high street chemists within the year, following a decision by the Committee on the Safety of Medicines (CSM) that it does not need to be prescribed by a doctor.
fields.body:
Women may be able to obtain the morning after pill over the counter at high street chemists within the year, following a decision by the Committee on the Safety of Medicines (CSM) that it does not need to be prescribed by a doctor.

There are bureaucratic hurdles yet to be overcome, but the committee's decision is seen as a watershed by those who have campaigned to allow women access to the emergency pill without having to run the gauntlet of a disapproving doctor.

"This is a tremendous step forward," said a spokeswoman for the British Pregnancy Advisory Service. "It puts to bed allegations that it would be medically unsafe for pharmacists to sell emergency contraception without a prescription."

Birth control advocates are rejoicing at a move which they see as allowing women greater control of her own fertility.

But a spokesman for the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child said: "This is not contraception - it is effectively a huge dose of hormones which causes abortion.

"We are also concerned for the safety of the women and girls who take it. It can have serious side effects. We are concerned that a busy pharmacist may not have time to go through the potential problems with a woman asking for this product, and may not pick up on dangers that a doctor would."

The CSM's ruling relates to only one brand of morning after pill: Levonelle 2. Its manufacturer, Schering Healthcare, applied to have it re-classified so it could be sold over the counter. But once one brand is available in the high street, others will follow.

The committee decided that allowing it to be bought in pharmacies is "unlikely to present a direct or indirect danger to the health of women aged 16 and over when used without the supervision of a doctor".

Pharmacists will not be allowed to supply the pill to under-16s and will have to refer any woman taking medicines which might interact with the pill to the doctor, as well as advising all women to see the doctor for follow-up advice.

The Medicines Control Agency is now embarking on a six-week consultation to establish what outside groups and the public think of the decision. It will then make recommendations to ministers.

If all goes as expected, regulations will be laid before parliament in the autumn and the pill could be available in chemists by the end of the year.

The pill will work up to 72 hours after intercourse, but is best taken as early as possible. Many women are embarrassed to ask their doctor for it or cannot get an appointment in time. Some private clinics, like the Marie Stopes clinic, sell it, but only by appointment.

"Our contraceptive education service helpline receives numerous calls from women who have experienced difficulties in obtaining emergency contraception," said Anne Weyman, chief executive of the Family Planning Association.

Ann Furedi, of the British Pregnancy Advisory Service, said she thought it unlikely that ministers would decide not to allow the pill to be sold in pharmacies on social grounds. "This puts women much more in control," she added.

"The issue is that this if it is accepted that this can be a pharmacy medicine, it entirely changes the way emergency contraception will be used. It de-stigmatises it. Women can get it without having to justify their situation. "

She said her only worry followed a pilot scheme in Manchester in which, it was claimed, some pharmacists questioned women about their recent sexual intercourse, making them uncomfortable.

"It should be possible to supply emergency contraception in the same way as other products," she said.

fields.headline: Make or break for peace
fields.standfirst: Mr Trimble must now persuade his party
fields.trailText: Here we are again in the midst of yet another make or break moment in the Northern Ireland peace process. In a week the fate of the Good Friday agreement will be in the hands of the 800-odd members of the Ulster Unionist council.
fields.body:
Here we are again in the midst of yet another make or break moment in the Northern Ireland peace process. In a week the fate of the Good Friday agreement will be in the hands of the 800-odd members of the Ulster Unionist council. They will have to decide on whether to return to Stormont's power-sharing executive. The postponement gives David Trimble's team time to work on the crucial 200 or so undecided members - an important breathing space given the efficiency and speed with which the anti-agreement camp have been campaigning for the last week with glossy leaflets and phone canvassing. It is also make or break for Mr Trimble's leadership. Pull this off, and he has resolved the questions arising from the previous leadership challenge earlier in the spring.

Mr Trimble's failure to embrace and promote the IRA's statement on decommissioning has been frustrating and allowed his hardliners to make mischief. In place of persuasion he has appeared to spend much of the past 10 days asking for clarifications and wringing concessions (on flags and names) from the British government. If this negotiation helps him convince his council he is no pushover, then one may end up applauding a shrewd understanding of his side's insecurities. There has been some frustration in London and Dublin that Unionists too often get stuck on the detail. Why, they ask, cannot Mr Trimble inspire his troops with the big picture? Mr Trimble's strategy has been aptly described as the politics of resignation rather than of inspiration. But perhaps he knows best how to coax his party into peace; after all, the big picture - power-sharing which entails decisions such as Barbre de Bruin's siting of Belfast's main maternity hospital in a Catholic area - often horrifies an insecure community.

The concessions that the British government has been producing this week like white rabbits from a hat at a children's tea party, have meanwhile infuriated nationalists. There has been the appearance of a dual peace process: the negotiating proper is paralleled by Mr Blair's billet doux to the Unionists. If Mr Trimble pulls off his vote next Saturday, the nationalists' ire might be considered a reasonable price to have paid. If not, nationalists can argue with justification that the Unionists are only in the peace process to obstruct it. No sooner do the IRA give a significant concession on decommissioning than a series of other vital objections emerge. The vote next Saturday will finally flush out exactly the extent of their commitment to peace; there is nothing left for them to hide behind.

Peter Mandelson's concessions on flags and the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary are a fudge which will, inevitably, come unstuck. But every stage of the peace process has been accompanied by unhappy but unavoidable fudges; that is the messy nature of negotiated peace. Some issues are effectively set aside to get everyone over the immediate hump; the rationale is that progress generates its own momentum, which in time can solve previously intractable problems.

Now, having helped Mr Trimble all it can, the British government must stay out of what is an internal Unionist debate. Pleas of "the world will not respect Unionism" kind can be counter-productive; the Unionists are used to following their own moral imperative which is often at odds with everyone else. They are never going to seize a peaceful future with confident enthusiasm; all we can hope for is that Mr Trimble can persuade them that returning to Stormont is the smaller risk.

fields.headline: Mugabe changes tack
fields.standfirst:
Election monitors will face an uphill task

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Political, state-sponsored violence in Zimbabwe is getting worse, not better, in the wake of President Robert Mugabe's belated decision to call a general election next month.
fields.body:
Political, state-sponsored violence in Zimbabwe is getting worse, not better, in the wake of President Robert Mugabe's belated decision to call a general election next month. The ruling party, Zanu-PF, has its own ideas about how a democratic election campaign should be conducted. These include the beating up of primary school teachers in front of their classes. The terrified pupils are then instructed to go home and warn their parents about the consequences of backing any of the opposition parties. Gangs of Mr Mugabe's supporters have invaded factories, mines, hospitals and businesses, dishing out violence and threats. In rural areas, farmworkers have been particularly targeted. From Harare itself come reports of torture centres and door-to-door searches by Zanu thugs.

This systematic, nationwide intimidation of the electorate began with attacks and occupations of white-owned farms earlier this year. Mr Mugabe declared land reform to be Zimbabwe's most pressing issue and passed a constitutional amendment allowing confiscation without compensation. Since then, Britain has renewed its offer of £36m to assist land transfers from rich to poor. Thabo Mbeki, the South African president, has successfully worked with the UN to gain additional financial backing from Scandinavian countries. The white farmers' organisations are also ready to cooperate with a genuine reform programme free of the corruption which has marred such efforts in the past. All that those concerned ask is that Mr Mugabe call off his mobsters, halt the violence, and finally allow the country to vote in a free and fair election.

This he will not do, for in truth his sudden, urgent interest in land reform was only ever a pretext for letting loose his party henchmen and commencing the current wave of intimidation ahead of a poll he rightly fears he may lose. His tirades against white Zimbabweans and Britain were similarly cynical in inspiration. Mr Mugabe will no doubt happily accept western cheques for land reform but, tactically, he has already moved on. Now he is trying to set new conditions for Commonwealth and EU election monitoring while busily gerrymandering constituencies, disenfranchising whites, and warning voters that the ballot will not be secret. The violence, meanwhile, looks like continuing. Mr Mbeki says monitors may start arriving by next week. They will have their work cut out.

fields.headline: Perfect 'prince' who ran up £m debt
fields.trailText: He seemed a reasonable sort of chap. Turned up in October in a chauffeur-driven Jaguar emblazoned with a coat of arms of crossed sabres and palm trees, said he was Prince Ismael of Sandakan, a friend of the Sultan of Brunei, and moved into three deluxe suites in one of the Riviera's finest hotels.
fields.body:
He seemed a reasonable sort of chap. Turned up in October in a chauffeur-driven Jaguar emblazoned with a coat of arms of crossed sabres and palm trees, said he was Prince Ismael of Sandakan, a friend of the Sultan of Brunei, and moved into three deluxe suites in one of the Riviera's finest hotels.

For the staff of the five-star Negresco on the Promenade des Anglais in Nice, he seemed the ideal winter client: champagne dinners, handsome tips, a succession of attractive, female visitors.

Until last Wednesday, when the mountain of unpaid bills reached £260,000 and Ismael Nabou, a Mauritian of no fixed abode - but with outstanding arrest warrants in the US and Canada - was slung into jail and accused of fraud.

"The sad thing is, everyone really liked him here," said Jeanne Augier, 76, the hotel's managing director. "We never had an inkling, particularly because he paid his first few bills on the nail. He had style, you know."

The Negresco, whose 130 rooms cost between £175 and £275 a night, is described in the Michelin guide as "as much of a museum as a hotel, bursting with works of art and cultivating excess".

Mr Nabou played his princely role to perfection: his hire cars were BMWs and Mercedes and he bought diamonds from Nice's most prestigious shops - the bills remain unpaid.

While his retinue knocked back the booze with unseemly gusto, His Royal Highness waved away all but the first glass, murmuring discreetly, "It's my religion, you know."

So convincing was he that Ms Augier is still not quite willing to believe the accusations. "Actually," she said, "I think this endearing man has a heart of gold. It's just that he doesn't know how to manage all his money."

fields.headline: U-turn on share options
fields.standfirst:
Government bows to pressure from internet start-ups facing unpredictable tax bills

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government last night bowed to pressure from the hi-tech community which argued that the way tax was charged on share options threatened to derail the e-economy.
fields.body:
The government last night bowed to pressure from the hi-tech community which argued that the way tax was charged on share options threatened to derail the e-economy.

Financial secretary Stephen Timms announced plans to shift the burden of national insurance contributions on share option gains from employer to worker. The issue was regarded by many internet companies as the single most important threat facing their businesses.

The move was taken to ward off fears that the option schemes, which have become increasingly common, were a potential time bomb that could explode in the face of the emergent new economy.

Internet start-ups, which have low cash flows, are particularly exposed to sharply changed levels of liability that could arise when staff decide to cash in their options.

The danger arose in April 1999 when the rules governing options outside of inland revenue-approved schemes were changed. Before April, national insurance was paid only when options were granted, which meant the figure was predictable. By calculating national insurance when the shares are cashed, companies faced volatile and potentially far higher sums.

Financial website Interactive Investor International on Thursday blamed a sharp increase in losses for the half-year from £2.6m to £9.6m on a £4m provision to cover potential national insurance costs on share options.

Leigh Wood, chief operating officer of cable company NTL, welcomed the change. The company, which is listed on the Nasdaq exchange in the US, has 700 staff in Britain in its share options scheme.

"We are pleased the government has listened," Mr Wood said. "We were concerned about the potential liability and its effect on the business, and the scheme was under threat. This amendment means we will be able to carry on as before."

The burden can only be moved by agreement between employer and worker. The headline rate of tax on share option gains will be 47.32% under the new proposals - including a new tax relief allowing employees to offset any national insurance contributions against the income tax charge arising on share options gains.

There was still concern, however, that the Treasury had merely shifted the burden to employees instead of removing it altogether.

John Whiting, tax partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, said: "It's a step in the right direction but I'm not convinced it goes far enough."

There were fears that the compromise would not be enough to prevent a brain drain to countries where the tax liability on stock options would still be lower.

The review was announced in the chancellor's Budget speech and since then Mr Timms has met representa tives of 50 companies. He said: "I intend to continue this dialogue about how we can make Britain the best competitive environment for e-commerce. We want to attract business and jobs to Britain and help British companies compete in the global market."

There are two approved inland revenue share schemes: the SAYE sharesave scheme open to all employees and the Company Share Option Plan under which an employee can be granted options over shares worth up to £30,000.

Gains from both schemes are free of tax and national insurance.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: • Forget all that stuff about Tony and Gordon falling out over the euro, the real rivalry between the first and second lords of the Treasury is over who has the best website.
fields.body:
 Forget all that stuff about Tony and Gordon falling out over the euro, the real rivalry between the first and second lords of the Treasury is over who has the best website.

At the moment, No 10 is winning hands down, with its all singing, all dancing affair that allows visitors to embark on their tour of the corridors of power.

By contrast, this week's "highlights" on the Treasury site are the launch of the Myners study into institutional investment and the full text of the chancellor's speech to the Child Poverty Action Group. This is all about to change, however, because Mr Prudence has commissioned Bates - the company that designed the No 10 site - to give the Treasury's dreary web pages a makeover. Look forward then in three months to a history of boom and bust and 10 things you never knew about Dawn Primarolo.

 At the other end of the town, the Bank of England has a problem with inflation - the quarterly inflation report is getting so big that it will soon be too fat to staple together. The first report in February 1993 was a model of Hemingway-like brevity, a terse 48 pages; the latest clocked in at a Joycean 98 pages, but was at least a better read.

Bank insiders say the choice is to cut down the size of the report by removing the minutes of the meetings of the monetary policy committee to another publication, or give up altogether and turn the report into a book, with a proper spine.

 Underside was sorry to have missed the champagne luncheon sponsored by "dynamic accountants" Baker Tilly, and that riveting periodical Tax Journal, at which Peter Mason, the Abbey National's internationally feared group VAT director, was hailed as Britain's first "VATrat of the year".

This coveted award (the title has something to do with Hong Kong and the Chinese year of the rat) goes to the suit achieving a landmark VAT decision. Mason - according to his citation - has been the scourge not just of the high court and the European court of justice, but the VAT and duties tribunal to boot.

According to Baker Tilly, "the usually sober VAT community fizzed" when the magic envelope was opened. Of course it did.

 Talking of rats, there was much merriment over the port and cigars at the CBI's annual dinner when Rentokil supremo Sir Clive Thompson said that the former bosses' boss at Centrepoint, Adair Turner, was now in a garret somewhere working on a definitive 800-page tome about "fiscal rectitude".

Suspicions that some of the CBI's members found Turner a bit too clever (and left-wing) for his own good were confirmed by the belly laughs that greeted the boast by Sir Clive - not perhaps everyone's first choice for "phone a friend" - that he was now planning a slim 200-page autobiography, called Rats to Riches and Back Again, to give Turner a run for his money. Meeow.

 Listeners to the Today programme this week were treated to a vintage Clare Short performance. The international development secretary did a quick interview on the way to the airport in which she slated the European Union as the world's most useless development agency, riven by petty nationalistic rivalries, riddled with bureaucratic delays, wasting billions of euros, etc etc.

All absolutely true, of course, and made even better by the fact that Ms Short was en route to Brussels that day. Good to see she hasn't lost her touch.

 Meanwhile, the Japanese have come up with a wizard wheeze to prevent Jubilee 2000 campaigners from turning up en masse for the their annual demo at the G7 heads of government shindig. The smart boys in Tokyo are holding the summit on Okinawa and the cost of jetting to an island in the middle of the Pacific is proving prohibitively expensive for the J2000 stalwarts who formed human chains in Birmingham and Cologne.

One plan, apparently, is to have pictures of the summit beamed back to giant screens in Europe. It works for football, but shots of Blair and Clinton gladhanding or Gerhard Schröder tucking into some sushi? Don't see it somehow.

 A new health warning for addicts of the dreaded weed. On a recent flight to Brussels, just as the aircraft reached cruising altitude, passengers were given the usual stuff about the flight being of the non-smoking variety, smoke detectors fitted in the loo etc. Then a new variant. A sonorous annoucement that anyone caught lighting up would be asked to leave the aircraft - immediately.

Suspicions that some of the CBI's members found Turner a bit too clever (and left-wing) for his own good were confirmed by the belly laughs that greeted the boast by Sir Clive - not perhaps everyone's first choice for "phone a friend" - that he was now planning a slim 200-page autobiography, called Rats to Riches and Back Again, to give Turner a run for his money. Meeow.  Listeners to the Today programme this week were treated to a vintage Clare Short performance. The international development secretary did a quick interview on the way to the airport in which she slated the European Union as the world's most useless development agency, riven by petty nationalistic rivalries, riddled with bureaucratic delays, wasting billions of euros, etc etc. All absolutely true, of course, and made even better by the fact that Ms Short was en route to Brussels that day. Good to see she hasn't lost her touch.  Meanwhile, the Japanese have come up with a wizard wheeze to prevent Jubilee 2000 campaigners from turning up en masse for the their annual demo at the G7 heads of government shindig. The smart boys in Tokyo are holding the summit on Okinawa and the cost of jetting to an island in the middle of the Pacific is proving prohibitively expensive for the J2000 stalwarts who formed human chains in Birmingham and Cologne. One plan, apparently, is to have pictures of the summit beamed back to giant screens in Europe. It works for football, but shots of Blair and Clinton gladhanding or Gerhard Schröder tucking into some sushi? Don't see it somehow.  A new health warning for addicts of the dreaded weed. On a recent flight to Brussels, just as the aircraft reached cruising altitude, passengers were given the usual stuff about the flight being of the non-smoking variety, smoke detectors fitted in the loo etc. Then a new variant. A sonorous annoucement that anyone caught lighting up would be asked to leave the aircraft - immediately.

fields.headline: If the cap fits
fields.standfirst:
Ford chief checks out Land Rover

Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Ford chief executive Jacques Nasser was in cheery mood yesterday, sporting a company cap as he visited the Land Rover factory in Solihull - despite the news that Ford's British operations had run up losses of £119m last year.
fields.body:
Ford chief executive Jacques Nasser was in cheery mood yesterday, sporting a company cap as he visited the Land Rover factory in Solihull - despite the news that Ford's British operations had run up losses of £119m last year.

Ford is buying Land Rover from BMW for €3bn (£1.8bn) and the deal is expected to be clinched soon - though there have been unconfirmed reports that the US car company is looking for a cut in the original purchase price.

Nor was Mr Nasser the only car boss contemplating heavy losses. Carlos Ghosn, the Renault executive now in charge at Nissan, revealed yesterday that the Japanese company had lost $6.3bn (£4.26bn) last year but said the revival plan was going much faster than expected and forecast a return to profit in the current year.

Echoing earlier comments from Nissan executives he warned that the strength of sterling could increase the chances of the Sunderland plant losing production of the new Micra model to a factory in continental Europe.

"We cannot stay in this situation where we do not know where the pound will stabilise against the euro," he said at a Tokyo press conference. A decision will be taken at the end of the year with Nissan sources cautioning that the plant - rated as possibly the most efficient in Europe - will have to cut costs by 30% to compensate for the pound's strength against the euro.

Announcing the full-year figures for Britain, Ford made no direct reference to the exchange rate, blaming reduced revenues, overca pacity at its British plants and a slight downturn in the British car market.

The company has announced that it is ending car production at its Dagenham plant with the loss of 1,900 jobs - though it is investing heavily in engine production which will mean 500 new jobs.

Ford said the British market "will remain extremely competitive" this year.

fields.headline: Regulator raises iX merger questions
fields.trailText: The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges were forced on to the defensive yesterday as their plans to merge came under increasing criticism.
fields.body:
The London and Frankfurt stock exchanges were forced on to the defensive yesterday as their plans to merge came under increasing criticism.

The deal was a "win-win" situation, according to the Deutsche Börse, while the London stock exchange rejected complaints that the merger was a threat to the City's position as a financial centre.

The central bank of Hesse - Frankfurt's home state - which had earlier expressed reservations about the deal - yesterday threw its weight behind the merger.

Hans Reckers, the bank's president, said the alliance should not be allowed to fail because the administration of the merged exchange - to be called iX - would be in London.

But it emerged that the Hesse economics ministry, which regulates the Frankfurt exchange and which will have to approve the merger, has sent a letter to Deutsche Börse chief executive Walter Seifert seeking clarification on a number of issues.

At least two members of the German exchange's supervisory board have also expressed reservations.

Under the terms of the merger London would be the administrative centre for the merged exchange, the stock exchange's chairman, Don Cruickshank, would become chairman of the new entity and trading in blue chip stocks would be based in London.

Mr Seifert would get the job as chief executive and, although based in London, iX would use Frankfurt's Xetra trading system and would be the home for trading hi-tech stocks.

Although the deal has been crafted to appear as a merger of equals there are concerns about what will happen over clearing and settlement, the cost of the change-over, the use of the euro and whether companies which fall outside the blue chip and hi-tech sectors will be marginalised. And there has been criticism that it is being driven on by big US investment banks.

In a letter to the Financial Times yesterday the director-general of the Institute of Directors George Cox warned: "The proposed takeover of the London Stock Exchange - for that is effectively what it is -b y the Deutsche Börse has serious implications for London's continued role as the world's leading financial centre."

A spokeswoman for the London stock exchange denied any threat to London's position. "We would reject the idea that there is a takeover by Frankfurt. It will be a UK company headquartered in London."

A Deutsche Börse spokesman commented: "We regard this as a win-win situation for both exchanges and financial centres when these two exchanges are connected."

webTitle: Officials fail to check source of GM pollution

fields.headline: Officials fail to check source of GM pollution
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: No goverment officials have yet been to Canada to investigate the contamination of British crops by genetically modified material, more than a month after they were alerted to the mistake.
fields.body:
No goverment officials have yet been to Canada to investigate the contamination of British crops by genetically modified material, more than a month after they were alerted to the mistake.

Contamination of conventional plant seed with rogue GM pollen from plants grown at least half a mile away on the prairies is being blamed by the international company Advanta as the probable cause of the mistake that has led to the planting of thousands of acres of tainted oil-seed rape in the last two springs.

The government believes neither the company nor hundreds of farmers have committed an offence because they did not know of the contamination, although officials insist they are keeping the matter under review. The ministry of agriculture said no one had visited Advanta's Canadian arm in Winnipeg, Manitoba, or the site of the alleged cross-contamination in Alberta, although it was now considering sending an official.

"There were other more pressing requirements: finding out where we stood legally and whether there was any environmental or public health risk," a spokesman said.

The admission came as Advanta and its seed merchant distributors continued to seek the exact locations of farms that used the contaminated rape seed. Advanta UK said most were likely to be in the north of England and Scotland. "We still don't know the precise distribution of it. We wish we did."

Farmers who had bought the seed were still reluctant to identify themselves publicly last night for fear of damaging their own businesses. Many want the government to announce a compensation package - an option so far ruled out by ministers.

Advanta in Britain was unable to say whether the seeds were contimated by other companies' products or its own. The technology for the genetic material found in the seed was developed by Monsanto, which licenses many seed companies.

The government still holds that its initial advice was that no offence had been committed but "we are continuing to examine the facts and will take action as appropriate".

Two advisory committees and the food standards agency also said there was no threat to the environment or health. Ministers were awaiting the response of the advisory committee on animal feed.

The health and safety executive had not been consulted because it was "not considered a body to take a lead on any issues involved", nor had the crown prosecution service been consulted, despite the fact that breaking environmental protection law is a criminal offence.

Advanta in Canada last night insisted it had internal evidence that pointed "very strongly" towards cross pollination rather than errors in any other part of the process including shipping, as suggested by Canadain minsiter Lyle Vanclief yesterday. But identifying the source would require very expensive tests.

Howard Morris, its general manager, said no official from Britain or other countries affected - Sweden, France and Germany - had visited. "I don't think that is unusual. In a situation like this, it is government to government and we have had discussions with Canadian government officials."

fields.headline: Parity hit after warning
fields.trailText: Parity, the IT consultancy, saw its shares plunge yesterday following a profits warning that coincided with the general panic surrounding technology stocks.
fields.body:
Parity, the IT consultancy, saw its shares plunge yesterday following a profits warning that coincided with the general panic surrounding technology stocks.

Parity reported pre-tax profits of £21.3m in the 12 months to end-December, compared with £20m a year earlier, on turnover up 8% at £314m.

But an accompanying statement on first-quarter trading warned: "Whilst e-business continues to be very buoyant, the group, in common with its competitors, continues to experience very dull market conditions for traditional services," indicating that the firm's core business of recruiting casual IT professionals, such as maintenance staff and programmers, has yet to recover after last year's pre-millennium bug slowdown.

Chairman Philip Swinstead said yesterday: "Everyone in the industry is debating when the traditional market will come back, but no one can say exactly when." The situation will change he said "as large bricks and mortar companies shift from the pilot stage of e-business projects to full implementation of interfaces".

He added that Parity has "been shifting the overall focus of the group to e-business," citing last year's purchase of TMS Information Solutions, a knowledge-management systems company, and December's acquisition of web designer Interactive Developments.

In March, shares in Parity hit a peak of 720p before being caught in the general technology rout. Yesterday, the price slid another 47p to 158p.

fields.headline: Marconi in hi-tech overdrive
fields.trailText: Marconi, the fast-expanding telecoms equipment maker, yesterday laid out ambitious plans to exploit the expected surge in third generation mobile phones and the demand for broadband fibre optic networks.
fields.body:
Marconi, the fast-expanding telecoms equipment maker, yesterday laid out ambitious plans to exploit the expected surge in third generation mobile phones and the demand for broadband fibre optic networks.

Reborn from the hulk of the old engineering heavyweight GEC, Marconi announced a 48% rise in operating profits last year to £750m on sales up 40% to £5.72bn from £4.09bn or a slight increase in pre-tax, pre-exceptional earnings from £640m to £654m. After exceptionals these were down heftily, from £976m last year to £523m.

Chief executive Lord Simpson, who has transformed the group since the demerger of its defence arm last year, explained the confusion in that it had moved to US accounting principles, notably on depreciation, prior to a New York listing later this year. But, even on a like-for-like basis, operating profits were up 22% on an 11% rise in sales.

But Marconi saw its shares dragged down by the slump in technology stocks, becoming London's biggest loser with a 12.7% fall to 765p, down 111p. Unabashed, Lord Simpson, who described the fall as "very disappointing", bought some shares "to show this is not a very good valuation of a company delivering 48% growth in profits".

The ebullient Scot, who has bought up more than two dozen firms in the last three years, including the US mobile phones software company MSI last month, revealed details of the "Genoa experiment" to break into the burgeoning 3G mobile networks supply market.

Lord Simpson said the aim was to create "a virtual business model" rather than build a new plant and manufacture components. Rather, Marconi will rely on partnerships for this, he added, denying the group had been left behind by groups such as Nokia and Ericsson. Marconi is also investing heavily in broadband equipment such as tunable lasers, which send light down fibre optic networks, increasing their productivity.

"We are going to build a whole new business as a world-leader in optical components through the expansion of our centre at Caswell, Northants," he said.

Lord Simpson pointed to "a period of consolidation" after the array of acquisitions, including last year Fore Systems and Reltec, two American suppliers of internet equipment such as routers. These, which contributed £407m and £790m respectively to sales, made record earnings in the last quarter to March 31.

The group's systems division, including petrol pumps and medical imaging in the US, is switching out of hardware into software and solutions, as evidenced by this week's $100m contract with Coca-Cola to turn its vending machines into online kiosks and cash dispensers. But Lord Simpson admitted Marconi was still experiencing some trouble in exiting its "old economy" businesses.

fields.headline: Dresdner's golden handcuffs
fields.standfirst: Bank pays out £240m in bonuses to hold on to its fickle staff
fields.trailText: Dresdner Bank paid out up to £240m - the equivalent of almost £32,000 per employee - to staff at its investment banking arm in an attempt to stop an exodus of talent during the merger negotiations with Deutsche Bank earlier this year.
fields.body:
Dresdner Bank paid out up to £240m - the equivalent of almost £32,000 per employee - to staff at its investment banking arm in an attempt to stop an exodus of talent during the merger negotiations with Deutsche Bank earlier this year.

The bank is also understood to have guaranteed the level of this year's bonuses for Dresdner Kleinwort Benson (DrKB) employees who agreed to stay.

The "special payments", which the bank said were designed to "secure its competitive position", put a big dent in the German bank's first quarter profits that fell by just over 50% to €133m. Excluding the special charge, profits were up by 47.7% at €687m.

Yesterday Dresdner declined to give any further details of the bonus payments to the 7,500 staff at DrKB - around half of whom are based in London.

But the bank appears to have achieved its aim. Around 200 employees are understood to have left during the period of uncertainty when the merger negotiations were going on - though Dresdner sources insist that the bank was able to continue recruiting during the period.

The merger deal eventually collapsed last month after Dresdner refused to agree terms that would effectively have spelled the end of DrKB.

The bonus payments were larger than analysts had been expecting and, though the company has accounted for them against first quarter profits, it is understood they will not be paid to staff until July.

Yesterday Dresdner's new chief executive, Bernd Fahrholz, said that the bank planned to cut some 5,000 jobs over the next three years. Most of the jobs to go will be in Germany as Dresdner contracts its retail branch network and cuts its headquarters staff.

Mr Fahrholz shrugged off speculation that Dresdner represents a tempting takeover target.

He argued that the bank would "go forward on its own" and he pledged heavy investment in the corporate investment banking operations, e-commerce and private banking - totalling some £2.1bn over the next two to three years. DrKB would be positioned as "a leading European investment bank" but with global reach, Mr Fahrholz said.

Analysts generally welcomed the new strategy. It "sounds solid and focused. He is focusing on fee-based business and investment banking," said one analyst.

webTitle: Chains to hold back the bull runners

fields.headline: Chains to hold back the bull runners
fields.standfirst: Expect more exotic packages
fields.trailText: Dresdner has had to pay heavily for the failed merger with its Frankfurt rival Deutsche Bank, as illustrated by the lorry-load of gold handcuffs delivered to the Fenchurch Street headquarters of its London-based investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.
fields.body:
Dresdner has had to pay heavily for the failed merger with its Frankfurt rival Deutsche Bank, as illustrated by the lorry-load of gold handcuffs delivered to the Fenchurch Street headquarters of its London-based investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

The sweeteners average £32,000 per employee, but the bank's most profitable star financiers are bound to be pocketing some very hefty cheques indeed.

No one should be too surprised. The merger came at a time when demand for those with investment banking skills - especially in London - was high, and when the jobs toll at DrKB, if and when Deutsche took over, was likely to be ghastly. The noise of rustling job offers and CVs being polished up must have been deafening.

Regardless of the merger with Deutsche going ahead, the investment banking staff were made aware of where they would be asked to stand - out in the cold. And, with Dresdner presumed to be holding talks with any number of alternative merger partners, quality staff are not bothering to wait around. A respected name seems to leave every couple of days and yesterday's £240m payout smacks of desperation.

Some may see this as an example of outrageous bull market excess. Others, sitting in houses they would like to sell, might simply hope that it further inflates London's house market bubble. But the chances are that this sort of payments and/or loyalty package is something British business will have to get used to. Investment banks are resorting to increasingly exotic packages to keep highly trained personnel in place and out of the hands of starry-eyed venture capitalists promising a fresh and funky lifestyle in the new economy.

Parallel investment plans, where individual bankers are allowed to come in alongside their parent firms in backing young, highly promising ventures at attractive early-money rates, are now commonplace. Companies without highly rated shares to spray around are looking for new ways of identifying value and then passing it on directly to employees.

The spread of this phenomenom is well documented, with staff from those sectors considered to be in vogue in internet terms continuing to flow out of old-economy firms. By most accounts, the dot.com sell-off in the markets has only slowed the flow, not stemmed it.

If the sight of paper wealth spontaneously combusting in the markets has not been enough to keep top staff buckled down at the likes of Kleinwort Benson, then the assumption has to be that the flow may become unmanageable if and when the markets recover. And it will not be restricted to investment banking.

Parthus punt
Well, yes, some might put it down to the luck o' the Irish, but we can assume there is rather more to the rush to get a piece of a Dublin-based semiconductor chip designer called Parthus Technologies on its market debut yesterday.

The stock jumped from a sale price of 85p, at which investment bank Goldman Sachs helped the company raise £111m through the London and Nasdaq stock markets, to 180p at one stage before closing at 149p, valuing this seven-year old company at £770m. Co-founders Brian Long, the chief executive, and Peter McManamon, his bookman, are together worth a fraction over £200m on paper - not a bad result on a day when other technology stocks (as measured by the Techmark 100) slumped 8.7%.

The excitement stems from the fact that this company specialises is designing chips for mobile phones, and the betting is that Europeans will take to clicking and reading and sending emails on the move in just the same way they have taken to yapping. Yes, we are talking m-commerce here.

As such, Parthus is up against much bigger competitors, such as Britain's Arm Holdings, not to mention Intel - which yesterday, amid all the dot.com carnage, skipped ahead of Microsoft and Cisco Systems to become the world's biggest company by stock market value. But the betting is, that with all sorts of mobile internet devices hitting the shops later this year (and the technology to make these gizmos work properly coming on stream in the summer of next year), the market is easily big and open enough to play for.

The rush for Parthus provides further evidence of investors' desire to buy the picks 'n shovels companies of the modern gold rush (the internet infrastructure providers), rather than trying to work out which business-to-consumer hopefuls (such as Boo.com) may or may not dig up a few nuggets.

The sweeteners average £32,000 per employee, but the bank's most profitable star financiers are bound to be pocketing some very hefty cheques indeed. No one should be too surprised. The merger came at a time when demand for those with investment banking skills - especially in London - was high, and when the jobs toll at DrKB, if and when Deutsche took over, was likely to be ghastly. The noise of rustling job offers and CVs being polished up must have been deafening. Regardless of the merger with Deutsche going ahead, the investment banking staff were made aware of where they would be asked to stand - out in the cold. And, with Dresdner presumed to be holding talks with any number of alternative merger partners, quality staff are not bothering to wait around. Others, sitting in houses they would like to sell, might simply hope that it further inflates London's house market bubble. fields.headline: MoD denies families Chinook reports
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has used the government's new freedom of information code to ban the release of two confidential reports to the families of pilots blamed for the Chinook helicopter crash off the Mull of Kintyre which left 25 members of the security services dead.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has used the government's new freedom of information code to ban the release of two confidential reports to the families of pilots blamed for the Chinook helicopter crash off the Mull of Kintyre which left 25 members of the security services dead.

In a decision that would be unaffected by the freedom of information bill that becomes law later this year, John Spellar, junior defence minister, has refused to release an airworthiness report on the Chinook because he says it is policy advice, and a report on an incident involving an American Chinook because it was supplied in confidence by a foreign government.

Both justifications will still apply when the bill becomes law this year, because Jack Straw, home secretary, has imposed blanket bans on policy advice and information provided by third parties. Mr Spellar is known to have been one of the home secretary's strongest supporters to retain secrecy in government when the bill was discussed in cabinet committee.

The requests for the release of the information were made by Michael Tapper, father of one of the pilots, Jonathan Tapper, and were pressed by Robert Key, Tory MP for Salisbury and a junior defence spokesman.

Mr Tapper and John Cook, the father of the second pilot, Rick Cook, have been fighting to clear their sons' names of the blame for the 1994 crash, which the ministry has insisted was not due to any malfunction. But it has always refused to release any reports.

Mr Tapper sought the airworthiness report because it was a full-scale assessment of the RAF Chinook carried out by Boscombe Down, the ministry's main air research centre, before the helicopter went into service. The helicopter tested was an identical model to the one that crashed. The National Audit Office, parliament's financial watchdog, has referred to the report in an investigation on defence procurement because it called for the helicopter's computer software to be rewritten before it went into service.

Release of the report would call into question the ministry's judgment on whether it should have gone into service.

The US report reveals details of an incident when a US army version of the helicopter rolled over and flew upside down until the pilots were able to regain control. After Mr Key failed to get the ministry to release the report, an application was made under the US freedom of information act, and the report has been passed to the families.

Mr Tapper has appealed against the first ruling and is to take the case to the parliamentary ombudsman.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Campaign for Freedom of Information, said: "I can't see how a technical report on the airworthiness of a helicopter before it goes into service can be classified as policy advice. This smells of a cover-up."

webTitle: Treasury's record surplus revives Labour backbench protests

fields.headline: Treasury's record surplus revives Labour backbench protests
fields.trailText: Backbenchers yesterday renewed pressure on the chancellor to spend more on key public services, to appease disgruntled traditional Labour voters, after official figures showed the Treasury recorded its biggest ever surplus for the month of April.
fields.body:
Backbenchers yesterday renewed pressure on the chancellor to spend more on key public services, to appease disgruntled traditional Labour voters, after official figures showed the Treasury recorded its biggest ever surplus for the month of April.

With negotiations between ministers over this summer's spending review reaching their climax, Labour MPs said Gordon Brown could afford to be more generous than the plans laid out in last month's Budget.

Amid concern over this year's 75p increase in pensions, one senior backbencher said last night: "Gordon has been in real trouble in the party following the local election results. Our view was that our great economic wizard had dropped us in the mire."

The figures, published by the office for national statistics, showed the public sector net cash requirement, the amount the government needs to bridge the gap between its income and expenditure, was in the black by £6.748bn in April, the first month of the financial year.

This was almost three times the amount expected in the City and the biggest April surplus on record.

Although the figures were artificially boosted by tobacco manufacturers paying customs and excise duty early, to avoid an expected increase in the Budget, economists said they underlined the rude health of the public finances.

"The strength of the public finances means the progressive loosening of the fiscal stance unveiled in this year's Budget can easily be afforded without jeopardising the chancellor's fiscal rules," said Richard Iley, of the Dutch bank ABN Amro.

In the Budget, Mr Brown announced that NHS spending would rise by 5.6% a year in real terms from 2001-02, compared to 2.5% for overall government spending. Allocations to government departments other than health will be revealed in the new public spending review, due to be announced before the end of July. With the lion's share of the remaining cash expected to go to education and transport, economists say there will be little left for others.

But Peter Kilfoyle, who resigned as defence minister complaining that the government was neglecting its heartland support, said that if the purse strings remained tight "it will be very difficult to explain to my constituents why, when all this money is coming in, their needs can't be addressed.

"We go back to the same basic political conundrum faced by all governments - there are things that have to be done on the macro level which have an impact on people's lives but aren't easily communicated to the electorate. But the hard political reality is that the electorate wants concrete developments on the ground."

The Treasury said: "We are currently preparing the spending review in line with the spending totals announced in the Budget. These plans allow for substantial increases in key government priorities and there's no question of deviating from them."

A spokesman added that, as part of a wider crackdown on avoidance of tobacco duty, the government intended to restrict the amount manufacturers were allowed to release from warehouses ahead of the Budget each year. The Exchequer lost £300m this year as a result of the industry anticipating the Budget.

 Mortgage lending fell sharply in April, creating hopes that Britain's frothy housing market might be nearing its peak. Gross lending last month was £9.4bn, well down on the £10.7bn recorded in March, but still up on last year's figure of £8.8bn.

fields.bylineHtml: Mark Atkinson and Lucy Ward

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Leinthall Earls
fields.trailText: Here where the quiet, crumpled hills of north-east Herefordshire melt imperceptibly into the wooded heights of south Shropshire, we watched a pair of buzzards quartering the space above Yatton Hill and Ladyacre Plantation on a morning of dappled skies.
fields.body:
Here where the quiet, crumpled hills of north-east Herefordshire melt imperceptibly into the wooded heights of south Shropshire, we watched a pair of buzzards quartering the space above Yatton Hill and Ladyacre Plantation on a morning of dappled skies.

This is very much Marcher country, once controlled by the all-powerful Mortimers from their base at Wigmore Castle, a couple of miles across the flood plain from Leinthall Earls. It's appropriate that the long distance path crossing this landscape and linking Ludlow with Kington is called the Mortimer Trail. It comes south-westward along the crest of the long, wooded ridge to drop eventually to cross the River Lugg at Aymestrey.

We went up through bluebell woods where wood anemone had brightened the floor only weeks earlier. On the leafy crest, views limited by trunk and branch, we turned to the south-west and mounted to one of the most remarkable archaeological sites in England. Croft Ambrey is an Iron Age fort occupied between 400 BC and AD 50, a huge rampart thrown up to enclose 24 acres a thousand feet above sea level. Of all the sites purporting to be the last stronghold of Caractacus, this has the strongest claim.

Even today it's a dramatic fortress, its grassy earthwork a snaking curtain wall punctuated with ancient oaks and gilded with gorse banks. Up atop the highest mound, where cock pheasants strutted in the sunlight, we looked to the south-west and saw the far blue rise of the Black Mountains. There, easily identifiable, was the proud prow of Hay Bluff overlooking the unseen Wye where it comes curling out of Wales. As we gazed we could easily have been standing on George Butterworth's Idle Hill of Summer.

Hidden by dense wood cover due south lies the old park surrounding Croft Castle. This house has been in the longest ownership of one family of any in Herefordshire.

Up on the old fort rampart it isn't hard to believe the claim that more than a dozen counties can be seen in clear weather.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Branson plans mobile assault
fields.body:
Branson plans mobile assault

Sir Richard Branson yesterday disclosed plans to establish mobile phone businesses across the US, Japan and mainland Europe by the autumn after the Virgin Group founder signed a $1bn (£670m) Asian joint venture with Singapore's SingTel Mobile. Mr Branson said he aimed to replicate worldwide the British success of Virgin Mobile, which has 250,000 customers six months after launch. "We want to try and be the first truly global mobile phone company and the deal with SingTel is a step towards that," he said.

The pan-Asian venture will follow the British business model by repackaging SingTel airtime under the Virgin brand name. Virgin's UK partner is One2One. The initial targets will be Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea with negotiations under way for services in China and India. Virgin will own 50% of the venture but is putting up only $50m against SingTel's investment of $500m. Sir Richard said negotiations over a deal in continental Europe included Deutsche Telekom, which owns One2One.

China signs EU trade deal

European Union and Chinese diplomats struck a market access deal yesterday which removes one of the last obstacles to Beijing joining the World Trade Organisation. After five days of negotiations, and a last-minute intervention from the Chinese premier, Zhu Rongji, the two sides agreed a deal which will allow European companies to take stakes of up to 50% in sensitive areas such as the telecommunications, financial and motor sectors. China is still some months away from becoming the 137th member of the Geneva body which polices global trade rules. First it must strike deals with Switzerland and Mexico, which senior trade diplomats believe are unlikely to be settled until the autumn.

Perpetual rides to Wickes aid

Wickes, the DIY retailer facing a hostile £327m bid from rival Focus Do It All, confirmed yesterday that "exploratory talks" have taken place since the offer was announced "with a number of potentially interested parties". The company also beefed up its defence with the support of its biggest institutional shareholder - Perpetual Unit Trust Management. The fund manager said the revised offer from FDIA "substantially undervalues" Wickes and did not reflect its growth potential. Perpetual holds some 8.3% of Wickes's share capital. Its support follows Schroders' decision to accept FDIA's raised 430p-a-share cash bid on Wednesday. Schroders had been Wickes's biggest shareholder with a 19.7% stake.

Feldberg to run Barclays in US

Barclays yesterday appointed Chester Feldberg, from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, America's central bank, to the new position of chairman of the bank's American operations. Matt Barrett, Barclay's chief executive, said Mr Feldberg would help the bank build its operations in the US.

webTitle: Everyone loves Mo, bar a few ministers

fields.headline: Everyone loves Mo, bar a few ministers
fields.standfirst:
She is the most popular member of cabinet with the public yet could face the sack. What does the future hold for Mowlam?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: She is the most popular member of cabinet with the public yet could face the sack. What does the future hold for Mowlam?
fields.body:
At any time in the past few months, a sensible betting MP might have put a fiver on Mo Mowlam leaving Tony Blair's government at the next reshuffle and done so at ever-diminishing odds. No two people quite agreed what was going wrong in New Labour's love affair with Mo, but clearly something was.

Then the Guardian's annual ICM poll on the cabinet popularity ratings this week confirmed what ordinary voters-in-the-street, from her Redcar constituency to the Falls Road in Belfast, could have told the government for free: Dr Mowlam remains its most popular asset at a time when it is becoming less lovable in the eyes of many voters.

"She came to my constituency and she was quite literally mobbed. People love Mo," recalls one cabinet colleague who admires her enormously. "We'd be mad not to use her talents and popularity properly."

"Mo?," says another senior minister. "She's behaving like a rogue elephant and acting in a pretty dumb way at present."

The Guardian/ICM poll clearly suggests that 58% of voters agree with the first minister even though few know very clearly what her progress-chasing, joined-up-government role at the Cabinet Office involves. Her profile - even on the Today programme - has been lower than expected.

But the second minister also has a point, although it is little understood outside government. Even Mo's admirers know she can be difficult.

"It has never been easy to fit Mo into the right job, that was true even in opposition," says one. She herself acknowledges her populist instincts and even the comparison some people make between her and Ken Livingstone: easier to admire at a distance than close up. "In some ways Mo is above politics, she's anti-politics," concedes a Labour apparatchik.

But what about all those newspaper stories suggesting that Downing Street is out to get Mo because she is so popular that Tony Blair is jealous? The thesis was explicitly endorsed by Channel 4's recent Rise and Fall of Mo Mowlam. Mo was discarded because she was "a popularity threat," said leftwing MP, Alan Simpson and others.

The main culprit fingered for spreading the poison was the prime minister's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, who was also blamed for upsetting Frank Dobson. Mr Powell denies the villain's role, and Mowlam - who took the trouble to buy him a drink in a Westminster corner on Tuesday night - says she does not blame him either. True or false? There is conflicting evidence.

Indeed some evidence suggests that Mo herself likes to talk about her troubles rather than to bottle them up and that at least some of the media gossip has been generated by her talking aloud about her perceived tormentors or letting her chums do so.

Thus a front page story in the Independent on Sunday is said to have been the result of a heart-to-heart with the paper's editor, Janet Street-Porter, who wanted to flush out those shadowy whisperers. Yet those closest to Mr Blair are not easily caught playing the whispering game.

Mo has hinted that she is not enamoured of much of the machinery-of-government stuff. She loves the anti-drugs crusade, but it is well known that her views are more liberal than Mr Blair's. "Is it a big enough job for Mo? I don't know," says one of the big players in the Blair team. "She has an appeal and talent that is unique in politics. We've got to find a way to make better use of it." That hardly sounds as if a P45 is being prepared in the No 10 accounts department.

Others have argued that it is Mowlam who has had enough, not the other way round. Her banker husband, Jon, lost his job last year - hence the £350,000 future memoirs deal to cheer up the bank manager - and friends wonder whether she is fully recovered from that very public brain tumour.

There again, they admit, Mo was always wayward, a rule-breaker, perfectly capable of pinching someone's pint or - in an interview incident - a woman journalist's bangles.

That is why folk love Mo. Her spontaneity is real. The journalist, Julia Langdon, who is completing her biography, contradicts Mowlam's own explanation of her popularity - Belfast and the illness. "Her popularity isn't about either as such. It's about the way she handled them both," says Ms Langdon.

The jury is still out on Mowlam's role in brokering the Good Friday agreement. Her shrewd deputy, Paul Murphy, now Welsh secretary, has been heard to say "No Mo, no peace process," and her style won many friends in Northern Ireland, especially on the nationalist and republican side of the conflict.

The loyalist paramilitaries liked Mo too - she famously risked a visit to the Maze - but Unionists found her too unversed in detail, too green towards the end and too uninhibited for their restrained and uptight culture. She swears more than the average Northern Ireland secretary.

Their proof of the pudding was that Blair (or his surrogate Jonathan Powell) took over much of the final negotiation. But so did Dublin's Bertie Ahern, with Bill Clinton in the wings. Unionists have long been spoiled for attention from the big league.

Yet, against that, there are echoes of the same complaint from Whitehall, that Mo is too detached, off the case too often, too much - in that deadly phrase - a "loose cannon."

That is what people like about Mo, she's so natural that she gets away with things that would have other ministers in hot water. "I've not read the whole article [on the Guardian's poll] because I didn't know I was coming in [to the BBC] until half an hour ago. But I've skimmed it," she cheerfully admitted this week on the World at One. She went on to admit that the government's position was "far from good" but not bad for mid-term. "We are listening, but people do not perceive that we are." Candid to a fault.

At present she seems to feel under-valued and is letting it be known in a Mo-ish way. "It's a strategy that is badly backfiring at a political level, if not at a public level," says a ministerial critic. "She seems to have acquired a touch of martyr's syndrome in Northern Ireland, some of its victim psychosis."

That is not Blair's view, nor that of most Labour MPs. As usual Mo defies categorisation. One junior minister this week predicted that she would take over from Chris Smith to become the next minister for culture, media and sports.

That is mere speculation, but not stupid. Blair wants to harness her distinctive talents. In culture, media and sport they are more accustomed than the average Orange Lodge to extroverts with a weakness for cheerful profanity.
