The Guardian/ICM poll clearly suggests that 58% of voters agree with the first minister even though few know very clearly what her progress-chasing, joined-up-government role at the Cabinet Office involves. Her profile - even on the Today programme - has been lower than expected. But the second minister also has a point, although it is little understood outside government. Even Mo's admirers know she can be difficult. "It has never been easy to fit Mo into the right job, that was true even in opposition," says one. She herself acknowledges her populist instincts and even the comparison some people make between her and Ken Livingstone: easier to admire at a distance than close up. "In some ways Mo is above politics, she's anti-politics," concedes a Labour apparatchik. But what about all those newspaper stories suggesting that Downing Street is out to get Mo because she is so popular that Tony Blair is jealous? The thesis was explicitly endorsed by Channel 4's recent Rise and Fall of Mo Mowlam. Mo was discarded because she was "a popularity threat," said leftwing MP, Alan Simpson and others. The main culprit fingered for spreading the poison was the prime minister's chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, who was also blamed for upsetting Frank Dobson. Mr Powell denies the villain's role, and Mowlam - who took the trouble to buy him a drink in a Westminster corner on Tuesday night - says she does not blame him either. True or false? There is conflicting evidence. Indeed some evidence suggests that Mo herself likes to talk about her troubles rather than to bottle them up and that at least some of the media gossip has been generated by her talking aloud about her perceived tormentors or letting her chums do so. Thus a front page story in the Independent on Sunday is said to have been the result of a heart-to-heart with the paper's editor, Janet Street-Porter, who wanted to flush out those shadowy whisperers. Yet those closest to Mr Blair are not easily caught playing the whispering game. Mo has hinted that she is not enamoured of much of the machinery-of-government stuff. She loves the anti-drugs crusade, but it is well known that her views are more liberal than Mr Blair's. "Is it a big enough job for Mo? I don't know," says one of the big players in the Blair team. "She has an appeal and talent that is unique in politics. We've got to find a way to make better use of it." That hardly sounds as if a P45 is being prepared in the No 10 accounts department. Others have argued that it is Mowlam who has had enough, not the other way round. Her banker husband, Jon, lost his job last year - hence the £350,000 future memoirs deal to cheer up the bank manager - and friends wonder whether she is fully recovered from that very public brain tumour. There again, they admit, Mo was always wayward, a rule-breaker, perfectly capable of pinching someone's pint or - in an interview incident - a woman journalist's bangles. That is why folk love Mo. Her spontaneity is real. The journalist, Julia Langdon, who is completing her biography, contradicts Mowlam's own explanation of her popularity - Belfast and the illness. "Her popularity isn't about either as such. It's about the way she handled them both," says Ms Langdon. The jury is still out on Mowlam's role in brokering the Good Friday agreement. Her shrewd deputy, Paul Murphy, now Welsh secretary, has been heard to say "No Mo, no peace process," and her style won many friends in Northern Ireland, especially on the nationalist and republican side of the conflict. The loyalist paramilitaries liked Mo too - she famously risked a visit to the Maze - but Unionists found her too unversed in detail, too green towards the end and too uninhibited for their restrained and uptight culture. She swears more than the average Northern Ireland secretary. Their proof of the pudding was that Blair (or his surrogate Jonathan Powell) took over much of the final negotiation. But so did Dublin's Bertie Ahern, with Bill Clinton in the wings. Unionists have long been spoiled for attention from the big league. Yet, against that, there are echoes of the same complaint from Whitehall, that Mo is too detached, off the case too often, too much - in that deadly phrase - a "loose cannon." That is what people like about Mo, she's so natural that she gets away with things that would have other ministers in hot water. "I've not read the whole article [on the Guardian's poll] because I didn't know I was coming in [to the BBC] until half an hour ago. But I've skimmed it," she cheerfully admitted this week on the World at One. She went on to admit that the government's position was "far from good" but not bad for mid-term. "We are listening, but people do not perceive that we are." Candid to a fault. At present she seems to feel under-valued and is letting it be known in a Mo-ish way. "It's a strategy that is badly backfiring at a political level, if not at a public level," says a ministerial critic. "She seems to have acquired a touch of martyr's syndrome in Northern Ireland, some of its victim psychosis." That is not Blair's view, nor that of most Labour MPs. As usual Mo defies categorisation. One junior minister this week predicted that she would take over from Chris Smith to become the next minister for culture, media and sports. That is mere speculation, but not stupid. Blair wants to harness her distinctive talents. In culture, media and sport they are more accustomed than the average Orange Lodge to extroverts with a weakness for cheerful profanity.

fields.headline: Burning ambition doomed to failure
fields.trailText: There's a new technology buzz-word - burn rate. It is shorthand for the speed with which internet companies consume cash resources. The word on the street is that burn rates are so high that many dot.coms are close to financial exhaustion.
fields.body:
There's a new technology buzz-word - burn rate. It is shorthand for the speed with which internet companies consume cash resources. The word on the street is that burn rates are so high that many dot.coms are close to financial exhaustion.

In this ever shrinking financial world, investment obsessions transfer swiftly from fashion-setting America to the rest of the globe. Only weeks ago US tech stocks were rocked by an article in Barrons, the Wall Street publication, containing alarming projections about the shrinking cash resources of many leading net stocks. Similar doom-mongering is now all the rage in Europe.

The obsession with burn rates is understandable. This week Boo.com became Britain's first high-profile tech flop. Like Icarus flying too close to the sun, Boo.com's catwalk-quality young management team overreached itself and its financial wings melted.

Boo.com's burnout is no ordinary tale of ambition thwarted. The online sportswear retailer threw a reported £80m of venture capital funding at the market "opportunity" in just over a year. At shutdown, its burn rate was about $1m a week, more than its monthly revenue.

However great the company's starting cash pile, it is questionable whether it could ever have turned in a positive cash flow. Its technological performance was poor, partly because its plans were far too ambitious - a state-of-the-art web platform beyond the means of most customers' PCs and a simultaneous launch in a variety of countries and languages.

Who, one might ask, trusts so much money to such young and inexperienced executives? Boo.com's backers contained a mix of the wealthy and the powerful, from investment bank JP Morgan to the Benetton family. In retrospect they are sure to question their original investment decisions, but it should be remembered that Boo.com is likely to have been but one investment in large dot.com portfolios.

Perhaps Boo.com could have made it under different circumstances. The collapse of technology stocks in recent weeks has, however, shrivelled the appetite of investors for net stocks. The mesh through which investors sieve tech opportunities is now ultra fine. At the turn of the year there was barely a filter to be seen.

It is not surprising to hear the gloomy predictions of analysts modelling the burn rates of quoted net stocks. The vast majority of these companies are, after all, start-ups. Investors expect them to build viable businesses a few years out. By their nature such start-ups are expensive - building platforms, "buying" customers - and require the coffers to be replenished repeatedly.

This is all very well while investors remain "on message". The need for second round, third round and subsequent fundraisings was clear in prospectuses. But now there must be severe doubt about the ability of even the soundest dot.coms to top up their finances in their dash for growth.

Somehow the collective faith of investors in the financial miracle of the web must be restored. Only time will tell whether even the best internet ventures can be transformed into profitable businesses that reward founding investors. In the meantime, the financial world has to believe that they can, otherwise there is no room at all for quoted dot.coms.

The number of new internet flotations has slowed dramatically. Those that are creeping to market are often pricing their equity well below original expectations. E-tailers are just about unfloatable under any circumstances. B2B ventures have more chance of success, but only if they have demonstrable products generating demonstrable revenues.

Unless investor appetite recovers, or alternative sources of finance are discovered, the entrepreneurial drive behind the development of web commerce could be crushed. Much depends on the ability of bricks-and-mortar businesses to take the gilded tech butterflies in hand without crushing them in their fists.

There is clearly lots of room within traditional businesses for pioneering techies. The long term winners in e-tailing, for example, should be the high street retailers with brand awareness and high levels of customer trust.

Such traditional businesses must be wrestling with "build or buy" decisions. The fall in tech shares and the closure of the funding door by investors should encourage many companies to acquire capability wholesale rather than building brick by brick.

The good news is that there are many possible bricks-and-mortar buyers of dot.coms. It may be that the grey-beards rather than the gel generation are the ultimate winners.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharpe Securities

webTitle: East Timor refugees swept away in floods

fields.headline: East Timor refugees swept away in floods
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Scores of people have died and tens of thousands have lost their homes in floods sweeping along the border between Indonesian West Timor and independent East Timor.
fields.body:
Scores of people have died and tens of thousands have lost their homes in floods sweeping along the border between Indonesian West Timor and independent East Timor.

Hundreds of people are still missing and rescuers who flew over the area for the first time yesterday said they saw people clinging to trees and rooftops and groups sheltering on small patches of high ground as muddy water more than two metres deeps swirled for mile after mile, sweeping away access roads.

Staff coordinating relief efforts at the local government office in Atambua, a hill town 20 miles north of the flooded area, confirmed 81 bodies had been found. Local media reports said the death toll was at least 140.

The vast majority of the victims found so far are East Timorese women and children who were living in squalid refugee camps in the West Malaka sub-district of West Timor when the floods began on Tuesday. Local authorities are blaming a combination of prolonged monsoon season rains and a tidal surge caused by the full moon for the scale of the disaster.

"We still have no idea how many people have died," said Tunggul Madyetono, one of the rescue coordinators in Atambua. "People are describing how their relatives were washed out to sea. In some areas the water is still rising so it will be several days before we get a clear picture of what has happened.

"Many people have not eaten properly for three days so they are starting to eat the carcasses of their dead livestock. Rain is forecast for tonight. If it does rain heavily then the situation will get much worse."

Initial assessments suggest more than 20,000 people have lost their homes and that at least another 50,000 have been affected by the flood. Thousands of tonnes of recently harvested crops have also been destroyed.

webTitle: Barman! A plate of your best haute cuisine, please

fields.headline: Barman! A plate of your best haute cuisine, please
fields.trailText: Welsh people are sensitive | Virgin on the oppressive
fields.body:
After all my moaning about what's awful in this country, a thick new book plops on to my desk - Roger Protz's Britain's 500 Best Pubs. Protz makes the point that the unsung revolution in pubs is the food - "no longer synonymous with stale sandwiches, packet soup, instant whipped potatoes and vegetarian lasagne. Marvellous food is now being served the length of the land."

He's right; country pubs are leading the way. The other day in one of his choices, the Dundas Arms in Berkshire, I had hot smoked salmon with Jersey royals and courgette cream which would have been the speciality in any West End restaurant, but at twice the price.

But it's not just the food. Bit by bit, muzak and juke boxes are disappearing. Three or four real ales are often available. Children are increasingly welcome anywhere in the pub. Most amazing, some car parks are being grassed over to make beer gardens, with rickety tables and umbrellas that collapse on to your drink. It's not all perfect.

Possibly the tough drink driving laws mean that people can't go to country pubs to get wellied, and are happy to spend the money on good food instead. Either way, we all benefit.

 Gosh, Welsh people are sensitive. I didn't say last week that the language is only used to abuse English tourists covertly, merely that it does happen. As it did to my friend, bilingual Tim Jones of the Times. He took an English friend to a north Wales pub where they played darts with the locals, who were smiling and friendly. But, in Welsh, they were crude and offensive about the visitors. After the game, Tim thanked them warmly in English, then let rip with a tirade of abuse in perfect Welsh. It must have been a hugely satisfying moment.

And the late, much lamented, John Harrison, who was BBC correspondent in South Africa, had a Greek mother. He once held a birthday party in a Greek restaurant in London, and the evening ended with traditional plate-smashing. He was appalled to see that they had charged him £1 a plate - a fortune then - on the bill. After a blast of Greek which would have brought a blush to the cheek of a Piraeus docker, they cut it down to 10p a plate.

Reader Mark Williamson of Milton Keynes sends an extract from Alan Garner's memoirs, The Voice That Thunders. Garner was a classicist at school and on a trip he and his friends stopped at a shop in Tomen-y-Mur. The customers immediately switched from English to Welsh. "Our form master then asked us, in Greek, what we wanted to buy. So, for possibly the first time in Wales, a shopping list was drawn up in Attic Greek, to total silence from the other customers. Then to add insult to injury, the master conveyed the requirements to the shopkeeper in fluent Welsh."

 The other day I went to some big launch, backed by the prime minister, to persuade young persons to become entrepreneurs. There in the audience, smiling happily, was our own most famous entrepreneur, Sir Richard Branson. That very day the Guardian carried a report that Branson had been forced to apologise for sending threatening lawyers' letters to Australian firms called Virgin, which had had the temerity to wish to carry on trading under their old names even after Sir Richard had launched his internal airline, Virgin Blue. Outrageous behaviour! I gather the Catholic Church still talks about the Virgin Mary: stiff missive on its way from Sir Richard there.

Meanwhile, Roger Virgin phones from Wales. He is a carpenter who has been trading as Virgin Building Services for 20 years. Such impudence was naturally rewarded by another bullying letter. Sir Richard assured me that the matter had been settled, but Roger Virgin is angry because so far he hasn't received any apology, either for the ludicrous letter, or for their derogatory implication that his building firm was on a level with Virgin services, eg their trains. Next month he is off on a bike ride from St Malo to Nantes, in aid of the NSPCC. It would be appropriate if Sir Richard sponsored him very generously. If he does I shall be happy to record the fact.

 Congratulations to the BBC for declining to show live the Queen Mother's birthday celebrations. It's largely a corporate stunt, and if anyone cares they can watch it on ITV. (Did you know that, although the BBC wiped almost all the tapes of the sensationally funny Dud 'n' Pete show, Not Only But Also, they have every single Trooping Of The Colour preserved - a treasured memento of what?)

But the royals have largely lost the plot. In early 1995 I ran a story in the Observer saying that Prince Charles did not actually want to inherit the throne; the thought filled him with depression. Naturally the palace angrily denied this. But then, reading the memoirs of Lord Goodman's confidante David Selbourne this week, I saw that the lawyer reported in 1992: "He doesn't appear to want to be king, as far as I could gather." Like New Labour, our monarchy seems to have lost the vital distinction between the truth and what they want to see in the papers.

webTitle: Hague looks to revival of party's Scots prospects

fields.headline: Hague looks to revival of party's Scots prospects
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague believes the Conservatives can claw back at least 10 seats in Scotland at the next general election, reversing the wipeout of the party north of the border in May, 1997.
fields.body:
William Hague believes the Conservatives can claw back at least 10 seats in Scotland at the next general election, reversing the wipeout of the party north of the border in May, 1997.

Buoyed by recent opinion polls suggesting the gap between the Tories and Labour has closed to just seven points, Tory strategists are for the first time since the last general election daring to put a figure on the scale of potential gains.

Mr Hague yesterday said he expected to see MPs from his party returned to office in Scotland because of the Tories' stance over the scrapping of the pound.

Launching the Scottish leg of his party's UK-wide keep the pound campaign in Edinburgh, he claimed economic and monetary union might transfer more power to Brussels and Frankfurt than devolution had given to Edinburgh.

Suggesting that keeping the pound was "the settled will" of the Scottish people, he said: "Only the Scottish Conservatives will offer the people of Scotland what most of them want on this issue at the next election - and we confidently expect this will be one of the policies that will see Scottish Conservative MPs returned when that day comes."

One party source said: "At the 1992 election, the Tories went up, against most expectations, from 10 to 11 seats in Scotland, before losing them in 1997. William believes there are clearly a minimum of ten winnable seats. Though people say Scotland is a Labour fiefdom, there is a strong Tory tradition."

Tories believe they can cash in on voter discontent with the Scottish parliament, claiming they will be the "only firmly unionist party" at the next election. However, they may find that a tricky card to play, since they have accepted devolution in Scotland and Wales.

There may also be flaws in Mr Hague's argument that Scots will also welcome the Conservatives' newly toughened stance on law and order and asylum.

While Scotish Tories have clawed back a measure of political credibility under the leadership of David McLetchie and the stewardship of Sir Malcolm Rifkind, they have done so under a voter-friendly, moderate banner.

Earlier this month, Sir Malcolm publicly urged Mr Hague to follow the example of the Scottish Tories and adopt a more "moderate rhetoric".

Mr Hague said yesterday that he worked very closely with Mr McLetchie and Sir Malcolm. "We are a party now appealing to people who have previously voted for other parties. The Scottish Conservatives have given robust support to everything I have said about asylum seekers and about crime. We are standing up for the majority.

"We are also, in the coming months, going to set out what we believe on health, education, transport and the environment. We will be addressing all of these issues as well. We have seen some success in Scotland in doing that and we intend to do it in the rest of the UK."

Later, Mr Hague had to cut short a walkabout in central Edinburgh when he was heckover his policy on asylum seekers. At one point a member of Mr Hague's group became involved in a minor scuffle with one protester, who tried to get near the Tory leader, and Mr Hague was forced to seek refuge in the party's Princes Street headquarters.

Earlier, the nationalist group, Scots Asians for Independence, accused Mr Hague of pursuing "skinhead" policies.

webTitle: Bush seizes the vital centre ground

fields.headline: Bush seizes the vital centre ground
fields.standfirst:
Murmurs of discontent rise from the Democratic camp as Gore loses favour among key voters

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Supporters of Vice-president Al Gore are increasingly worried that their man is losing the initiative in this year's US presidential election to his Republican rival, George W Bush.
fields.body:
Supporters of Vice-president Al Gore are increasingly worried that their man is losing the initiative in this year's US presidential election to his Republican rival, George W Bush.

They believe Mr Bush has re-established himself in the centre-ground of the American electorate after a lurch to the right during the primary battle with John McCain. They also fear that Mr Gore remains too closely associated with Democratic party interest groups to earn victory in November.

"I'm quite worried. Governor Bush has seized the mantle of centrist reform which Bill Clinton wore in 1992 and 1996," said one senior source.

Mr Bush's strong showing in recent polls was again underscored in a survey this week by the New York Times; the poll gave Mr Bush an eight-point lead over Mr Gore, compared with a two-point lead last month, while a clear majority of Americans now expect Mr Bush to succeed Mr Clinton.

The poll confirmed a clear shift in the political fortunes of the two presidential candidates during the past two months. When the presidential primary season came to an end in March, Mr Gore seemed to be moving ahead in the polls, sparking confidence among Democrats that they were on course to retain control of the White House.

Yet the Gore campaign has slipped badly of late. In this week's poll, Mr Bush led Mr Gore by 47% to 39%, with 52% believing that the Republican candidate will be elected president, compared with only 29% for his rival.

A succession of other polls have also shown Mr Bush in the lead. Since March, Mr Bush has widened his lead in almost every survey and has regained the advantage among groups of voters who were central to Mr Clinton's success in 1992 and 1996. He is now the leader among Catholics, independents, north-easterners and, most dramatically, among women.

Mr Bush led by 50% to 36% among men in the latest poll, and by 44% to 42% among women. His lead among women is particularly significant because Mr Clinton carried the female vote by a margin of 16% in 1996. Mr Bush also leads by 14 points among married women with children, a group which is often cited as the key to victory in modern presidential elections.

"It is moving Governor Bush's way on many fronts. Bush seems to be more in tune with the electorate than Gore," Professor Thomas Patterson of Harvard University said after the results of the poll were announced.

Two key factors have combined to make the early summer months fruitful for Mr Bush. First, he has assiduously rebuilt his strength in the political centre-ground by pushing a series of "compassionate conservative" policies. Mr Gore, on the other hand, has stumbled once again and has appeared to lose direction.

Alarm about Mr Gore's performance is particularly strong among the "new Democrats" who support Mr Clinton and his "third-way" political programme. These Democrats believe Mr Gore has mistakenly followed an orthodox Democratic strategy of appealing to organised labour and the traditional coalition of party interest groups, which has allowed Mr Bush to capture the "vital centre".

"Bush is reshaping the image of his party by his consistent and deliberate embrace of Bill Clinton's strategy," said one prominent New Democrat insider. "It is very canny and very effective, and Al Gore has allowed it to happen."

Mr Gore's critics charge that Mr Bush has succeeded in taking the initiative on benefit entitlements and on global trade issues, while ridding his party of its "anti-government" reputation, whereas the vice-president has been too ready to tailor his campaign to party interest groups.

The good news for Mr Gore is that, even though he trails in the head-to-head race with Mr Bush, the voters still seem to prefer the vice-president's stance on the campaign's main issues. By 47% to 39%, voters prefer Mr Gore on the social security pension system, despite Mr Bush's detailed policy speech on that matter this week. Mr Gore also leads by six points on education.

The Democratic candidate can also console himself with the fact that he is doing better now than he was at the end of 1999, before the start of the primary season, when Mr Bush routinely led him by double-figure margins.

"We've made up a lot of ground with George Bush. I'm not worried about George Bush at this point," the Gore campaign chairman, Tony Coelho, said.

Nevertheless, discontent within the Gore camp appears to be growing. Much of the criticism centres upon their candidate's abrupt switch of policy in March in favour of granting permanent-residency status to the Cuban boy Elian Gonzalez, a move which was widely seen as an opportunistic quest for votes in Florida.

"It is still a very close race," said Gore campaign strategist Carter Eskew. "In terms of what Bush is doing, there's some good camouflage going on. But eventually voters will see through it."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was not a day for the faint hearted yesterday as the blue chip index suffered its second biggest fall of the year and the Techmark slumped to its lowest level this year.
fields.body:
It was not a day for the faint hearted yesterday as the blue chip index suffered its second biggest fall of the year and the Techmark slumped to its lowest level this year.

The 3% fall in the FTSE 100 to 6045, which wiped £41bn off the value of the stock market, looked minor in comparison with the 9% slide in the Techmark, which ended a brutal day at 3,083, a level last visited on December 1.

The day after the high-profile internet shopping firm Boo.com called in the receivers, dealers said that a profits warning from IT group Parity did little to boost sentiment. The group lost almost a quarter of its stock market value to end 47p lower at 162p, but above its worst level of 140p.

Other technology stocks felt the pain, including Baltimore,which fell 70p to 419p, ARM Holdings, down 70.5p to 615.5p, and Logica, which ended at £14.06, down 249p.

Anxiety fed through to the telecoms sector, where British Telecom lost 41p to 881p and Cable & Wireless fell 46p to 987p. It was an an unfortunate day for Marconi to issue its maiden set of results as a telecoms supplier, its shares sliding 111.5p to 765.5p.

Media groups were not unscathed. Daily Mail & General Trust slumped 64p to 882p while Pearson lost 239p to £18.84.

Most of the stocks that managed to cling on to gains were from the "old economy", including drinks group Diageo, up 17.5p to 546.75p, and rat-catcher Rentokil Initial, 4% higher at 140.25p, a 3.75p gain.

Outside the FTSE 100, Scottish & Newcastle was 6% higher at 549.5p, while Provident Financial led the FTSE 250 index with a rise of 53p to 703p after being tipped by a broker.

Among the smaller stocks, one the biggest climbers was Country Gardens, the garden centre group, which admitted it had received a takeover approach from its rivals Wyevale Garden Centres. As a result Country Gardens, which said it was considered the offer along with other options, was 24% up at 256.5p. Predator Wyevale was little moved at 490p, down 0.5p.

It was a sorry day for Glenchewton, a household goods distributor, after an attempted reverse takeover failed. Returning to the market for the first time since March 9, the shares immediately halved in value to 65.5p.

webTitle: Trimble hits campaign trail in make-or-break week for deal

fields.headline: Trimble hits campaign trail in make-or-break week for deal
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, will visit all 18 constituencies in Northern Ireland to sell a return to government with Sinn Fein this month on the back of the IRA's offer on weapons.
fields.body:
David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, will visit all 18 constituencies in Northern Ireland to sell a return to government with Sinn Fein this month on the back of the IRA's offer on weapons.

He will go head to head with his chief rival, Jeffrey Donaldson, MP for Lagan Valley, in a series of interviews next week as unionism reaches its defining moment. Whatever the result, there could be a party split.

Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, after giving a series of interviews backing Mr Trimble, is now expected to take a back seat. Some Ulster Unionist supporters of the Good Friday agreement believe any concerted contribution from him could prove counter-productive.

They recall the adverse impact regular interventions from the government had on Ulster Unionists during the referendum campaign two years ago. They also point to Mr Mandelson's low popularity rating.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, said the week-long campaign would determine whether the agreement would "live or die". His party will keep a low profile to leave the pitch clear for Mr Trimble.

His Ulster Unionist council had been scheduled to meet today to vote on a return to devolution. But Mr Trimble, after deciding to recommend that move only on Thursday, decided to delay it for a week to allow him to mount a concerted campaign.

Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist party, who called on Ulster Unionists to vote against a return to government, labelled Mr Trimble as chief salesman for the IRA. He refused to say whether his party would again take up its ministerial positions.

Mr Trimble's team is taking a pugnacious approach. It wants to emphasise progress on retention of the RUC name and on the issue of flags over government buildings in the 12 days following the Hillsborough Castle proposals.

The team says the IRA's offer, to put arms completely and verifiably beyond use and to allow outside inspectors regularly to visit some of its dumps, could never have been achieved without the pressure it applied. It believes it is now time to put the IRA to the test again.

Mr Trimble knew that to try to win over the 860 members of the council with just one day's campaigning would be impossible, with the well-organised anti-agreement camp believing it had 60% of the vote. The week's delay puts distance between his doubts and the vote.

Sir Reg Empey, chief negotiator of the Ulster Unionists, and enterprise minister in the suspended executive, outlined another key aspect. He warned the failure to implement the agreement would lead to joint-rule.

John Taylor, UUP deputy leader, said he was unable to back Mr Trimble as matters stood. He was hoping for further concessions on the RUC, although he indicated he was satisfied the flags issue had been settled.

Mr Trimble denied he would adopt a "back-me-or-sack-me" approach, believing that it would antagonise delegates. But he admitted his political future was on the line.

Mr Mandelson said: "It's make or break week for Northern Ireland. The choice for the Ulster Unionist council will determine its politics, stability, and also its economic prosperity for a long time.

"David Trimble has achieved what unionists have been demanding for a decade. He has had considerable success. He deserves the support of his party."

fields.headline: Stamp of authority
fields.standfirst: The Royal Mail
fields.trailText: As the Titanic began to sink, two Post Office employees were seen hauling sacks of letters to the upper decks in the forlorn hope of finding space in a lifeboat for them.
fields.body:
As the Titanic began to sink, two Post Office employees were seen hauling sacks of letters to the upper decks in the forlorn hope of finding space in a lifeboat for them.

Their action was in line with the tradition that the mail had to get through at all costs. But the sorters, and their 9m letters, went down with the ship.

The tradition had been built up over more than four centuries. In England, the Royal Mail, which is considering changing its brand name for overseas services, can trace its ancestry back to 1516 when Sir Brian Tuke was appointed by Henry VIII as master of the posts.

His job was to see that the royal mail - and the king himself - travelled safely to their destinations. Charles I turned the Royal Mail into a public service in 1635 to offset the cost to the royal purse. Letter charges were based on the number of pages and the distance to the delivery point. It would have been a junk mailer's paradise since the recipient, not the sender, paid the postage.

After the English civil war, the Royal Mail became the responsibility of the General Post Office, set up by act of parliament in 1660.

The service was greatly improved in the late 18th century when lightweight mail coaches replaced the old stagecoaches. The mail coaches were fast, travelled at night, and ran to a timetable. They carried guards to deal with highwaymen. The horses were changed every 10 miles.

The coaches were to be replaced by an even greater technological advance, the railway. The first mail carried by train was in 1830 - from Manchester to Liverpool. The first travelling sorting office was a converted horse box on the train between Birmingham and Warrington, and within 20 years mail coaches had disappeared from the roads.

The Royal Mail's biggest revolution was triggered by the publication in 1837 of a pamphlet entitled Post Office reform: its importance and practicability. It was the work of a little known radical, Rowland Hill.

Hill's ideas were the foundation of today's postal system. He proposed a system of uniform rates and pre-paid postage. The penny black, the world's first adhesive postage stamp, was introduced in 1840.

When Hill's secondment from the Treasury came to an end, his political friends created the £1,200-a-year post of secretary to the postmaster-general specially for him.

Anthony Trollope, a clerk at the GPO in London, was sent to Ireland in 1841 as a postal surveyor. During his time there, he reorganised postmen's rounds to make them more efficient and started his career as an author, writing 1,000 words each day before going to work.

Trollope is credited with inventing the pillar box, which first appeared in St Helier, Jersey, in 1852. It was designed by John Vaudin, a local man. The first London boxes in 1855 were rectangular, though the standard red cylindrical design was established by 1859.

The Royal Mail introduced the halfpenny postcard as a cheap alternative to letters in 1870. The parcel post was started in 1883.

The modern Royal Mail handles about 77m letters a day. Sorting the mountain of mail has been helped by the introduction of post codes - first used in Norwich in 1959.

The Royal Mail has survived competition from the electronic media - phone, fax and email - partly as a result of the growth of junk mail. But leaner times are to come. The letter monopoly which it has enjoyed since the 1600s is likely to be reduced or even abolished in the next few years to encourage competition.

Mail will still get through, but the postman delivering it may well be working for a German, Dutch or US post office.

webTitle: Protests fail to halt Tyson bandwagon

fields.headline: Protests fail to halt Tyson bandwagon
fields.standfirst:
Boxing match in national stadium hailed as showpiece for Glasgow

Boxing: special report
fields.trailText: The Mike Tyson bandwagon appeared to be turning into an unstoppable commercial force yesterday, even as protests intensified over the decision to let him fight in Glasgow.
fields.body:
The Mike Tyson bandwagon appeared to be turning into an unstoppable commercial force yesterday, even as protests intensified over the decision to let him fight in Glasgow.

The boxing promoter, Frank Warren, claimed more than 15,000 people had applied for tickets for the bout with Lou Savarese before yesterday's confirmation that it would take place at Hampden Park on June 24.

The Scottish Football Association, defending its decision to allow the use of the national stadium, said the fight would be a showpiece event for Glasgow - a view echoed by one of the city's leading hoteliers.

"For three or four days next month the whole world will be talking about Mike Tyson in Glasgow and watching film from Glasgow," said Klaus Zsilla, general manager of the Hilton hotel, which has a provisional booking for the Tyson entourage. "It is advertising for the city you could not pay for."

Elsewhere, efforts were continuing to try to reverse the decision by the home secretary, Jack Straw, to let the boxer, a convicted rapist, into the UK for the second time. The Scottish National party will call on the Scottish parliament next week to seek a judicial review of the decision.

The SNP leader, Alex Salmond, said the parliament would be within its rights as guardian of the public interest in Scotland to challenge the decision in court. The Scottish executive has already indicated it will not mount a legal challenge, but it is understood that at least one Glasgow rape crisis group is considering court action.

Other women's groups are said to be planning to try to disrupt the fight if it goes ahead. Julie Bindel, of the UK campaign group Justice for Women, which unsuccessfully sought a judicial review of Mr Straw's decision to allow Tyson into the UK last January, said the group would not mount another challenge. But she said: "It is really outrageous that the government can make this decision to let in a convicted rapist at a time when it is holding a sexual offences review with tightening of rape laws right at the heart of it."

Earlier, a spokesman for Downing Street backed Mr Straw's decision. "We deplore violence against women and the government has put in place several initiatives to tackle that problem because it is a very real problem," he said.

"But equally Jack Straw has to reach a judgment in his capacity as home secretary. He has said that in reaching that judgment he has been fair and impartial and set out the reasons for making that judgment. It is not a judgment that is made about Mike Tyson and what he has done. Jack Straw has legal responsibilities under the immigration act and he has to exercise those."

The home secretary is ready to meet concerned MPs, who plan to make their opposition to the decision clear in a Westminster debate on Tuesday.

Mr Warren, meanwhile, said that six facilities in England had expressed interest in hosting the fight, and he claimed that Celtic football club had offered Celtic Park at a discounted rate in an unsuccessful attempt to stage the bout. Celtic has refused to comment.

Mr Warren is confident a crowd in excess of 40,000 can be attracted to Hampden, making it the biggest gate for a boxing promotion in Britain since 1993 when Chris Eubank and Nigel Benn fought a draw at Old Trafford in front of 42,000 spectators.

He said Tyson was "delighted" to have been given the opportunity to return to fight in front of what will be the largest live audience of his career.

"People are entitled to their opinions about Mike, after all we live in a democratic society.

"I don't intend to be his apologist, but there are a lot of people who want to see him fight."

Julie Bindel, of the UK campaign group Justice for Women, which unsuccessfully sought a judicial review of Mr Straw's decision to allow Tyson into the UK last January, said the group would not mount another challenge. But she said: "It is really outrageous that the government can make this decision to let in a convicted rapist at a time when it is holding a sexual offences review with tightening of rape laws right at the heart of it." Earlier, a spokesman for Downing Street backed Mr Straw's decision. "We deplore violence against women and the government has put in place several initiatives to tackle that problem because it is a very real problem," he said. "But equally Jack Straw has to reach a judgment in his capacity as home secretary. He has said that in reaching that judgment he has been fair and impartial and set out the reasons for making that judgment. It is not a judgment that is made about Mike Tyson and what he has done. Jack Straw has legal responsibilities under the immigration act and he has to exercise those." The home secretary is ready to meet concerned MPs, who plan to make their opposition to the decision clear in a Westminster debate on Tuesday. Mr Warren, meanwhile, said that six facilities in England had expressed interest in hosting the fight, and he claimed that Celtic football club had offered Celtic Park at a discounted rate in an unsuccessful attempt to stage the bout. Celtic has refused to comment. Mr Warren is confident a crowd in excess of 40,000 can be attracted to Hampden, making it the biggest gate for a boxing promotion in Britain since 1993 when Chris Eubank and Nigel Benn fought a draw at Old Trafford in front of 42,000 spectators. He said Tyson was "delighted" to have been given the opportunity to return to fight in front of what will be the largest live audience of his career. "People are entitled to their opinions about Mike, after all we live in a democratic society. "I don't intend to be his apologist, but there are a lot of people who want to see him fight."

webTitle: Firm fined £125,000 for shipyard worker's death

fields.headline: Firm fined £125,000 for shipyard worker's death
fields.trailText: The horrific death of a worker known as Mr Shipyard was an accident waiting to happen, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The horrific death of a worker known as Mr Shipyard was an accident waiting to happen, a court heard yesterday.

Andrew McClelland, 57, died instantly after being struck by a fibre rope which snapped as he helped winch a ship into a dry dock on the river Tyne.

Cammell Laird was fined £125,000 at Newcastle crown court after earlier admitting a breach of health and safety regulations.

The winching operation involved ropes being attached to the Atlantic Horizon and pulled in by a crane. The role of Mr McClelland, a father of four from Sunderland was to ensure the ropes did not snag. He had earned his nickname after more than 40 years' service in the region's shipyards.

David Rowland, for the Health and Safety Executive, said the company had allowed a dangerous method of winching ships into dock to be carried out.

"The defendants had not carried out a risk assessment of the operation. This prosecution is based on the fact that the unsafe system of working caused unnecessary strain on the rope and that this was an accident waiting to happen.

"The rope would inevitably snag in the course of the procedure and the operation required employees to stand in a danger zone...

"At the cost of a few hundred pounds the procedure has now been changed and under the new system employees no longer have to stand in the danger area." Press Association

fields.headline: X marks the spot
fields.standfirst: Let the (male) kissing commence
fields.trailText: General de Gaulle, during his exile in wartime London, undoubtedly did a lot of it, sometimes in the blackout. Yet the bobbies left him alone. Eric Cantona probably indulged a bit, too, on both sides of the Pennines. Though he was hauled before the beak for karate-kicking a Crystal Palace fan they never touched him for it.
fields.body:
General de Gaulle, during his exile in wartime London, undoubtedly did a lot of it, sometimes in the blackout. Yet the bobbies left him alone. Eric Cantona probably indulged a bit, too, on both sides of the Pennines. Though he was hauled before the beak for karate-kicking a Crystal Palace fan they never touched him for it. As for what goes on in the Arsenal dressing room and manager's office, mon cher. Just imagine how often Messrs Petit, Wenger and Anelka pucker up and plant their gallic lips on each other's cheeks without a whiff of a prosecution? But just imagine Lee Dixon and Tony Adams at it - the legion of decency, a posse of constables and the Crown Prosecution Service would be on the case as quick as a ball off Hakar Sukur's boot. The French are left alone because they are French, which in itself is a kind of gross indecency.

Still, the predictably hysterical reaction yesterday to the announcement of a long-overdue spring cleaning for the sexual offences laws, including men kissing each other in public, was not about protecting traditional English modesty. It was merely homophobic ... gays will leap upon one another on every corner subverting the public by their tender expressions of intimacy. They won't; so what if they did. Actually, heterosexual male kissing - interpreted broadly as the vague passage of the lips near another man's chops - is becoming common. What is extraordinary is how long it has taken the law to catch up with a culture, which has not always been so prudish. Sir Walter Raleigh did a lot of it without for one moment thinking the next step was to remove his doublet and hose. Prince Charles sealed with a kiss a father's right to embrace his children. It might be going a bit far for Tony Blair to greet, say, John Reid with a sloppy one, but it would be a conforming use to embrace Chris Smith - who is already a happy kisser on public occasions, without frightening the horses.

fields.headline: Frank Blackaby
fields.standfirst: Economist with a passion for world peace and disarmament
fields.trailText: Frank Blackaby, who has died of cancer aged 78, made his mark in two fields - economics and peace research. The influence he had in both is a testament to the passion of his beliefs and his writing, and he demonstrated his high moral sense by being a conscientious objector, working during the war with the Friends Ambulance Service.
fields.body:
Frank Blackaby, who has died of cancer aged 78, made his mark in two fields - economics and peace research. The influence he had in both is a testament to the passion of his beliefs and his writing, and he demonstrated his high moral sense by being a conscientious objector, working during the war with the Friends Ambulance Service.

Brought up within a non-Conformist family, he went to the Perse School, Cambridge. With Cambridge degrees in classics and economics, he began his career as an economist at the Treasury. In 1958, he moved to the London-based National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR), and, between 1963 and 1968, edited its economics review, the first independent contribution to the understanding of the economic situation of the day.

Under Frank's editorship, the review's reputation grew. It made available economic information and analysis to those in business, academia and government. For the first time, Britain had available a systematic view of economic developments and probable trends in global economics.

But Frank believed the review should also describe policy options. In the early 1960s, it put forward devaluation and incomes policy as desirable measures, in opposition to the government's line. The review described the consensus of the institute's team of economists, and Frank's strength as an editor was his ability to lead a group to that consensus.

In 1968, he took a two-year leave of absence from the NIESR and joined the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI), an independent foundation established in 1966 to commemorate that country's 150 years of unbroken peace, and specialising in problems of disarmament and international security. In 1969, SIPRI published its first yearbook, an annual account of world military expenditures, developments in military technology, and efforts to achieve and disarmament.

Frank edited the first two yearbooks, establishing methods for calculating military expenditures at current and constant prices. The first yearbook gives series for military expenditure between 1948 and 1968 for 118 countries. The arms trade section estimates the value of exports of major weapons to third world countries since 1950. These unique registers were a major contribution to issues of arms and arms control. He also led a major research project on the global arms trade.

Frank returned to the NIESR in 1970, producing numerous articles and three books - British Economic Policy 1955-68, De-industrialisation and The Reform Of the Wage Bargaining System. In 1981, he returned to Stockholm as director of SIPRI, a post he held for five years.

During this period, he became increasingly interested in nuclear weapons issues, writing on, for example, the debate about renouncing the first use of nuclear weapons. He argued that the use of weapons that would indiscriminately destroy enemy forces and population and seriously injure the defended people - as well as neutrals not engaged in the conflict - could never be justified.

Frank strongly opposed the expansion of Nato. He pointed out that Russia justifies its need to retain nuclear weapons on the grounds that it has a one-to-three inferiority in conventional weaponry against those of the expanded Nato forces. He believed that, with the end of the cold war, Russia should have been integrated into the European security structure.

After leaving SIPRI, Frank campaigned energetically for nuclear disarmament. In particular, he advocated the negotiation of a treaty abolishing nuclear weapons in timed stages. This he did through the Pugwash conferences on science and world affairs, and as president of Abolition 2000.

At the moment, nuclear disarmament negotiations are moribund. Even though the Start (Strategic Arms Reduction Talks) II Treaty has been ratified, Russia and the United States will still each deploy 3,500 strategic nuclear weapons by the year 2003. The treaty allows both countries to keep large numbers of strategic nuclear warheads in reserve, and does not cover tactical warheads. The best estimate is that there will be at least 11,000 warheads on each side by the year 2003.

Frank still believed that a nuclear-free world is feasible. He thought this the only rational position, against the irrationality of today's huge arsenals, and the risk of their spread or use in terrorism. He argued for worldwide pressure to move in this direction, and more than 2000 organisations have signed on to Abolition 2000's campaign.

Frank's contributions to economics and peace research are noteworthy. A shy man, who would hum during lulls in conversation, he was able by tact and patience to get a diverse group of researchers to work together effectively and develop a consensus. He was a good writer, able to explain complex ideas simply. The nuclear disarmament community can ill afford to lose people of his calibre.

He had one son with his first wife, and two children, a son and a daughter with his second wife, Mary Acland-Hood, who survives him.

fields.headline: Urgent train safety measures unveiled
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: An urgent programme to install removable windows, extra hammers, and escape route lighting in trains over the next year following the Paddington and Southall rail crashes was unveiled yesterday by the Health and Safety Executive.
fields.body:
An urgent programme to install removable windows, extra hammers, and escape route lighting in trains over the next year following the Paddington and Southall rail crashes was unveiled yesterday by the Health and Safety Executive.

The need for immediate action has been pressed at both the public inquiries covering the crashes, and the HSE is looking for swift action by the train operating companies.

It has given the train and station operators until July 24 to reply to its proposals, with the intention of introducing new regulations within a year. For the first time, companies will be charged for inspections to defray a substantial increase in costs for policing the new inspection regime.

In a terse introduction to the proposed regulations, the executive says the "industry could and should do better" on safety and that operators will have a new duty to make sure this is done.

It says suitable instructions to passengers on how to escape and to use escape equipment must be made available and there must be sufficient signs to identify emergency equipment.

At the inquiry into the Paddington crash, when 31 people died and more than 400 were injured, several passengers have commented on the absence of instructions on opening doors in an emergency, but the train operating companies say there are well displayed notices above doors explaining how catches can be released.

The HSE has also suggested that data recorders should be fitted on all trains and drivers' conversations should be noted.

The association of train operating companies, which represents Virgin, Stagecoach, National Express and others, pointed out that data recorders were installed on trains less than 12-years-old. Retro fitting was difficult in older trains because there was insufficient room in the driver's cab.

The association said it would examine the HSE's proposals with great care.

fields.headline: Hand jive
fields.trailText: Yesterday, in a queue of traffic, I saw a 30-something male tapping his hand on his car roof (to the beat of music from within). Rather like the first cuckoo in spring, it told me that summer had definitely arrived.
fields.body:
Yesterday, in a queue of traffic, I saw a 30-something male tapping his hand on his car roof (to the beat of music from within). Rather like the first cuckoo in spring, it told me that summer had definitely arrived.

This pathetic gesture is obviously regarded, by a significant number of men, as some kind of machismo action ("look at me, I'm well 'ard"). Firstly, you don't see any thirtysomething women doing it and, secondly, the instinctive place to tap your hand, in a car, is on the steering wheel.

Therefore, most roof tappers have obviously seen someone else performing the action and perceived it as "the thing to do" in slow traffic. Very pathetic!

Why don't they show everyone how tough they really are by tapping away when the temperature drops below zero?
Patrick Dodd
London

webTitle: The long and short of it

fields.headline: The long and short of it
fields.trailText: Now the government is prepared to take on the puritan lobby (Go-ahead for reform of sex laws, May 19), perhaps it will also amend the 1967 Abortion Act and bring this into the 21st century and into line with most of Europe.
fields.body:
Now the government is prepared to take on the puritan lobby (Go-ahead for reform of sex laws, May 19), perhaps it will also amend the 1967 Abortion Act and bring this into the 21st century and into line with most of Europe. There is limited point in better protecting women from rape if we do not alleviate one of its consequences by cutting the paperwork, foregoing the need for permission from two doctors, and reforming the rigid criteria which govern the availability of legal abortion.
Diane Munday
St Albans
dianemunday@care4free.net

 Denis MacShane MP asks how come my pre-Blairite "giants" managed to get themselves kicked out so often by the voters. He was abroad for part of the period, so perhaps he can be forgiven for not noticing that Harold Wilson won four elections and only lost one. So far, Mr Blair has won only one.
Ian Aitken
London

 Re the long sentences and sexual performance debate (Letters, May 19): George Orwell observed "any fool can write long sentences, a great writer keeps the sentences short". Did he suffer from premature ejaculation?
Paul Wellings
Colchester, Essex

 Daniel, you got it wrong (Letters, May 18). English sex is short. Sorry.
Andy Alaszewski
Hull

 I'm not surprised half the children surveyed thought potatoes grow on trees (Sean French, G2, May 17); 95% of the children I know think money grows on trees as well.
D Smith
Evesham, Worcs

 Why not have a statue to the devil in Trafalgar Square (Letters, May 15)? It could be known as the Plinth of Darkness.
John Reith
London

fields.headline: Women bugged by IT
fields.trailText: Many seemed surprised that the so-called Love Bug virus writer might be a woman (Search on for cybercrime fix, May 16). I think this has nothing to do with the fact that women are not seen as the stereotypical virus writers and more to do with the fact that not enough women are actually working in this sector. Most people simply do not associate women with IT.
fields.body:
Many seemed surprised that the so-called Love Bug virus writer might be a woman (Search on for cybercrime fix, May 16). I think this has nothing to do with the fact that women are not seen as the stereotypical virus writers and more to do with the fact that not enough women are actually working in this sector. Most people simply do not associate women with IT.

A poll of our members' databases of IT contracting staff revealed an average of only 16% of female contractors. The proportion of females on computing degree courses in the UK fell from 24% in 1980 to 10% in 1987 and has levelled at about 12% in 1999. With the continuing skills shortage in the IT arena, surely one way of fixing this problem would be to attract more women into the sector? Most organisations claim to prefer recruiting women into their IT departments given the chance. Yet only 8% of the UK's principal programmers are women.

Despite all the talk about teleworking and flexible working hours, employers seem to be very slow to introduce these measures. They are simply not doing enough to encourage women to make IT their career choice or to entice them back after a career break. The IT industry also needs to invest in training people from other sectors. It must do something now to change its image, and create a long-term, flexible recruitment and employment strategy to become an attractive career of choice for women.
Ann Swain
Chief executive, Association of Technology Staffing Companies

fields.headline: Power move
fields.trailText: Lynne Featherstone (Letters, May 19) criticises the independent Police Complaints Authority for not having the powers we should like to have. The PCA cannot currently institute a complaints investigation. In the case she quotes we had been involved for some time and then took it on for a supervised inquiry.
fields.body:
Lynne Featherstone (Letters, May 19) criticises the independent Police Complaints Authority for not having the powers we should like to have. The PCA cannot currently institute a complaints investigation. In the case she quotes we had been involved for some time and then took it on for a supervised inquiry.

Ms Featherstone criticises the lack of information given out at the end of an investigation. We endeavour to explain the outcome of cases and the reasoning behind our decisions fully. Since 1988 we have been calling for greater openness in the complaints system and removal of the law that restricts what we may disclose. Hopefully the reformed system will give the PCA these much-needed powers.
Molly Meacher
Deputy chair, Police Complaints Authority

webTitle: Now I know what it's like to be reshuffled, says Oakley

fields.headline: Now I know what it's like to be reshuffled, says Oakley
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC's political editor, Robin Oakley, has laid bare his dismay at being replaced earlier than expected, comparing himself to a "dumped" minister shunned by former colleagues.
fields.body:
The BBC's political editor, Robin Oakley, has laid bare his dismay at being replaced earlier than expected, comparing himself to a "dumped" minister shunned by former colleagues.

Mr Oakley, who had intended to cover the coming general election before falling victim to a BBC "reshuffle", said yesterday: "I shall look upon the next government reshuffle, when it comes, from a new perspective.

"When your own boss has called you in to say 'Splendid work these eight years, old chap, but I need your position for a younger man', and the whole affair has been trampled over for days by the media ... it does induce a little more sympathy for ministerial victims than we political journalists generally tend to show.

"Like dumped ministers, I have encountered the phenomenon of embarrassed contacts and colleagues deliberately failing to catch your eye or busying themselves with their papers until you are safely past.

"And no doubt like them I have been heartened by the warmth of messages from true friends and from people I never thought knew me that well."

Mr Oakley, who will be replaced this summer by the Observer and Daily Express columnist Andrew Marr, 40, spoke out at length for the first time about his removal in the parliamentary magazine, The House.

News this week that he would be replaced in the post he has held since 1992 caught television insiders by surprise.

Mr Oakley, a former political editor of the Daily Mail and the Times, who intended to retire at 60, also used his interview in The House to take a swipe at media coverage of his replacement.

"Oakley replaced by Marr was not much of a story (except to me, Mrs Oakley, and my bank manager) so it had to be spiced up as a plot.

"Somehow they had to sustain the idea that Andrew, an independent-minded and rational journalist of proven quality, was Downing Street's candidate. And to make that work, I had to be presented as some kind of Tory creature, never mind that I had spent eight years doing a totally impartial job at the Beeb in a way which had my family complaining that they couldn't even get an opinion out of me on what film to go to without an 'On the one hand ... and on the other'."

Mr Oakley also said he had learned lessons from being the reported rather than the reporter. "Nobody I spoke to used all my quotes accurately," he complained.

"Most reflected the general sense reasonably enough but either filled in the gaps in their shorthand with guesses, or felt the need to spice up my words to improve the story."

His advice to his successor was to get as much technical training as he can. He himself had only a week. After a few days on air, he was told he looked both nervous and haughty on camera.

It turned out he had been looking at the little red light on top of the camera, rather than directly into the lens. "Nobody had even thought to tell me where I should look."

And his message to Andrew Marr: "Have fun. Oh, and do try to go home occasionally. The working day is 12 hours, going on 15. But then that's what some ministers work too, before they get reshuffled."

fields.headline: Wakeham is wrong again
fields.trailText: Lord Wakeham is wrong yet again (Letters, May 19). The Press Complaints Commission is an ineffective body which does journalism no favours.
fields.body:
Lord Wakeham is wrong yet again (Letters, May 19). The Press Complaints Commission is an ineffective body which does journalism no favours. For example, it insists that people must complain before it is prepared to investigate a breach of its code of conduct, no matter how blatant - or how important - any breach may be. That means a newspaper can go out on a limb with unproven allegations, and, if those involved do not complain and/or have the funds to seek legal redress, the paper gets away with it. The less-responsible editor might think that worth a few sleepless nights.

Nor does the PCC make much positive attempt to encourage complaints. All too many people see it as the paid-for defender of the newspaper industry and not an independent watchdog that will inhibit a prurient press.Those in the public eye know that a complaint will not only drag them over the coals for a second time, but also make them targets for future press intrusion.

When Lord Wakeham departs from the commission, it is to be hoped that his successor will restore a much-needed robustness to its policing role.

Jock Gallagher, Former executive director, Association of British Editors
info@broadv.u-net.com

 Lord Wakeham's patronising response to my criticism ascribes to me views I don't hold and then tries to deflate them with his customary weasel words. Why doesn't he answer the major charge: people with legitimate cause ignore the PCC because they regard it as a toothless watchdog; celebrities refrain from using it because of the necessity of republishing their original complaint. There have to be other answers.

Gerald Isaaman, London

webTitle: Justice in sight for Guatemalan victims

fields.headline: Justice in sight for Guatemalan victims
fields.standfirst: Massacre charges test the will of the populist new government
fields.trailText: Posters of wanted men and escaped prisoners are not uncommon in Guatemala, but one which has just appeared carries a special frisson. The wanted men are no less than a former president, a former minister of defence and a former chief of staff of the armed forces. The offences they are wanted for are "crimes against humanity and war crimes" carried out during the 36-year civil war which ended with a peace treaty in 1996.
fields.body:
Posters of wanted men and escaped prisoners are not uncommon in Guatemala, but one which has just appeared carries a special frisson. The wanted men are no less than a former president, a former minister of defence and a former chief of staff of the armed forces. The offences they are wanted for are "crimes against humanity and war crimes" carried out during the 36-year civil war which ended with a peace treaty in 1996.

Formal charges against the three men alleged to have been responsible for some of the worst massacres of the war were made this month, shortly after the Nobel peace laureate Rigoberta Menchu lodged accusations in Spain against the former dictator and current speaker of the assembly Efrain Rios Montt and six other political or military leaders.

Next month the trial is due to begin of five people accused of complicity in the murder in 1998 of the Roman Catholic bishop Juan Gerardi, two days after he presented the church's report on the atrocities, entitled Never Again.

The charges have special resonance in Latin America, after the Pinochet case. They will be seen as a test of Alfonso Portillo's populist law-and-order FRG (Guatemalan Republican Front) government, elected in January.

The accusations against former president Romeo Lucas Garcia, former chief of staff Benedicto Lucas Garcia, and former defence minister Luis Rene Mendoza Palomo relate to 10 massacres of indigenous people, involving 800 lives, which occurred during the "scorched earth" military policies of 1981-82.

They happened in Mayan villages suspected of giving support to the anti-government guerrillas, and were of shocking brutality. In one, a woman was disembowelled, the foetus of her child removed and the head of a dead villager placed in her belly. In another village, the women were ordered to cook the soldiers' meals and then slaughtered by them.

Unarmed villagers were tortured, garrotted, hanged, beheaded and shot. The women, including the mentally ill, were routinely raped. Small children were killed and the villages set on fire, often with villagers still inside their homes.

The ground is prepared

The case was prepared by the the Centre for Legal Action on Human Rights, which was set up to bring human rights violations to court. It has worked for three years with an umbrella group of surviving victims of the massacres.

The next stage is for the public prosecutor's office to take on the investigation. The centre has done its work so that there can be no claim that there is insufficient evidence to proceed, and it will act as co-prosecutors when the case goes to trial.

The centre's legal director, Paul Seils, a former Glasgow lawyer, said two investigations were made into the periods of greatest slaughter in the civil war, in which an estimated 100,000 to 200,000 people died, about 1.5% of the population. He said the centre was conscious of the difficulty of bringing such a case, but believed that it had many purposes.

"Even if they cannot finally be prosecuted, we have to expose that in order to change the system," he said

"As an institute, our role is not only to defend human rights but to have a responsible attitude to strengthening the rule of law, whether by exposing the frailty of the system or by pursuing the prosecutions of people who have broken the law."

It was important, he said, for justice to be pursued in Guatemala, for if it was carried out elsewhere many of the victims would not know it was happening, since the indigenous Mayan population is largely illiterate and most do not speak Spanish.

"This is a serious question about recon ciliation, and for those communities to feel a part of a new Guatemala they have to feel that the people they lost are valued and their right to justice is also valued," he said. "It's not about vengeance, it's about reconciliation."

The Menchu action

Realistically, the former president Romeo Lucas Garcia is unlikely to be tried, since he is reported to be suffering from Alzheimer's disease, and is in Venezuela. The other two could face their accusers, however, if the political will is there and international pressure is applied. If convicted, they could be jailed for 20 to 30 years.

In a separate move, Ms Menchu has begun an action for genocide against Mr Rios Montt in the Spanish courts. Her action, which implicates six other military and civilian leaders, is also concerned with events in the early 80s, including a military assault on the Spanish embassy in which 37 people, including her father, died, and with the murder of four Spanish priests. The Spanish courts are investigating the charges, as they did those against General Pinochet.

The response from those accused in Guatemala has been swift. General Oscar Mejia Victores, a former military dictator, has counter-accused Ms Menchu with treason, alleging that she has violated the constitution by taking the case to Spain. "Death to Menchu" graffiti have appeared in the city.

"There have been death threats against myself," said Claudia Samayoa, director of the Rigoberta Menchu Foundation. She said that, whatever the final outcome of the case, those who had lost relatives in the massacres were pleased that the accusations had been made.

"Some are saying, 'I don't care if he goes to jail, it's enough that he is accused'."

"We are threatened every day that if we touch their sector we will surely be killed," Ms Menchu said. "I hope that this is a thing of the past."

Mr Rios Montt has already changed his travel plans because of the accusations, cancelling a proposed trip to Paris, although he claimed that this was because he found Guatemala "prettier" in the spring.

He told reporters: "I fear only God." He refused the Guardian an interview.

The man of peace

The third case involves someone who did indeed hope that such killing was a thing of the past. In April 1998 Bishop Gerardi made a speech in the cathedral as he introduced the publication of the church's Never Again report, which found the military responsible for more than 90% of the atrocities committed in the civil war.

"Peace is possible," he said, "a peace that is born from the truth. It is a painful truth, full of memories of the country's deep and bloody wounds."

Two days later the 75-year-old Gerardi was bludgeoned to death as he got out of his car to enter his home beside San Sebastian church.

Now five people have been charged in connection with his murder: three men with military connections who are accused of the killing and a priest and a cook who are accused of complicity.

There are grounds for believing that this case may very well come to trial. One member of the current government is Edgar Gutierrez, a respected human rights worker whom Mr Portillo coopted into the role of adviser on international affairs. Mr Gutierrez was a personal friend of the murdered bishop and he has made it clear that he will do everything he can to ensure that justice is done.

Last Friday a group of Mayan women entered the cathedral for a special mass. Each carried a blown-up studio portrait of a son or daughter. The Mothers of the Disappeared sat beneath the vast oil painting of the Ascension of Christ and listened as a Ladino (of Spanish ancestry) priest told of the resurrection.

At the end of the mass they placed quetzal coins, minted to celebrate the peace process, into the collection box.

Each photo carried the question "Donde estan?" (Where are they?)

The legal processes that are moving slowly forward may not give them the answers they seek, but at least they know that, after nearly 20 years, the world may finally hear the question being asked.

fields.headline: Violence is still their goal
fields.trailText: Does David Lacey really believe that football fans still care whether the FA's 2006 World Cup bid is successful or not (Outbreak of English disease close to epidemic, May19)? The only interests served by the staging of the tournament in this country would be those of the FA, clubs and sponsors.
fields.body:
Does David Lacey really believe that football fans still care whether the FA's 2006 World Cup bid is successful or not (Outbreak of English disease close to epidemic, May19)? The only interests served by the staging of the tournament in this country would be those of the FA, clubs and sponsors - the only time the fans become an issue is when the question is raised as to who will stump up for the extortionate ticket prices or when disorder such as that witnessed in Denmark breaks out.

The uglier, battle-scarred face of English football was paraded before the world's media in Copenhagen and the FA's propaganda machine could offer nothing but damage limitation. This in the wake of Istanbul, Rotherham and an alleged cover-up over an incident between two organised hooligan gangs in the Midlands last month. Who could honestly argue that such a scenario would necessarily be so bad in light of what's still going on? Contrary to the perceived view of so-called experts, football violence has never gone away.
Shaun Smith
Mirfield, W Yorks

 As a black season-ticket holder at Highbury, I was deeply troubled by the violence in Copenhagen. Sitting amongst the Premiership's highest number of minority-ethnic supporters, I had naively hoped Wednesday's game would be remembered for footballing reasons. Despite press stories of vengeful Leeds supporters infiltrating proceedings, there has been little coverage of the activities of the Grey Wolves- a Turkish fascist group - or the vast number of ticketless German-based Turks travelling to Denmark for the Final. It is only after these matters are taken into the equation that the battered name of Arsenal can be restored.
James Randolph
London
james_randolph@hotmail.com

 From the BBC to Channel 4 News from the Sun to the Guardian we are made to believe that the football riots in Copenhagen were the result of a badly organised police force, which at one point just stood by and watched while the hooligans were slaughtering each other. The Danish police, the people, ultimately the government should have known better. After all, it was the fact that alcohol was available near the stadium which invited, if not caused, the chaos. Little mention has been made concerning the core of problem: the outrageous behaviour of so-called football fans and the reasons why they do it. What I would like to know about is the background, the deeper root of the problem. What is it in those societies that breed such despicable thugs? A little more analysis would be in place instead of the feverish focus on stab wounds and incompetent policing. One of the reasons why the Danish police was so ill-prepared could be that they are not used to dealing with these kinds of football fans.
Berit Sandberg
Southampton

 We have been once again confronted with the English disease and before investigations have even begun one can hear the familiar soundings of insufficient Danish policing from our quarters. Surely we must realise we can no longer place blame at the door of nations such as Denmark, who rarely experience such violence, and accept our responsibility. While some violence may be mitigated due to circumstance, hooliganism remains entirely devoid of justification and we could do considerably better than accredit it with a passport.
Tom Shelford
Bristol University ts8778@bris.ac.uk

 It is most annoying to note once again that the English press refer to these troublemakers as "British hooligans". They are not. They are English hooligans.
Alan McAllister
Hong Kong
