fields.headline: Blunkett's cash boost
fields.trailText: I understand the frustration of headteachers about capital repairs. But the picture being presented in the open letter (Local heads deal schools blow to Blair, May 18) does not begin to appreciate the huge difference already made by the new deal for schools.
fields.body:
I understand the frustration of headteachers about capital repairs. But the picture being presented in the open letter (Local heads deal schools blow to Blair, May 18) does not begin to appreciate the huge difference already made by the new deal for schools. Far from being a "patchwork", this is part of a systematic drive to get to grips with a 20-year school repairs backlog. Most schools in the country have already had some money. Many have had it to remove temporary classrooms, get rid of outside toilets, repair or replace roofs or build new labs and school buildings.

If it were possible to wave a magic wand and repair every school tomorrow, of course I would do so. We are doing the sort of audit of the repairs backlog which the Tories never dared to do. That's why Durham heads know the extent of the backlog - and it will enable us to plan future capital spending. With the forthcoming comprehensive spending review, schools will have a clear sense of what is available in future years.

Equally, it is untrue to say that we are not enabling schools to budget year after year for teachers' salary increases. This year, the salary increase was 3.3% and inflation was under 2.5%. And on top of an increase in education authority funding of 4.6%, every comprehensive school in Durham is receiving at least £30,000 to spend as they choose.

When we were elected in 1997, schools had just received their third real terms budget cut in a row. Revenue spending had fallen in real terms by £60 a pupil since 1994. We immediately increased planned spending in 1998-99 to avert what would have meant 25,000 teacher job losses. In 1999-2000, spending rose in real terms, and this year alone it has increased after inflation by £180 per pupil - £300 since the election. Capital spending on schools this year is three times that in 1996-97.
David Blunkett
Secretary of State for Education

webTitle: Short urged to reject funding for Chad oil pipeline

fields.headline: Short urged to reject funding for Chad oil pipeline
fields.trailText: A pipeline which will allow the oil reserves of Chad to be exploited by a consortium of oil companies is due to be approved by World Bank directors next week despite the fact that its own confidential report says the plan has a 50% risk of failure.
fields.body:
A pipeline which will allow the oil reserves of Chad to be exploited by a consortium of oil companies is due to be approved by World Bank directors next week despite the fact that its own confidential report says the plan has a 50% risk of failure.

Fears about security, corruption and human rights abuses in Cameroon and Chad, as well as concern that poverty alleviation - the main purpose of funding the pipeline - will not be realised, have been played down in the report to the bank's directors.

The decision by two of the original consortium members, Shell and Elf, to pull out of the project after it was widely criticised by environmental and human rights groups has also been glossed over in the bank's project appraisal.

Clare Short, secretary of state for overseas development and a World Bank governor, is to decide this weekend whether to back the loans for Chad and Cameroon to fund the building of the pipeline. Environmentalists want her to reject the plan but her department said on Thursday that she had not yet read the report.

In a copy of the document passed to The Guardian, it is clear that the main beneficiaries of the bank funding for the 600-mile pipeline from Chad's oil fields to Cameroon's coast will be Exxon, the oil company leading the consortium, and the two new members - Chevron and Petronas.

A conservative estimate of the net revenue for the 28 years the pipeline is expected to be in operation is more than £6bn, less than a quarter of which will go to the two African countries.

The annual £40m revenue for Chad will double the government's income and total almost £1.2bn. Cameroon will get £12m a year.

The bank report says Chad is 164th out of 174 nations in poverty indicators. Oil was found 25 years ago but has not been exploited because of past unrest, an inhospitable investment climate, unfavourable geography, and a dearth of trained staff.

Because of these problems only the bank's support of £350m in loans to the two countries will provide the confidence for the commercial banking sector to stump up the £2bn investment needed for the venture.

The bank's own report says there is a "significant" risk that the project will not reach its objectives - including poverty alleviation. In the bank's jargon, significant risk is classed as a 50% chance of objectives not being reached.

A deterioration in the security situation in Chad, absence of commitment to environmental protection in Chad and Cameroon, and human rights failures are all classed as significant risks. But the financial risks to the oil companies and the World Bank are classed as "low", partly because they have first call on all revenues.

In a letter to Ms Short, Tony Juniper, policy director of Friends of the Earth, said: "This project has the capacity to pose major environmental threats, support corrupt governments who are guilty of human rights abuses and help exacerbate climate change."

He added: "If there is to be long-term coherence between commitments to fight climate change, debt relief and sustainable development policy aimed at poverty eradication, then this project cannot be approved in its present form."

webTitle: Mouse in the house:  Paris's super-chic épicerie plagued

fields.headline: Mouse in the house:  Paris's super-chic épicerie plagued
fields.trailText: One of the smartest areas of Paris - housing, rather embarrassingly, the capital's best-known food shop - has been overrun by a plague of small grey mice, a French newspaper reported yesterday.
fields.body:
One of the smartest areas of Paris - housing, rather embarrassingly, the capital's best-known food shop - has been overrun by a plague of small grey mice, a French newspaper reported yesterday.

Publishing a photo of two rodents cavorting in Fauchon's windows, Le Parisien said the super-chic grocery shop had, in recent weeks, become a nocturnal playground for vermin.

The store, whose boast is that it can supply any foodstuff known to man, was founded in 1886 by Auguste Fauchon. It stocks 20,000 rare and sought-after items including mustard flavoured with the coral of sea-urchins, and honey produced by the bees kept on top of the Palais Garnier opera house.

Its managing director, Jean-Claude Crochard, said his staff had never reported seeing mice in the shop, but admitted that the company's offices were suffering something of an infestation. "We're spending a fortune on getting rid of them, once or twice a month," he said.

At another famous épicerie on the Place de la Madeleine, the 130-year-old Hédiard, the story was the same. "The damn things are everywhere on every floor," complained a flustered shop assistant.

Fabien Squinazi, director of Paris town hall's hygiene laboratories, said the problem could be due to the recent construction of a new metro line, the Meteor, under the square. "It may be that the beasts have been driven to the surface by all the construction work," he said. "We're keeping a close eye on it."

fields.headline: Testing ... testing ... testing
fields.standfirst: Is the nation's obsession with examining its pupils placing a continuous burden of toil and stress on teachers, parents and children?
fields.trailText: At Clapham Manor primary school in south London on Thursday, 24 children, all 10 or 11 years old, sit in silence completing, along with an estimated 599,976 children in classrooms around the country, a key stage 2 English writing test.
fields.body:
At Clapham Manor primary school in south London on Thursday, 24 children, all 10 or 11 years old, sit in silence completing, along with an estimated 599,976 children in classrooms around the country, a key stage 2 English writing test.

Some fidget, some look around the room, but most work diligently. They have to deliver one piece of writing from four choices.

Their teacher, Liz Dougan, has read through the paper with them. They have had 15 minutes to plan and 45 minutes to write. They are in their normal classroom, but some parts of their walls have had to be covered - aides-to-learning like "explanation" words.

When the exam finishes there is no heavy sighing, no hint of tears. They just sit while their teacher gathers their papers, and wait for the next thing, which happens to be the Guardian asking them how it went. Four thought it was hard. Fourteen thought it was easy. Twelve were nervous before. Sixteen enjoyed it. Four thought their parents were worried about how they did.

"You don't have to look for things to do - it's just your imagination," said Ali.

"We have done so many practice tests before this," said Rachel.

Penny said she was worried. "I don't think I'm really that good at writing."

Ivan, Ishika, Ali and Ajjaz said they did homework for this week's SAT tests, 20 minutes a day for four or five weeks.

Why had they done the test? "It helps you get to a good secondary school and when you get into a good secondary school it helps you get a good job or get into college," said Penny, though in fact her results will come out too late to affect which school she gets into - though they might affect which stream she is put in.

"I think we did the exam to see the level the school was. It's for us to help the teachers," said Ajjaz.

These children don't seem the stuff of the lurid stories painted in advance of the SAT tests, when parents took to the airwaves to complain of the stress they and their offspring were under, and union delegates warned of child suicides because of exam stress, as in Japan.

"What drivel!" replied Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, but the education secretary, David Blunkett, offered to "very seriously consider" dropping for seven-year-olds if it could be shown that children were under pressure. BBC Radio 4's Today programme sent him emails from parents and teachers, but nothing to change his mind. Nothing over the past fortnight - when 11-year-olds have been completing key stage 2 tests - or through May, when the sevens have been going through key stage 1 - has moved him either. The qualifications and curriculum authority says there have been no major problems.

But there have been worrying anecdotes. In Queniborough primary, in Leicestershire, a parent told the headteacher, Chris Davis, spokesman for the National Primary Heads Association, how her daughter, 11, had been making excuses all weekend as to why she couldn't do the tests; on Friday and Saturday it was a headache, on Sunday she was physically sick several times.

Cramming
There is no doubt, too, that schools are taking the tests increasingly seriously - although few have copied a school in Leicester, Taylor Road primary, which had pupils in school last Sunday to cram for the key stage 2 tests and spent four mornings of the Easter holidays holding revision classes.

Ministers have closed a loophole which allowed teachers to see the tests two weeks in advance. But one parent in Westminster this week told the Guardian how his son, 10, had said his class had been divided into four groups for the tests - "to make it easier for the teachers to explain the questions to us," came the reply.

Worries about over-professionalisation have come to the fore, with concerns that the tests are being used for reasons other than the benefit of the child. And there are fears that children are simply being tested too much.

As educationalists make a renewed push to emphasise play, as "hyperparenting" goes out of fashion in the US, and there are cheers for the success which Summerhill, the liberal private school in Suffolk, had in fending off inspection criticisms, schools are going in the other direction. Critics believe they are guided by a government which, from the education secretary to the chancellor, is preoccupied with toil. Testing is still on the increase - for high-fliers, for low-achievers, and to measure the "dip" in performance in the first year of secondary school. A clever child could soon have only one year, aged six, completely free of nationally recognised summer exams.

Schools are already conscious of the impact of published test results at 11 and 16, which affect their place in the school league tables. Enthusiastic heads such as Brian Hazell at Clapham Manor, who believes in testing, and is enormously proud of his achievements, dislike the way some parents compare results without taking into account the intake and background of the pupils.

But it emerged this week that sales of optional QCA tests for eights, nines, and 10s in English and maths have soared, with 20,000 primary schools - 5,000 more than last year - buying them. That means an estimated 560,000 children - about 90% of the age group nationwide - are sitting them. Union leaders believe the cause is the government's introduction of performance-related pay for teachers. To win the extra £2,000, teachers must demonstrate that their pupils are achieving more "relative to their prior attainment". What better way than government-backed tests?

Most schools test at eight, nine and 10 anyway, to establish progress. Some union officials believe - although it is not proven - that sales of tests from other organisations will have fallen away. But the link to pay seems likely to put more pressure, through the teachers, on the parents.

Alan Smithers, professor of education at Liverpool University. said: "We were under-testing, in that we only had an exam at the end of compulsory education and really no national testing in between, so we didn't know what was happening. But since tests were introduced at seven, 11 and 14, things have moved on.

"We decided that as the tests we put in were probably benefiting the education system we have just started adding more and more and now it looks as though the whole concept has gone away from tests as an indicator of student progress to becoming the main purpose of education.

"We are testing now to find out how our children are doing, secondly to find out how the schools are doing, and thirdly to find out how the teachers are doing.

Frenzy
"We are going away from diagnostic testing with national testing at the end of compulsory education, so children are being tested virtually all the time. We have got into a testing frenzy at the moment." He notes also pressure to reach the government's targets at age 11 - with 80% of children expected to reach the required literacy standard and 75% the numeracy standard by 2002.

Prof Smithers believes that testing is necessary is 11, 16 and 18. But beyond basic literacy and numeracy, he asks, "to what extent do you capture the purpose of education in a test?

"Education is really about the basic ways of making sense of life in preparation for an uncertain future. You don't develop that individual sense of responsibility for your life if you are constantly being tested."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, says: "There is a danger that you lose the richness of education that comes from the breadth of the curriculum. The excitement of learning for young people is about history and geography and technology and all the other subjects as well as English, maths and science."

To Prof Smithers, with more testing comes less time for creativity, for crucial but more nebulous learning; he notes the government's rush to crowbar topics like citizenship into the curriculum because they are no longer being covered, more organically, in subjects like history. "We need to see what is essential and then actually start reducing the requirements on that basis."

SATs, says Margaret Morrissey, of the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations, have "really become a quite magnificent obsession".

"Everywhere a parent walks there is a book or a learning aide that they can use and purchase with their child. It's very difficult now to find a game that you can purchase to use with your child."

But at schools like Clapham Manor, the exams have gone well. The teachers have prepared, but they prepare for every lesson. The school, praised to the hilt by Ofsted this year, is hopeful. And for their 11-year-olds, SATs are not even the biggest stress they face academically.

"The SATs come too late for the secondary schools to judge children," says Mr Hazell. "The secondary schools are doing their own tests and they are doing them at the end of the year. Some children have to go to seven or eight secondary schools for tests."

Testing, testing ... the exam regime children face - Britain

Age
Four to five (start of year one): Baseline assessment. Must be assessed within 7 weeks of starting primary school, covering basic speaking and listening, reading, writing, mathematics and personal and social development.

Six : No tests.

Seven : Key stage one tests in reading and maths. Marked by schools internally. Results reported to parents but not used for league tables.

Eight: Optional tests in English and maths available from the qualifications and curriculum authority (QCA).

Nine: Optional tests in maths and English from QCA. By 2001 "world class" tests in maths and/or problem solving for best 10%.

10: Optional tests in maths and English from QCA.

11: Key stage two, end of primary assessments. Externally marked and used for league tables.

12: Pilot tests for pupils who did not achieve level 4 at age 11 have gone ahead this month. Optional tests being prepared to measure dip in many children's performance in their first year of secondary school.

13: From 2001: "world class" tests for high flyers in maths and problem solving.

14: Key stage 3 tests. 600,000 pupils in 5,500 schools. Externally marked, but not used to produce league tables.

15: A year off, but some bright children can do GCSEs a year early.

16 : GCSEs

17: GCSE retakes, AS exams (optional). From 2000, pupils will be encouraged to do 5 subjects at AS, and continue with three of those into A-level.

18: A-Levels. From 2002, Advanced Extension Awards will be introduced for brightest students.

Testing, testing ... the exam regime children face - Abroad

Germany
Tests are set by state, not nationally.

Age
six onwards: Pupils are assessed by coursework and end-of-year tests in the "sitzenbleiben" system, which means "to remain sitting". If pupils do not perform well enough they are made to resit the year.

10: Sitzenbleiben record is assessed before entry into secondary school.

19: "Abitur" university entrance exams in two main subjects plus three subsidiary subjects.

Japan
No national exams. Tests are set by district.

12: Junior high school entrance exams in four to six subjects, referred to as "exam hell". These exams determine stream of high school and affect university entrance.

15: Senior high school entrance exams

18: University entrance exams comprising at least 10 papers.

New Zealand
No national testing until 16.

16: School Certificate in five or six subjects

17: Sixth Form Certificate, assessed internally by individual schools.

18: Higher School Certificate in five subjects for university entrance.

United States
No national testing. Exams vary from school to school in each state.

17: Scholastic Assessment Tests, multiple choice reasoning tests, for university entrance.

France
No national testing until 14 to 15.

14-15: Brevet des colleges, two-year coursework and exams in three main subjects with subsidiary subjects.

18: Baccalaureat in nine or 10 subjects for university entrance.
Angelique Chrisafis

To Prof Smithers, with more testing comes less time for creativity, for crucial but more nebulous learning; he notes the government's rush to crowbar topics like citizenship into the curriculum because they are no longer being covered, more organically, in subjects like history. "We need to see what is essential and then actually start reducing the requirements on that basis." SATs, says Margaret Morrissey, of the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations, have "really become a quite magnificent obsession". "Everywhere a parent walks there is a book or a learning aide that they can use and purchase with their child. It's very difficult now to find a game that you can purchase to use with your child." But at schools like Clapham Manor, the exams have gone well. The teachers have prepared, but they prepare for every lesson. The school, praised to the hilt by Ofsted this year, is hopeful. And for their 11-year-olds, SATs are not even the biggest stress they face academically. "The SATs come too late for the secondary schools to judge children," says Mr Hazell. "The secondary schools are doing their own tests and they are doing them at the end of the year. Some children have to go to seven or eight secondary schools for tests." Testing, testing ... the exam regime children face - Britain Age Four to five (start of year one): Baseline assessment. Must be assessed within 7 weeks of starting primary school, covering basic speaking and listening, reading, writing, mathematics and personal and social development. Six : No tests. Seven : Key stage one tests in reading and maths. Marked by schools internally. Results reported to parents but not used for league tables. Eight: Optional tests in English and maths available from the qualifications and curriculum authority (QCA). Nine: Optional tests in maths and English from QCA. By 2001 "world class" tests in maths and/or problem solving for best 10%. 10: Optional tests in maths and English from QCA. 11: Key stage two, end of primary assessments. Externally marked and used for league tables. 12: Pilot tests for pupils who did not achieve level 4 at age 11 have gone ahead this month. Optional tests being prepared to measure dip in many children's performance in their first year of secondary school. 13: From 2001: "world class" tests for high flyers in maths and problem solving. 14: Key stage 3 tests. 600,000 pupils in 5,500 schools. Externally marked, but not used to produce league tables. 15: A year off, but some bright children can do GCSEs a year early. 16 : GCSEs 17: GCSE retakes, AS exams (optional). From 2000, pupils will be encouraged to do 5 subjects at AS, and continue with three of those into A-level. 18: A-Levels. From 2002, Advanced Extension Awards will be introduced for brightest students. Testing, testing ... the exam regime children face - Abroad Germany Tests are set by state, not nationally. Age six onwards: Pupils are assessed by coursework and end-of-year tests in the "sitzenbleiben" system, which means "to remain sitting". If pupils do not perform well enough they are made to resit the year. 10: Sitzenbleiben record is assessed before entry into secondary school. 19: "Abitur" university entrance exams in two main subjects plus three subsidiary subjects. Japan No national exams. Tests are set by district. 12: Junior high school entrance exams in four to six subjects, referred to as "exam hell". These exams determine stream of high school and affect university entrance. 15: Senior high school entrance exams 18: University entrance exams comprising at least 10 papers. New Zealand No national testing until 16. 16: School Certificate in five or six subjects 17: Sixth Form Certificate, assessed internally by individual schools. 18: Higher School Certificate in five subjects for university entrance. United States No national testing. Exams vary from school to school in each state. 17: Scholastic Assessment Tests, multiple choice reasoning tests, for university entrance. France No national testing until 14 to 15. 14-15: Brevet des colleges, two-year coursework and exams in three main subjects with subsidiary subjects. 18: Baccalaureat in nine or 10 subjects for university entrance. Angelique Chrisafis

fields.headline: Reviews
fields.standfirst:
Asian cinema dominates impressive array of films

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Easily the best English language movie this year - and perhaps even the best of the lot - is The Yards , a sensationally thrilling, devastatingly tough and sinewy tale of gangland violence and city hall corruption in New York from James Gray, the director who brought us Little Odessa. James Caan is outstanding as Uncle Frank, the industrialist who bribes his way into city contracts, and gives a job to ex-con Leo (Mark Wahlberg), who in turn teams up with his smooth-talking buddy Willie (Joaquin Phoenix).
fields.body:
Easily the best English language movie this year - and perhaps even the best of the lot - is The Yards , a sensationally thrilling, devastatingly tough and sinewy tale of gangland violence and city hall corruption in New York from James Gray, the director who brought us Little Odessa. James Caan is outstanding as Uncle Frank, the industrialist who bribes his way into city contracts, and gives a job to ex-con Leo (Mark Wahlberg), who in turn teams up with his smooth-talking buddy Willie (Joaquin Phoenix).

All the principals are superb, and the film is set to become a modern classic. It is certainly better than the festival's other New York story: Amos Kollek's Fast Food, Fast Women, a derivative and prurient sub-Woody Allen film about caffeine-wired Manhattanites falling in and out of love.

Many English language films are outclassed, however, by the wonderfully intelligent and rich Asian cinema that has dominated the festival. Of this, the best is Edward Yang's sublime Yi Yi , or A One and a Two, about a Chinese family in Taipei: one debt-racked brother makes an unsuitable marriage that puts his elderly mother into a stroke-induced coma, and another brother runs into an old flame, who he jilted 20 years previously. Yang, for whom this film represents a triumphant return to form, handles its structure with a masterly and confident looseness, letting this freewheeling, garrulous story almost tell itself. This film is in pole position for the Palme D'Or.

Also very creditable is Chunhyang , from the South Korean director IM Kwon Taek: a 13th century tale of a young nobleman who falls in love with the daughter of a courtesan, then is forced to leave her when he is summoned away to court. The film is narrated by a traditional singing chorus, and the result is a delicately charming and erotic tale of great sweetness.

Gohatto is Nagisa Oshima's odd film about two gay samurai in late 19th century Kyoto. With its violent martial scenes and vigorous coupling, it does not quite have the watercolour delicacy traditionally associated with period Japanese pictures. Starring Takeshi Kitano as one of the grizzled elders who look on the infatuated youths with tolerant bemusement, this film could become a cult.

From Europe, literary period dramas have been much in evidence, many perhaps inspired by the success of Raul Ruiz's Proust adaptation last year. Olivier Assayas gave us his ample account of Jacques Chardonne's Les Destinées Sentimentales , about a family firm producing fine porcelain. The fastidious connoisseurship associated with this sets a rather cold tone for the film, which nevertheless has some beautiful performances from Charles Berling and Emmanuelle Béart.

Nothing could be more unfashionable than a Merchant Ivory film, and yet James Ivory's adaptation of Henry James's The Golden Bowl is a remarkably substantial, successful rendering of this enigmatic and mysterious text, which goes far beyond the banal theme of infidelity. Despite some pretty clod- hopping captions - "Three years later", and so on - Ivory managed to capture much of this elusive story, and Uma Thurman is excellent as the worldly Charlotte Stant.

Elsewhere, Pavel Lounguine's La Noce , or The Wedding, is the raucous and cacophonous tale of a young Russian miner's nuptials, as he marries his beautiful childhood sweetheart, who has been the mistress of a wealthy mafia hood. This is a little crude, but has moments of comic energy.

Quite the opposite is Amos Gitai, back in competition after last year's wonderful Kadosh with a distinctively long, slow, and mostly wordless film: Kippur , a disconcertingly uncritical and context-less account of four Israeli soldiers' experience in the Yom Kippur war of 1973. Mostly composed in a series of long continuous takes, this confers a weird, glassy serenity on the most frenzied battle scene.

Once again, it is impossible not to be impressed by the range of films in competition, particularly the Far Eastern ones, demanding though these are in terms of critical attention. There was a paucity of comic films this year, and many entries seemed prolix, with three-hour films far from uncommon, and one lasting three hours and 37 minutes. At best, this is self-indulgent. At worst, it is cruel and unusual punishment.

fields.headline: Training company in fraud inquiry
fields.standfirst: Firm at centre of allegations 'netted tens of thousands'
fields.trailText: An investigation into bogus claims for vocational qualifications has been launched after allegations that a private training company has pocketed tens of thousands of pounds of taxpayers' money.
fields.body:
An investigation into bogus claims for vocational qualifications has been launched after allegations that a private training company has pocketed tens of thousands of pounds of taxpayers' money.

The firm, Underhill Training Ltd, has agreed to repay thousands of pounds to a further education college after it submitted false claims for government funding to train dozens of students in their National Vocational Qualifications (NVQs) at fees of up to £1,900 each.

A team of auditors from another client, Thames Valley Enterprise, was sent into Underhill's offices on Thursday to seize documents relating to the 104 trainees after it was alleged that at least four claims - involving serving soldiers based at Chelsea barracks - were fraudulent.

The Department for Education and Employment has now launched a full investigation. The trainees, who include BT Cellnet engineers, had no knowledge of the fraudulent qualifications awarded in their names.

Underhill, which sub-contracts from government-funded training and enterprise councils (TECs) to provide on-the-job-training for young people aged 18 to 25, faces allegations that staff falsified attendance records, forged the signatures of assessors, employers and students on time sheets and assessments, and made funding claims for people who never finished their courses and others who never even enrolled.

Occupationally-based training has become one of Britain's biggest growth industries, with the "edu-business" estimated to be worth more than £1.3bn a year.

But the government was forced to set up a special unit dedicated to fighting fraud involving TEC funds in 1996 following a National Audit Office report into allegations of bogus claims.

The latest allegations suggest, however, that companies may still be able to abuse administrative loopholes within the TEC funding system.

Underhill, based in Slough, has training contracts with two TECs, Thames Valley Enterprise and Focus in central London, as well as franchise deals with Bracknell and Wokingham College and Uxbridge College.

The company, which is expected to have a turnover of £1.2m this year, also provides training for employees at BT Cellnet, Parcelforce, Marconi Communications and Wickes, the DIY superstores.

Sources within the company claim that many more of the 400 certificates awarded by Underhill in the past year may have been "unsafe", a claim which if proved true would involve hundreds of thousands of pounds.

Bracknell and Wokingham College terminated its contract with Underhill last month after an internal audit revealed that the company had falsely claimed almost £36,000 in fees for BT Cellnet employees studying for NVQs in telecommunications.

Underhill has agreed to repay the fees claimed for the students, most of whom denied any knowledge of the NVQ courses when they were contacted by college staff.

The college must now repay £111,000 in fees to the Further Education Funding Council plus a penalty which may run into tens of thousands of pounds.

Minutes of a meeting on April 14 reveal the college's concern about Underhill.

Other Underhill clients are also understood to be instigating audits of their contracts with the company, including Thames Valley Enterprise.

Underhill staff claimed that most qualifications awarded by the firm were assessed internally, with external authorisation made only by post from the awarding body, the telecommunications vocational standards council, int-elect, in Milton Keynes.

The board of directors at Underhill Training Ltd issued a statement yesterday saying they had co-operated fully with the audit team and made all records available.

"We are not aware of any significant issues of concern, and continue to operate to resolve this matter ...

"With reference to Bracknell College, this matter was discussed and resolved last month and is now considered closed."

webTitle: Life for serial sex attacker aged 16

fields.headline: Life for serial sex attacker aged 16
fields.trailText: The four victims of Britain's youngest ever serial sex attacker watched as he was sentenced to life at the Old Bailey yesterday.
fields.body:
The four victims of Britain's youngest ever serial sex attacker watched as he was sentenced to life at the Old Bailey yesterday.

William Senior, who was 15 at the time, was branded "merciless, brutal and dangerous" by Judge Timothy Pontius. Senior, now 16, had pleaded guilty to two charges of rape and two indecent assaults.

The judge said: "Your pleas of guilty spared your victims what would have been the horrifying experience of reliving in court the nightmare each suffered.

"You were merciless. You made threats to kill and they all believed you were armed with a weapon."

As Linda Strudwick, prosecuting, outlined the details of the attacks, the victims sat next to each other, wiping tears from their eyes.

The first victim, a care worker aged 29, was attacked in Streatham, south-west London, on October 22 last year, while walking home alone. She was grabbed from behind and forced into a side road where Senior punched and dragged her to the ground. He threatened to kill her but police arrived after she screamed for help.

Senior was under a curfew order at the time, while in a residential care home in Streatham. He was arrested but because of the victim's reluctance to make a statement the police had no option but to release him.

The second attack was in the early hours of November 14, on a student aged 28 in Streatham.

His next two victims were attacked within hours of each other on November 21. The first was a business woman aged 30 attacked near Streatham Common station at 6pm.

She was grabbed from behind and taken to waste land, where she was violently assaulted. Senior ran off when passersby were alerted by her screams.

Senior then travelled to Kingston, Surrey, and raped a woman aged 25 who had just left a pre-Christmas party.

Senior was not arrested again until DNA evidence matched him to all four women.

Before he was arrested in January, he robbed a man, to which he also pleaded guilty.

David Harounoff, defending, said that Senior was often high on a cocktail of alcohol and cannabis.

He was the youngest serial sex attacker this country had seen.

webTitle: Air rage woman arrested after attack on crew

fields.headline: Air rage woman arrested after attack on crew
fields.trailText: A woman aged 26 was arrested yesterday after allegedly head-butting a member of the cabin crew on an overnight flight from Florida to Manchester during which she was handcuffed and locked in a toilet.
fields.body:
A woman aged 26 was arrested yesterday after allegedly head-butting a member of the cabin crew on an overnight flight from Florida to Manchester during which she was handcuffed and locked in a toilet.

The disturbance on the Airtours A330 Airbus carrying 360 passengers was so serious that the pilot had to delay landing for half an hour until the woman was safely restrained.

He alerted police who arrested the woman, travelling with her two children, when the aircraft reached the terminal. Her two sons were met by their grandmother.

The incident began halfway through the flight from Orlando when staff intervened to stop the woman, from Withington, Manchester, smoking in a lavatory.

Airtours officials said she became aggressive and crew and passengers struggled to restrain her with plastic handcuffs.

She is then alleged to have head-butted a crew member, who was later taken to hospital, and to have scratched another. She was bundled into the lavatory but later broke free.

Chief Inspector Gill Mellor, of Manchester Airport police, said: "The actions of this passenger created a very dangerous situation for other passengers and crew.

"Initially, the aircraft was over the Atlantic and the captain had to decide whether to return to Orlando or continue with the flight.

"Then on approach to landing, a lot of passengers were out of their seats because of the woman's behaviour, and the captain was forced to abandon initial attempts to land."

A spokesman for Airtours said: "The passenger was warned when it was thought she was smoking in the downstairs lavatory. She became abusive and a restraint kit was used. It was after the restraints were put on her that she assaulted one of our female cabin staff."

webTitle: The missing star and the joker in the pack

fields.headline: The missing star and the joker in the pack
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: One worries for Kim Basinger. The Hollywood star who may or may not present the Palme d'Or tomorrow night - she still has not shown up - may be right not to leave her ranch.
fields.body:
One worries for Kim Basinger. The Hollywood star who may or may not present the Palme d'Or tomorrow night - she still has not shown up - may be right not to leave her ranch.

Last year's farce when the rather tired and emotional French star Sophie Marceau presided over a shambles which ended in Rosetta, a film which almost no one had seen - or has seen since - winning, may be nothing on the histrionics this time.

The joker in the pack is Lars Von Trier, the mad, bad and dangerous Danish director whose feud with his leading lady, Bjork, has done so much to enliven the festival - he called her a "mad woman" and accused her of eating her costume.

Von Trier, who drove down from Copenhagen in his camper van - he is too phobic to fly - is not best pleased by some of the reviews of Dancer In The Dark, his emotionally shattering musical in which Bjork sings from the scaffold. While several of the butchest critics on the circuit sobbed right through it, Variety, the industry bible, hated it with a venom.

Given that the last time a Cannes jury tried to give Von Trier a minor prize he called its chairman, Roman Polanski, a "midget" and kicked his scroll into the audience, I would be a very worried if I was Luc Besson.

Besson, who looks more and more like a missing member of Duran Duran, is a picture of misery as it is. Those in the know blame the French director's recent break-up with the model-turned-actress Mila Jovovich, whom he made a star in The Fifth Element and Joan Of Arc. It might, of course, just have been having to watch the three-hour 40-minute Japanese film Eureka, which some steel-buttocked critics proclaimed a masterpiece.

Anyone can see the poor boy is pining and there must have been another pang when Mila turned up at Dame Elizabeth Taylor's $100,000-a-table Aids bash with a younger and slimmer model. The prospect of Catherine Deneuve in a porn movie may just restore his will to live. Von Trier has been teasing the ice queen of French cinema with the chance to reprise her housewife hooker in Luis Bunel's Belle du Jour in a skin flick he is threatening to make.

"I think I might have to make a few changes to the script," said Deneuve coyly, only for the great Dane to reply, "Yes, Catherine knows more about these things than I do."

I'm sure it will all be very tasteful, unlike anything John Waters, the king of kitsch, has ever had a hand in. "Bad taste is America's gift to the world," he quipped.

In Cannes with his new film Cecil B Demented, Waters had a confession to make about his biggest hit, Hairspray.

"I accidentally made a family movie. When it got a PG rating I was so ashamed I wanted to slit my wrists."

There is no danger of that with Cecil B Demented, a mad caper about a gang of cinephiles who kidnap screen siren Melanie Griffith to punish her for all her awful films.

Those sensitive souls who worried that Alan Parker might inflict his "philistine" taste for blockbusters on the public now that he is running the new Film Council, can breathe easy.

I feared the worst when Lynne Ramsay, the brilliant Scottish director whose debut, Ratcatcher, was the arthouse find of the festival last year, accidentally spilled a glass of wine over him.

But turning to face the culprit, Parker's scowl softened into a smile. "I'll treasure that stain," he said. "It will be my Jackson Pollock."

Even though it has been a surprisingly good Cannes, it has not been a vintage one for the Brits. Ken Loach's Bread And Roses is not tipped for major honours, though there is hope in the Director's Fortnight where Mark Herman's Purely Belter and Stephen Daldry's debut Dancer - films that both owe a debt to Loach's Kes - have won friends.

Palme d'Or contenders

Dancer In The Dark
It's got great songs, great dance scenes and, er, an execution too. Lars Von Trier's emotionally pummelling musical starring Bjork will cause a row if it wins or loses. Critics have rarely been so divided over a film.

The Yards
James Gray's solid New York story of graft and family ties starring Mark Wahlberg and James Caan has been compared to On the Waterfront. A safe, if uninspired, bet, it would ensure Hollywood returned in droves next year.

Eureka
Japanese, three hours and 40 minutes long, and about the trauma of a bus driver who survives a bloody hijack, it doesn't sound terribly promising but critics were bewitched.

Yi Yi
The most superior of family soap operas from the prolific Taiwanese director Edward Yang. Beautiful, subtle storytelling may not be enough, however.

Nurse Betty
Neil LeBute's misanthropic and very funny comedy about a TV soap addict whose fantasies about a heart-throb star come true in the most unexpected way. Will make Rene Zellweger an even bigger star. Comedies, however, seldom win prizes.

Song From The Second Floor
Roy Anderrson, who hasn't made a feature film for 25 years, returns with a brilliant oddity. Benn Anderson of Abba fame wrote the score. A dark horse that might just nip in at the finish.
fields.bodyText: One worries for Kim Basinger. The Hollywood star who may or may not present the Palme d'Or tomorrow night - she still has not shown up - may be right not to leave her ranch. Last year's farce when the rather tired and emotional French star Sophie Marceau presided over a shambles which ended in Rosetta, a film which almost no one had seen - or has seen since - winning, may be nothing on the histrionics this time. The joker in the pack is Lars Von Trier, the mad, bad and dangerous Danish director whose feud with his leading lady, Bjork, has done so much to enliven the festival - he called her a "mad woman" and accused her of eating her costume. Von Trier, who drove down from Copenhagen in his camper van - he is too phobic to fly - is not best pleased by some of the reviews of Dancer In The Dark, his emotionally shattering musical in which Bjork sings from the scaffold. While several of the butchest critics on the circuit sobbed right through it, Variety, the industry bible, hated it with a venom. Given that the last time a Cannes jury tried to give Von Trier a minor prize he called its chairman, Roman Polanski, a "midget" and kicked his scroll into the audience, I would be a very worried if I was Luc Besson. Besson, who looks more and more like a missing member of Duran Duran, is a picture of misery as it is. Those in the know blame the French director's recent break-up with the model-turned-actress Mila Jovovich, whom he made a star in The Fifth Element and Joan Of Arc. It might, of course, just have been having to watch the three-hour 40-minute Japanese film Eureka, which some steel-buttocked critics proclaimed a masterpiece. Anyone can see the poor boy is pining and there must have been another pang when Mila turned up at Dame Elizabeth Taylor's $100,000-a-table Aids bash with a younger and slimmer model. The prospect of Catherine Deneuve in a porn movie may just restore his will to live. Von Trier has been teasing the ice queen of French cinema with the chance to reprise her housewife hooker in Luis Bunel's Belle du Jour in a skin flick he is threatening to make. "I think I might have to make a few changes to the script," said Deneuve coyly, only for the great Dane to reply, "Yes, Catherine knows more about these things than I do." I'm sure it will all be very tasteful, unlike anything John Waters, the king of kitsch, has ever had a hand in. "Bad taste is America's gift to the world," he quipped. In Cannes with his new film Cecil B Demented, Waters had a confession to make about his biggest hit, Hairspray. "I accidentally made a family movie. When it got a PG rating I was so ashamed I wanted to slit my wrists." There is no danger of that with Cecil B Demented, a mad caper about a gang of cinephiles who kidnap screen siren Melanie Griffith to punish her for all her awful films. Those sensitive souls who worried that Alan Parker might inflict his "philistine" taste for blockbusters on the public now that he is running the new Film Council, can breathe easy. I feared the worst when Lynne Ramsay, the brilliant Scottish director whose debut, Ratcatcher, was the arthouse find of the festival last year, accidentally spilled a glass of wine over him. But turning to face the culprit, Parker's scowl softened into a smile. "I'll treasure that stain," he said. "It will be my Jackson Pollock." Even though it has been a surprisingly good Cannes, it has not been a vintage one for the Brits. Ken Loach's Bread And Roses is not tipped for major honours, though there is hope in the Director's Fortnight where Mark Herman's Purely Belter and Stephen Daldry's debut Dancer - films that both owe a debt to Loach's Kes - have won friends. Palme d'Or contenders Dancer In The Dark It's got great songs, great dance scenes and, er, an execution too. Lars Von Trier's emotionally pummelling musical starring Bjork will cause a row if it wins or loses. Critics have rarely been so divided over a film. The Yards James Gray's solid New York story of graft and family ties starring Mark Wahlberg and James Caan has been compared to On the Waterfront. A safe, if uninspired, bet, it would ensure Hollywood returned in droves next year. Eureka Japanese, three hours and 40 minutes long, and about the trauma of a bus driver who survives a bloody hijack, it doesn't sound terribly promising but critics were bewitched. Yi Yi The most superior of family soap operas from the prolific Taiwanese director Edward Yang. Beautiful, subtle storytelling may not be enough, however. Nurse Betty Neil LeBute's misanthropic and very funny comedy about a TV soap addict whose fantasies about a heart-throb star come true in the most unexpected way. Will make Rene Zellweger an even bigger star. Comedies, however, seldom win prizes. Song From The Second Floor Roy Anderrson, who hasn't made a feature film for 25 years, returns with a brilliant oddity. Benn Anderson of Abba fame wrote the score. A dark horse that might just nip in at the finish.

fields.headline: Company vitae
fields.standfirst: FirstGroup, which this week unveiled profits of £121.5m, valuing the firm at £849.6m
fields.trailText: FirstGroup, which this week unveiled profits of £121.5m, valuing the firm at £849.6m
fields.body:
You should feel the ride quality in its bendy buses?

Yes, its articulated super buses operate in Manchester, Leeds, Bradford, Edinburgh and Aberdeen. It is the leading UK-based international passenger transport group, employing more than 28,000 people. It has an annual turnover nudging £2bn with a fleet of more than 8,000 buses and more than 22% market share. It also controls rail franchises operating the Great Eastern Railway, Great Western Trains and North Western Trains.

Is there a lot of brass in buses?

This week, after posting pre-tax profits of £121.5m, up 28% on turnover of £1.8bn, stockbrokers were asking 196p a share,valuing the firm at £849.6m.

When was it formed?

Until 1985 it was part of the state-owned National Bus Company, operating as Badgerline with a few dozen buses in and around the Weston- super-Mare area. The business was successful enough, but on its own it was never likely to satisfy its ambitious management, headed by managing director Trevor Smallwood.

Then the government passed legislation allowing the National Bus Company to be privatised. The management at Badgerline realised they had a once-in-a-lifetime chance to own their company and make serious money. They moved fast and by September 1986 they had bought Badgerline with the help of loans from Hill Samuel and NatWest. With the flotation came yet more expansion, swallowing Stoke-on-Trent bus company PMT in 1994 for £23m, adding another 500 buses to its fleet and another 1,400 staff to the payroll.

But the merger with its Scottish rival GRT a year later spelled the end of the Badgerline name when the merged group became FirstBus. The same year, with rail privatisation a reality, it won the franchise to run the Great Eastern route, serving parts of Essex and Suffolk. It also took a stake in Great Western Holdings, operator of services in the north west and from Bristol to London. Another name change was needed as FirstBus was now more than a bus company; enter FirstGroup. And since then it has added a controlling stake in Bristol International Airport.

Any tips to charm its recruiting officers?

You must mention its introduction of new articulated super buses which are 18 metres long with two sections and already operate in several large cities. It is a major backer of the government's new proposals for the bus industry contained in the White Paper on transport to create an integrated national transport network. And show awareness of its contract to design, build and run the £50m City of Edinburgh Rapid Transit (CERT) bus route between the airport and the city centre. The nine-kilometre busway is expected to be operational by 2001.

Applaud last year's successful opening of its Croydon Tramlink and heap praises on its decision to form a consortium that will put up 60% of the cost of building a tram service to ease Bristol's congestion problems.

What are the chances of a foreign posting?

It has just recently spent £603m to buy Ryder Public Transportation Services (RPTS), the second biggest US operator of school buses, with more than 10,200 school buses in 25 states.

Do equal opportunities get a front seat?

It is one of those rare British companies that invites an employee director chosen by a staff referendum to sit on its main board; current employee director is Jean Weatherhead. Thanks to ThinkFirst, its survey of staff attitudes and expectations, it has come up with a new training and development programme reflecting employee views to spread best people-managemant practice across its operations.

Any clues on workers' wages?

Average salaries work out around £17,000, boosted by an employee share ownership plan that distributes 5% of pre-tax profits among 29,000 eligible employees.

Busloads of cash for the bosses, no doubt?

That's such a last century sentiment; haven't you heard that in the real world bosses are paid according to their market value? Average boardroom salaries before bonuses or perks work out at around £143,000 with the highest paid director pulling in £262,000.

Who fields applications?

Personnel functions are devolved down to each operating business, so in the first instance write to Louise Howell, the company secretary, at 32a Weymouth Street, London W1N 3FA.

 Compiled by Nick Pandya

fields.headline: Dutch fireworks owner arrested
fields.trailText: One of the joint owners of the Dutch fireworks warehouse which exploded last weekend, killing 20 people and wounding almost 1,000, has turned himself in to the police and been arrested.
fields.body:
One of the joint owners of the Dutch fireworks warehouse which exploded last weekend, killing 20 people and wounding almost 1,000, has turned himself in to the police and been arrested.

Wilhelm Pater walked into a police station late yesterday afternoon, the regional prosecutor in Almelo, Nienke Zwart, said last night.

An estimated 100 tonnes of fireworks stored on the premises ignited during a fire, causing a deadly blast which devastated an entire district of the city last Saturday afternoon.

The justice ministry issued national and international arrest warrants after a search of the men's homes and offices on Thursday, on suspicion of breaking the storage conditions set out in their environmental permit.

Enschende city officials said earlier in the week that the two had contacted them through their lawyer and promised to cooperate with the official investigation into the explosion.

Mr Bakker's whereabouts remains a mystery, although a Dutch newspaper reported that he had spent two days in hospital at Gronau, just across the German border.

Film screened in the Netherlands this week showed Mr Bakker in the crowd fleeing as the explosion occurred.

City officials said immediately after the blast that the warehouse was fully licensed and had passed routine safety checks just three days earlier.

But it was quickly questioned whether the inspectors were equipped to monitor the strength of the explosives, and not just the number of boxes stored in the concrete bunkers.

In January 1997, it has emerged, the company was given a permit to expand its storage area.

But there were later complaints that the metal containers used for the explosives were placed dangerously close to one another.

An expert was quoted yesterday as describing the storage conditions as "incredible."

In a related development, the Vrij Nederland newspaper reported that a Dutch army officer had been suspended because of a conflict of interest in working as a freelance consultant to firework companies which his job required him to supervise.

Many townspeople complained that they had not known of the warehouse's existence, and asked why it was allowed to be in the heart of a residential area.

Figures issued by the city last night showed that the number of people still unaccounted for had dropped to 10.

Initially the police were overwhelmed with reports of 4,400 missing, and called in reinforcements to help track them down and quell fears that many more lives were lost.

Of the 964 people injured, 28 were still in hospital yesterday, six of them in intensive care .

Last night the prime minster, Wim Kok, was due to join Crown Prince Willem Alexander at the head of a silent procession in memory of the 20 victims.

Earlier, firefighters paid their last respects to two colleagues who died fighting what started as a routine blaze. Two more are to be buried today.

"Four of us did not return," read a condolence message in the national daily de Volkskrant.

"We are stirred, immensely saddened and barely realise what has happened."

The four died when the storage bunkers containing the explosives went up in an enormous blast which damaged 400 houses and flattened the heart of the Roombeek district.

webTitle: Order of the boot for Mr Punch

fields.headline: Order of the boot for Mr Punch
fields.trailText: The last Punch and Judy man in Brighton - and one of the few left by the seaside in Britain - is being compelled to hang up his truncheon, sausages and jester's cap.
fields.body:
The last Punch and Judy man in Brighton - and one of the few left by the seaside in Britain - is being compelled to hang up his truncheon, sausages and jester's cap.

Traders on the resort's promenade, which has been regenerated with "fairly upmarket" bars and restaurants, object that his colourful and flamboyant ways clash with their modern ambience.

For Mike Stone, 43, who has worked his pitch for more than 25 years under the name "Sgt Stone", it was a sudden end with little more dignity than Mr Punch's own fate.

Last June celebrities including the mayor of Brighton attended a beach party celebrating his silver jubilee. In January the News of the World chose Roger Bamber's Guardian picture of his stall as one of the five best photographs of the millennium.

But on Sunday, as he was setting up his show, Brighton's new mayor, Andy Durr, who works as a volunteer at the nearby fishing museum, advised him that seafront traders felt hostile towards him.

Mr Stone said: "He said they felt the show was too noisy and the children shouting annoyed them. It was a friendly warning but he told me there was not any room for me any more. The council has been very supportive over the years but I suppose there's nothing they can do. I can't carry on the show because I'll be worrying about who's going to hit me. Apparently I am not quite trendy enough to fit in with the revamped seafront.

"The problem is obviously the fact that, while children are waiting for my show, they are not buying ice creams or putting 50ps into arcade machines. I draw crowds but I don't generate revenue the traders can see.

"I'm just a booth the size of a phone box. Brighton is nicknamed Silicon Beach now. It's all arcades, electronics and theme bars. Perhaps I am an anachronism now. But I promise you the children themselves still love a live show."

There have been suggestions, especially in a cartoon in yesterday's Brighton Evening Argus, that Mr Stone may have sometimes entered too fully into the spirit of Mr Punch outside as well as inside the booth.

Of these, he said unrepenetantly: "Controversial, colourful and flamboyant behaviour is in the tradition of the Italian commedia dell'arte, from which Punch and Judy comes."

A Brighton and Hove council spokesman said: "The council does not have a problem with Mr Stone. He doesn't need a licence. He is allowed to have a small pitch and we have even given him a small grant. We are not aware of any official complaints about him.

"The main focus of the problem seems to have come from the traders. He is a fairly controversial character. He does somehow seem to have upset them. It's a great pity that they can't sort it out."

The loss of Mr Stone leaves only seven resorts with professional Punch and Judy shows. These include Paignton, Swanage and Lowestoft.

But an estimated 100 professionals still do shows at children's parties and shopping malls. Last night Glyn Edwards, coordinator of the Punch and Judy college of professors, said: "It's a pity there is no longer one in Brighton. But the vacancy will only prove temporary. It's like car parking spaces. Someone else will move in to fill this one."

fields.headline: Keep pace with best trackers
fields.standfirst: It's the cheap way to buy equities but choose your trust carefully, says Sandra GrandisonMoney Unlimited
fields.trailText: For those looking to invest in equities, index tracker funds offer a cheap way of doing so. You know your fund will not diverge by more than a small percentage from the market it is following. But, if you're there for long-term growth, which index and fund should you choose?
fields.body:
For those looking to invest in equities, index tracker funds offer a cheap way of doing so. You know your fund will not diverge by more than a small percentage from the market it is following. But, if you're there for long-term growth, which index and fund should you choose?

An index tracker is designed to replicate the movements of a stock market index, therefore producing the same performance.

The main attraction of a tracker fund is its low charges. Actively managed funds tend to cost more to run than trackers. The aim of active managers is to produce above-average performance by choosing shares that will outshine the general trend. This means they need more investment research and analysis, often a higher turnover of stocks, which in turn means higher dealing costs and annual management charges.

But tracker enthusiasts are not just restricted to the main indices - the FTSE-100 or FT All Share - there are also a growing number of overseas trackers. And last year the FTSE techMark 100 index was launched, focusing on companies that are involved in technology.

The better known FTSE-100 is made up of Britain's biggest publicly quoted companies. Using a computer to run the tracker fund, this is programmed to trade shares in line with the movement on the market. The value of the tracker fund will move in direct proportion to that of the FTSE-100 itself.

By choosing an index tracker private investors avoid the risk of ending up with a poor performing fund although, in return, they give up the chance of finding one of the better performers.

But there is concern that trackers have reached the end of their rails. Vodafone Airtouch is now worth around 14% of the FTSE-100 - unit trusts are supposed to put no more than 10% of their total funds in any one investment.

Ian Millward, of the independent financial adviser Chase de Vere Investments, thinks it is not a good time to invest in tracker funds because of this. He says: "Don't invest in a FTSE-100 tracker. If you're in one, move to an FT All-Share tracker because there are more shares and you can spread the risks."

Of the funds that track the FT All-Share, he recommends M&G Index Tracker with no initial fee and 0.3% annual management charge for investors looking for long-term growth.

For a FTSE-100 tracker, Ben Yearsley, of IFA Hargreaves Lansdown, would go for Liontrust Top 100, the cheapest tracker on the market with no initial fee and a 0.295% annual management charge.

HSBC Asset Management conducts quarterly research of active managers versus their benchmark index, examining whether active funds are adding value against an index.

The research shows the global strength of technology, media and telecoms stocks helped active managers to beat indices over the past 12 months.

The latest fund to track the FTSE-100 is from a new company called iShares, based in Dublin. The company's first fund, the iFTSE 100, is a new type of investment - a hybrid of an investment trust and a unit trust and is managed by Barclays Global Investors.

iShares works as an exchange traded fund, in other words a fund with shares quoted on the stock market. Like investment trusts, this fund will trade on the London stock exchange.

But, unlike tracker funds offered by unit trusts and open-ended investment companies (Oeics) which change the price once a day, iShare's price will vary throughout the day like an investment trust. And in line with the most competitive trackers, the annual management charge is 0.35%.

So, if you're investing in a tracker fund pick the right index first, then choose the cheapest trust. But don't expect miracles - when stock markets fall, your fund will track down along with it, and there's nothing you can do about it.

webTitle: Dot.coms versus not.coms: how to pick the winners

fields.headline: Dot.coms versus not.coms: how to pick the winners
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Forty years ago saving with an endowment contract was considered pretty racy. But a succession of government measures aimed at getting more of our savings into the stock market has changed all that.
fields.body:
Forty years ago saving with an endowment contract was considered pretty racy. But a succession of government measures aimed at getting more of our savings into the stock market has changed all that.

Today's savers have Peps, Isas, shares from demutualisations and a host of other investments that people in the 1960s would have considered more liberating than the contraceptive pill.

And along with the choice of investment vehicle has come the choice of which market to invest in. Forty years ago most people paid their money to an insurance company for 25 years and received a nice lump sum at the end of it.

Today investors have to weigh up the old economy against the new economy - on top of longer lasting concepts such as geographical and currency splits.

But what is the old economy and does it stand to provide greater or lower capital growth than the new economy over the next decade?

The old economy is defined by experts as the more traditional blue-chip companies that are seen as part of a country's history, such as Cadbury Schweppes, Barclays Bank and Unilever.

New economy companies are those taking advantage of the latest sciences to grow or change their businesses and provide services with a heavy bias towards technological solutions.

The performance monitoring company Standard & Poor's includes internet, technology and telecoms stocks in its definition of new economy and says that over the past three years these sectors have returned more than 300% for investors. The old economy, which Standard and Poor's says is anything not in these sectors, has in turn gained only 45% over the same period.

But the experts are split over whether this trend will continue and where people should be putting their money to achieve the greatest growth over the next 10 years.

Merrill Lynch's director of European quantitative strategy, Markus Barth, says rising interest rates dampen earnings growth, which affects the old economy companies more than the new.

"We think the majority of growth in the UK is going to come from new economy stocks," he says.

Scottish Equitable's investment strategy guru Alistair Byrne agrees. "We have a longer term preference for technology sectors but only established companies, not startups," he says.

He also warns of the excesses of the old economy stocks: "We're seeing so-called old economy stocks having to invest huge amounts of cash in technology to keep up with the competition. They're leaking cash for not much gain, and they're paying all the money into the new economy."

Colin Morton, BWD Rensburg UK equities income trust fund manager, says this relationship makes it impossible to look at the two economies in isolation.

"It's one economy where everyone is reliant on each other," he says. "If the so-called old economy does badly then it is bad for the so-called new economy because they are the ones buying the so-called new economy's products."

And he believes that some old economy companies who have been adapting to demand for more than 100 years will continue to do so and be profitable. He cites Cadbury and Scottish & Newcastle as examples. "People eat chocolate and they drink beer. They won't stop."

IFA Towry Law's Charles Levett Scrivener says old economy investments could even outperform new economy investments over the shorter term.

"For people taking a 10-year view we are positive on the new economy, for shorter term, five to 10 years and immediate income needs, it's the old economy," he says.

But with such diverse views on the future of the old and new economies, where do investors go to get a slice of the massive gains seen in the new economy?

The head of research at Hargreaves Lansdown, Mark Dampier, says investors should not choose between the two economies just now. "You can't divorce the two economies so it's probably best to put it into a growth fund and let the unit trust manager do the worrying," he says.

Sedgwick Independent Financial Consultants' research manager, Bob Marriott, agrees, saying a growth fund is a good option for a balanced portfolio. "At the moment we just don't know which way it is going to jump," he says.

And when you consider Standard & Poor's figures, which show a loss of 14.12% in new economy investments over the past month, this advice appears sound.

But Mr Marriott warns it is not as simple as picking the first growth fund you come across.

He says: "You need to check the remit of the manager who should be able to take advantage of any technology boom, but should not be rushing around buying dot.coms."

webTitle: Chasing thrills? Then make sure you can spot the risks

fields.headline: Chasing thrills? Then make sure you can spot the risks
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Putting money in the stock market can be risky business.But the extent of that risk can vary according to the type of product and the market in which it invests.
fields.body:
Putting money in the stock market can be risky business. After all, those small print warnings are not just there to test your eyesight.

But the extent of that risk can vary according to the type of product and the market in which it invests.

Collective investment products such as unit trusts and investment trusts are usually considered lower risk than buying direct equities. You are less likely to try to outguess the market when you have a portfolio that cannot be broken up.

The risks are still there. But just what is risk? One technical definition is the "variability of results" -another is the "variability of a fund from a benchmark" such as an index. Some reckon a fund that has halved when its benchmark has also lost 50% as "low risk" because it is "not volatile" while a trust that doubles when its index stands still is high risk.

There is another side to risk - time is the great healer. While a fund may have high volatility on a day-to-day basis, over a long period, it is likely to revert to a more sedate graph.

Generally, the greater the level of risk you are prepared to take in an investment, the higher the potential that the value of the investment will increase or decrease.

A low-risk investment does not necessarily mean it will be a good investment. For example, a deposit with one of the large clearing banks that offer 2.5% interest, fixed over a five-year period, would be an extremely low-risk investment. It would also be a particularly bad investment, as UK gilts will give a higher return over the same period, with even lower risk - they're backed by the government.

The major factor relating to the risk of an investment product is the market in which it invests. Equity-based funds are considered to be higher risk than cash and gilt funds, as stock market values can rise as well as fall.

Funds that invest in the UK blue-chip market are at the safer end of the risk scale, while those investing in emerging markets and Asia are considered higher risk.

Products that focus on the US or Europe are generally slightly higher risk than those funds that invest in the UK, due to currency fluctuations. Global equity funds are deemed less risky because they offer the advantage of diversification rather than sticking to one country.

Technology funds offer extreme growth potential, but the risk is also substantial, particularly in light of the ups and downs of the US hi-tech market.

The risk guidelines issued by many of the unit trust and Oeics (open-ended investment companies) take into account market conditions, as well as currencies, asset classes and previous performance of the fund managers. These risk ratings, published on product literature, are intended as a guide only, as they just relate to a product provider's own range of funds.

Fidelity ranks risk profiles on a scale of one to seven, with one being the lowest. It has ranked its MoneyBuilder cash Isa fund as one, and at the other end of the scale has ranked its new Asean fund and Japan Special Situations fund as seven.

Most investment trust providers also print risk ratings on their marketing literature. These ratings are available on the Association of Investment Trust Companies' website (www.itsonline.co.uk

webTitle: 'Love Bug 2' warning as US firms hit

fields.headline: 'Love Bug 2' warning as US firms hit
fields.trailText: British computer users yesterday escaped the worst ravages of a derivative of the I Love You virus which devastated computer systems worldwide earlier this month.
fields.body:
British computer users yesterday escaped the worst ravages of a derivative of the I Love You virus which devastated computer systems worldwide earlier this month.

The latest virus, dubbed NewLove-A, brought some networks on the west coast of America to a halt on Thursday.

A virus that changes its code each time it infects an individual operating system, NewLove-A is a more sophisticated version of the LoveBug. It erases the entire contents of an individual hard drive, but because it takes up a substantial amount of memory it spreads much slower than the I Love You virus.

NewLove-A arrives in email form, with the "forward" prefix, Fw, in the subject line, followed by a name from the user's address book. The virus then randomly selects a recently opened file from the start/document menu and attaches it as a .vbs file. Clicking on the attachment releases the virus into the hard drive. It also sends itself to the first 50 people in the user's address book.

Graham Cluley, spokesman for leading UK anti-virus firm Sophos, said they had not received any complaints from UK users but recommended vigilance.

"The easiest way to avoid trouble is not to open unsolicited attachments on email. If it is unsolicited and in some way suspicious then don't go near it. The easiest way to stop it is to put a block on all emails that contain the .vbs suffix."

The Californian software firm, Trend Micro, reported that several companies in the US had been affected, including one which lost the use of 5,000 machines on Thursday night.

Only users running Microsoft Outlook email programme for Windows are vulnerable to the new virus, and yesterday Microsoft announced they would be introducing measures to reduce the chances of users unwittingly infecting their computers.

"We will be introducing prompts to Outlook which will encourage people to download the attachments on to the hard drive, and then scan them for viruses before opening them.

"People are quite virus-aware at the moment thanks to the I Love You virus. It was just two weeks ago and people are still on their toes looking out for anything odd turning up in their inbox."


FBI virus warnings
