webTitle: Hi-tech spin gives funds new image

fields.headline: Hi-tech spin gives funds new image
fields.standfirst: One sector is turning to the internet to cast off its dowdy reputation. Michael Ross reportsMoney Unlimited
fields.trailText: One sector is turning to the internet to cast off its dowdy reputation. Michael Ross reports.
fields.body:
Over most periods, investment trusts have beaten rival collective investments such as unit trusts and open-ended investment companies thanks to a combination of low charges and the ability to borrow so they can gear up when markets are booming.

But they are little used by private investors and are seen as old-fashioned. Now, however, the investment trust sector has adopted a change of tactics in a bid to lose its dowdy Victorian image.

Last year, the Association of Investment Trust Companies enlisted crooner Paolo Conte to entice investors to the world of investment trusts for its multi-million pound "its" advertising campaign.

The £2.1bn Witan investment trust sent glamorous "hit squads" into London's square mile to promote the trust for its own £350,000 advertising campaign.

They are also moving on to the internet; today investment trust information is just the click of a mouse away. The Association of Investment Trust Companies has led the charge and its website offers a section on understanding investment trusts and how they work can for you.

There is a trust finder that helps you to find an investment trust that suits your needs, and allows you to link through to the individual website. People can also download factsheets on aspects of investments.

"You can get information on investment trusts for children, for mortgages, for income or capital growth, for individual savings accounts, for split capital investment trusts or 'its' for pensions. You name it, you can get it," says the AITC's Annabel Brodie-Smith.

The AITC is not alone in providing services for the internet-savvy investor. Most of the big-name companies including the likes of Fleming, Foreign & Colonial, Dresdner RCM, Henderson and Witan have websites designed to woo and help potential investors. The sites give up-to-date performance data and share prices, while investors can download brochures, application forms and key features documents for their trust ranges.

But some have taken the concept a step further. For example, visitors to the Edinburgh Fund Managers site can now select and apply for Isas online. The application takes about 20 minutes with a navigation panel showing where you are in the process. Once the application is complete investors are emailed to confirm that their investment is being processed.

When it comes to funds that are embracing technology, investment trusts have as much to offer as their unit trust counterparts. The two names that frequently crop up are Finsbury Technology and Henderson Technology. And it is easy to see why.Despite falling by nearly a third from recent peaks, Finsbury Technology is still worth three times its value a year ago, while Henderson, down by a quarter from all-time highs, stands at four times its launch value.

Indeed, the Henderson fund has come in for some criticism because its fund managers are set to get a slice of a £40m performance fee for beating its "inappropriate" benchmark index by 200% last year. Henderson is entitled to 15% of the difference.

Both trusts invest in small and medium sized companies across the globe, although US-based companies currently dominate their portfolios.

But while there are small number of specialist technology trusts on the market some analysts believe the smaller UK investment trusts could offer an alternative for investors wanting exposure to technology.

Many other trusts have significant weightings in technology stocks. They offer people a cheap way into technology because many can be bought on substantial discounts compared with the premiums of Henderson and Finsbury.

Trusts such as Murray Enterprise and Henderson Smaller Companies have more than half of their portfolios invested in tech stocks, yet are trading at discounts of about 20%.

But Merrill Lynch analyst Charles Cade warns investors that there can be drawbacks and believes investors should stick to a specialist technology fund if that is the sector they prefer.

"Several funds have concentrated portfolios with substantial stock-specific risk," he says. "An advantage of a technology fund is you know what you are getting. With a general technology fund the tech weighting could be 50%-75% at the time of investment but it could change significantly over time."

Top tips for single shares

Fancy a punt on a share? It's not so easy as it once was, according to NatWest Stockbroker's Jeremy Batstone.

"People can no longer complacently buy a share and stick it in a bottom drawer," he says. "The buy-hold strategy has run its course. Investors must now manage stocks more actively and look for areas of high economic activity."

His three top tips are: Shire Pharmaceuticals - the £2.7bn company's main product is Adderall which helps treat hyperactivity, but the big interest is on the anti-Alzheimer's drug Reminyl - providing it passes US tests.

Sprint, worth £2.3bn, is big in telecoms equipment and network communications.

And £5.4bn CMG said "I love you" to the "ILOVEYOU" virus because it is big in internet security as well as systems. It's a high earnings, high-potential stock.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £80,000 for UK's rarest stamp
fields.body:
£80,000 for UK's rarest stamp

Britain's rarest postage stamp was yesterday sold for £80,000 by London auctioneer Stanley Gibbons to an anonymous American buyer.

The stamp was an unused King Edward VII 1904 6d IR Official. It was taken out of circulation on its day of issue, May 13, 1904.

Rival Whitehall demos clash

Police yesterday closed Whitehall after a violent clash between 300 Eritrean demonstrators and a rival Ethiopian demonstration outside Downing Street.

The Eritreans were protesting about the Ethiopian army offensive against Eritrean forces. Police said there had been "one or two arrests". At least three people were taken to hospital.

RUC awards in Kosovo

The chief constable of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, yesterday presented medals at Pristina in Kosovo to up to 60 of his officers, including his son Darryl, who are serving with the UN peace keeping forces.

Irish end search for disappeared

Irish police are tonight to call off their search for the bodies of victims of IRA murders. Digging at five locations in the Republic for the "disappeared" after the IRA relayed new information proved fruitless.

BBC producer cleared of GBH

A BBC producer, Chiaku Nwosu, 40, who felled a colleague's jealous ex-boyfriend, martial arts exponent Philip Birthem, in self-defence, was cleared of causing grievous bodily harm by Southwark crown court yesterday.

webTitle: French drifter confesses to killing three women

fields.headline: French drifter confesses to killing three women
fields.trailText: The man suspected of murdering three young women in France, including the Staffordshire student Isabel Peake, has confessed to the killings in a graphic three-page interview with a French magazine.
fields.body:
The man suspected of murdering three young women in France, including the Staffordshire student Isabel Peake, has confessed to the killings in a graphic three-page interview with a French magazine.

Sid Ahmed Rezala, who was arrested in Lisbon in January and is awaiting a Portuguese appeal court's decision on his extradition to France, told Le Figaro magazine that he had killed the women after seeing "flashes" that seemed like "an order to execute".

The 21-year-old Algerian-born Frenchman is wanted for questioning over the death of Ms Peake, whose partly-clothed body was found next to a railway line in central France last October. She had been returning to Britain for the weekend when she was pushed from an overnight train.

French police also want to question Rezala over the deaths of Corinne Cailloux, 36, who was stabbed 15 times in the toilets of the Paris-Ventimiglia sleeper in December, and Emilie Bazin, a former girlfriend whose body was found soon after in a cellar in the northern town of Amiens.

"May God help all their families and bring misery down on me," Rezala told the magazine's reporter from his cell in the hospital wing of Caixas prison, in Lisbon. "If someone had done that to someone from my family, I would have killed them, torn out their heart and eaten it."

A small-time drugs dealer and long-term drifter, Rezala was captured after a bungled three-month investigation by French police and a Europe-wide manhunt which saw him held and released by Spanish authorities in Barcelona.

He may yet walk free, however, since Portuguese law allows extradition to be refused to countries, like France, that can impose prison sentences longer than Portugal's 30-year maximum.

webTitle: Book now for all the fun of the fairs

fields.headline: Book now for all the fun of the fairs
fields.standfirst: June is the month when hordes of bibliophiles attend London's two big markets. Stewart Dalby reviews the goods on offer.
fields.trailText: June is the month when hordes of bibliophiles attend London's two big markets. Stewart Dalby reviews the goods on offer.
fields.body:
It may well be true that more and more people are buying books on the internet, but one thing the net has not done is affect the success of the book fair.

There are book fairs all over the country all of time, in village halls, town halls, and hotels. But June is a special month for book fairs. This is when the Provincial Book Sellers Association (PBSA) holds its annual jamboree in the Hotel Russell in London's Bloomsbury and more fairs in adjacent hotels.

June is also the month for the Antiquarian Book Fair, organised by the Antiquarian Booksellers Association which was founded in 1906. It seems to get bigger every year. The fair moved recently from Grosvenor House to Olympia ,where it is being held this year from June 8-11, to accommodate the greater numbers wanting to exhibit.

One dealer explains the success of the book fair as follows: "If you are buying a book because you want to read it, then the net is obviously a good way to proceed. Your local bookshop might not have what you want and these websites are quick and efficient.

"But if you are a serious collector or a general collector you need to see what you are buying. You need to confirm the book is what the catalogue says it is, that no pages are missing and such like. Condition is important to the value of a book and condition is something difficult to establish unless it is in your hands."

For whatever reason, lots of books are sold at the fairs. The dealer continues: "When you consider the average cost of a book at the PBSA fair is in the hundreds and they turn over £1m in a few days, that means a lot of books. The average cost at the Antiquarian Book Fair is rather higher, but the Fair takes some £1-2m in just four days."

In the strictest definition an antiquarian book is anything published before 1820, when they introduced wood into the paper. Certainly there are some old and venerable books at the Fair. Anyone who collects travel literature would be interested in the great age of exploration, roughly from James Cook at the end of the 18th century to the likes of Richard Burton and David Livingston in the late 19th.

Bernard J Shapero Rare Books, a leading London dealer specialising in travel, medicine and science books, has a complete set of James Cook's three circumnavigations of the globe from 1768 to 1779 before he was killed in Hawaii. These are priced at £17,500.

But the word antiquarian is something of a misnomer as far as the Fair is concerned. The dealers prefer the American description of old books as rare and used books, rather than antiquarian and second-hand. The Fair covers all periods and there is something for every pocket.

And there are some contemporary books. Much has been made of the craze for modern first editions, which seems to have got completely out of hand. A complete set of three books of JR Rowling's Harry Potter books are on offer for £15,000. Her first book, The Philosopher's Stone, sold for £4.95 in hardback.

In my never-ending quest to find the next big thing in alternative investments I shall certainly stop by Brian Lake's Jarndyce books stand. Although a specialist in Dickens, he has also carved out a little corner in what he calls bizarre books. He has made the definition easy by publishing an updated version with Russell Ash of his Bizarre Books (Pavilion Books, £6.99, e-mail: ash@pavilion.co.uk), which contains 2,000 titles.

He says that he knows these titles exist because he has them or has seen all of them. Ignoring the many smutty ones here are a few titles: Barbs, Prongs, Points, Prickers and Stickers: A Complete and Illustrated Catalogue of Antique Barbed Wire, and A Hundred and Forty Ways of Spelling Birmingham.

The book is very amusing, but do these tomes amount to a collectible field? Brian Lake says: "When I started this 20 years ago there were a number of collectors in California with big collections. Now it is growing here. Let me put it this way. I have a window display in my shop opposite the British Museum of 80 of these books. They are not for sale but I could sell them 20 times over. One book called Fish Who Answer The Telephone, which I thought was worth £15, I sold to an Italian film director who insisted on paying £50 for it.

Brian Lake does not have the field all to himself. At the Fair will be Roger Treglown, a Cheshire dealer specialising in chess. He says Bizarre Books are very specialised but there is growing interest. He has on offer: The Resistance of Piles to Penetration, London 1950 - about civil engineering at £145 - and The Cement and Concrete Association: How Concrete Can Help the Pig Breeder, London 1950, at £10.

Modern Firsts were given a push when a book was published about them, so you never know.

 Readers wanting to visit the Fair can obtain a free ticket for June 9 onwards by ringing the ABA office on 020-7439-3118.

webTitle: A special delivery for the Blair babe

fields.headline: A special delivery for the Blair babe
fields.standfirst: Eileen Sheridan looks at top trinkets for tots and cool kit for kids as Cherie and Tony prepare for the birth of their number four
fields.trailText: Eileen Sheridan looks at top trinkets for tots and cool kit for kids as Cherie and Tony prepare for the birth of their number four.
fields.body:
Forget the Three Wise Men, this month it's the turn of 415 Labour MPs to make a pilgrimage with gifts for that other infant - the Blair babe. If they want to climb higher on the greasy political pole, nothing will help their ascent more than a judiciously chosen, politically correct present for the fourth young Blair.

But because they are more accustomed to the corridors of power than the aisles of Mothercare, Jobs & Money this week is kindly offering them some guidance on what and where to buy that present. Infant clothing is a safe bet for a gift and if those Labour MPs take heed of our advice, Cherie will be saved from a mountain of Babygros. There is a lot out there to spend your money on.

Consensus has it that the Blairs are Baby Gap sort of parents, but they might be swayed by clothes from Young England if their Euro sentiments don't rule out classic British baby style.

The company has launched a mail order service with items such as a white duck-smocked romper at £59 or a white baby nightgown embroidered with ducks at £29.50. It is also available with blue bears or pink rabbits, but you're taking a risk on the sex with that. Young England also sells quality Babygros in cotton jersey at £28 or short-sleeved rompers in the same fabric for £27. For a mere £80 you can buy a button-on suit for the older baby with blue Oxford cotton bottoms and a white shirt. There is also a range of traditional children's clothes in high quality fabrics.

Department stores are always a good place to look and the exclusive Hoopers group, with branches in Wilmslow, Torquay, Harrogate and Tunbridge Wells, sells deeply trendy children's wear by Kenzo, Marese, Miniman, Jean Bourget and Petit Bateau.

All-in-ones from Bourget are £34 and from Petit Bateau they cost from £20 to £30. Its best seller is a navy blue version with a one- button grandad collar. The Bourget range for slightly older babies and children comes in sophisticated neutrals and includes things like a hooded sweat top at £22.95. There are co-ordinating hats, socks and bootees. The Kenzo baby range is very fashion conscious, says Hoopers, with leggings at £20, t-shirts at £14.95, cardigans at £25 and sweatshirts at £20. Dresses for girls cost £35, but just think of the label.

And if the baby is a boy, some buying for the future could include Timberland sweatshirts at £29.95, dungarees at £30, shorts at £24 and an outdoor jacket at £54.

Selfridges also specialises in international brands at its Kids' Universe section. The Oxford Street store reports that one of its new lines, the stylish French Chipie, is selling out fast. The range is denim-based with baby dungarees at £32.99 and £42.99, dresses at £29.99 and t-shirts at £12.99 and £17.99. The Trussardi range has body suits at £29.99 and sleepwear at £24, £26 and £32 and there is a pack of three hats at £29.99.

The eco-conscious can give gifts from a company like Spirit of Nature which produces underwear, sleepwear and rompers in undyed and unbleached 100% organic cotton. There is a beige striped range from cotton grown on recultivated land by Peruvian Indians. A bodysuit is £10.29, a sleepsuit £19.29, leggings £7.09 and booties £5.49. Its Sea and Sand range in sassy nautical stripes has t-shirts at £11.90 and shorts at £10.50. The same company sells natural accessories and toys.

People who want to spend rather more can invest in nursery furniture from a company like Canterbury-based L&T Morgan, which sells co-ordinated hand made pieces. Its furniture is made by local craftspeople - one is in Rye, Sussex.

A favourite buy is the nursery chair with the child's name and date of birth painted on it. They cost £40 with rush seats in four designs. A painted sleigh bed will set you back £380 (mattress not included), crib, £130, chests of drawers range from £310 to £380 and a child's wardrobe is £360.

Other items include stools with names at £30, a fish mobile at £35 and a series of jolly toys and games. One of its best sellers is an alphabet glove puppet caterpillar for the nursery wall at £35. A rocking horse is £215.

Super-busy shoppers can, of course, purchase online. Like every other area of commerce, websites for baby goods are multiplying fast. www.babyworld.co.uk is also a club which runs competitions, features, pregnancy diaries, birth stories and news. Membership is free and the site describes itself as a thriving babywear community. Competitive prices can be found on www.webbaby.co.uk and Boots also has a website, www.boots.co.uk.

A more unusual gift would be a cast of the baby's hands or feet in silver, bronze or glass from wrightson & platt (www.wrightsonandplatt.co.uk). The cast takes about 20 seconds to do and involves a home visit. Delivery takes four weeks. "They are very popular for first babies," says Denise Wrightson, "It marks a very special moment and each piece is unique. It's often members of the family or godparents who commission them."

Feet cost £725 a pair in silver, £360 for bronze and £380 for glass. Hands are more expensive at £440 for bronze, £480 for glass and £385 for silver. They can be mounted on marble or presented loose and Wrightson says people like to handle them and use them as paperweights. "Glass is more fragile but it adds another dimension," she says.

And finally, a word in Tony's ear. Since conspicuous consumption is no longer off limits, take a look at Cartier's new mother and baby jewellery. Tender Toys are based on Meccano and come in small yellow and white gold pieces - pram, tricycle, rocking horse and car to be worn on a child's charm bracelet or by the mother as a pendant, at £630 each. Tender Bestiaire are dove, koala or elephant mother and offspring brooches in white or yellow gold with diamonds. Prices from £1,750 to £4,350. Or there is the famous panther pendant and chain - a female panther and her young in yellow gold and diamonds. Price £12,400.

Who to call:

Young England...................................... tel 0207 259 9000

Selfridges................................................. tel 0207 629 1234

Spirit of Nature.......................................... tel 01582 847370

L&T Morgan.......................................... tel 01227 713973

Wrightson & Platt................................... tel 0207 652 2182

webTitle: Ask Figaro for a quick lesson on managing your holdings

fields.headline: Ask Figaro for a quick lesson on managing your holdings
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: A new website - www.askfigaro.com - now provides independent, user-friendly advice on investment funds.
fields.body:
A new website - www.askfigaro.com - now provides independent, user-friendly advice on investment funds. It lets you evaluate existing holdings with a number of interactive tools, as well as helping site visitors choose new investments.

There are comparison tools for sectors, performance tables, and the ability to examine a fund manager's expertise across a variety of assets, such as bond or smaller company funds. It can all be presented in a graphical format, so net users can produce material that would shame the average adviser.

If you want help, there is a selection of tutorials including decision trees, questionnaires and glossaries to finetune choices. The site will also recommend funds if it is asked.

And one type that it will consider is Cat standard funds. These comply with government guidelines on costs, access and terms. And they are purring ahead of the opposition, according to new research from fund measurement experts Fitzrovia. It calculates that compared with the average unit trust in the UK All Companies sector, an initial £7,000 Isa investment in one of the few actively managed Cat trusts - most are passive index trackers - would now be worth £1,507 more than average higher charging unit trust.

fields.body:
A trail of blue smoke tomorrow will trace the course of one of the odder triangular relationships in literary history - between George Bernard Shaw, Lawrence of Arabia, and a classic British motorbike.

A cavalcade of members of the Brough Superior Owners Club, riding hugely valuable museum pieces - each worth between the price of a small house, and the price of a very large house - will make the 150-mile journey from Clouds Hill in Dorset, home of T E Lawrence, to Shaw's Corner at Ayot Saint Lawrence, Shaw's hideous home in Hertfordshire. It was a trip Lawrence made hundreds of times on his Brough Superior, before dying in a crash on one in 1935.

The rally this year commemorates the 50th anniversary of Shaw's death in the house, in November 1950, after he fell out of an apple tree at the age of 94.

On the surface, the grumpy pacifist iconoclast had little in common with the war hero author of Seven Pillars of Wisdom - apart from a weakness for inordinately long prefaces. In fact, the two men became firm friends.

Lawrence was so in awe of Shaw that he only agreed to visit his house with a friend on the assurance that the great man was away. Shaw was home, and the men took an instant liking to one another, which surprised both of them.

Shaw called him "a very strange fellow, a born actor and up to all sorts of tricks". The rally is due to arrive at Shaw's Corner, now owned by the National Trust, at 4pm, and the bikes will remain on display at the house until 6pm.

Lawrence was a dashing motor cyclist, covering thousands of miles on a succession of Brough Superiors. Shaw, safer on his bicycle with the specially lengthened frame to fit his spindleshanks, was the terror of the village on his two stroke, frequently colliding with stationary objects or falling off.

The Brough Superiors were hand built in Nottingham between 1921 and 1939 when the family firm closed. Their slogan was "the Rolls Royce of motor-cycles". Only 3,000 were built, of which an estimated 1,000 survive. Rally organiser Justin Wand will be riding his 1926 Brough SS100: "It was designed in 1925 and guaranteed to have a top speed of 100 mph, an absolute phenomenom at a time when most cars pootled along at about 35 mph."

The most valuable ever sold is the missing link in tomorrow's parade. Lawrence owned seven of the motorbikes in all. The one which was a present from Shaw and his wife was sold in the US for almost $4m.

fields.headline: Tories turn green over incinerators
fields.trailText: A moratorium on the building of all new incinerators, until British scientific research rules out a cancer risk, was called for yesterday by Archie Norman, the Tory party's environment spokesman.
fields.body:
A moratorium on the building of all new incinerators, until British scientific research rules out a cancer risk, was called for yesterday by Archie Norman, the Tory party's environment spokesman.

This will increase pressure on Michael Meacher, the environment minister, who is expected next week to give the go-ahead to a new chain of incinerators as part of the government's waste strategy.

The Tory party's policy appears to be aimed at opening up a new front against the government and seizing the green agenda in the same way that William Hague took on Tony Blair over law and order.

Alongside the ban on new incinerators are a host of policies traditionally associated with opposition from the Liberal Democrats.

These include the building of municipal composters - similar to the giant one on the Isle of Wight - and a commitment to recycling, including a guarantee that the local dustcart will provide a recycling service to every home in Britain.

The Tories promise more cash for local councils to increase recycling and end landfill dumping and a new "zero waste agency" to spearhead the initiative.

Householders will also be offered subsidised rainwater butts and composters to encourage recycling.

The new Conservative policy also calls for tougher penalties for companies caught illegally dumping waste and pledges to name and shame councils with poor recycling records.

It says: "We will introduce a moratorium on new incinerators until independent British scientific evidence proves they are safe. Labour have failed to meet the challenge of recycling... We propose a target that 50% of household waste should be recycled or composted by 2020."

Mr Norman said: "Labour have failed to stem the growth of waste in this country. As a result they want to build 165 incinerators on people's doorsteps. Following the US environmental protection agency report on the carcinogenic effect of dioxide produced by incineration, the government should bin their white paper and commission an independent report."

fields.headline: Waste watchdog attacked by MPs
fields.trailText: The £600m environment agency is lambasted by MPs today for "lack of vision, ineffective management" and for "punching below its weight" on influencing public opinion on green issues.
fields.body:
The £600m environment agency is lambasted by MPs today for "lack of vision, ineffective management" and for "punching below its weight" on influencing public opinion on green issues.

A damning report from the Commons environment select committee accuses the agency of failing to act as an agent of "joined up" government and senior management of undermining its own committed staff - creating a high turnover in jobs and low morale, and making it ineffective to tackle many issues. The report says there is a "culture of fear" inside the agency with staff suppressing spontaneity and innovation, in case they get marked down by senior managers who disapprove of their initiatives.

The report also backs up the expose by the Guardian and Channel 4's Dispatches programme on illegal dumping to avoid the landfill tax.

The MPs say: "We are dismayed that this very serious environmental problem should have been effectively ignored for so long. The possibility that the landfill tax would encourage fly-tipping was a major concern for environmental groups, local government and the public from its introduction in October 1996.

"Regardless of the concerns expressed at that time, and of our observations and recommendations on the subject in two subsequent reports, the government and the environment agency have failed to take the necessary action to prevent the illegal dumping of waste. In the meantime, untold damage may be being done to our environment. We recommend that the environment agency take urgent steps effectively to tackle this very serious problem, and that the government provide it with necessary funding to enable it to do so."

The MPs also back the Guardian's findings and complaints that the courts do not have enough powers to fine people for dumping or causing environmental damage. They call for a review of the sentences and fines imposed on companies, demanding much higher fines.

"It [the review] should... provide companies with a financial incentive to take the right environmental option rather than to cut corners to the detriment of the environment, by ensuring that the level of the fine is always more than any financial benefit from the offence."

They also want companies to have to publish details of convictions for environmental offences in their annual reports.

Control of radioactive waste discharges by the agency is also attacked. The MPs say the rules are unclear, and the agency and industry do not seem to know what to do. They point out that talks have been dragging on for years to solve this problem "with as yet no positive outcome". They say the agency is working in a vacuum.

The report also criticises the agency for failing to take the lead on the growing of genetically modified crops and for not taking enough initiatives over flood defences.

Andrew Bennett, Labour MP for Denton and Reddish, and chairman of the committee, said yesterday: "We need the environment agency to be an effective watchdog and a leading campaigning organisation. At the moment, if you ask anybody who are the three leading figures and organisations on the environment, most people would say Michael Meacher, Greenpeace, and Friends of the Earth. The chairman of the environment agency ought to be one of the top three people in the country but he is not."

webTitle: Accident victims left stranded by ruling

fields.headline: Accident victims left stranded by ruling
fields.standfirst: The House of Lords has ruled that agreements for 'free' car hire after a crash are invalid. Richard Colbey looks at the implicationsMoney Unlimited
fields.trailText: The House of Lords has ruled that agreements for 'free' car hire after a crash are invalid. Richard Colbey looks at the implications.
fields.body:
It was confirmed last week that most agreements for "free" car hire after an accident are invalid. The House of Lords upheld a decision made by the Court of Appeal last year that Vanessa Dimond could not recover £346 from the CIS, insurers of a Mr Lovell, whose car ran into the back of her Suzuki.

Ms Dimond hired a replacement car from 1st Automotive. This was based on a charge of nearly £46 a day, compared with the £24, which was the usual rate for hiring a smallish car at that time. However, 1st Automotive informed Ms Dimond she would not have to pay until she recovered the money from Mr Lovell's insurers.

Although the CIS accepted that Mr Lovell was entirely to blame for the accident, it refused to pay up. It claimed that Mrs Dimond was under no obligation to pay 1st Automotive as her agreement with that company was unenforceable under the Consumer Credit Act 1974. It also claimed that there was no reason why it should pay any more than the normal rate for car hire. The insurers had won on the first point in the Court of Appeal. The Lords agreed with this. A contract to provide anything, including car hire, on credit is only enforceable if it is made in the approved manner, which Mrs Dimond's agreement hadn't been. Once it was established that she could not be required to pay, she had suffered no loss. The car hire company had no direct claim against Mr Lovell, so they were out of pocket.

A majority of the Law Lords also, unlike the Court of Appeal, thought that even if Mrs Dimond has been liable to pay the hire company, she could not recover the whole amount from the insurers. She had to mitigate her loss by only using a reasonably competitive company to supply her with a hire car.

The decision may make it a great deal more difficult to get a car on credit hire after an accident. Shares in Helphire, one of the main companies providing this type of service, fell by 39% after the ruling, while, conversely, the motor insurance industry reckons it will save some £30 million per year by not having to meet such claims.

Although these court cases have caused a great deal of interest among lawyers and insurance companies, surprisingly few others seem aware of them.

Many car hire companies continued to offer such arrangements despite the Court of Appeal's decision. Even the Consumers' Association seems to be providing advice without reference to these developments. Which? this month reports a case where Accident Assistance, a credit hire company, attempted to charge its member Colin Marsh £16,000 for two months' hire of a Mercedes when his own was damaged.

When it emerged that the driver who caused the accident was uninsured, the hire company tried to recover the money from Mr Marsh. Although the Consumers' Association were able to persuade Accident Assistance not to pursue Mr Marsh, neither seemed to realise that it was, in any case, unenforceable.

Finding that insurance companies refuse to pay them, some credit hire companies may now follow Accident Assistance's approach of trying to get the money back from the hirer. Even if the amount sought is inherently reasonable, there is no obligation to pay it, unless an agreement complying with the Consumer Credit Act has been properly executed.

The Association of British Insurers hopes to shortly introduce a scheme that will enable people whose cars are damaged through no fault of their own to hire a replacement car while theirs is repaired.

This may provide a way around the decision in Mrs Dimond's case. Until it is introduced, drivers for whom having a car is essential would be best off with a comprehensive policy that enables them to recover hire costs automatically from their own insurers

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

webTitle: It can pay to stay outside

fields.headline: It can pay to stay outside
fields.standfirst: Most people assume that it's best to invest in bricks and mortar, but renting a house can be cheaper and less stressful, says Elizabeth Langton
fields.trailText: It is supposed to be one of those indisputable facts of life that buying a home is cheaper than renting. Renting, say well-meaning friends and relatives, amounts to pouring money down the drain. Far better to get something for your money - a little corner you can call your own even if in truth it is owned by a bank or building society.
fields.body:
It is supposed to be one of those indisputable facts of life that buying a home is cheaper than renting. Renting, say well-meaning friends and relatives, amounts to pouring money down the drain. Far better to get something for your money - a little corner you can call your own even if in truth it is owned by a bank or building society.

But this is only half the picture. Renting is still cheaper than buying in some of the most desirable areas of London. Most of us wouldn't get anywhere near the asking price for a Knightsbridge pied-á-terre but could afford to rent a broom cupboard with a smart postcode.

And when the property market is going mad, would-be buyers may be well advised to hold on to their cash and keep saving while waiting for the market to calm down.

Naturally, the lenders are eager for us to see the advantages of buying a home. Abbey National says it has firm evidence that buying the average UK home can be as much as 42% - or £129,000 - cheaper than renting over 25 years. Even though house prices are shooting through the roof in many parts of the country, house buyers can still save thousands of pounds by climbing on to the property ladder, says the bank.

Savings can vary from a few thousand pounds to about £255,000 depending on the size of the house and where you live in the country. When the difference is so marked, renters should ask themselves whether they are happy to pay for their landlord's fast cars, says Miles Bingham, head of mortgage marketing at the Abbey.

In the south-east the average home-owner saves £172,598, closely followed by East Anglia where the saving is £166,000. But direct price comparisons do not take into account the overall price of owning a home. The Abbey National's calculations have included the basic cost of main-taining a property but few homeowners are content to do just that.

They install kitchens, bathrooms, a loft conversion. They make over bedrooms, gardens and build exten sions. Savings are needed just to cover the cost of buying and selling. The recent hike in stamp duty has hit movers in property hot spots hard, adding £1,500 to the cost of buying a £300,000 home.

But there are other hidden costs according to the Woolwich's annual cost of moving survey. The average price of local authority and other searches has risen by nearly 28% to £101, irrespective of the value of the property. Solicitors' charges too are up, typically 8% to 9%.

This all means that a buyer would need to find an additional £7,222 to cover the extra cost of moving from a £250,000 to a £300,000 property. Renters, on the other hand, don't live in fear of negative equity and are not responsible for the property they live in.

Long-term renter Gill South, aged 34, is bemused by her friends' enthusiasm for getting a foot on the property ladder. She and her husband are renting a spacious one-bedroom flat in Muswell Hill, North London for £750 per month. "There is a feeling here that you are a second- class citizen if you are renting, but you do feel very free knowing you can move after just six months' notice," says Ms South. She says the great thing about renting is having someone to call when something breaks. Although sometimes you need to hassle landlords it is still their responsibility and not yours.

"We were living in Holloway and decided we wanted something a bit nicer. At the end of 1998 we looked into buying but were horrified at the prices. I know of two people who were looking to buy flats a year ago. They were put off by silly prices and when queues started to form outside estate agents when flats came on to the market. One has rented a studio in Belsize Park, a place she wanted to live but couldn't afford to buy into," she explains.

Ms South originally hails from New Zealand, where renting is much more commonplace. "People don't buy in their early 20s there. They rent for much longer and save up a hefty deposit."

Renting here has a downmarket reputation among both landlords and tenants but things are improving. The government is supporting moves to breathe new life into the rental sector and wants to consign images of cockroach-infested flats ruled by unscrupulous landlords to history. Ministers are supporting the National Approved Letting Scheme, which was launched earlier this month.

The scheme, a joint venture between the Empty Homes Agency and estate agents', letting agents' and surveyors' organisations, is designed to protect tenants and landlords. NALS members promise to adhere to a code of conduct and tenants who use NALS agents have access to redress if things go wrong.

NALS spokesman Hugh Dunsmore-Hardy hopes the scheme will herald a revival in rented property. "This country needs a viable rented sector and we hope NALS will encourage landlords into the market place and increase the amount of rented property available. If property is well managed then renting will no doubt become a more attractive option than it is now."

fields.headline: Rare red kite found poisoned
fields.trailText: Police are investigating the poisoning of a rare red kite which was released last year in Britain's largest reintroduction programme for birds of prey.
fields.body:
Police are investigating the poisoning of a rare red kite which was released last year in Britain's largest reintroduction programme for birds of prey.

The young adult male was found on moorland near Pateley Bridge, north Yorkshire, after messages from a micro-transmitter attached to the bird on release indicated it had stopped flying.

The body of the kite, a russet-coloured hawk whose numbers reached a national low of 12 because of shooting and poisoning, was traced to an area where its reintroduction was resisted last year by gamekeepers and grouse-shooting syndicates.

Tests showed it had eaten an illegal rat poison, alphachloralose, although it is not clear whether the bird was deliberately targeted or chanced to scavenge rabbits being controlled by contaminated bait.

The death is a serious blow to attempts to start a breeding colony of red kites in the north, building on the success of an experiment in Wales. The breed, recognisable by its slender wings, distinctive V-tail and mewing call, was saved from extinction by Welsh enthusiasts who saw numbers rise to more than 50 by the mid-80s.

Deliberate poisonings have since affected the Welsh colony, but the death at Pateley Bridge is the first loss in the north since 23 kites were released last year on the Harewood estate near Leeds.

"The loss of this bird is an outrage," said Andy Bunten, Yorkshire regional officer for the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, which is working with English Nature on the project. "The use of poison in the countryside is illegal and dangerous."

Harewood estate manager, Christopher Ussher, said the released colony co-existed with game birds, but the kites have been blamed by gamekeepers and shooting interests for taking pheasant and grouse chicks from the moors.

webTitle: Widow wins fight for millionaire's sports car

fields.headline: Widow wins fight for millionaire's sports car
fields.trailText: The widow of a millionaire businessman won a high court victory yesterday against a close woman friend of her husband for the return of his cherished £55,000 Aston Martin.
fields.body:
The widow of a millionaire businessman won a high court victory yesterday against a close woman friend of her husband for the return of his cherished £55,000 Aston Martin.

Judge Christopher Tetlow rejected a claim by Amanda Stonestreet that Rino "Roberto" Santi, who made his fortune with a company specialising in Italian food, had made her a gift of the classic car shortly before he died aged 60 last July.

The judge made an order for the "delivery up" of the vehicle to Gillian Santi, a part-time GP, from East Grinstead, West Sussex.

Ms Stonestreet, from Pevensey Bay, East Sussex, who had a platonic relationship with Mr Santi, had received gifts from him including her home, cars, holidays and cash, but she had failed to establish "there was a gift in this case", said the judge.

The Santis married in 1976 and had a daughter Francesca, now 16. He became an alcoholic and the couple separated in 1996, the court heard.

The Aston Martin DB7 at the centre of the case was a gift on his retirement from the business, Pasta Reale, in 1997. That car and his E-type Jaguar were "prized possessions".

Mr and Mrs Santi remained on reasonable terms. A decree nisi was granted in March 1997 but a decree absolute was never entered.

The judge said Mr Santi enjoyed female company and was generous towards his women friends. He liked to surround himself with attractive young women, who were "trophies". Press Association

fields.headline: Berlin Philharmonic stung by Scorpions
fields.trailText: The Berlin Philharmonic is associated with many things - among them defining renditions of Beethoven and the commanding presence of its august former conductor, the late Herbert von Karajan.
fields.body:
The Berlin Philharmonic is associated with many things - among them defining renditions of Beethoven and the commanding presence of its august former conductor, the late Herbert von Karajan.

What it had not been linked to - at least till now - was heavy rock and oral sex. Yet, on a CD circulating in the German capital this week, one of the world's most revered classical orchestras can be heard backing a pop group as they belt out the lines:

"The bitch is hungry
... So give her inches".

The Berlin Philharmonic's first experiment in "crossover" has landed it in a maelstrom of controversy that also threatens to mar next month's opening in Hanover of the world fair, Expo 2000. The orchestra's musicians, who are free to enter commercial ventures on their own account, agreed to record and perform Expo 2000's official anthem with the veteran German band, the Scorpions.

They are due to play together at the fair on June 22 and have already cut a joint album which is due to go on sale three days earlier. A pre-release version stamped with the Expo logo carries the anthem and a re-recording with the Berlin Philharmonic of a 1984 Scorpions' hit that contains the lyrics above.

A spokeswoman for Sir Simon Rattle, the Berlin Philharmonic's chief conductor-designate, said yesterday he had no comment to make on the joint venture. But he had earlier been quoted as describing it as a "terrible idea... a horrible idea".

In Berlin, the manager of the orchestra, who is leaving next year, said his departure was linked to the crossover experiment.

Expo 2000 is the biggest global event to be staged in Germany since the ill-fated Munich Olympics of 1972. The organizers have said they hope it will offer the world a new image of the reunited nation.

More than 170 countries are expected to take part, including such bastions of moral conservatism as Saudi Arabia and the Holy See. Some are likely to want to know how the organizers came to lend their name to a CD with lyrics that are plainly offensive to many people.

Dr Elmar Weingarten, the orchestra's manager, said the Berlin city authority, the Senate, had ordered him to arrange the concert at Expo against his will.

"I said: 'OK. I do it, reluctantly, with a bad conscience. But I have to do it. I have to follow your instructions".

The pressure had contributed to his departure. "One of the reasons is, of course, the treatment of the Senate in this situation", Dr Weingarten said.

He added that his objections were musical rather than moral: "It is not what I think this orchestra should do when they do crossover".

The present chief conductor, Claudio Abbado, said last month: "One ought to do all things with good taste, but I find that the Scorpions do things with dreadful taste".

The band has been around since the 1970s, and had an international hit after the fall of the Berlin Wall with "Winds of Change". But its following in Germany today is largely among ageing bikers, and one critic has expressed the fear that they could gather in large numbers at Expo for the group's concert with the Philharmonic on June 22.

Another commentator, Caroline Fetscher of the Berlin newspaper, Der Tagespiegel, described the official anthem, Moment of Glory, as "triumphal and politically regressive".

She said that if the orchestra had "known more about the many movements in modern music and pop music, they certainly would not have co-operated with the Scorpions. It's dinosaur stuff. Whoever put this together just didn't give it enough thought".

Those dodgy lyrics in full

It's early morning
The sun comes out
Last night was shaking
And pretty loud
My cat is purring
And scratches my skin
So what is wrong
With another sin
The bitch is hungry
She needs to tell
So give her inches
And feed her well
More days to come
New places to go
I've got to leave
It's time for a show

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Violence fears ease in Harare
Zimbabwe war veterans' leader Chenjerai Hunzvi was fined and given a suspended jail term yesterday for defying a court order to end forcible takeovers of white-owned farms.
fields.body:
Violence fears ease in Harare
Zimbabwe war veterans' leader Chenjerai Hunzvi was fined and given a suspended jail term yesterday for defying a court order to end forcible takeovers of white-owned farms.

The relatively lenient sentence appeared to ease fears that violence would worsen if he were jailed. Reuters, Harare

Paraguay coup attempt fails
Paraguay's government said that forces loyal to fugitive coup leader Gen Lino Oviedo drove tanks through the capital, Asuncion, and blasted a hole in Congress before surrendering yesterday.

Security forces arrested a lawyer, a congressman, five retired officers and at least 25 serving soldiers. Reuters, Asuncion

Peru election in turmoil
Peru's top election body yesterday refused to postpone a May 28 presidential vote even though the opposition candidate vowed not to run unless there was a three-week delay.

Alejandro Toledo had refused to take part in the run-off against President Alberto Fujimori without a delay, saying there was insufficient to ensure the vote was fair. Reuters, Lima

Nappy days for horses
If councillors have their way, Vienna's famous carriage horses will soon be in nappies. The city council is set to pass a law stipulating that all horses wear a sack to avoid them "soiling the streets". Reuters, Vienna

webTitle: Yeltsin drank Chequers dry, says Dame Norma

fields.headline: Yeltsin drank Chequers dry, says Dame Norma
fields.trailText: When the former Russian president Boris Yeltsin visited Chequers in 1994, he and his entourage "cleaned the house of gin", Dame Norma Major will reveal in a BBC Radio 4 interview tomorrow.
fields.body:
When the former Russian president Boris Yeltsin visited Chequers in 1994, he and his entourage "cleaned the house of gin", Dame Norma Major will reveal in a BBC Radio 4 interview tomorrow.

Talking to the presenter Sue Lawley on Desert Island Discs, the wife of the former Tory prime minister said that in return Mr Yeltsin and his colleagues brought their own supply of black bread and Coca-Cola to the premier's country home.

"A lump of stilton and a bunch of sage from the garden accompanied Boris back to Russia, such was his love for both," she said.

Dame Norma also described the tribulations of living at 10 Downing Street. She admitted that the first six months there were very difficult, with no support or help.

She told Miss Lawley that she cried a lot during that time, but, in defence of the staff at Downing Street, she recognised there had not been a prime minister's wife there for a long time. She liked to be in control of her environment and she felt out of control during those first months.

The illness of their son James - he suffered blackouts - had been a great shock to her. But he was making good progress and coping well with a pacemaker. Press intrusion had been difficult for their son, but it had made him a better person.

webTitle: Life for killers who threw two off bridge

fields.headline: Life for killers who threw two off bridge
fields.trailText: Three young men have been jailed for life for the murder of Timothy Baxter, 24, a student beaten senseless and thrown into the Thames from Hungerford bridge, central London, in June last year.
fields.body:
Three young men have been jailed for life for the murder of Timothy Baxter, 24, a student beaten senseless and thrown into the Thames from Hungerford bridge, central London, in June last year.

Sonni Reid, 20, John Riches, 22, and Cameron Cyrus, 18, were given life terms at the Old Bailey yesterday, having been convicted last month. Three juveniles also responsible for the attack - boys aged 15 and 17 and a girl aged 16 - were ordered to be detained at Her Majesty's pleasure.

At the trial the gang, who said they had carried out the attack for fun, tried to blame each other for Mr Baxter's death and the attempted murder of his friend Gabriel Cornish. Convicting the six of murder and attempted murder, Judge Ann Goddard said that they had shown no mercy to Mr Baxter and were guilty of "heartless, gratuitous violence".

Reid and Riches were also found guilty of attempting to rob the students and stealing a wallet and assaulting Matthew Reynolds, 22, at the Embankment. The 17-year-old admitted attempted robbery and theft.

The trial heard that Reid and Riches and the 17-year-old had tried to rob the students at around 4am as they walked home after a night in the West End of London. While they did so the other two juveniles and Cyrus walked on to the bridge from the other direction. Mr Cornish, 25, appealed to them for help, not knowing they knew the robbers. Instead of helping, they joined in the attack.

After throwing the men off the bridge the gang walked away trying to hide their faces from security cameras. Mr Cornish was rescued but Mr Baxter did not regain consciousness and drowned. His body was recovered the following day.

The gang were caught only after police viewed hundreds of hours of closed circuit surveillance video. Cameras captured Mr Baxter and Mr Cornish making their way to the bridge near the Strand, and showed their attackers as they made their way from the scene. The girl and the younger of the juvenile boys were filmed kissing after the attack.

Reid, Riches and Cyrus, all of no fixed address, and the juveniles from south London had denied murdering Mr Baxter and the attempted murder of Mr Cornish. The group were said to spend their days among London's homeless community, often sleeping rough in Leicester Square.

Mr Baxter, a graduate of Manchester University, had been due to study law. His parents, Sam Baxter and his wife Linda, were in court to hear the verdict, along with the families of the accused.

Detective Chief Inspector David Shipperlee said after the case: "It was the most callous of acts by a group of young people.

"They not only beat these two young people unconscious but they - it would appear for fun - picked them up and threw them over railings into the River Thames. Anyone in their right mind would have known it would cause someone's death."

fields.headline: Nursery owner cleared of abuse
fields.trailText: A former nursery owner was yesterday cleared of 12 charges of abusing children in her care.
fields.body:
A former nursery owner was yesterday cleared of 12 charges of abusing children in her care.

Margaret Price, of Felinfach near Brecon, who had already been cleared of two charges of child cruelty, was acquitted of another 12 charges of child cruelty at Merthyr Tydfil crown court, in south Wales.

After the verdicts were delivered, Judge Gareth Davies expressed concern about the way police had carried out the inquiry after allegations were made against Mrs Price, who ran the Playtime nursery in Brecon.

He added that taking an emergency order to close the nursery in March 1999 after taking only five statements from witnesses seemed "an extreme measure when considering the possibility of the danger to children".

David Aubrey QC, prosecuting, said a retrial would not be in the public interest.

Mrs Price was congratulated by friends and the families of some of the children at the nursery.

Outside the court, her solicitor, Catherine Stewart, said: "Mrs Price leaves as she came here on April 17 without a single conviction. She is pleased with the outcome and would like to thank the legal team, family and friends.

"She has lost a highly successful nursery which she built up over five-and-a-half years and has had to endure 14 months of anguish and trauma and a four-week trial. Mrs Price is thrilled at proving her innocence against allegations by members of staff that she had dismissed or disciplined."

She added that Mrs Price would be considering taking legal action against Dyfed Powys police and the social services department of Powys county council and would welcome an independent inquiry.

webTitle: Germans hotly debate the bare facts of summer

fields.headline: Germans hotly debate the bare facts of summer
fields.trailText: Earlier this week Gabriela went to an art gallery on Oranienburgerstrasse in the heart of Berlin. She was gazing at one of the works on display when she became aware that the man next to her had no clothes on.
fields.body:
Earlier this week Gabriela went to an art gallery on Oranienburgerstrasse in the heart of Berlin. She was gazing at one of the works on display when she became aware that the man next to her had no clothes on.

He was, on the other hand, wearing high-heeled shoes and a long string of pearls so, even by the standards of Berlin, he was a little unusual.

Not so the young woman on the green. Near the Guardian bureau there is a small park, overlooked on three sides by tall official buildings. In the middle of the lawn last Wednesday there was a solitary sunbather. And she was as naked as the day she was born.

We are in the grip of a heatwave here. On some days Berlin has been hotter than Barcelona, and as the pollen count has risen, so too have nudity levels.

My earliest sighting was in the Grunewald, the wood on the south-western edge of the city. My wife and I rounded a corner to find an elderly gentleman sitting on a bench chatting with another man.

The younger man was clothed. The elderly gent was not.

By this week the Tiergarten, Berlin's leafier equivalent of Hyde Park, was carpeted with sunbathers in the buff.

So what is it that moves Germans, or at least Berliners, to rip off their kit with such alacrity? When I asked a friend, she was indignant.

"You need to be putting the question the other way round. We like to take off our clothes when the sun comes out because it's a natural, healthy thing to do. What you should be asking is why the British don't take their clothes off when the sun comes out.

"And I'll tell you why. It's because you're all verklemmt (inhibited)."

Perhaps she's right. But we are in a terrain of paradoxical distinctions. The British still seem to be shocked by topless sunbathers, yet they have half-naked models in their press. The French, Spanish and Italians shrug off topless sunbathing, yet they are stupefied by the idea of timidly erotic photos alongside news stories.

In those instances, though, we are talking about something altogether narrower than what is on display in Berlin. Here we are talking - or rather seeing - reproductive organs: bits which all but the most primitive societies have felt a need to cover up.

German in-your-face urban nudity can be traced to a specific time and place: the Englischer Garten in Munich in the late 1960s. Munich is the capital of Germany's most Catholic and conservative region and one theory is that stripping off is a facet of the social revolution which swept Europe after 1968. That would square with its popularity in Berlin, where the spirit of 68 is as alive as anywhere.

But it does not square with the fact that Germans who thoroughly disapproved of the May revolt think nothing of lounging around in mixed saunas. Hence the rival theory that, like the Scandinavians, Germans in general and Berliners in particular have a different, healthier relationship with their bodies.

That was not what Eva Jaeggi, a Berlin writer and former professor of clinical psychology, thinks. While she did not believe it was necessarily a product of the 60s, she did feel it represented a rebellion of sorts.

"I don't think that this is sign of being at home with one's body at all," she said. "It's too self-conscious. Maybe in Sweden it's another story, but here I think it's a way of being intentionally, deliberately free. I never really had the feeling that people are relaxed when they do it. They do it because they have to show they are free."

German society tolerates stringent limitations on individual freedom in the name of the common good. Perhaps taking off your clothes is a way of showing that you can't be expected to obey them all.

In those instances, though, we are talking about something altogether narrower than what is on display in Berlin. Here we are talking - or rather seeing - reproductive organs: bits which all but the most primitive societies have felt a need to cover up. German in-your-face urban nudity can be traced to a specific time and place: the Englischer Garten in Munich in the late 1960s. Munich is the capital of Germany's most Catholic and conservative region and one theory is that stripping off is a facet of the social revolution which swept Europe after 1968. That would square with its popularity in Berlin, where the spirit of 68 is as alive as anywhere. But it does not square with the fact that Germans who thoroughly disapproved of the May revolt think nothing of lounging around in mixed saunas. Hence the rival theory that, like the Scandinavians, Germans in general and Berliners in particular have a different, healthier relationship with their bodies. That was not what Eva Jaeggi, a Berlin writer and former professor of clinical psychology, thinks. While she did not believe it was necessarily a product of the 60s, she did feel it represented a rebellion of sorts. "I don't think that this is sign of being at home with one's body at all," she said. "It's too self-conscious. Maybe in Sweden it's another story, but here I think it's a way of being intentionally, deliberately free. I never really had the feeling that people are relaxed when they do it. They do it because they have to show they are free." German society tolerates stringent limitations on individual freedom in the name of the common good. Perhaps taking off your clothes is a way of showing that you can't be expected to obey them all.

webTitle: Spider gene spins goats' milk into super fibre

fields.headline: Spider gene spins goats' milk into super fibre
fields.trailText: An incy-wincy spider and a goat called Peter are poised to pool their natural resources to produce a material so strong that the Pentagon wants to use it in its anti-ballistic defence systems.
fields.body:
An incy-wincy spider and a goat called Peter are poised to pool their natural resources to produce a material so strong that the Pentagon wants to use it in its anti-ballistic defence systems.

This latest improbable sounding biotechnology breakthrough means that goats' milk produced on a farm in the rolling countryside east of Montreal will help produce a substance 10 times stronger than steel but with the flexibility needed for stitching in the most delicate of medical operations.

Large scale production of the super-strong material, to be known as BioSteel, will begin later this year. The new product has been created by implanting spider genes into a specially bred herd of tiny brown goats.

This results in the production of silky protein strands in the goats' milk which can be extracted and spun into BioSteel fibres.

All that is needed now is for Peter and his fellow African dwarf goat Webster, currently chomping hay on a Quebec farm, to sire sufficient nannies to begin the production phase.

Once Peter and Webster have spread themselves about sufficiently, the Quebec based Nexia Biotechnologies company expects to be able to produce ultra-light bullet-resistant vests for soldiers and police, which is why the project has stirred such interest from both the US and the Canadian military.

"It's a pretty effective system", Nexia boss Jeffrey Turner says. "What you need is probably the production from one goat in one month to produce a vest."

If this all seems to belong to science fiction, then the science fact is that Mr Turner believes that Peter's baby goats enable him to capture the strength and elasticity of spider silk in a way which overcomes the inherent production problems which would exist with an inherently unmanageable spider farm.

"An inch-thick rope of this material would be able to stop a jet fighter landing on an aircraft carrier," says Dr Randy Lewis of the University of Wyoming, who has also spearheaded attempts to produce spider silk outside the spider.

The fibre has two major potentials, first in advanced industrial applications such as ballistic protection and aerospace, and second in medical devices such as suturing and artificial tendons.

Peter and Webster were bred successfully at the start of this year.

They each carry a single spider silk gene in their genetic make-up of some 70,000 goat genes. Since they became sexually mature this spring, they have been set to work siring the silk producing herd.

"We've combined the old and the new," Mr Turner told an interviewer this week. "The old is represented by the goats and their milk - which is used to make cheese. The new is the genetic engineering."

fields.headline: Science's brave new world
fields.trailText: Giant Salmon
fields.body:
Giant Salmon

Fish farmers in eastern Canada have bred "giant salmon". The genetically engineered fish grow twice as fast as normal salmon and reach regulation size in about 18 months. US scientists are also seeking to develop fast growing breeds of catfish and trout for mass consumption

Pigs

The "Enviropig", genetically engineered by researchers at Canada's University of Guelph, was bred to produce manure far less harmful to the environment, making farm operations cleaner and more cost-efficient. Scientists are also seeking to breed a pig that produces a leaner pork chop

Lobsters and shellfish

MetaMorphix, a US company, is attempting to grow giant lobsters, mussels, shrimp and scallops

Three years ago, Edinburgh-based genetic engineers developed Rosie, a cow who produces the human breast milk protein which scientists argue would be healthier for humans to drink. New Zealand government researchers have developed a herd of super-producing dairy cattle

Sheep

Scientists at an Australia government agency are working on sheep that grow faster and produce more wool, while eating the same amount of food as normal sheep. The sheep are also being bred to shed their fleeces without the need for shearing.

Chickens

American scientists have tried to create "giant chickens" by blocking natural growth genes. They are also developing featherless chickens

- Andy Murdoch

fields.headline: Girl, 10, dies in mock 'rebirth'
fields.trailText: Police have arrested three people for conducting a controversial "rebirthing" therapy on a 10-year-old girl who died after being wrapped in a blanket despite telling them she could not breathe and feared for her life.
fields.body:
Police have arrested three people for conducting a controversial "rebirthing" therapy on a 10-year-old girl who died after being wrapped in a blanket despite telling them she could not breathe and feared for her life.

The procedure, aimed at helping children bond with their parents by making them "relive" birth, was captured on closed-circuit television while the girl's horrified mother watched from a nearby room, according to the Jefferson County sheriff's office.

The girl, Candace Newmaker of North Carolina, told the therapists seven times that she could not breathe and said six times that she was going to die. But instead of unwrapping her, the therapists said "you got to push hard if you want to be born - or do you want to stay in there and die?" An arrest warrant was issued for a fourth person on Thursday.

The adopted girl, who had been treated for Attention Deficit Disorder and depression, lost consciousness during the procedure and died next day in hospital. Those arrested have been charged with "child abuse resulting in death".

webTitle: Attila the Hun comes to tea

fields.headline: Attila the Hun comes to tea
fields.trailText: Say what you like about the Huns, but they knew how to wear skirts. In they swept from the central Asian steppes in skirts that were not only made of leather, but the leather of very heavy cattle. They commanded respect among the natives of the Hungarian plain, where they settled, for their accomplished horsemanship. What those peoples didn't understand, though, is that some of the most dedicated Huns were literally glued to their mounts. Heavy clothes, undismountable steeds - you can see why the Huns upset the apple cart of polite society.
fields.body:
Say what you like about the Huns, but they knew how to wear skirts. In they swept from the central Asian steppes in skirts that were not only made of leather, but the leather of very heavy cattle. They commanded respect among the natives of the Hungarian plain, where they settled, for their accomplished horsemanship. What those peoples didn't understand, though, is that some of the most dedicated Huns were literally glued to their mounts. Heavy clothes, undismountable steeds - you can see why the Huns upset the apple cart of polite society.

But what really impressed everybody was that when the Huns arrived in town, their skirts did not billow. This was because the Huns' womenfolk stitched heavy stones inside their hems. This meant that these parodoxically fierce but shy warriors could keep their dignity intact in battle.

The Huns ate raw meat. Their chief drink was made of finely grated chairs blended with ox blood and alcohol. Their table manners scared the Vandals, the Alans, the Visigoths, the Ostrogoths and many other types of goth. The Barrys, however, had offensive table manners all of their own and so were not at all upset when the Huns came, as they did, for tea. Such is history.

But what do we want from history? One of the talking heads in Attila: Scourge of God (History Channel) suggested that history as it is practised today is much better than that done in the dark ages. In those benighted times, she claimed, the only historians who were listened to were not those who discovered objective facts, but people who could tell good stories no matter what the facts were. But has our practice of history improved since those days? If you watch the History Channel this is often what you get: good stories, told racily, with academic talking heads looking ashamed to be involved. I like this kind of history.

The boring objective truth, if there is such a thing, was skirted in favour of unreliable detail and montages composed from woodcuts of Attila overlaid by Roman centurions from the Hollywood era marching into battle. One of them, I feel sure, was Victor Mature, strong of arm, shapely of calf and confused of expression. How would Victor have managed in close combat with Attila? Badly.

But back to the 5th century, where things were hotting up. Attila had whipped the Huns into a tight federation and proposed that they get medieval on the Roman's asses and other domestic animals. The Romans were themselves no mean skirt wearers, but theirs were never made of leather. Heavens, no. Their skirts were made of gossamer, silk and bits of fluff. They wore these skirts as they lounged in decadent luxury while others peeled their grapes for them. They wore skirts while their slaves painted pornographic pictures of women who didn't even wear skirts. It was, as Gibbon pointed out, one sick mother of a society.

These dissolutes rode into battle waving balloons on sticks, while their footmen carried placatory gifts of iced skinny lattes. They were no match for Attila and what can only be described as his associate Huns. He popped their balloons, snatched their gourmet coffees and laid waste to their homes. In 452, Attila was at the gates of Rome. Unfortunately, at this stage many of his warriors contracted the plague, which, it is said, can be dispiriting to those involved. Worse than that, his wooden waggons were so weighed down with Roman plunder (gold, jewels, balloon and stick kits) that the Huns' pillagingwas impeded.

As a result, Attila withdrew to his Hungarian fastness. There he married a hotsy-totsy Germanic noblewoman. On his wedding night, he went to the nuptial bed full of raw meat, grated chairs and ox blood liberally laced with alcohol. Perhaps predictably, his nose haemorrhaged and he suffocated on his own blood.

Attila's demise prompted Chaucer to write: "Bleeding at the nose in drunkenness/A captain should live in soberness." But that is nonsense. One of the best ways to die, quite obviously, is drunk with a German noblewoman in your arms. Either that or torn apart by lions.

After slaves had caused the waters to be held back by means of temporary dams, Attila's men laid him to rest on a Hungarian river bed. History, that recalcitrant beast, doesn't record whether Attila was wearing his traditional skirt. But let's hope he was. It would have weighed him down a treat.

webTitle: The only language these people understand

fields.headline: The only language these people understand
fields.standfirst: Flimflam flamflew and fokloric flatulence
fields.trailText: Flimflam flamflew and fokloric flatulence
fields.body:
William Hague says he means to break with the gutless liberal consensus which has governed British attitudes to law and order over the postwar years. Many Tories will cheer. But others will be more sceptical. Is Hague really ready to make the break with the recent past which he promises, and sweep us back to the good old days? I see little sign of it. I suspect he has yet to make contact with Councillor Edward Trevor, Conservative representative for the South Cheam ward of the London Borough of Sutton.

Asked by the Sutton and Cheam Guardian (no relation to this one) what should be done to the hooligans who recently ravaged the ornamental gardens in Nonsuch Park, he said it was no use chucking such people in jail. "It just costs the taxpayer a lot of money," he said. "This sort of thing is done by a lot of yobbos and these days there is insufficient punishment thanks to the do-gooders. They should have a hand or an ear cut off." I understand there is a Mr Sankoh in Sierra Leone who has just lost his job and could probably give the councillor a tip or two.

 But at least what he says is unspun. I begin to think that, in every sense, the concept of spin doctors has had its day. (Please note that I do not use the vulgar expression "past its sell-by date" which by now should have been retired to the Archive of British Cliché, along with "to kill for".) It is not entirely clear where the expression sprang from. I had always associated it with cricket: spin doctors are there to make the story deviate from the straight truth, much as spin bowlers cause the ball to deviate from a straight line. But the term comes from the US, where precious few spin bowlers practise, so that can't be it.

I see that "being spun" is equated in some dictionaries with being twisted, and there are also odd connections with other nefarious practices. I did not know until now, for instance, that a spinning house was a place of correction to which lewd and incorrigible women used to be sent. Why such people should be equated with doctors is altogether more curious. In earlier days, when practitioners by and large knew what they were doing, that connection was supportable. But the present generation, who try to persuade gullible Labour MPs to pretend that this month's local elections were a triumph for Labour and a terminal setback for Hague, do not deserve such a designation.

I think the term we should use from now on is "flamster". Their techniques go little further than flamming. The word "flam", by the way, appears to derive either from "flimflam" (defined as a nonsense, or confidence trick) or from "flamfew" (a bauble or trifle). The main meaning of flam nowadays is a blarney or deceit: a comparable concept is hype. All of which seems extremely apposite. The fact that "flamster" also evokes a kind of inflamed hamster seems wholly appropriate too.

 Publication of a volume of poems by the late William Empson has led a number of newspapers to publish photographs of the poet in quite advanced age. I find the beard he displays quite remarkable. Empson made his name in his twenties with a book called Seven Types Of Ambiguity and one cannot but think that this also applies to his beard. Most people's beards proceed from their chins, but Empson's chin was clean shaven. His beard (these photographs suggest) came directly out of his neck.

Indeed, when looked at without one's glasses, it resembles a kind of ruff, suggesting some practical purpose, like keeping his neck warm in winter. (Did he shave it off every spring and grow it again every autumn?) I think I have seen beards like this in photographs of local yokels on the walls of country pubs, but I do not remember encountering any in real life.

A reader has kindly sent the following gem, which comes from the editor's notes to a book called The Aran Islands by JM Synge (Penguin, 1992). "Franz Nikolaus Finck spent four months in Aran in 1894/5 researching his thesis. An Aran-born writer, the late Breandán Ó hEithir, has disinterred from this work the phrase "Ni bhéarfainn broim dreólín ar dhuilleog cuilinn agus is beag an puth gaoth é sin!" (I wouldn't give the fart of a wren on a holly-leaf, and it's the small puff of wind that is) which the linguistic anarchs of Synge's plays would be hard pressed to emulate."

I commend this line to students of vituperation, while hoping it will be quoted in the original only.

 The festivities to mark the Queen Mother's attainment this coming July of the grand old age of 99 years, 11 months are now to be televised on the ITV channel. This follows the BBC's refusal to screen it on the grounds that it has better things to do with its time. The Daily Mail, that monument to human mendacity, calls this a triumph for the Mail campaign against the BBC decision.

I cannot see why. The Mail's aim was to bully the BBC into reversing its view that obeisances to her majesty ought to be kept until August, when she finally gets to 100. The paper promulgated its case by linking this decision with other so-called evidence of a far left takeover of public service broadcasting, including the appointment of notorious leftwing ranter Andrew Marr to be its political editor.

The BBC, much to its credit, has ignored this clamour entirely. It has stuck to its guns, perhaps with the unspoken thought that the Daily Mail should go and jump in the nearest cesspool. It might even have muttered under its corporate breath the euphonious mantra: "Ni bhéarfainn broim dreólín ar dhuilleog cuilinn agus is beag an puth gaoth é sin." There is therefore no retreat by the BBC and no triumph for the newspaper. Would that all such trials of strength ended so happily.

A pedant writes: I do not understand your preprepenultimate sentence. How can a cesspool jump in a cesspool?

Smallweed blandly replies: All sorts of amazing things are possible with modern technology, chummy.
