fields.headline: The last word on   Prophecy
fields.standfirst: Study prophecies when they are become histories.  - Sir Thomas Browne
fields.trailText: Study prophecies when they are become histories. - Sir Thomas Browne
fields.body:
It seems that the third prophecy of Fatima, kept secret until now, concerned the assassination attempt on the Pope in 1981. Heaven's choice of what to alert us to is a mystery - the famines, genocides, earthquakes and plagues provided by the divine mercy since Fatima were not advertised as forthcoming in its bulletin, yet the assassination attempt was.

According to Cardinal Angelo Sodano, the Vatican secretary of state, a complete text of the prophecy will be published after what he unblushingly describes as "appropriate" preparation, so perhaps the special significance of the event will be explained.

Still, the banality of most Christian messages from heaven since St John (the Apocalypse is a hard act to follow) is something of a relief in comparison to those in other religions, which seem mainly to encourage the murder of heretics (i.e. those who disagree with you).

News that the third prophecy was fulfilled two decades ago suggests that the Vatican know their Thomas Browne. Prophecies are always more plausible when their futures are in our pasts, so that we can interpret them historically. As with Rorschach blots, the past is very generous in the interpretations it admits. If, as with the quatrains of Nostradamus, the prophecies themselves are couched in maximally obscure terms, a happy marriage results: all prophecies can be made to come out true.

In biblical times, and for a long period afterwards, "prophecy" meant interpreting the will of God. A prophet was a teacher, a moralist, as well as a forecaster. All religions and traditions have their seers. Apollo, frustrated in his passion for the chaste Cassandra, cursed her prophecies so that no one would believe them. Tiresias the blind seer saw more and further than any sighted man.

Soothsayers have never been short of work because humans are superstitious and life uncertain, a profitable combination. The church condemned many seers as votaries of Satan, on the grounds that attempting to know the future is sinful. This applied only to prophecy not licensed by the church itself, of course, and represents a market strategy for undermining the competition.

Prophecy in the sense of foretelling the future makes sense only if determinism is true, that is, if the future history of the world is settled and fixed. Theologians have their work cut out reconciling the free will required for sin with the omniscience of God who, knowing everything, knows what is to come. The medieval Schoolmen devised elaborate explanations of how human freedom and divine foreknowledge can coexist. For sheer ingenuity their arguments earn high marks.

Prophecy has a respect- able and necessary cousin, which is rational forecasting based on past experience and current data, with a view to assessing what is more probable than not in such matters as tomorrow's weather, next year's social trends, and the long-term effects of pollution. All life is movement into the future, and therefore planning and preparing is essential if life is to be worth living. The premise of this view is the exact opposite of the one underlying belief in prophecy: it is that the future does not exist, but is ours to make.

Even in antiquity the examination of auspices was not always seen as predictive, but as revealing the current state of the gods' attitudes. If they were hostile, the likelihood was that the proposed venture - a battle, or the building of a palace - would fail. But enough libations and sacrifices could change the gods' minds, securing success.

Some ancient philosophers recognised the startling implication of this idea. It is that if we can influence what will happen, we are therefore responsible for what will happen, for even doing nothing is a choice. Regarding the future as open therefore makes us the captains of our fate. To think the opposite - that prophecy is possible, and that therefore the future is fixed - leaves us merely fate's victims.

fields.headline: British directors rue Hollywood ad
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Ridley and Tony Scott, two of Britain's most celebrated film directors, reacted with fury and more than a little embarrassment to an advertisement placed by their company which critics say is offensive to black people and women.
fields.body:
Ridley and Tony Scott, two of Britain's most celebrated film directors, reacted with fury and more than a little embarrassment to an advertisement placed by their company which critics say is offensive to black people and women.

They apologised profusely for the advert, in the trade weekly Shoot, which has led to picketing of the company's Hollywood offices and protests by civil rights groups.

It shows an elderly bare-breasted African woman with the caption: "In South Africa, this is what SAG means."

The ad promotes the commercial film-making facilities in South Africa and announces that a member of the Scotts' company, RSA USA, will be setting up a temporary office there during the strike by members of the American Screen Actors Guild - better known in the business as SAG.

Ridley Scott's film Gladiator is currently enjoying great success in the US.

The strike started nearly three weeks ago by SAG and the American Federation of Television and Radio Advertising (Aftra), involves 135,000 actors. They are objecting to proposed changes to the way they are paid, which they claim would cost them money. Makers of commercials have threatened to shoot their ads abroad or use non-union actors.

"We are shocked and appalled," SAG said. "It clearly insults women, actors and advertisers."

A protest supported by the National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People, Aftra and the AFL-CIO union federation was held outside RSA's offices on Thursday.

Initially, RSA USA defended the ad. A spokeswoman said: "It's a bit of shock value for shock value's sake. But there is a lot of business at stake here."

But when the Scott brothers became aware of what had been done, their response was as explosive and spectacular as their films.

"We knew absolutely nothing about this advertisement and are as upset, sickened and appalled by the situation as anyone else," they said in a statement.

The company said: "We made a huge mistake . . . we are truly and deeply sorry."

fields.headline: Free thinking welcome
fields.standfirst: Paul Myners, head, Treasury review of institutional investment
fields.trailText: This is the man asking the questions. The head of the Gartmore fund management group has set his peers almost 50 brainteasers about an industry in which he has spent most of his 30-year career. But Paul Myners, who is also non-executive chairman of Guardian Media Group which publishes the Guardian, insists he is not going to second-guess the answers.
fields.body:
This is the man asking the questions. The head of the Gartmore fund management group has set his peers almost 50 brainteasers about an industry in which he has spent most of his 30-year career. But Paul Myners, who is also non-executive chairman of Guardian Media Group which publishes the Guardian, insists he is not going to second-guess the answers.

Myners' list, which threatens to turn the arcane world of pensions and insurance investment upside down, was drawn up during a Caribbean holiday. He has until the next budget to establish why the country's leading investors, who between them control £800bn of assets, plough the bulk of their money into the same companies, starving new business of cash.

The problem, which Myners describes as a "consensual" way of investing, is at the core of Gordon Brown's aim to boost productivity and innovation and promote longer-term investment. The premise is to establish why the country's pension funds put 0.5% of their investments into venture capital while US investors channel 5% of assets towards young enterprises.

If the investigation cracks City orthodoxy and fund managers change their ways, the performance of their funds could improve which should mean lower pension contributions for workers and a better quality of retirement.

Open mind

"This is linked to productivity, it's about promoting national competitive advantage through innovation," says Myners. Explaining how the industry became trapped in a conservative mindset, where pension fund trustees increasingly trust their assets to investment managers who track market indices rather than make decisions about individual stocks, is far from easy. Encouraging a fresher way of thinking will be tougher still.

On Myners' hit list, for example, is the way a pension fund's performance is measured - every 90 days even though the fund might have a 70-year life - and the effect on investment decisions. The investigation is in its early days but Myners is already facing jibes - chiefly that he is too much of an insider and his own group Gartmore, which he has run since 1985, is guilty of the shortcomings he is now digging into. Others ask why the industry needs an investigation, citing unnecessary and costly government meddling.

Conversely, the Financial Times has toyed with the idea that he could become Sir Paul if he gets to the bottom of the matter. The 52-year-old finds this dis tracting and repeats that he is approaching the investigation with an "open mind," although he was described by one commentator last week as an "amiable lunatic" for taking on the role.

An indication of his concerns might be his view about how fund performance has been measured since the 1970s, a "tool that was originally intended to enlighten and inform and has now become a tool of entrapment". The charge is that quarterly league tables focus people on the short term, not just the fund managers but also the trustees. "There has to be accountability. The question is appropriateness," he says.

Myners sees his questions as critically important to the health of the economy. "They are all inter-related; it's how the trustees link to goal-setting, to consultants, to performance measurement and to regulation," he says. "You need to understand all those to comprehend why we appear to have developed very very consensual activity."

Among regulations with which Myners will grapple are minimum funding requirements for pension funds and insolvency ratios for insurance companies.

The review lends itself to comparison with the controversial investigation into banking competition by Don Cruickshank commissioned for this year's budget and which resulted in a competition commission inquiry into banking for small and medium sized business. Myners dislikes the comparison and hopes his "journey of enquiry" will have far-reaching consequences for everyone.

"Ask any fund manager 'if you could invest for 10 years would you invest the money differently?'. I think it beggars belief that they wouldn't say yes," he says.

Of all the criticisms bounced at Myners, he rushes to defend Gartmore, which suffered from pension fund consultants who brought clients in the early 1990s only to switch their loyalty when performance spluttered. (The Guardian pension fund was one client to move in the early 1990s.) "In the last 20 years Gartmore has outperformed in 16. We underperformed in four, three of which, like London buses, came in a row in 1995, 1996, 1997," he says.

He dismisses suggestions that Gartmore has become an index-tracking firm. It is through Gartmore that Myners has achieved personal wealth, overseeing three changes in ownership during 15 years at the helm. Each time, he says proudly, the new owners have doubled their money in less than four years. The most recent change was two months ago when Gartmore was sold to Nationwide Mutual of the US, after being discarded by Royal Bank of Scotland, the new owners of NatWest.

Myners steered through the change of ownership from a group which had previously fired him, when NatWest was trying to clinch a merger with Legal & General last year.

He admits to feeling "pretty awful" as he stumbled from the offices of NatWest's advisers one afternoon but nevertheless pays tribute to Sir David Rowland, the NatWest chairman who sacked him and then asked him to stay on to help try to fend off the hostile bids by Royal Bank of Scotland and Bank of Scotland.

On his bike

Myners might not have ended up in the City at all. Adopted from an orphanage in Bath by a Cornish couple - "I know nothing about my natural parents, I don't wish to" - he spent his childhood in Cornwall before obtaining a first class degree in education. Two terms at a Wandsworth girls comprehensive put him off and got him on his bike - literally, because of a postal strike - around City firms to look for work. Wedd Durlacher, later part of the now-defunct BZW investment bank, gave him his break.

He then completed a stint at the Daily Telegraph, where he is said to have told colleagues that he would not be around long as he wanted to make money. Myners says he has "no recollection" of his motivator. "I think I've been very fortunate to be part of a successful business and that's given me much more satisfaction than working for pay," he says.

Myners divides his time between the City and the Cornish home where his second wife lives with their two young children (he has three from his first marriage). As for political tilt, he has been commissioned by governments of both hues to delve into the arcane but crucial world he knows and loves.

Measuring his success will not be easy. Myners says it will depend on whatever the chancellor implements. Then, it could take several years before results feed through. He does not believe everything about the industry is wrong. "It is working incredibly well in offering people in pensions schemes a comfortable retirement in comparision with their forefathers. There's a lot of good here but can we do it better?"

It is now over to the fund managers, consultants, trustees and pensioners themselves to fill in the questionnaire by the July deadline. Then Myners can start the number crunching.

fields.headline: Never trust a therapist
fields.standfirst: Arnold Wesker’s latest play, about child abuse, is brave, honest and urgent, says Michael Billington
fields.trailText: Arnold Wesker’s latest play, about child abuse, is brave, honest and urgent, says Michael Billington
fields.body:
We read a lot these days about "grey power", the realisation that pensioners can swing elections. What few have noticed, at a time when youth is prized, is that in the theatre too the oldies are fighting back. The most popular plays in London are by writers such as Frayn, Bennett, Nichols and Plater, all of whom are technically eligible for bus passes. And further proof that creativity is not dimmed by age comes from Arnold Wesker's Denial, which deals with false memory syndrome.

Wesker himself is the victim not so much of repressed memories as of exaggerated nostalgia. In Britain, we prize so highly his early works - The Kitchen, Roots, Chips with Everything - that we tend to downgrade everything he has written since. One reason, I suspect, is that we favour obliqueness over Wesker's brand of emotional directness.

If I have any personal regret it is that Wesker now largely forswears the kind of choreographed action that characterised his early, autobiographical plays. No one can forget the lunch-hour pandemonium of The Kitchen or the night-time raid on the coke store in Chips with Everything. As Wesker once said in an interview, "The theatre is a place where one goes to see things happening." But, as he has increasingly focused on ideas or moral dilemmas, he has scaled down dramatic action.

Throughout his career, however, one subject has always dominated Wesker's thinking: family cohesiveness. As Tynan shrewdly noted in 1960, "His characters belong together, even when they are not on speaking terms with each other." And it is the attempt to dissolve the molten security of family that is the real subject of Denial.

In 21 scenes and 90 minutes, Wesker shows Jenny, whose marriage and career have broken down, accusing her father of raping her as a child; even her mother and grandfather have been complicit in persistent sexual abuse. Needless to say, the accusations come at the prompting of a therapist, Valerie, who is seeking the cause of Jenny's depression. But is she unlocking genuinely repressed memories or seeking a facile explanation for Jenny's problems?

The danger in a play on this theme is obvious: of lapsing into therapist-as-villain melodrama. But, with considerable dramatic cunning, Wesker largely avoids that trap. As played by Susan Tracy, Wesker's Valerie at first seems maternal, caring and indignant at the vilification she and fellow therapists have to endure. As she explains to a TV interviewer, she is the one who has seen "eight-year-olds with vaginas burst open by cycle pumps, young boys with gaping anuses, children who shud der at your touch". What she cannot forgive is violation of childhood trust.

But, as the play progresses, we see that Valerie, haunted by her experiences as a Cardiff social worker, seeks a catch-all solution to complex problems. In slowly shifting the balance of sympathy, Wesker also comes up with one of the most honest admissions I've heard on the British stage in a long time: the acknowledgement by Jenny's father that there is a tactile pleasure in the bathing, handling and kissing of children that stops short of sexual abuse. The speech is delivered by Jeremy Child with fervent candour. It also underlines Wesker's key point: that proven child abuse is wicked, but if we deny the joy of sensual physical contact between parent and child we are destroying family life.

Even if the play is not perfect - the family friend unable to repress his own memories of the Nazi death camps smacks too much of an antithetical device - it is brave, honest and urgent. It is also well directed by Andy Hay, neatly designed by Tom Piper, and strongly acted by all concerned, including Nicola Barber as the accusatory Jenny and Rosemary McHale as her defiant mother. In the end, the play is a vehement assertion of the validity of the nuclear family and of the pleasurable intimacy of the parent-child relationship. It is, I suspect, the promotion of such unfashionable ideas that makes Wesker the British theatre's congenital outsider.

 Denial is at Bristol Old Vic (0117-987 7877) till June 10.

fields.headline: Walk on the mild side
fields.standfirst: Jamie McCallum  watches a rock legend get lost in his music
fields.trailText: Jamie McCallum watches a rock legend get lost in his music
fields.body:
Once part of the Velvet Underground, one of America's great songwriter-poet-musicians, a musical hero to countless bands and living proof that drugs can't possibly be that bad for you, Lou Reed has achieved the status of rock god. For some, that would be enough on which to retire to Hawaii on their laurels, but not Reed. While Paul Simon re-releases his old songs, Reed is on the road again - wearing the same clothes again - bringing his new endeavours to an audience who perhaps would have preferred him to simply trot out the classics. With nothing to prove, however, Reed did as he pleased.

In the main, An Evening with Lou Reed at the Edinburgh Playhouse was triumphant. The first hour was a showcase of work entirely from his new album Ecstasy, and it soared the dizzy heights and plumbed the murky depths of human experience with typical Reed panache.

Wrapping up brutality in a tender, simple melody, Rock Minuet was characteristic of the set, describing as it did "the thrill of the needle and anonymous sex" and, with Modern Dance, Reed proved he was one of the few songwriters who could rhyme moon, noon and June and make it sound as if no one had ever done it before.

But after that smooth musical arc, which brought the audience to a high, albeit a sedate one, the low was to follow. Song after song melded into a meandering instrumental break punctuated with the lazy lyrics ("You're as dumb as my thumb") and repetitive guitar riffs; not even the exceptional way in which they were played could stop the audience fidgeting. Yet Reed seemed to be oblivious. Like a senile penguin left to his own devices, he was evidently having a great time but was inured to everyone else's enjoyment.

Hardly engaging with the audience at all, it wasn't until the second encore - an hour later - that Reed actually said hello to those beyond the stage. It was a joy to see him jam with his band but it would have been better not to feel quite so surplus to requirements. In compensation, though, he did wheel out Perfect Day and Sweet Jane to satisfy the audience's - if not his own - yearning for songs of old. Looking everything like a musician with a back catalogue weighing him down as well as buoying him up, Reed rocked but he didn't once break a sweat.

fields.headline: Ye of little faith
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... a question of religion
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... a question of religion
fields.body:
When I asked a senior colleague this week how he would describe the Guardian's attitude towards the coverage of religious affairs, he said that, for as long as he could remember, it had been a mixture of neglect and disdain, persevered in despite the best efforts of a long succession of good religious affairs correspondents. Many readers would agree with that, or put it even stronger.

Some readers - and journalists who work on the paper - believe we are routinely prepared to print or allow to be printed remarks that are offensive to Christians that we would not dream of directing at others, for example Jews or Muslims, because we know there would be uproar and that we would probably acknowledge such a reaction as justified. From time to time, I feel I should say, we do manage to offend Jews, Muslims, and many others. Do we really seem disinclined to develop the sensitivity, or objectivity, in matters of faith that the paper has struggled to achieve in dealing with race or homosexuality, or (the suggestion of one journalist) vegetarianism? That is how some readers see it.

Most of the complaints come from Christians, perhaps because they form the majority of those readers who profess some religious faith, but we do not really know. We assume that our readership includes people of all faiths and none. But we have no idea how many of you adhere to this or that religion, or to a non-religious belief that you regard as at least equally valid. Everyone seems to have a different idea, with "not many" the popular notion. I think we might be surprised by the results of a survey.

We are in a state of similar ignorance about the beliefs of the paper's own journalists - the people who make up the "we" I keep referring to - and perhaps we should not ask; but at least one reader thinks it might be relevant, making the point roughly like this - if your reporter is as godless as he (or she) appears to be, then no wonder he writes uncomprehendingly about other people's beliefs. The paper puts its faith, so to speak, in the idea that the professional attitudes of its journalists will prevail. Is that safe? One journalist said the general view of religious matters inside the Guardian was that they were not "cool".

But to return to the complaints: "I have been a loyal Guardian reader for over 20 years... I don't mind the paper giving constructive criticism of the Church, but there appears to be no attempt at balance." And from another reader: "The constant mocking of religious faith and practice... is painful to most Christians." This correspondent says she has read the Guardian for her whole life and values its "radical approach", as many of her Christian friends do, but she adds:"I would regard it as sinful to mock anyone's religion, be it Christian or other faiths."

One reader, the wife of a Methodist minister, says she is giving up the Guardian because of what she perceives as its constant misrepresentation of "what the churches are all about". "I can only guess at your intentions in rubbishing the churches but I would like to ask why you always ignore what actually goes on?" She then lists the fund-raising activities for charities and relief organisations in which her church is involved. Others point to the role of churches in the inner cities and invite the question whether life would be poorer there without them.

A frequent complaint is that the paper has an apparently insatiable appetite for the weirder aspects of faith and for the sexual activities of adherents and ministers, rather than for important issues actually touching people's spiritual lives. Journalists are seen, by some critics of our coverage, as pond skaters showing little or no awareness of, or interest in, the depths.

Perhaps we are exaggerating. The Church of England recently conducted what might be called a negativity survey of newspaper coverage of its activities, searching for the words "failing" and "decline" or "declining". It concluded that the "straightest", or least negative, reporting, was in the Times and Guardian.

What most correspondents, and others to whom I talked this week, now seem to recognise is the effort that is made to reflect the faiths represented in a multi-cultural society. We are not, as the religious affairs correspondent pointed out, a noticeboard for the Church of England. Indeed, we do not carry the leaders on religious values at Christmas or Easter that some papers still run, because we think we can safely assume that non-believers and believers in non-Christian faiths among our readers consider the Guardian to be just as much their paper as do the Christians.

The editor says there is no reason why the scepticism applied in other areas of reporting should not be applied to the paper's coverage of religious affairs. Scepticism is not the same as scorn; although every now and again, some will insist, we seem closer to the latter.

Email: reader@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Phantom of the opera house
fields.standfirst: So Andrew Lloyd Webber is to be staged at La Scala.  Martin Kettle doesn't think it's good enough
fields.trailText: So Andrew Lloyd Webber is to be staged at La Scala. Martin Kettle doesn't think it's good enough
fields.body:
Occasionally events occur which are so counter-intuitive that the only possible response is disbelief: consider this week's official announcement that La Scala opera house, Milan, will produce Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical The Phantom of the Opera. Lloyd Webber at La Scala? It is not so many decades since Arturo Toscanini's decision to perform the works of Wagner at this temple of Italian opera was met with consternation. Even today, there is a faction of the Scala audience still sniffy about that Austrian interloper Mozart. Many opera lovers want La Scala to be faithful only to its great Italian traditions: Rossini, Donizetti, Verdi, Puccini.

Pierluigi Panza, the correspondent of Milan's Corriere della Sera, was unsettled by the news. Reporting Lloyd Webber's Milan press conference this week, Panza could hardly believe what he was hearing: "Yesterday, the king of the musical appeared on the stage where Callas once sang." The musical itself will not be performed on those very boards. In 2002, La Scala will do a Covent Garden and close for two years while the theatre, dating from 1778, is renovated. During the closure, the company will operate from the newly-built Teatro degli Arcimboldi: Lloyd Webber's work will be staged there in 2003.

However, it will not be a touring production brought in merely to earn revenue during the close season, as happens at the London Coliseum when Eng lish National Opera isn't there. This will be the real thing, a fullblown Il Fantasma dell'Opera, sung in Italian by opera singers, with the Scala orchestra, as part of the season.

This is not the first time La Scala has pioneered operatic repertoire. It may have a reputation as a place of tradition, but it has frequently experimented, commissioning works by Nono and Stockhausen in the 70s, and performing in factories. This summer, it will give its first performances of Bernstein's West Side Story. Scott Joplin's opera Treemonisha is also scheduled.

Yet La Scala's decision can only be fully understood in an Italian context: the country has undergone a non-violent cultural revolution in the past two decades. The great tenor Carlo Bergonzi said last month that Italians can no longer sing opera. "They don't study. In 10 years' time, opera singers will be miked." Now that prediction seems over-optimistic.

But why The Phantom? The huge popularity of Lloyd Webber's musicals has never been matched by critical acclaim, which West Side Story had from the start. Most critics are dismissive about Lloyd Webber's musical abilities. Audiences feel his work is on in quite enough theatres already. The idea of Phantom at La Scala is shocking. Even to the composer. The proposal, Lloyd Webber said , came "like a bolt from the blue". He was flattered and delighted. "It is a fantastic opportunity that I have never been able to enjoy in the musical theatre."

Artistically, this is the core of the issue of whether the move is sacrilege. Like Mozart and Wagner, Lloyd Webber clearly writes something that can be described as "music theatre". But does that mean that anything which can be called music theatre should be performed in the opera house? Not surprisingly, Lloyd Webber says yes. "I never thought there was any difference between opera and musicals that are through-written. Music theatre is music theatre. It either works for an audience or it doesn't."

Opera houses are minded to agree. Most houses are run by pragmatists. If the piece works, and people buy tickets for it, they will give it a go. Theatre managers are entrepreneurs who want to attract audiences. The idea that opera houses are run by snobby acolytes of tradition is mostly untrue. Even at Bayreuth there are debates about whether works other than Wagner's might be performed there.

It makes little sense to say that musicals ought never to be allowed in the opera house. We should be with Lloyd Webber on that. Musicals are music theatre, and in some cases more fun and more lasting in their appeal than unrevivable modern operas. The doors should be thrown open to new audiences. But the real test ought to be quality, not category. If the musical is good enough, put it on. You have to have the confidence to sort the bad from the good. And that's the problem about La Scala. Lloyd Webber acknowledged this. "I agree with Duke Ellington," he said. "There are only two kinds of music. Good music and bad music."

My history teacher, David Bury, put it unforgettably. He was an opera fan, challenged by a group who assured him that the Rolling Stones were better than opera. "If someone tells me that The Chocolate Soldier is as good as Don Giovanni," he thundered, "that's not an opinion, that's rubbish."Is Phantom as good as Don Giovanni? The question answers itself. Is he worth La Scala's time and effort? I don't think so, but I could be wrong.

fields.headline: Writer and underwriter
fields.standfirst: As the poet Tom Paulin and others enjoy lottery largesse,  John Mullan  looks at patronage and wonders if artists today would be more creative if they were starving in garrets
fields.trailText: As the poet Tom Paulin and others enjoy lottery largesse, John Mullan looks at patronage and wonders if artists today would be more creative if they were starving in garrets
fields.body:
What does a writer with high artistic ambitions have to do to get financial backing? In past centuries, you had to tickle the fancy of some grand courtier with cultural pretensions. In the Soviet Union, you had to please Stalin. Under our present dispensation, you have to impress Carol Vorderman. For the latter (recently famed for thinking Shakespeare "as dull as ditchwater") is one of the "trustees" of the new National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts (Nesta), which this week awarded to 13 "amazing people", including several writers, lump sums large enough to banish thoughts of the garret.

Inevitably for a scheme devised, as it proclaims, "to seek out creative people and innovative ideas", Nesta is funded by the National Lottery, that "tax upon stupidity", as economist Adam Smith called it. Every year the interest from £200m of lottery money - about £10m - is to be doled out in order to promote what the body's chief executive Jeremy Lewis calls "the development of an artistic gift, or a new discovery, product or theory that improves the quality of life for everyone". Nesta's largesse includes the financing of educational projects and innovative small businesses. It also funds "fellowships" worth up to £75,000 to each fortunate paragon of creativity.

Some of these beneficiaries are engaging-sounding inventors: a couple of scientists unable to squeeze from their universities the funding for idiosyncratic research; a self-educated inventor who devises special sets of wheels for moving difficult loads. There is also an assortment of writers and artists. There is the dancer and choreographer who has £75,000 to visit Scottish Highland communi ties in order "to develop and explore new, original approaches to creating and presenting dance and to examine how physical landscapes influence form, language and music in the evolution of culture and identity". There is the maker of animated films who has £63,000 to support her efforts to "help business find new, creative approaches to problem-solving". And, attracting most publicity, there is Tom Paulin.

Paulin, Fellow in English at Hertford College, Oxford and the BBC's favourite literary critic, has been given £75,000 to help him write an epic poem about the second world war. His poetry, he says, is usually "written in time stolen from teaching, marking, administration, writing reviews and critical work". Now he will be free from time-stealing. As will the other poet among the new fellows, Lavinia Greenlaw and the writer WG Sebald.

Perhaps it is a recommendation of the scheme that Nesta identifies the candidates for its generosity so mysteriously. It has 100 "nominators" across the country - "experts and leaders in a broad range of fields, who are in daily contact with new talent and thinking". Each nominator gets to recommend two individuals. After you have done your nominating, you are replaced by a new nominator. (But who shall nominate the nominators?) This sounds promisingly odd - as if at least one or two of these nominators might volunteer some brilliant crank whose creativity was restrained only by his or her life of unremitting toil as a manual labourer. Yet the suspicion lingers that habitués of the arts media might nominate each other.

Final choices from among the candidates are made by Nesta's trustees. This body has its quota of scientists and administrators, perhaps able to judge the plausibility of technological proposals. What about the writers? Authorship being a rivalrous profession, it might be just as well that there are no actual writers amongst the trustees (and maybe Carol Vorderman leaves well alone when poetry is discussed). Yet, however alive these worthies are to what writing is likeliest "to cross conventional boundaries" (their declared criterion), is their money (not that it is, of course, "their" money at all) ever going to allow "the development of an artistic gift" that would otherwise be suffocated?

Doubters are likely to observe that writing is least in need of subsidy, being - unlike, say, staging operas - a pretty cheap occupation. You can hear this thought worrying the Nesta representatives as they explain why Tom Paulin needs all that cash. "He will undertake an intense period of research and experimentation" - limbering up before the lines begin to flow. Yet is this enough to say that Paulin, however harassed by the demanding students of Hertford College, Oxford and the phone calls from BBC producers, would not be able to write the mooted epic without his lottery windfall?

In more expensive art forms, the argument for subsidy has usually been less embarrassed, though it has often met the counter-argument that state funding produces mediocrity by removing the responsibility to please. Recently, arguments have centred on lottery funding for British films, voiced most grumpily by veteran London Evening Standard film critic Alexander Walker. He would have it that, by easing the pressure to reach out to an audience, such funding merely encourages self-indulgence and sloppiness - and therefore produces bad films.

Walker's scepticism is rooted in his observation that cinema is one of the most purely commercial of art forms. It lives or dies by its capacity to excite paying customers. Does the same argument work for writing? True Thatcherites always tell you about Shakespeare and Dickens, the greatest of talents being the biggest successes at the box-office.

Most of Shakespeare's educated contemporaries, however, would have thought it far nobler to write for a patron than for the many-headed multitude. Best of all if that patron were the state, in the celestial person of the monarch. Then, in the 18th century, in Britain at least, the market took over. When Samuel Johnson said "No man but a blockhead writes, except for money," he was embracing what would once have appalled any literary gentleman: the idea that commerce and literature should go hand in hand.

Johnson despised the patron, defined in the dictionary that made his name as "One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence, and is paid with flattery". He lauded publishers ("booksellers" as they were called), the true friends of literature. He also, however, accepted a substantial pension from George III that greatly smoothed the last 20 years of his life.

Johnson's celebration of writing for the market once seemed liber ating. Voltaire, like a procession of other enlightened travellers to London at the time, admired a country where anything could be published that might have enough readers to recoup the costs. Booksellers were large-minded men compared with princes and courtiers. Some recent historians, notably John Brewer in The Pleasures of the Imagination, have described how a democratic culture - of art, music, drama and literature - was only produced because, during the 18th century, patronage gave way to commerce.

Yet patronage has not always been unproductive. Not only have toadying writers and artists make admirable literature and art (Spenser, Jonson, Dryden, among poets), once upon a time toadying itself - the art of the compliment, as it was thought of - could itself be a creative achievement. To get Nesta loot you have to apply via a form on the organisation's website. Once, you would have had to write a flattering or celebratory piece of verse.

More awkwardly for cultural Thatcherites, what would William Blake have done without his handful of wealthy and eccentric patrons? The weirdness and exquisiteness of his laboriously etched, hand-coloured Songs of Innocence and Experience took them as far from commercial viability as is possible. He was a writer without any kind of public.

Similarly, James Joyce's experimental, laboriously hewn fiction would hardly have been possible without the obstinate support of Harriet Shaw Weaver, who was his lifelong benefactor and who was convinced of his genius when only Ezra Pound and Joyce himself seemed to share the opinion. Indeed, Joyce seems to offer Nesta hope of doing a lasting service to literature. It may have been the rich and eccentric Weaver who got A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man published, but the composition of his masterpiece, Ulysses, was supported by what amounted to state patronage. In 1915, he received a grant from the Royal Literary Fund and, soon after, a grant from the civil list. It is a nice detail that this great Irish genius had the backing of the British state.

Those who would have writers kept a little lean and hungry can argue that financial support also compromises and disarms. It is sometimes thought to have strangled Wordsworth's poetry. In 1813 Wordsworth was given a large sinecure by Lord Lonsdale, the local Tory grandee, and later admirers of his early verse (and his early radicalism) like Shelley and Browning were to judge that this was the end of him. We certainly no longer read most of what he produced during his last 37 years without financial anxieties but with establishment friends.

Poets, of course, have a special problem. How many have ever made money from poetry? Alexander Pope, yes. Ted Hughes, but most of it posthumously. Not many others that spring to mind. With the small fortune that he made from translating Homer's Iliad into elegant English couplets for an elegant English readership, Pope had the privilege of mocking the scramble of versifiers for the favour of potential benefactors: "Like the vile straw that's blown about the streets,/ The needy poet sticks to all he meets."

Poets have always had to do day jobs (thus all that midnight scribbling). In the 20th century, as private incomes have become less common and life more expensive, they have often had to lead two separate lives. TS Eliot worked in Lloyds Bank every morning, until rich admirers clubbed together to rescue him, and Wallace Stevens was an executive with a Connecticut insurance company. Nowadays, while would-be novelists often survive by scribbling for newspapers and magazines, universites have become the public-spirited patrons of poets. American universities in particular buy them in (Geoffrey Hill, Derek Walcott) and bask in the reflected glory. Even famous Seamus has relied on the odd honorary professorship. Both sides benefit from this bargain. The academy looks as though it is treating literature as a living organism; the poet looks as though he is a thorough person of letters. And one imagines that Nobel prize-winners do not have to mark too many undergraduate essays.

There seems little pattern to what we might now judge the "worthwhile" outlay of patrons in the past. Except that eccentric rich people with tastes somewhat out of kilter with their times (not Charles Saatchi, therefore) have been more likely to strike gold than committees or high-minded public bodies. Blake and Joyce needed patrons who were as odd as them. The great German lyric poet Rilke used to receive donations from an anonymous benefactor who was, in fact, Ludwig Wittgenstein - an ascetic man with a family fortune (and good taste).

The other lesson is that money is best invested in those who, in Wordsworthian fashion, are capable of giving things up for the sake of their art. Retirement to an isolated cottage to produce only poetry might not be mandatory, but the Nesta trustees might consider making their grants conditional on the renunciation of media employment until the poetry is finished.

fields.bodyText: What does a writer with high artistic ambitions have to do to get financial backing? In past centuries, you had to tickle the fancy of some grand courtier with cultural pretensions. In the Soviet Union, you had to please Stalin. Under our present dispensation, you have to impress Carol Vorderman. For the latter (recently famed for thinking Shakespeare "as dull as ditchwater") is one of the "trustees" of the new National Endowment for Science, Technology and the Arts (Nesta), which this week awarded to 13 "amazing people", including several writers, lump sums large enough to banish thoughts of the garret. Inevitably for a scheme devised, as it proclaims, "to seek out creative people and innovative ideas", Nesta is funded by the National Lottery, that "tax upon stupidity", as economist Adam Smith called it. Every year the interest from £200m of lottery money - about £10m - is to be doled out in order to promote what the body's chief executive Jeremy Lewis calls "the development of an artistic gift, or a new discovery, product or theory that improves the quality of life for everyone". Nesta's largesse includes the financing of educational projects and innovative small businesses. It also funds "fellowships" worth up to £75,000 to each fortunate paragon of creativity. Some of these beneficiaries are engaging-sounding inventors: a couple of scientists unable to squeeze from their universities the funding for idiosyncratic research; a self-educated inventor who devises special sets of wheels for moving difficult loads. There is also an assortment of writers and artists. There is the dancer and choreographer who has £75,000 to visit Scottish Highland communi ties in order "to develop and explore new, original approaches to creating and presenting dance and to examine how physical landscapes influence form, language and music in the evolution of culture and identity". There is the maker of animated films who has £63,000 to support her efforts to "help business find new, creative approaches to problem-solving". And, attracting most publicity, there is Tom Paulin. Paulin, Fellow in English at Hertford College, Oxford and the BBC's favourite literary critic, has been given £75,000 to help him write an epic poem about the second world war. His poetry, he says, is usually "written in time stolen from teaching, marking, administration, writing reviews and critical work". Now he will be free from time-stealing. As will the other poet among the new fellows, Lavinia Greenlaw and the writer WG Sebald. Perhaps it is a recommendation of the scheme that Nesta identifies the candidates for its generosity so mysteriously. It has 100 "nominators" across the country - "experts and leaders in a broad range of fields, who are in daily contact with new talent and thinking". Each nominator gets to recommend two individuals. After you have done your nominating, you are replaced by a new nominator. (But who shall nominate the nominators?) This sounds promisingly odd - as if at least one or two of these nominators might volunteer some brilliant crank whose creativity was restrained only by his or her life of unremitting toil as a manual labourer. Yet the suspicion lingers that habitués of the arts media might nominate each other. Final choices from among the candidates are made by Nesta's trustees. This body has its quota of scientists and administrators, perhaps able to judge the plausibility of technological proposals. What about the writers? Authorship being a rivalrous profession, it might be just as well that there are no actual writers amongst the trustees (and maybe Carol Vorderman leaves well alone when poetry is discussed). Yet, however alive these worthies are to what writing is likeliest "to cross conventional boundaries" (their declared criterion), is their money (not that it is, of course, "their" money at all) ever going to allow "the development of an artistic gift" that would otherwise be suffocated? Doubters are likely to observe that writing is least in need of subsidy, being - unlike, say, staging operas - a pretty cheap occupation. You can hear this thought worrying the Nesta representatives as they explain why Tom Paulin needs all that cash. "He will undertake an intense period of research and experimentation" - limbering up before the lines begin to flow. Yet is this enough to say that Paulin, however harassed by the demanding students of Hertford College, Oxford and the phone calls from BBC producers, would not be able to write the mooted epic without his lottery windfall? In more expensive art forms, the argument for subsidy has usually been less embarrassed, though it has often met the counter-argument that state funding produces mediocrity by removing the responsibility to please. Recently, arguments have centred on lottery funding for British films, voiced most grumpily by veteran London Evening Standard film critic Alexander Walker. He would have it that, by easing the pressure to reach out to an audience, such funding merely encourages self-indulgence and sloppiness - and therefore produces bad films. Walker's scepticism is rooted in his observation that cinema is one of the most purely commercial of art forms. It lives or dies by its capacity to excite paying customers. Does the same argument work for writing? True Thatcherites always tell you about Shakespeare and Dickens, the greatest of talents being the biggest successes at the box-office. Most of Shakespeare's educated contemporaries, however, would have thought it far nobler to write for a patron than for the many-headed multitude. Best of all if that patron were the state, in the celestial person of the monarch. Then, in the 18th century, in Britain at least, the market took over. When Samuel Johnson said "No man but a blockhead writes, except for money," he was embracing what would once have appalled any literary gentleman: the idea that commerce and literature should go hand in hand. Johnson despised the patron, defined in the dictionary that made his name as "One who countenances, supports or protects. Commonly a wretch who supports with insolence, and is paid with flattery". He lauded publishers ("booksellers" as they were called), the true friends of literature. He also, however, accepted a substantial pension from George III that greatly smoothed the last 20 years of his life. Johnson's celebration of writing for the market once seemed liber ating. Voltaire, like a procession of other enlightened travellers to London at the time, admired a country where anything could be published that might have enough readers to recoup the costs. Booksellers were large-minded men compared with princes and courtiers. Some recent historians, notably John Brewer in The Pleasures of the Imagination, have described how a democratic culture - of art, music, drama and literature - was only produced because, during the 18th century, patronage gave way to commerce. Yet patronage has not always been unproductive. Not only have toadying writers and artists make admirable literature and art (Spenser, Jonson, Dryden, among poets), once upon a time toadying itself - the art of the compliment, as it was thought of - could itself be a creative achievement. To get Nesta loot you have to apply via a form on the organisation's website. Once, you would have had to write a flattering or celebratory piece of verse. More awkwardly for cultural Thatcherites, what would William Blake have done without his handful of wealthy and eccentric patrons? The weirdness and exquisiteness of his laboriously etched, hand-coloured Songs of Innocence and Experience took them as far from commercial viability as is possible. He was a writer without any kind of public. Similarly, James Joyce's experimental, laboriously hewn fiction would hardly have been possible without the obstinate support of Harriet Shaw Weaver, who was his lifelong benefactor and who was convinced of his genius when only Ezra Pound and Joyce himself seemed to share the opinion. Indeed, Joyce seems to offer Nesta hope of doing a lasting service to literature. It may have been the rich and eccentric Weaver who got A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man published, but the composition of his masterpiece, Ulysses, was supported by what amounted to state patronage. In 1915, he received a grant from the Royal Literary Fund and, soon after, a grant from the civil list. It is a nice detail that this great Irish genius had the backing of the British state. Those who would have writers kept a little lean and hungry can argue that financial support also compromises and disarms. It is sometimes thought to have strangled Wordsworth's poetry. In 1813 Wordsworth was given a large sinecure by Lord Lonsdale, the local Tory grandee, and later admirers of his early verse (and his early radicalism) like Shelley and Browning were to judge that this was the end of him. We certainly no longer read most of what he produced during his last 37 years without financial anxieties but with establishment friends. Poets, of course, have a special problem. How many have ever made money from poetry? Alexander Pope, yes. Ted Hughes, but most of it posthumously. Not many others that spring to mind. With the small fortune that he made from translating Homer's Iliad into elegant English couplets for an elegant English readership, Pope had the privilege of mocking the scramble of versifiers for the favour of potential benefactors: "Like the vile straw that's blown about the streets,/ The needy poet sticks to all he meets." fields.headline: A glorious salute
fields.standfirst: 'I don't know why he felt such antipathy towards champagne. Perhaps he disliked bubbliness of any kind, in drink or people'
fields.trailText: 'I don't know why he felt such antipathy towards champagne. Perhaps he disliked bubbliness of any kind, in drink or people'
fields.body:
Bruce Bernard, the picture editor, photographer and art connoisseur who died of cancer in March, was not without his affectations. When he knew his death was imminent, he decided that there should be no funeral, but a party to celebrate his "outstanding weaknesses". I am not sure quite what he thought they were. A fondness for drink is not a terrible thing, though it may have contributed to his rather frightening flashes of temper. "Fuck you," he kept shouting at me during one of our last dinners together when he thought I was being patronising. Actually, he had fewer weaknesses and more virtues than most people, since he was essentially kind and generous, and his anger was always short-lived. And if he did have weaknesses that I didn't know about, I don't see why we, his friends, should have been invited to celebrate them rather than his many and obvious virtues.

In any case, a Committee For The Celebration Of Bruce Bernard's Outstanding Weaknesses was established, and set about organising the party in accordance with his last wishes. These were printed on the invitation, and very idiosyncratic they were, too, reflecting both some of his unfathomable prejudices and the deep seriousness with which he approached all matters, even such relatively unimportant ones as what to eat and drink. On the drink to be served at the party, for example, Bruce wrote the following instructions, couched in strange, almost biblical language: "I would favour the Macallan Whisky though there are those who favour the flavour of peat more than I do. Beer should not be overlooked as should neither be wine. Château Musar is highly potable, and the best Champenoise should be freely available. Champagne should be provided by those who cannot do without it by paying for it themselves. This is the only drink that would not be paid for by the Committee For The Celebration Of Bruce Bernard's Outstanding Weaknesses."

I don't know why he felt such antipathy towards champagne. Perhaps he disliked bubbliness of any kind, in both drink and people. He certainly couldn't be described as bubbly himself. Indeed, despite his central amiability, he verged in manner on the lugubrious. His sense of humour was considerable, but it was of the W C Fields variety. Possibly, he shrank from the thought of being associated even after death with the kind of jollity that champagne implies. The Committee followed his instructions to the letter, except, so far as I could see, in the provision of champagne for people to purchase (though some bottles may have been hidden away somewhere). Maybe it decided, rightly, that it would be doing Bruce a favour by excluding champagne from the premises altogether, for he clearly would have begrudged both its presence and the presence of those who insisted on drinking it.

On the food, Bruce wrote: "If I were there, I would especially like cold lamb cooked to a dull pink throughout - also the best rare beef. Potato salad with the finest potatoes and dressing would seem imperative. I may well, it will be appreciated, never see another potato again, and Branston Pickle seems to me a very good thing." Bruce was, in fact, something of a gourmet, and an excellent cook himself. He made excellent Italian dishes, among other things. But he never lost his affection for the basic English food that he had presumably consumed in countless pubs throughout his life, perhaps especially in his youth when he toured England as a stagehand. Anyway, it was to this kind of food that his thoughts turned in his final days. Once again, the Committee acquitted itself with distinction. Cold meats were served in little buns, and potato salad in transparent plastic mugs.

The party was held last Saturday in large domed gallery in Bayswater. It was a boiling-hot day, and the room was crowded with Bruce's friends. I was surprised by how few of them I had met. Those that I knew were mostly journalists or Bruce's relations, but they were in a small minority. There were members of the art world there, but most of the guests seemed to be veterans of the old bohemian Soho in which Bruce spent much of his adult life. They had that special camaraderie of war veterans who know that nobody but them can understand the experiences they have shared.

A small reproduction of a Lucian Freud portrait of Bruce hung on a wall at the end of the room, a bit like the icon of a cult leader or Communist dictator. Silence was called for the playing of a Bach chaconne that went on for 10 minutes, and when it ended the heavens opened and released torrents of rain that mercifully relieved the heat. It was a glorious salute to a great man. Bruce may never see another potato, but we, for sure, will never see another him.

fields.headline: How to eat ice cream
fields.trailText: Women have a much deeper and more intense relationship with ice cream than they do with men. That's because with ice cream you get a lot more variety and a greater sense of physical satisfaction.
fields.body:
Women have a much deeper and more intense relationship with ice cream than they do with men. That's because with ice cream you get a lot more variety and a greater sense of physical satisfaction.

Deciding on what ice cream to have is one of the most complex decisions known to woman. Generally, you're either a fruity woman or a dark chocolate/caramel/coffee women.

Vanilla women don't really exist, and you're probably dealing with a man in drag. Women will try any new flavour of ice cream once. There is something mystical about the state of ice creaminess, and anything that has been elevated to that condition, be it sausages, carrots or petroleum jelly, deserves respect.

The quantity of ice cream is an easier decision; however much there is available is one portion. Cute little individual tubs are like tester paint pots - they give you a clue as to what effect you'll get once you crack open the proper, industrial-size tub. Similarly, when you're having a cone, one scoop is a sure sign that you don't really like ice cream. Those cones have been tested up to a maximum of five scoops, and three scoops is a sensible minimum for a growing woman.

One way of making sure that you're not at the mercy of ice-cream shops is to have a freezer at home that has a better and bigger selection, with 24-hour opening. Just remember to get your favourite ice cream out 10 minutes before you need it. There's nothing worse than sitting down to your favourite soap, and then having to wrestle with a power saw and blow-torch to get a decent scoop from the tub.

A really difficult decision is whether to share ice cream. This decision is often made for you by the flavour. Obviously, you can hand out vanilla left, right and centre, but if it's a holy grail flavour that you can find only in one specialist supermarket in Truro, then you should eat the entire tub under a thick towel with the phone off the hook. In the worst-case scenario, when a so-called friend asks for a spoon, give her a teaspoon and give yourself a reasonable head-start with a ladle.

Ice cream is a comfort food; when you're in front of the television with a bowl of Belgian white chocolate ice cream, you've got everything required for complete happiness. Oh, and a man to get the refills.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Gothic horror
fields.standfirst: 'As I sit on the loo, I am irritated by our violently colourful bath towels'
fields.trailText: 'As I sit on the loo, I am irritated by our violently colourful bath towels'
fields.body:
'If you really want to know, they chased me." Ex-Spouse is defending his extra-maritals. Quietly, because his aunt is in the next room. "Elaine chased me. And if my memory serves me right, about 30 years ago, even you chased me."

Below-the-belt, that. But I'm afraid it's probably true.

"Dulcie!" Aunt rushes in looking anxious. "Something's wrrrong, dearr! When I lean forward, I get this pain between my shoulder blades and it goes shooting up my throat into the rrroof of my mouth."

"It's only heartburn," comments Ex-Spouse sourly. He hates it when there's another hypochondriac in the house. "Just don't lean forward."

Heartburn. Don't lean forward, and don't look back. I chased him! It's true! I went all the way to Oxford on the bus, because they'd just closed the Oxford-Cambridge line (Marsh Gibbon-Lords Bridge). I asked him if he'd like to play Jacques in my production of As You Like It. And he's been playing Jacques ever since and sometimes I like it and sometimes I don't. It was his dark, Gothic looks that betrayed me. Emily Bronte's got a lot to answer for.

"But I want to lean forrward, dearr ! I wanted to plant a few dahlias in Dulcie's garrrden, to give it a bit of colourr! "

Make excuse and run off to bathroom, incandescent with rage. Never mind Gordon's infidelities, it's his aunt's horticultural impertinence that I can't stand. A bit of colour, indeed! Never trust a nation who invented the tartan.

I am going into my Oriental phase, you see. Even as I sit on the loo, I am irritated by our violently colourful bath towels. If only they were all a nice, quiet white. But towels last forever. You're stuck with the same old blue-and-yellow towels you bought back in 1975, just as you're stuck with the same old blue-and-yellow husband.

Open bathroom window and admire the as-yet unlandscaped back garden. It is dominated by a vast bullying opportunist rose that vaults everywhere putting down suckers. I'm hoping to sell it to Nato - along with Aunt Elspeth's latest cheese, produced from the milk of surly goats who haunt the crags of the north. To be honest, I think she's lucky to have escaped with only heartburn. I can still smell it festering in the fridge, even when I'm upstairs lying in bed with the duvet over my head.

"Mum? D'ya like my new look?" Harriet appears decked out in a range of black fetishistic clothes acquired from Camden Market. She is in the full flush of Rocky Hollywood. She adorns herself with Gothic crosses, straps, and instruments of torture. She is now a Museum Of The Inquisition. I hesitate, then deliver the required compliment.

"You don't like it!" Her eyes flare in their sooty sockets. "You're so, like, tight! An' you told me you were Gothic yourself in the 70s!"

Assure Harriet that she is the most beautiful person on the planet, and retreat to the back garden with secateurs. My plan is to get rid of everything and replace it with gravel, bamboo and railway sleepers (Lord's Bridge-Marsh Gibbon). I shall sit in the house and look out admiringly at its unchanging Zen simplicity. Don't even mention bloody dahlias. Perhaps the aunt would be satisfied with a colourful window-box under the stairs.

Ex-Spouse comes out of the house. "Can I help you?" he asks. I don't like the word gobsmacked but sometimes it is unavoidable. Hand him the secateurs and ask him to get rid of enormous thicket of rampant rose. With any luck, he will get pricked quite a lot. Quite appropriate, really.

Go back indoors and walk straight into what he came out to avoid - Aunt and Harriet having words. "I only said that a skirt that shorrrt might give the wrong kind of people the wrrrong ideas, dearr ."

"I've got a right to wear what I like! An' I don't care what people fink!" Harriet flounces off in her ready-ripped black tights. If I hadn't given in to an impulse and chased Gordon to Oxford (wearing, as I seem to recall, black from head to foot), I'd never have had Henry and Harriet. It's not surprising she's turned out a bit Gothic. If only I'd married the bloke playing Touchstone.

"Don't worry, Auntie," I sigh. "It's just a phase."

She smiles sympathetically.

"I know what'd cheer you up, Dulcie! Toasted goat's cheese and oatcakes!"

D'ya like my new look?" Harriet appears decked out in a range of black fetishistic clothes acquired from Camden Market. She is in the full flush of Rocky Hollywood. She adorns herself with Gothic crosses, straps, and instruments of torture. She is now a Museum Of The Inquisition. I hesitate, then deliver the required compliment. "You don't like it!" Her eyes flare in their sooty sockets. "You're so, like, tight! An' you told me you were Gothic yourself in the 70s!" Assure Harriet that she is the most beautiful person on the planet, and retreat to the back garden with secateurs. My plan is to get rid of everything and replace it with gravel, bamboo and railway sleepers (Lord's Bridge-Marsh Gibbon). I shall sit in the house and look out admiringly at its unchanging Zen simplicity. Don't even mention bloody dahlias. Perhaps the aunt would be satisfied with a colourful window-box under the stairs. Ex-Spouse comes out of the house. "Can I help you?" he asks. I don't like the word gobsmacked but sometimes it is unavoidable. Hand him the secateurs and ask him to get rid of enormous thicket of rampant rose. With any luck, he will get pricked quite a lot. Quite appropriate, really. Go back indoors and walk straight into what he came out to avoid - Aunt and Harriet having words. "I only said that a skirt that shorrrt might give the wrong kind of people the wrrrong ideas, dearr ." "I've got a right to wear what I like! An' I don't care what people fink!" Harriet flounces off in her ready-ripped black tights. If I hadn't given in to an impulse and chased Gordon to Oxford (wearing, as I seem to recall, black from head to foot), I'd never have had Henry and Harriet. It's not surprising she's turned out a bit Gothic. If only I'd married the bloke playing Touchstone. "Don't worry, Auntie," I sigh. "It's just a phase." She smiles sympathetically. "I know what'd cheer you up, Dulcie! Toasted goat's cheese and oatcakes!"

fields.headline: Clear winners
fields.standfirst: Last century, art glass-making became industrialised. But, says Lesley Jackson, its unique beauty survived large-scale production
fields.trailText: Last century, art glass-making became industrialised. But, says Lesley Jackson, its unique beauty survived large-scale production
fields.body:
Of all the man-made materials we encounter in our daily life, glass is the most intriguing - at once utterly prosaic yet potentially sublime. Windows, milk bottles, jam jars, lightbulbs, casseroles and computer screens. This is the everyday face of mass-produced utilitarian glass - literally colourless - and most of the time we take it completely for granted, although we look through it and handle it all the time.

But glass, with its unique qualities of luminosity and fluidity, has a creative dimension and, in the hands of a craftsman, can be blown and twisted into breathtaking forms. It can be saturated with colour - think of the John Piper windows in Coventry Cathedral - and has an unparalleled richness and intensity when infused by light.

Unlike pottery, which lends itself to solo production, most glass is made in factories, or workshops at the least. Heating a furnace to melt the raw materials is an expensive business, and it is uneconomic to do this on a small scale. Glassmaking is a naturally collaborative process, and because incandescent molten glass is so tricky to handle and has to be worked at arm's length on the end of a blowing iron, makers almost invariably work in teams. Making glass by hand requires incredible dexterity and is extremely labour-intensive, which is why such factories are often found in clusters, as at Murano or Stourbridge, so that they can draw on a pool of skills. This explains, too, why certain countries have emerged as glass-superpowers, through the strength of their collective expertise.

I remember distinctly the moment when I became a glass-head (a technical term coined by my partner to describe people addicted to glass). It was when I travelled to Scandinavia a decade ago, and went around visiting glass factories and glass museums in Sweden, Denmark and Finland. Physically, it was a real slog, because they were always in the most obscure places, but on an artistic level it was a real discovery. I could hardly believe there was so much beauty in the world. Since then, it has become my mission to draw attention to this undervalued art form, and to make it more widely known.

Most glass collectors tend to specialise in a particular factory or type of glass, and they spend their lives tracking down examples to fill gaps in their hoard. It's a bit like the Victorian obsession with butterflies and beetles, except that the hunting grounds of glass-heads are car-boot sales, auctions and antiques fairs.

While I can appreciate this fascination with minutiae, there are so many interesting factories that I would hate to feel I was missing out by honing in on one. Also, by taking a broader view, you can enjoy the flowering of glass design in certain countries at different times. Leave the dross - of which there is plenty - and just enjoy the best.

Modern glass as we know it today really began a century ago, with the emergence of the dynamic, organic, expressive Art Nouveau style. Art Nouveau embraced many different materials, but glass was at the epicentre of the new movement. Tiffany, with his lustrous, iridescent vessels, and Gallé, with his sculptural, multi-layered cameo glass, released its potential and acted as catalysts for a century of creativity to come. At this date, domestic glass was almost invariably decorated, and techniques such as cutting, engraving, etching and gilding were widely used. After the first world war, however, and particularly after the stock market crash of 1929, the market for lavish ornamental glass diminished, and during the 30s there was a much more pragmatic approach to design.

This was when Sweden emerged as a glass superpower, spearheaded by the inspirational firm of Orrefors. Orrefors recruited leading artists and sculptors - first Edward Hald and Simon Gate, then Edvin Öhrström and Vicke Lindstrand - who, as well as designing stunning art glass, created modestly priced, plain, elegant tableware for the home. The influence of Orrefors was soon felt throughout the Swedish glass industry, inspiring rival firms such as Kosta to great heights as well. Within a short time, cross- fertilisation had spread to neighbouring Denmark and Finland, paving the way for a second wave of creativity, even broader and more powerful than the first, after the second world war. In the 50s and 60s, the cool, curvilinear Scandinavian Modern style triumphed throughout Europe and the United States, and no self-respecting contemporary home was complete without its Orrefors vase, Iitala tumblers or Holmegaard bowl.

Sweden was one of the few countries whose glassworks continued operating during the second world war. When hostilities were finally over, the whole geography of the glass industry had changed forever. The most radical restructuring took place in Czechoslovakia, where the glass industry was nationalised in 1948. This resulted in hundreds of previously independent factories and decorating workshops being placed under the control of a handful of centrally administered national corporations.

Rather than stifling creativity, however, nationalisation triggered a renaissance in Czech glass design. The state-run system gave designers such as Stanislav Libensky and Pavel Hlava the freedom to develop their talents as glass artists, and they responded by creating some of the most mesmerising glass vessels and sculptures ever seen. When large-scale displays of Czech art glass were mounted at the Brussels Expo of 1958 and the Montreal Expo of 1967, they transfixed the world.

The explosion of creativity in Italy during the 50s probably had as much to do with the country's liberation from fascism as the ending of the war. Vivid colours, extravagant forms and dazzlingvirtuoso technical wizardry were the characteristics of Italian post-war glass. Inspirational firms such as Venini and Barovier & Toso, which had already established their design credentials between the wars, produced ravishing new work, year after year. The Milan Triennales and the Venice Biennales provided high-profile artistic showcases for their achievements, while the post-war boom supplied the ideal economic conditions for expanding their markets abroad. Working alongside were a host of ebullient small firms such as Archimede Seguso, Arte Vetraria Muranese and Seguso Vetri d'Arte, led by brilliant maestri, who breathed new life into traditional Venetian glassmaking techniques.

After this golden era, the tide turned. The oil crisis and the recession of the mid-70s forced many glassworks out of business, and since the 80s there have been numerous mergers within the industry, which has become increasingly bland and commercialised. At first, these takeovers were confined to factories within particular countries, but, of late, the takeovers have become international, threatening the identity of the old glass superpowers. In the Czech Republic - a region that for so long was the powerhouse of European art-glass manufacture - the old state system of production has been dismantled and its remains taken over by the private sector. What a creative century it has been, though - full of rich pickings for glass-heads of all persuasions for many years to come

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.standfirst: www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk
fields.trailText: Blair/Brown and heavypetting.com
fields.body:
Mike has run away with the embryologist, bringing Mum's Assisted Hatching programme to a sudden end, but as usual her main concern was unpredictable. 'Redwood hasn't been himself ever since that bastard left. I suppose all young dogs need a father figure . . .' she said. I trawled the net and found the Association Of Pet Behaviour Counsellors at www.apbc.org.uk. 'Aggression, destructiveness, toileting problems' headed the list of behavioural disorders that they treat; it sounded uncannily like some of my colleagues in the City. I would have bought the poor dog a fabulous collar from www.heavypetting.co.uk, but Mum is not as keen as I am on retail therapy, so I gave her a list of counsellors instead.

Having solved Redwood's crisis, I was free to concentrate on my own: what to wear for my date with Ricky. I visited the much-publicised www.Ready2Shop.com and spent ages completing the figure questionnaire that seems to be the key element. I suppose the site seized up once they realised how amazing my body is, but I found myself clicking everywhere on the screen without result; after a while, the semi-abstract graphics suggested bits of Vanessa Feltz after her diet. I left empty-handed.

As a New Labour zealot, I voted for Frank Dobson (I wonder who his other supporters were; I'm sure I know them all), but he remains an enigmatic figure. Now that the election is behind us, I decided to find out what he really thinks, so I entered 'Blair/Brown'. I was amazed to see that the first site that came up was Blair Brown Nude! Pics!, and the rest were quite similar. In www.hard-to-find-actresses.com, I found that Blair Brown had been the star of The Days And Nights Of Molly Dodd, a mid-90s TV series that bombed in the US. She should have moved here.
