fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck is caught in a generous mood
fields.body:
A novelist wrote a wonderful sentence about a young person's discovery of wine: 'She loved the shapes of bottles and of course the romantic names and the pictures of the pretty manor houses on the labels, and she loved the link with rivers and hillsides and climates and hot years, and the range of learning and experiment afforded by wine's infinite variety; but what she loved more than these was the taste - of peach and earth and honeysuckle and raspberries and spice and cedarwood and pebbles and truffles and tobacco leaf; and the happiness, the quiet ecstasy that spreads through heart and limbs and mind.'

The first reader whose card or letter identifies the novel and its author before the last day of June, I will take to lunch at Le Gavroche in London. The six runners-up, I'll send signed copies of my next book. I am feeling ecstatic today.

There is a quiet ecstasy about drinking good wine. There is a quiet ecstasy, I find, about tracking down good wine. Many people, especially those professionally employed in the wine trade, find it faintly incredible that I should discover such pleasure in supermarkets' wine shelves, but there it is, I do. (It is not an ecstasy which necessarily spreads, quietly or with brass trumpets, to other shelves but that's another story.)

Safeway now. The very name of this supermarket deadens the arteries that connect to the ecstatic channels, but it has some interesting and individual wines and this week's column is devoted solely to wines from it. Let me open with the most absurd: the one you can, until the 28th of this month, get past the checkout for £2.79. This is Caballo de Plata Bonarda/ Barbera 1999, a joyously rich red from Argentina. Of course it is simple. Of course it is unpretentious. Of course it is forward, ripe and fruity. But if you have spicy food on the table or waiting for you at the BYO Indian restaurant around the corner, then this wine is a marvellous bargain. It rates 15 points out of 20.

More tannic is Syrah Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (15 points, £3.49), which is also fantastic value, for it offers deliciously juicy richness with a dry, balanced finish. It's forward and very modern. Cabernet Sauvignon Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £3.99), meanwhile, is an entertaining double-whammy, where claret-like tannins meld with Italian-style fruit in an earthy clash of pleasure-giving, ripe, fat fruit. Leatherier, and indeed more immediately quaffable, is Domaine de Contenson Merlot Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £4.49). The welcome from the fruit is generous and warm and F - the fictitious heroine referred to above - would find it inspiring. Castillo de Molina Cabernet Sauvignon Reserva 1998 (16 points, £5.99) would not inspire familiar feelings, for it comes from Chile, which at the time of F's early drinking career did not feature on the curriculum. It is a friendly wine, and full of such subtle, complex charms that you wonder how on earth it can be related to the same cabernet sauvignon grape that grows elsewhere in the world. Only the most aromatic 157 branches of Safeway stores have this wine (call 0162 271 2926 for details).

La Cuvée Mythique Vin de Pays d'Oc 1998 (16 points, £6.49), which is coming into selected branches around now, is one of the most elegantly robust of d'Oc reds I ve clapped lips on for a couple of years. This vintage has provided compression and bite, and an impressive wine of character and style has emerged. At 70 Safeways stores is the organic Californian Fetzer Bonterra Zinfandel 1997 (16.5 points, £8.99), which is the acme of rip-roaring fruit: sunny, ripe, soft, urgent-to-please, gently quirky, pure, natural and massively quaffable. It is a superbly modern mouthful; nothing quiet about the ecstasy on offer here.

And last, there is the thunderous Fitou l'Exception 1998 (18 points, £8.99, also at 70 branches). It s a wine to touch F's soul. It is a vividly rich and warmly textured Fitou of truly exceptional character: complex, very structured, full of richness, hugely striking and bold, and deeply satisfying. It demands food to show its muscles, yet will lift, with its lushness, any mood. A stunning wine.

fields.headline: Border control
fields.standfirst: April showers? Torrents, more like. Now it's time to inspect your borders, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: April showers? Torrents, more like. Now it's time to inspect your borders, says Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
With 152.1mm of rain, we had the wettest April since records started in 1913; 1998, with 117.6mm, was the next wettest, so maybe we have a temporary trend. As a consequence, the foliage of certain daffodils was attacked by a fungal disease, turning it yellow a good month before it would naturally have died away. This means that the bulbs have not had the chance to build up their energy and will flower poorly next year. There are other similar cases. But overall, plants have loved all that moisture; ferns in particular. If we run into drought later, we shall, restrospectively, be extremely glad that the aquifer was topped up earlier on.

My borders are amazingly lush, but just to look at them raises all sorts of questions. Ours are full of forget-me-nots - myosotis - that weave among other plants and create an overall theme. When to clear them away? Left for too long, they can easily overpower smaller neighbours. However, among strong perennials, they will themselves automatically be enveloped.

Are there plants that are not doing as well as we had hoped and expected? If so, why? I have one keen gardening friend who is always so busy in her borders that the plants never have time to settle down and look unhappy, simply for that reason.

But they may be looking peaky for quite other reasons. Because they are undernourished, for instance, or overcrowded (as can so easily happen with self-sowns). In that case, we should get busy - dig them out and replant far more thinly and in improved soil - which usually means enriched with well-rotted, bulky organic goodies. Sometimes we give a fillip to spring growth with a top-dressing of inorganic fertiliser, Growmore, which works well if there is plenty of moisture about.

Much as we welcome many self-sowns, there are times when we get better results from controlled sowings. For those living in the warmer south, there is a brilliant late-summer to autumn-flowering annual, Polygonum orientale (seed from Thompson & Morgan). You could still sow that in a pot, but keep it cool, or the seeds won't germinate. Pot the seedlings individually and they will produce finer plants than those self-sown from a previous year's display. This species grows 2m tall, and is hung all over with deep-pink racemes of blossom at a time when most annuals are giving up. In even warmer climates, it can become a weed.

Each plant requires a stake, but that can be half the length of the plant's height, and therefore totally unobtrusive. There are many plants such as this, whose stems are stiff enough but which may keel over at the base if high winds coincide with wet soil. A strong, short cane, or post with a single tie, will give sufficient support. Lychnis chalcedonica is such an example; also hollyhocks and verbascums. The tall, proud oriental poppy, 'Goliath', may escape with no support, but I give a group one or two canes and a single tie of soft string twisted around each stem. By contrast, there is a double orange oriental, 'Olympia', that you see a lot in Scotland, often growing in roadside verges. It has maniacally-twisted stems lying all over the place. In the context, this doesn't matter.

In our borders, there are some plants that we know will need support sooner or later. If we wait till the plant has already collapsed, things will never be the same again. Rescue operations always look wretched, with trussed-up bundles of re-erected stems.

That said, I must admit that visible staking, or other support, can rather spoil the look of an otherwise beautiful plant, so I like to leave the job until as late as I dare. As with delphiniums, for instance. Their bright-green, deeply-cut foliage is a joy in itself. Massive canes, or posts, placed around them spoil the scene. So we quite often delay the job until they are already 1.5m high. The same with Clematis recta 'Purpurea'. It will eventually need supporting with brushwood to a height of 2m.

Some gardeners (always male) actually enjoy the sight of stakes; they are making a statement: "There's a gardener in control here, and no messing", is the message. If thick new canes appear half-a-metre above their display of standard fuchsias, so much the better. I hate that, believing that our necessary interference should be as unobtrusive as possible. The picture has been artificially created, it is true, but that is no excuse for exposing the mechanics, any more than in a flower arrangement.

So, if you are using bamboo canes and they have to be partially visible for a few weeks, let them be weathered ones that lost their pale colouring and gloss while supporting tomatoes or something with no artistic pretensions.

Metal supports should be unobtrusively dark. The type of metal support makes a difference, too. Link stakes can be pushed in exactly where needed, allowing more flexibility than hoops. When using brushwood around thin-stemmed colonies, you must anticipate your plants' eventual height with long enough pieces - but not weeks before any support is necessary

fields.bodyText: With 152.1mm of rain, we had the wettest April since records started in 1913; 1998, with 117.6mm, was the next wettest, so maybe we have a temporary trend. As a consequence, the foliage of certain daffodils was attacked by a fungal disease, turning it yellow a good month before it would naturally have died away. This means that the bulbs have not had the chance to build up their energy and will flower poorly next year. There are other similar cases. But overall, plants have loved all that moisture; ferns in particular. If we run into drought later, we shall, restrospectively, be extremely glad that the aquifer was topped up earlier on. My borders are amazingly lush, but just to look at them raises all sorts of questions. Ours are full of forget-me-nots - myosotis - that weave among other plants and create an overall theme. When to clear them away? Left for too long, they can easily overpower smaller neighbours. However, among strong perennials, they will themselves automatically be enveloped. Are there plants that are not doing as well as we had hoped and expected? If so, why? I have one keen gardening friend who is always so busy in her borders that the plants never have time to settle down and look unhappy, simply for that reason. But they may be looking peaky for quite other reasons. Because they are undernourished, for instance, or overcrowded (as can so easily happen with self-sowns). In that case, we should get busy - dig them out and replant far more thinly and in improved soil - which usually means enriched with well-rotted, bulky organic goodies. Sometimes we give a fillip to spring growth with a top-dressing of inorganic fertiliser, Growmore, which works well if there is plenty of moisture about. fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.trailText: Keith Allen
fields.body:
Keith Allen, 46, was born in Wales. He won a scholarship to public school, but ended up in borstal. A stand-up comedian who moved into acting, he has appeared in BBC1's Martin Chuzzlewit and the movies Trainspotting and Shallow Grave. Under the name Fat Les 2000, he has recorded a version of the hymn Jerusalem with Damien Hirst and Blur's Alex James. It will be England's official song for the European Football Championships. He has been married twice and has five children.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
My funeral with loved ones saying the nicest things about me.

What is your greatest fear?
Being thought of as an egomaniac.

With which historical figure do you most identify ?
Isambard Kingdom Brunel - an engineering genius who was also an aesthete.

Which living person do you most admire?
Damien Hirst - he's everything I suspected an artist to be.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Skidmarks on my cricket whites.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Farting silently just before leaving a crowded lift.

What is your favourite smell?
See previous answer.

What is your favourite word?
Twat.

What makes you depressed?
Not having ideas.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Unnecessary aggression.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Hypocrisy.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
Occasionally.

Do you believe in monogamy?
No.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
No. They're great fun to look at.

How do you relax?
I write short stories for children.

How often do you have sex?
Not enough.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
The devaluation of the pound.

What would your motto be?
Always embellish.

What keeps you awake at night?
Images of Kevin Keegan's pert bottom in tight-fitting shorts.

How would you like to die?
Quietly, after a long, painless illness.

How would you like to be remembered?
The man who rendered Max Bygraves speechless.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Do not rejoice till it's done.

fields.headline: Time for beds
fields.standfirst: Paul Williams shuns plant fashion and reads books about soil for fun - which is why, says Celia Woolfrey, he's one of the most exciting gardeners around.
fields.trailText: Paul Williams shuns plant fashion and reads books about soil for fun - which is why, says Celia Woolfrey, he's one of the most exciting gardeners around.
fields.body:
If gardener and writer Paul Williams was a plant, he'd be a self-seeded exotic - rare and rooted in an unlikely place in some hidden part of the garden, upstaged by the showier, more familiar plants clambering over each other closer to the house.

Williams is now considered one of the most innovative gardeners around, who built his reputation at Bourton House, in Gloucestershire, where he was head gardener for 15 years. He doesn't own a television set, let alone want to appear on it, which no doubt accounts for the low public profile. But though he's a plantsman more than a writer (he says), he has an easy style in the books he's written.

Born and bred in Staffordshire, Williams's passion for plants began on a hitchhiking jaunt to the Pyrenees, where he became interested in wild flowers. After a stint cutting grass for the council, where he met his wife, Barbara, his career got off to a start of sorts: "The head gardener at the local estate was retiring so I put in for the job and got it," he recalls. "It was a crap job, crap house - it leaked and everything - but I went to Edgbaston College down the road on day-release. There were two lecturers there who were just fabulous guys. It's the plants that turn you on at the end of the day, and these two very much had an interest in plants."

From there, he went on to do a landscape technology course at Pershore Agricultural College, including a sandwich year at Bourton House, which in turn led to his long involvement as head gardener. At Bourton, Williams had a free hand and the garden he created put the place on the map, attracting thousands of visitors each year. However, relations with the owners soured and, recently, Williams quit, leaving behind the plant collection he had built from scratch.

He and Barbara still live just a few miles away in Blockley, with their back garden packed with plants, many of which appear in his book, Creative Containers (Conran Octopus). Williams's own containers include finds from the local scrapyard: a heat exchanger wrapped in wire, planted up with spiky grass, and a metal ball-cock with holes cut into it, through which the green rosettes of sempervivums peek.

The book is a good example of Williams's "try anything" approach. No plants are banned because they are either too fashionable or too common: petunias are suddenly covetable when they are a soft yellow, called 'Brass Band' and are planted up in old olive-oil containers. Hanging baskets shake off their naff image and instead look stylish and low-key when they're woven from vine prunings and transformed into balls of ivy hanging from the branch of a tree.

Despite thinking of himself as a gardener rather than writer, Williams has just produced his third book, Garden Colour Palette. In this, the reader can mix and match different colour schemes via a kind of identikit format. And, if you're still not sure, there's also advice on what plants go well together.

What really excites him at the moment? "I'm still on a big plant kick, you know, giant foliage and jungly stuff: the big inulas, and the tropical stuff, the cannas. Herbaceous aralias. If you want to grow something big and jungly, grow them. Datisca cannabina shoots up six or seven feet and is hung with little tassles of green flowers."

He loves growth - whether it is fern croziers unfurling or ornamental rhubarb leaves bursting out of the ground - and talks about being "fired up" about the mechanics of plants. His sons don't share this enthusiasm, calling him the garden gnome, while Barbara is kinder - gently poking fun at his fondness for reading books about botany or soil in bed, and his frequent outbursts along the lines of, "Did you know, on the underside of an apple leaf in one square centimetre, there are 36,000 stomata. Isn't that amazing?"

"Well, it is amazing," says Paul, moving on to an explanation of how, in summer, a tree can get through 250 gallons of water a day: "Water's being sucked through the cells from the tip of the root to the top of the tree, under pressures of up to 460 pounds per square inch. That's a whole lot of suction."

Though no longer at Bourton, Williams still has plenty of opportunity to indulge his passion: he is currently working on three gardens. And, when not writing in his free time, he will be answering questions on the new website, dig-it.co.uk. "I was going to put an advert in: 'Rich patron wanted,"' he jokes. "I want someone who's got a lot of money and for me to run their glasshouse, buy the plants and do what I want to do."

 Garden Colour Palette, by Paul Williams, is published by Conran Octopus, priced £17.99. To order a copy for £14.99 (plus 99p UK p&p), phone 0800 316 6102, or send a UK cheque, payable to The Guardian CultureShop, to 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Garlic: the raw facts, part 2
fields.trailText: Garlic: the raw facts, part 2
fields.body:
The subject
Cooking (or not cooking) with Allium sativum .

The basics
Peel the cloves -unless you're making a rustic, homey braise, in which case they can just be stripped of the papery husks. Chop or slice them in preference to crushing. If you're going to use the stuff raw, make sure it's ultra-fresh. Use in immoderation, but use in accordance with the Immutable Rule Of Garlic Happiness - repeat after me: Deeply browned garlic is unpleasantly bitter and will damage the finished dish . That means cooking it (1) briefly, or (2) till the cows come home. 'Briefly' means a few seconds in hot oil before other ingredients go in to lower the temperature in the pan. 'The cows come home' means when the precious cloves are heated gently in any cooking medium containing a lot of water. That way, the temperature never rises far above 100C and the garlic never goes mahogany-like.

The details
In the Knowledge's personal experience, long-cooked garlic has minimally disastrous consequences for the breath of the person eating it. This is the resident excuse for using so much of the stuff in any braised, boiled and soupy concoctions. With the raw and the briefly cooked, of course, you're in dragon-breath territory. Foods that love the bountiful bulb? Anything short of lemon-meringue pie. The Knowledge's favourite lovey-doveys: extra-virgin olive oil, lemon, fresh coriander, flat-leaf parsley, butter, chicken (not necessarily in the same dish). The Knowledge's Oscar nominations for All-Time Great Garlic Dishes: homemade pesto, chicken with 40 cloves of garlic, escargots à la bourguignon. The Knowledge's next meal: Anti-Vampire Garlic-Pesto Bread (in Marlena Spieler's Feeding Friends, Piatkus, £9.99).

Where to buy
A modestly successful breath-freshener called BreathAsure: most chemists.

The easy way out
Garlic powder, chopped garlic in jars or tubes, garlic salt. And if you use any of them, you're a fool.

fields.headline: More bounce to the ounce
fields.standfirst: Gelatine's reputation has been on wobbly ground of late, says Jeremy Lee. Understandably so. But used with care, it can produce quite amazing results
fields.trailText: Gelatine's reputation has been on wobbly ground of late, says Jeremy Lee. Understandably so. But used with care, it can produce quite amazing results
fields.body:
'I just can't believe that you use it." "It's only gelatine, not poison." "Well, it is an unutterably foul substance that should be banned."

"That's altogether too harsh."

Harsh, indeed - though quite understandable when memory recalls some of the more garish images in the pantheon of food photography: tinned fruit suspended in a jewel-green jelly, and other such frightful horrors. The low cost and easy preparation of gelatine-based dishes secured its place in the domestic kitchen of yesteryear: sugar-soaked fruit aside, it was used to glaze many a boiled egg canapé and to dress up a wild salmon like a strumpet in an attempt to jolly along the buffet from hell. There must have been little thought as to how these dishes actually tasted, however, and most people's memories of such food are on a par with their distressed memories of school dinners - sheer torture.

But the realisation that these bouncing jellies were made by human hands - and, worse, that the unholy terrors of too many a sideboard were intended to look and taste like that - gives ample cause for thought. The simple truth is that cooks over-boinged their jellied food to make the serving of it all the easier, without regard as to whether it was edible or not.

However, it need not be so, for gelatine is also an essential ingredient in those wonderful savoury mousses that make such excellent use of the leftovers of ham or poached fish. When spread upon good bread, these make a simple and delicious lunch; and, when eaten thus, you realise that food made with gelatine need not bounce like Tigger.

Similarly, a jelly made from poached calves' feet, say, lightly flavoured with some fresh tarragon leaves, makes a delightful accompaniment to a terrine or poached chicken, the chicken cooked slowly in the same pot as the veal. Even better, there really is very little work involved in the preparation, although your judgment of the cooking must be good, and the cooking times adhered to with rigour. The dividends are well worth the extra effort. The same calves' feet jelly with a poached egg set inside, meanwhile, will beget the justly-famed dish of lore, oeuf en gelée . Alternatively, use the gelatine to set some roughly-chopped ham, an armful of fresh parsley and a little garlic, and you'll have created the equally lauded jambon persillé .

None of which makes up for the fact that gelatine, be it leaf or powder, is a most unappealing substance, being manufactured by boiling up bits and bobs of dead animals. But there are some entirely natural gelling agents out there. At the top end of the market, there is isinglass, made from the swim bladders of sturgeon, but - like the roe of that same fish - it is a very expensive ingredient indeed. Gelatine also hails from cod, carp and ling, among other fish, though the quality is not so fine as isinglass. The very finest natural gelatine, so legend has it, can set a hundred times its weight in liquid, after all.

There is also natural gelatine to be found in seaweed, which is rather less rarified. In Japan, there is agar-agar, but this is a habitué of laboratories rather than kitchens, as it does not melt at blood temperature, which is a vital requirement if it is to be put to culinary use. For the latter practice, you need to forage along the rocky coastlines of Ireland, the Hebrides and Brittany for carrageen (also known as pearl moss), from which gelatine is also procured - take, for example, the curious and wonderful recipe for carrageen pudding in Fergus Henderson's estimable Nose To Tail Eating.

So, if you, too, cannot find a redeeming quality in gelatine, and if its absence from your larder does not make the heart grow fonder, remember those endearing little mousses and the fact that a properly made jelly can be quite irresistible.

All recipes serve six.

Cucumber mousse

I particularly like this served alongside a baked fish that has been left to cool down, some boiled new potatoes and a little mustard mixed with sugar, oil, vinegar and dill. With an elegant bottle of chilled white wine, this makes a very pleasant repast indeed.

1 medium-sized cucumber

25g sea salt

3 tbsp top-notch white-wine vinegar

3 gelatine leaves

6 spring onions

1 small bunch chives

300ml good double cream

1 tbsp chopped parsley

500g curd cheese

A fully-charged pepper mill

Peel the cucumber, cut it in half lengthways, remove the seeds and chop into a small dice. Mix the salt and vinegar in a large bowl, and stir in the cucumber. Tip into a colander, set a plate atop to compress, and leave to drip for an hour or so. Put the cucumber into a linen cloth and squeeze dry.

Place the leaves of gelatine in a bowl of cold water to soften. Trim, clean and finely slice the spring onions and chives, and place in a bowl with the chopped parsley. Put the cheese in a bowl and break it up, then stir in the cream.

Remove the gelatine from the water and squeeze lightly. Put it in a small saucepan with any residual water and warm over a low heat until it becomes liquid, taking care that it does not boil. Stir the gelatine into the cream and cheese, then add the cucumber, chopped herbs and plenty of pepper. Taste to check if more vinegar or salt is required, then tip into a lightly-oiled bowl. Place in the fridge and leave overnight.

Ham mousse

A very good way to use up the remains of a ham or a hock.

340g cooked lean ham

3 gelatine leaves

140ml hot water

2 egg whites

290ml double cream

A fully-charged pepper mill

In a bowl, place the gelatine in the hot water and set this over a pan of simmering hot water. When the gelatine has fully dissolved, put it to one side to cool. Chop the ham very finely, and pound it to a paste - this may be done in a food processor, although the end-result is not quite as good as that prepared by hand.

Pour the cooled gelatine through a fine sieve, and mix into the ham paste. Lightly whip the cream until it just holds a shape, then fold into the ham mix. Add a generous grind of pepper, and stir. Cover the bowl, and place in the fridge for half-an-hour or so.

Whip the egg whites into stiff peaks, fold these into the mixture, then decant the lot into a handsome serving bowl. Chill for a few hours before serving.

Blueberry jelly

Blueberry and vanilla is a match made in heaven.

4 gelatine leaves

2 vanilla pods

500g blueberries

200ml light dessert wine

220g caster sugar

Put the gelatine into plenty of cold water for five to 10 minutes, until completely softened. Split the vanilla pods lengthways, and scrape out the seeds.

Put the blueberries, vanilla seeds and pods, wine and sugar into a heavy-bottomed pot. Over a gentle heat, bring the pot to a simmer and cook for five to 10 minutes. Push the blueberry mixture through a fine-mesh sieve or mouli.

Squeeze the gelatine leaves, and put them in a small pan with a few tablespoons of the blueberry purée. Warm gently until the leaves are fully melted, then add to the blueberry mix and stir to incorporate. Wet a mould (or moulds), tip off any excess water, then pour in the liquid jelly and refrigerate overnight.

Chocolate bavarois

Have everything to hand when putting together a Bavarois, for the moment the components are assembled the mixture will start to stiffen almost at once.

3 gelatine leaves

5 very fresh eggs

160g caster sugar

2 tsp cornflour

430ml milk

3oz dark, bitter chocolate

140ml strong coffee

1 tbsp caster sugar

140ml double cream

2 tbsp dark rum

2 tsp vanilla extract

Put the gelatine in plenty of cold water to soften. Separate the eggs, put the whites in a bowl and pop them in the fridge. Mix together the egg yolks and sugar, then stir in the cornflour. Put the milk and chocolate in a pan, and place over a medium heat. Squeeze the excess water from the gelatine, and put in a separate pan, along with the coffee. When the chocolate has fully melted into the milk and the mixture is quite smooth, pour it over the egg-yolk mix, stirring all the while. Tip the resulting chocolate custard back in the pan, place over a low heat and, stirring constantly, cook until thickened. Warm the coffee and gelatine until completely liquid, then stir it into the chocolate custard.

Beat the egg whites until they develop soft peaks, then add a spoonful of caster sugar and beat again until a glossy sheen is attained. Fold the whites into the hot chocolate mix, and set aside to cool. Carefully fold the mixture from time to time, to prevent it from splitting. Refrigerate if necessary, but do not allow to set. Rinse the mould (or moulds) with cold water and drain off any excess. Beat the double cream until lightly whipped and just holding a shape. Tip the rum and vanilla into the chocolate mix, fold in the cream, then decant into the mould. Place in the fridge and leave overnight to set.

To serve, dip the mould into a bowl of very hot water for just a few seconds, then run a hot thin knife around the edge of the Bavarois and invert on to a chilled plate. This is very good with ginger-flavoured custard

 Jeremy Lee is chef at the Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.
fields.bodyText: 'I just can't believe that you use it." "It's only gelatine, not poison." "Well, it is an unutterably foul substance that should be banned." "That's altogether too harsh." Harsh, indeed - though quite understandable when memory recalls some of the more garish images in the pantheon of food photography: tinned fruit suspended in a jewel-green jelly, and other such frightful horrors. The low cost and easy preparation of gelatine-based dishes secured its place in the domestic kitchen of yesteryear: sugar-soaked fruit aside, it was used to glaze many a boiled egg canapé and to dress up a wild salmon like a strumpet in an attempt to jolly along the buffet from hell. There must have been little thought as to how these dishes actually tasted, however, and most people's memories of such food are on a par with their distressed memories of school dinners - sheer torture. But the realisation that these bouncing jellies were made by human hands - and, worse, that the unholy terrors of too many a sideboard were intended to look and taste like that - gives ample cause for thought. The simple truth is that cooks over-boinged their jellied food to make the serving of it all the easier, without regard as to whether it was edible or not. However, it need not be so, for gelatine is also an essential ingredient in those wonderful savoury mousses that make such excellent use of the leftovers of ham or poached fish. When spread upon good bread, these make a simple and delicious lunch; and, when eaten thus, you realise that food made with gelatine need not bounce like Tigger. Similarly, a jelly made from poached calves' feet, say, lightly flavoured with some fresh tarragon leaves, makes a delightful accompaniment to a terrine or poached chicken, the chicken cooked slowly in the same pot as the veal. Even better, there really is very little work involved in the preparation, although your judgment of the cooking must be good, and the cooking times adhered to with rigour. The dividends are well worth the extra effort. The same calves' feet jelly with a poached egg set inside, meanwhile, will beget the justly-famed dish of lore, oeuf en gelée . Alternatively, use the gelatine to set some roughly-chopped ham, an armful of fresh parsley and a little garlic, and you'll have created the equally lauded jambon persillé . None of which makes up for the fact that gelatine, be it leaf or powder, is a most unappealing substance, being manufactured by boiling up bits and bobs of dead animals. But there are some entirely natural gelling agents out there. At the top end of the market, there is isinglass, made from the swim bladders of sturgeon, but - like the roe of that same fish - it is a very expensive ingredient indeed. Gelatine also hails from cod, carp and ling, among other fish, though the quality is not so fine as isinglass. The very finest natural gelatine, so legend has it, can set a hundred times its weight in liquid, after all. There is also natural gelatine to be found in seaweed, which is rather less rarified. In Japan, there is agar-agar, but this is a habitué of laboratories rather than kitchens, as it does not melt at blood temperature, which is a vital requirement if it is to be put to culinary use. For the latter practice, you need to forage along the rocky coastlines of Ireland, the Hebrides and Brittany for carrageen (also known as pearl moss), from which gelatine is also procured - take, for example, the curious and wonderful recipe for carrageen pudding in Fergus Henderson's estimable Nose To Tail Eating. So, if you, too, cannot find a redeeming quality in gelatine, and if its absence from your larder does not make the heart grow fonder, remember those endearing little mousses and the fact that a properly made jelly can be quite irresistible. All recipes serve six. Cucumber mousse I particularly like this served alongside a baked fish that has been left to cool down, some boiled new potatoes and a little mustard mixed with sugar, oil, vinegar and dill. With an elegant bottle of chilled white wine, this makes a very pleasant repast indeed. 1 medium-sized cucumber 25g sea salt 3 tbsp top-notch white-wine vinegar 3 gelatine leaves 6 spring onions 1 small bunch chives 300ml good double cream 1 tbsp chopped parsley 500g curd cheese A fully-charged pepper mill Peel the cucumber, cut it in half lengthways, remove the seeds and chop into a small dice. Mix the salt and vinegar in a large bowl, and stir in the cucumber. Tip into a colander, set a plate atop to compress, and leave to drip for an hour or so. Put the cucumber into a linen cloth and squeeze dry. Place the leaves of gelatine in a bowl of cold water to soften. Trim, clean and finely slice the spring onions and chives, and place in a bowl with the chopped parsley. Put the cheese in a bowl and break it up, then stir in the cream. Remove the gelatine from the water and squeeze lightly. Put it in a small saucepan with any residual water and warm over a low heat until it becomes liquid, taking care that it does not boil. Stir the gelatine into the cream and cheese, then add the cucumber, chopped herbs and plenty of pepper. Taste to check if more vinegar or salt is required, then tip into a lightly-oiled bowl. Place in the fridge and leave overnight. When the gelatine has fully dissolved, put it to one side to cool. Chop the ham very finely, and pound it to a paste - this may be done in a food processor, although the end-result is not quite as good as that prepared by hand. Pour the cooled gelatine through a fine sieve, and mix into the ham paste. Lightly whip the cream until it just holds a shape, then fold into the ham mix. Add a generous grind of pepper, and stir. Cover the bowl, and place in the fridge for half-an-hour or so. Whip the egg whites into stiff peaks, fold these into the mixture, then decant the lot into a handsome serving bowl. Chill for a few hours before serving. Split the vanilla pods lengthways, and scrape out the seeds. Put the blueberries, vanilla seeds and pods, wine and sugar into a heavy-bottomed pot. Over a gentle heat, bring the pot to a simmer and cook for five to 10 minutes. Push the blueberry mixture through a fine-mesh sieve or mouli. Squeeze the gelatine leaves, and put them in a small pan with a few tablespoons of the blueberry purée. Warm gently until the leaves are fully melted, then add to the blueberry mix and stir to incorporate. Wet a mould (or moulds), tip off any excess water, then pour in the liquid jelly and refrigerate overnight. Warm the coffee and gelatine until completely liquid, then stir it into the chocolate custard. Fold the whites into the hot chocolate mix, and set aside to cool. Carefully fold the mixture from time to time, to prevent it from splitting. Refrigerate if necessary, but do not allow to set. fields.headline: Food
fields.standfirst: Next time you buy prawns, check the origin, warns Joanna Blythman. People's lives depend on it
fields.trailText: Next time you buy prawns, check the origin, warns Joanna Blythman. People's lives depend on it
fields.body:
Don't you just love tropical prawns? Okay, they're not a patch on Scottish langoustine or Morecambe Bay shrimp, but they're still better than those pink curls from the North Atlantic that we've had to make do with for decades. You can get hold of them easily, too - big, chunky tiger prawns are now flown in from exotic Thailand, India and Bangladesh. Rejoice: at last a regular source of prawns fit for tempura, say, or for a coconutty Goan curry.

Too good to be true? Too right. This month, we will be asked by whistleblowers from those same countries to say no to tropical prawns. One Indian campaigner puts it this way: "I say that those who eat shrimp - and only the rich people from industrialised countries do - are eating, at the same time, the blood, sweat and livelihood of the poor people of the Third World."

Traditionally, tropical prawn-farming was a cottage industry - a small, sustainable harvest that alternated with the rice paddies in coastal areas that are rich in mangrove and coral. Wild prawns were caught by local fisheries and consumed by local people. But by the 80s, as industrial catches declined, those countries were encouraged, with financial aid from the World Bank and the UN's Food And Agriculture Organisation, to set up prawn farms as a way of attracting foreign currency. The legacy of this misguided advice has been devastating. In Thailand, the world's leading producer, disease associated with prawn "ponds" has been so severe that 70% now lie abandoned. Thailand's mangrove forest, a vital part of the tropical ecosystem, has been halved, and experts attribute 60% of that damage to prawn farming.

Mangrove is, in fact, unsuitable for prawn farming because it is too acid, but mangrove is inexpensive land, so lime is extracted from coral reefs and added to the water to adjust the acid balance. It's a double whammy: first, the mangroves go, then the reefs. And, all the while, salt-water leaks from the farms on to nearby agricultural land, thereby ruining it for food production. In an attempt to control the disease-prone mass in the prawn "ponds", pesticides, disinfectants, feed additives and chlorine become standard kit. But it's a futile exercise, it seems, as numerous viral diseases have swept through many Asian farms. There is evidence, too, of the widespread excessive use of antibiotics. And, far from taking pressure off the wild stocks, farmed prawns gobble them up voraciously and wastefully. They convert only 17% of what they are fed into consumable meat, up to 50% of which is derived from species of wild-caught fish, which are already in short supply.

Of course, not all the tropical prawns we eat are farmed. Some are wild, most of them trawled from the sea bed along with a hefty "by-catch" of non-target species, which is the stuff of life for both wild fish and local fisheries. As a result, to get to the ever-dwindling prawn stocks on the sea bed, trawlers in South-east Asia are now "clearing ground" by running chains along the sea bed to remove such "obstructions" as coral.

This madness will continue unless consumers in affluent countries reject prawns from these areas. The Swedish Society For Nature Conservation has spearheaded an awareness campaign, asking consumers to score them off their shopping list until there is some internationally audited supply of sustainably fished prawn. "The demand for tropical shrimp has been largely created by availability and recipes in glossy magazines," says Tove Zetterstrom, author of the society's forthcoming report. "Most people were not aware how they are produced. Wild and farmed supply cannot keep up with this artificially created demand."

And there is an alternative: one ironic side-effect of the overfishing in the North Sea of prawn-predator species such as cod is that pink prawn stocks have now stabilised. The region has stricter codes of conduct, too, both for the maximum allowable "by-catch" and the fishing methods used. As a result, says Zetterstrom, though "the North Atlantic fisheries for cold water prawns do have environmental impacts, they are still a better alternative than tropical ones".

So, does that mean it's back to soggy pink curls? Not necessarily. As Zetterstrom points out, the Swedes get their native prawns to the fishmonger's slab raw, unfrozen and, perish the thought, tasting of prawn. There's no reason why we can't do the same, as long as we tell our fish importers that we want it that way

 Industrial Shrimp Action Network, 020-7281 4561.

fields.headline: Race to the right
fields.standfirst: Are the current rhetoric about 'bogus asylum seekers' and the sustained sequence of racial attacks creating a climate where the far right can flourish? Poised to reap any benefit is a smooth-talking father-of-four living in the Welsh countryside. He is Nick Griffin, leader of the British National Party, and he's busy learning tricks from Jörg Haider's style of fascism
fields.trailText: Are the current rhetoric about 'bogus asylum seekers' and the sustained sequence of racial attacks creating a climate where the far right can flourish? Poised to reap any benefit is a smooth-talking father-of-four living in the Welsh countryside. He is Nick Griffin, leader of the British National Party, and he's busy learning tricks from Jörg Haider's style of fascism
fields.body:
Race is once more on the agenda in British politics, and at least one party on the far right is confidently hoping to capitalise on it. From his fastness in the Welsh hills, Nick Griffin, elected head of the British National Party (BNP) last autumn, is plotting to revive the fortunes of the most reviled party in Britain with a new strategy that he hopes will suit the temper of the times.

Gone are the swastikas, the shaved heads, the marches with Union Jacks fluttering. Instead, there is the stream of innocuous-sounding front organisations, the South West Family Defence Organisation, the British Countryman, Save Our Sterling, promoted in smooth fireside chats over the internet. Griffin wants to cast off the Nazi-worshipping past of his predecessors, he wants to remould the riff-raff, the social misfits, the racists, the anti-Semites, the skinheads, street thugs and the thousand-odd lost souls who make up the BNP's active ranks, and turn them, and the party, into a viable political machine. He thinks he can reverse decades of defeat for the far right, a political movement whose electoral fortunes generally run a poor second to the Monster Raving Loony Party. He believes he can make fascism and racial hatred acceptable around the (white) British dinner table by couching his politics in the language of moderation.

"People of my nationalist political persuasion," he says, "have to gain political power in the whole or we gain nothing, and the whole lot, British identity, just vanishes. If we are elected, we will effect a revolution, not bombs, but total change." You would expect him to talk like that, and a few months ago it would have been easy to dismiss Griffin as a political irrelevance. The British far right has, for the moment, shattered itself into a thousand antagonistic pieces. At a recent "demonstration" against refugees in Margate, the rump of the old National Front could barely muster three minibus-loads of skinheads to march around the town abusing asylum seekers. Even the biggest far-right fragment, Griffin's BNP, is tiny, with fewer than 1,500 members. And Britain seemed, especially under New Labour, immune from the deep-set continental xenophobia that has given rise to Jörg Haider's Freedom Party in Austria.

But, the climate may be changing. In the past year, Britain has seen a staggering, unprecedented rise in racial attacks, from the April 1999 Brixton and Brick Lane bombings, to the uncovering of alleged racial murders in Telford, to assaults in Leeds and the stabbing of the white boyfriend of black British athlete, Ashia Hansen, and threats to three other black Olympic sportsmen. Last week, it was reported that TV star Ali G had received death threats, apparently from the neo-Nazi group Combat 18. Many other racial incidents remain unreported, while black members of the public, such as Duwayne Brooks, the friend of Stephen Lawrence, complain of continued and increased police harassment - in spite of the Macpherson report.

The whole political mood music around race has, as black trades union leader Bill Morris noted, once more become hostile, intemperate and vengeful. A few Romanian beggars on the London Underground is officially a national crisis. "These people have come here with the intention of exploiting the system and exploiting their children. It's a vile thing to do," spat out New Labour's Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, in March, after private Labour focus-group polling revealed the asylum issue to be an electoral worry.

The Conservative leader William Hague is now blaming the government for the "racketeers" who are creating "a massive influx of bogus asylum seekers". His deputy, Ann Widdecombe, has proposed detention - summary imprisonment - of all asylum seekers. The issue was the highlight of the Tories' May 4 local government election manifesto. To their shame, New Labour's answer was to crank up the rhetoric and promise more "crackdowns", arrests, £10,000 bonds for "dodgy" Indian subcontinent visitors, new detention centres, vouchers-for-food, more "dispersals", fewer "disproportionate burdens", and the faster processing of applicants.

Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, has now announced plans to detain in secure accommodation asylum seekers whose applications have been refused. The "crisis" is directly attributed to the "flood" of asylum seekers now "invading" Britain. Hyped up by right-wing populist newspapers, "refugee" has practically become synonymous with "benefit abuser/beggar". But the cold reality is that the asylum seeker "epidemic" is largely the political creation of tabloid editorials, William Hague's ambitions and Downing Street's electoral worries.

In 1996, under the Tories, applications for asylum were 29,000. In 1997, the figure rose to 33,000, in 1998 to 46,000 and in 1999 to 71,000. This is a large increase, but still statistically insignificant given Britain's population of 60 million. If you average the figures over the past four years - 50,000 asylum seeker applications per annum - the British Home Office, under its international obligations, is being asked, in population terms, to consider one refugee case for every 12,000 UK citizens. Given that many applications will be rejected, the true figure for successful applicants is probably 1 per 25,000 native head of population. New Labour's ministers may, in their harsh, tabloid-pleasing rhetoric, be fighting back a "flood", but the asylum seekers "crisis" is actually a trickle.

"By heralding measure after measure to stop people entering Britain, the Home Office has given life to racists," says Bill Morris. In the elections for the London Mayor on May 4, the British National Party candidate polled 78,000 first and second preference votes - that is 10% of Ken Livingstone's vote. "The asylum seeker issue has been great for us," says Nick Griffin. "We have had phenomenal growth in membership. It's been quite fun to watch government ministers and the Tories play the race card in far cruder terms than we would ever use, but pretend not to. This issue legitimises us."

Griffin is not alone in believing that the racist tide is turning his way. "Race, through the asylum seeker issue, is going to be a big issue in the next election," says Claire Dissington, of the Anti-Nazi League. "If racism is legitimised through the mainstream parties, then the far right can only benefit. Already there has been an increase in attacks. If it continues, we are going to end up with a dead refugee."

Britain's would-be fascist leader is, of course, enthralled at the potential political opportunities of increased racial tension. Griffin, who has devoted his adult life to the fascist cause, wants to use a new wave of racial strife to re-unite those far-right fragments. He wants to make the BNP better so he can make things worse. Griffin is worth knowing about because he is the enemy of democratic and human rights.

Griffin came down from the hills to meet me in the little town of Welshpool, in mid-Wales, after dropping his four children at school. He was dressed in a neat black polo neck, a well-tailored collarless jacket and a grey wool overcoat. He was polite, friendly and clever enough to have looked me up on the internet and therefore be able to quote my own articles back at me. He has the air of being a cross between a hearty country estate agent and an eager but slightly clumsy novice Conservative candidate. He might live in Wales, but he speaks with an earnest English Home Counties accent. He raises pigs and chickens on his smallholding in the hills and there was dirt under his fingernails, but he is obviously far more at home behind a keyboard than a tractor.

Griffin's greatest political asset to the BNP is his smoothness, his seeming reasonableness. He is not some Ku-Klux Klan American-style Nazi frothing at the mouth. Instead, Griffin articulates blatantly racist policy as if enunciating the latest New Labour tweak to the mainstream consensus. "If the liberals would just let us have one island, one place, where we could go and do what we want to do by ourselves, most white nationalists would be quite happy to have it. But the liberal mind-set is utterly totalitarian. There is not one village, one farmhouse, if you have a TV, where I can hold my views and put them across to my children," says Griffin, whose Welsh farmhouse is resolutely television-free.

His language is peppered with terms such as "half-caste", "our British identity" and the ubiquitous "they", as in "they do not really adapt well to our schools". He makes great play of his changes to what even he admits were the old-style really crude racist policies of the BNP. Officially, the party now has a policy of voluntary repatriation for non-whites. "We would obviously give preference, in terms of homeward-bound grants, to couples with young families, couples with children aged 14 and younger. If they are here any longer then they are probably going to stay. We want them [black Britons] to go, and the number who go will be determined by how good it is over there and whether their children have a better life," he says.

Unofficially, Griffin is trying to move the party towards what he thinks everyone else will see as the acceptable face of Haider's Euro-fascism. "Haider is a straw in the wind for us, which shows what a nationalist party can do by moderating its language and thus appealing to ordinary people."

As part of that "strategy of moderation", Griffin has created front organisations, including The Countryman and Save Our Sterling, to campaign on specific issues, such as the farming crisis or the pound, in order to garner support and legitimise the BNP's agenda. He is a great believer in the internet, and the party has invested heavily in its website to spread the message. He is cheerfully full of spin, a self-acknowledged political opportunist for his racialist cause.

Wherever there is racial tension over asylum seekers, or a political gripe over low lamb prices, paedophiles, Ireland, the euro, new houses on greenfield sites, Stop The City demonstrations, he wants to join in, make it all worse, and recruit new members for the BNP. He is preparing for the day when some economic catastrophe revolutionises the BNP's political fortunes in the same way that mass unemployment facilitated Hitler's rise to power. The BNP's answer to this future crisis in global capitalism is novel and direct: withdraw from the European Union, whatever the economic consequences, impose import controls, and then hope to rule through the following chaos.

As befits a party leader, Griffin tries to come over as sincere and reasonable. He seems to think that by speaking calmly, as if the voice of moderation, it somehow makes racist and bigoted statements acceptable.

Griffin specifically moved to the Welsh countryside to escape multi-racial Britain. His own children now go to a local school near Welshpool. I asked him about that. "Would it bother me if there were a number of black children in the school? No. There were a couple of black children in the school when I was young, doesn't bother me, not a problem." I asked Griffin if he ever felt threatened by black people. "No, not at all, on an individual basis. It's a matter of survival, of our people, of our identity, as a whole. You can take small numbers of people, you can have someone as a friend." He claims to have black friends.

Griffin is against homosexuality, and GM foods; he is pro British beef-on-the bone, but is suspicious of the "environmentalist way of thinking, which is pure Marxism". He was really incensed about what he calls feminism's forcible conscription of little girls to be engineers, blaming "the neo-communist social attitudes of the 60s", which order us all to believe "we are a blank slate".

Griffin denies he is anti-Semitic. But in 1997, he published Mind-Benders, a tract that listed hundreds of Jews in the British media and purported to show evidence of the "globalist" - a code word for Jewish - conspiracy against the white race. In 1998, he was convicted of inciting racial hatred for publishing a white separatist/Holocaust denial magazine, The Rune. He was sentenced to nine months, suspended for two years.

Like the pro-Hitler historian David Irving, who Griffin says he has met only once, no fact, no argument, will ever challenge his racial views. "The debate on the Holocaust is not going to go away. Irving is not all that revisionist. There are others who are far more capable [of disproving the Holocaust]."

Griffin did not stop talking for three hours. We did a world's tour of the justifications for racism, from matrilineal DNA, the migration patterns 10,000 years ago of the Celts and the Scots, to the banana economics of "voluntary repatriation" (under the BNP, Britain would offer to buy all its bananas from the West Indies for 30 years in return for Caribbean agreement to the "repatriation" of black British citizens). Every so often, Griffin will slip in his own distinctive takes on Britain today. When he talks about "racial attacks", he means attacks by Asians on whites, and when he mentions "multi-culturalism", he uses it as an insult.

It is impossible to argue with him rationally. Griffin speaks, possibly even dreams, in a separate political language, in which race is the defining characteristic of everything. His arguments are a mish-mash of lies, intellectual confusions and illegitimate justifications. It is, after a time, almost painful, exhausting to be in his company. He buttresses his "argument" with anecdote or "incontestable" statistic, or made-up opinion poll. He does not so much defend a coherent political position as promote a moving chain of disparate but inter-linked prejudices. There is no real order to his thought. If you challenge him on one position, he simply jumps to another. "On individual policies, parts of policies, any individual, any party, makes mistakes. When you are in power, you have to adjust them. But the fundamental roots of my belief, evolutionary psychology, that human beings are the way they are primarily because of nature rather than nurture, is fixed. I do not just believe I am right, I know I am right. People are born different."

There is one other thing that is fixed. The BNP's unalterable starting and finishing point is the same; black people are inferior to white and there is a Jewish conspiracy to control the world. The BNP's aim is to remove the political rights of millions of British citizens because they are black or Jewish.

Griffin, now 40, has been a full-time politico since he lied about his age and joined the National Front when he was 14, in 1974. Griffin comes from a right-wing political background. His parents met as Young Conservative hecklers at a Communist Party meeting. His father, Edgar, was an accountant, and the family lived in Halesworth, in Suffolk, far from the racial frontlines of Britain of the 70s. Griffin attended a minor public school, St Felix in Southwold, where, after winning a scholarship, he was one of just two boys in the all girls' school. In his boyish enthusiasm, Griffin stood in a school mock election campaign for the 1974 general election - as the National Front candidate.

Industrial strife and the three-day-week convulsed Britain in the early 70s. Governments lurched from crisis to crisis, and in 1972 Idi Amin forcibly expelled 50,000 Ugandan Asians to Britain, an opportunity seized upon by racists to renew tensions triggered by 60s immigration rows and Enoch Powell's infamous "rivers of blood" speech. For Griffin and his father, it was time to join a new party, the National Front.

"It was a time when a large number of right-wing Tories, and people on the left, were quite convinced that Soviet-style communism was inevitable. The idea was that every Labour government ratcheted things to the left. The Tories were not ratcheting it back successfully - especially under Heath. My father saw a letter in the local paper from the NF's Norwich organiser. We went along to a local meeting and there was a speaker saying what I felt, what I had felt in a long, long while. I was not happy with everything in the NF, but it was a lot better than the Tory party."

Founded in 1967 to exploit racial tensions, the National Front grew rapidly and was, in name, soon Britain's fourth largest political party - in the 1979 General Election, it fielded 300 candidates. Soon, young Griffin was spending every free weekend at Excalibur House, the NF's headquarters in East London, doing security shifts, leaflet runs or provoking racial strife by selling NF papers at the local market in Hackney on Sundays. It was inspiring work for a young political soldier of the far right. "If you look back in hindsight, the NF was violence and skinheads and that kind of stuff - sub-proletarian hooliganism. But in 1974 it was not," he asserts. "When I joined as a young face, there were strong NF branches - Lewisham, Tower Hamlets, parts of Greenwich, Hackney - in places that are now almost exclusively non-white. There would be no point in trying to sell papers there now."

The National Front may have wanted to achieve semi-respectability, but its efforts were thwarted by the Nazi past of its leader, John Tyndall. Tyndall had been tried and convicted in the early 60s for paramilitary-style offences under legislation designed to curb the activities of Sir Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists in the 30s. In his defence, Tyndall told the court, "I am convinced that a peaceful social revolution as set out in Mein Kampf is what Britain requires to carry her back to her place in the world." Decades later, Tyndall was Griffin's immediate predecessor as head of the BNP.

The National Front was soon inextricably linked to street violence and racial attacks. For many of the NF's skinhead members, that was part of the attraction. Violence has been a hallmark of the British far right. Despite the spin and attempt at a moderate image, Griffin's new-look BNP is not so different from the National Front of the 70s. Griffin's BNP leadership election campaign manager, Tony Lecomber, was jailed in 1986 for three years for possessing explosives. In 1995, in The Rune magazine, Griffin himself wrote about the need to defend "rights for whites" with "well-directed boots and fists".

Griffin went to Cambridge University in 1977, where he studied history and law at the all-male, sporty Downing College, graduating with a 2:2 and a boxing blue. (He took up boxing after a fight with an anti-fascist in Lewisham.) At university, he was a social pariah. In a Union debate, he revealed his Front membership and was door-stepped by two student journalists. His face was plastered over the student newspaper. He says he filled his time with boxing training, weekends away with the Sealed Knot Society, re-enacting battles between Cavaliers and Roundheads, and other weekends enacting the racial revolution for the National Front. He even founded the Young National Front Students. You would have thought, given his extreme right-wing views, he would have found himself entirely isolated at university. If he was, he downplays it. "No one was significantly fussed about it. Had I been at Essex, it would have been a different thing. I knew people - known to be Front - who had a terrible time. They would walk in and no one would serve them in the college bar. If you believe something is right, it's a matter of self-respect that you stand up for it, even if other people tell you it's wrong."

After university, Griffin became a political worker at National Front HQ. But the far right was soon facing a crisis. The rise and rise of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, with her populist anti-trades union platform and victory in the Falklands in 1982, was sucking the political ground from beneath the National Front's feet. The far right started to splinter into a myriad of tiny groups. Tyndall walked out of the National Front in 1980, just before he was expelled.

For Griffin, there is no real bridge between his nationalist politics and Conservatism. "The Conservative Party is committedly internationalist and pure straight economic capitalist in its outlook. It does not have a nationalist outlook in its head. The Conservative problem with immigration is purely reactionary. It's because of black crime, or something like that. Whereas I would be opposed to immigration even if it was from people who, in larger numbers, were more law-abiding than us, more hard-working, cleverer than us and more productive. I would be opposed if it meant they were going to take over the country and change it so we do not have a homeland - which every people needs if it's going to survive."

In the past, the first-past-the-post electoral system made it difficult for extremist parties to get elected. The National Front might, in moments of acute racial division over issues such as the Ugandan Asians in the mid-70s, have won up to 10% of the vote, but mostly it barely retained its deposit, never mind won seats. In 25 years, the far right has only ever won one council seat - in 1993 in Tower Hamlets - and promptly lost it five months later. The unremitting message from the British electorate was rejection.

Crucially, the electoral system also created mainstream political parties that were informal "broad-church coalitions" with their own internal spectrum of left-right division. This allowed the right of the Conservative Party to expand into the political space the far right hoped to occupy on race or Europe. "Since 1958, every mainstream political party in Europe has been pro-European," says Roger Eatwell, professor of European politics at Bath University, and an expert on the far right. "In Austria, the anti-European alliance, outside the mainstream, was very important for Haider. In Britain, Europe has been a politicised issue, but the NF/BNP has still failed to develop a 'political space'. They are tainted as a Nazi party, and although people might pick up on bits of their programme, they can get many of the same ideas from the Conservative Party. Why vote for a bunch of bumbling incompetents when you can vote for a successful political party?"

Devolution, the new English regional assemblies, proportional representation, together with Griffin's "strategy of moderation", may however work in the BNP's favour. Ironically, out of sheer apathy by the legitimate parties, Griffin's BNP managed to get a councillor elected, unopposed, in Bromyard, Herefordshire in this month's council elections. "They are not going to take over the world tomorrow, but they are always there, festering away in the background," said a spokesman from the anti-fascist magazine Searchlight. "Where there is a lot of racism, there is potential for these groups to grow."

In 1983, and again in 1986, there were shattering splits in the NF provoked by personal hatreds, but also by an ideological struggle between competing doctrines of violent street fascism or the failed electoral road. Griffin infamously went to Tripoli in the late 80s to see if the Colonel would come up with some cash, just after the American bombing.

Griffin's Libyan trip, and his flirtation with various crackpot dictators, has itself given rise to a number of conspiracy theories about Griffin himself - that he has links with MI6 (something he denies). In the early 80s, a small group of fascists arrived in London, including Roberto Fiore and Massimo Morsello, both of whom were wanted by the Italian police in connection with offences concerning "subversive" association with armed groups. All Italian efforts to extradite the men from London failed. In the late 80s, when a Labour MP asked whether the two Italians had a connection with MI6, he received the standard government response to intelligence matters - that "a reply would not be in the public interest". It was taken as an indicator that Fiore and the others had indeed been recruited by MI6 and offered sanctuary in London. A lawyer for the two men later said that the Home Secretary had specified that extradition was denied because of insufficient evidence and because there are no equivalents in English law of the crimes they were accused of.

For years, Fiore and Griffin, as he himself admits, were ideological soul mates on the International Third Position. Fiore was his fascist mentor. And there are other links. Edgar Griffin, Nick Griffin's father, is still listed as the accountant on two charities connected to Fiore. These charities had their bank accounts seized last December by the Charity Commission amid suspicions that the money raised through their charity shops was being channelled to Fiore's fascist political party. The commission has yet to report.

By 1989, the National Front was national no longer. It collapsed in on itself and Griffin moved on. In 1990, Griffin had a serious accident that left him blinded in one eye. A shotgun cartridge buried amid burning rubbish exploded in his face. His left eye was badly damaged and had to be surgically removed. The painful injury left him depressed and he dropped out of his brand of politics for two years. He uses a glass eye. In 1994, Griffin was declared bankrupt after a property development project he was involved in went badly wrong.

Griffin returned to far-right politics after an offer from the old British Nazi, John Tyndall. After leaving the National Front in 1980, Tyndall had re-founded the British National Party in 1982 to keep the fascist flame alive in an ever tighter vessel. In 1996, Griffin began to edit Tyndall's personal mouthpiece, Spearhead magazine. After 36 issues and various machinations, he stood against Tyndall in a postal ballot for the BNP leadership and won. But, by then, every single household in Britain had already heard from Nick Griffin. He personally wrote the BNP's 1999 Euro manifesto. BNP election campaign leaflets were, under our electoral laws, pushed through 16 million letterboxes.

Will we be hearing from Nick Griffin in the future? Will the race issue, in its new guise as the "bogus asylum seekers crisis", dominate the forthcoming General Election, and will the two main political parties continue to use racist rhetoric borrowed from fascism? Or will the latest, and hopefully the last, British fascist leader suffer political oblivion in the Welsh hills. Unlike in France or Austria, the British far right has never managed to re-invent itself as a legitimate political movement. That will not stop Nick Griffin
fields.bodyText: Race is once more on the agenda in British politics, and at least one party on the far right is confidently hoping to capitalise on it. From his fastness in the Welsh hills, Nick Griffin, elected head of the British National Party (BNP) last autumn, is plotting to revive the fortunes of the most reviled party in Britain with a new strategy that he hopes will suit the temper of the times. Gone are the swastikas, the shaved heads, the marches with Union Jacks fluttering. Instead, there is the stream of innocuous-sounding front organisations, the South West Family Defence Organisation, the British Countryman, Save Our Sterling, promoted in smooth fireside chats over the internet. Griffin wants to cast off the Nazi-worshipping past of his predecessors, he wants to remould the riff-raff, the social misfits, the racists, the anti-Semites, the skinheads, street thugs and the thousand-odd lost souls who make up the BNP's active ranks, and turn them, and the party, into a viable political machine. He thinks he can reverse decades of defeat for the far right, a political movement whose electoral fortunes generally run a poor second to the Monster Raving Loony Party. He believes he can make fascism and racial hatred acceptable around the (white) British dinner table by couching his politics in the language of moderation. "People of my nationalist political persuasion," he says, "have to gain political power in the whole or we gain nothing, and the whole lot, British identity, just vanishes. If we are elected, we will effect a revolution, not bombs, but total change." You would expect him to talk like that, and a few months ago it would have been easy to dismiss Griffin as a political irrelevance. The British far right has, for the moment, shattered itself into a thousand antagonistic pieces. At a recent "demonstration" against refugees in Margate, the rump of the old National Front could barely muster three minibus-loads of skinheads to march around the town abusing asylum seekers. Even the biggest far-right fragment, Griffin's BNP, is tiny, with fewer than 1,500 members. And Britain seemed, especially under New Labour, immune from the deep-set continental xenophobia that has given rise to Jörg Haider's Freedom Party in Austria. But, the climate may be changing. In the past year, Britain has seen a staggering, unprecedented rise in racial attacks, from the April 1999 Brixton and Brick Lane bombings, to the uncovering of alleged racial murders in Telford, to assaults in Leeds and the stabbing of the white boyfriend of black British athlete, Ashia Hansen, and threats to three other black Olympic sportsmen. Last week, it was reported that TV star Ali G had received death threats, apparently from the neo-Nazi group Combat 18. Many other racial incidents remain unreported, while black members of the public, such as Duwayne Brooks, the friend of Stephen Lawrence, complain of continued and increased police harassment - in spite of the Macpherson report. The whole political mood music around race has, as black trades union leader Bill Morris noted, once more become hostile, intemperate and vengeful. A few Romanian beggars on the London Underground is officially a national crisis. "These people have come here with the intention of exploiting the system and exploiting their children. It's a vile thing to do," spat out New Labour's Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, in March, after private Labour focus-group polling revealed the asylum issue to be an electoral worry. The Conservative leader William Hague is now blaming the government for the "racketeers" who are creating "a massive influx of bogus asylum seekers". His deputy, Ann Widdecombe, has proposed detention - summary imprisonment - of all asylum seekers. The issue was the highlight of the Tories' May 4 local government election manifesto. To their shame, New Labour's answer was to crank up the rhetoric and promise more "crackdowns", arrests, £10,000 bonds for "dodgy" Indian subcontinent visitors, new detention centres, vouchers-for-food, more "dispersals", fewer "disproportionate burdens", and the faster processing of applicants. Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, has now announced plans to detain in secure accommodation asylum seekers whose applications have been refused. The "crisis" is directly attributed to the "flood" of asylum seekers now "invading" Britain. Hyped up by right-wing populist newspapers, "refugee" has practically become synonymous with "benefit abuser/beggar". But the cold reality is that the asylum seeker "epidemic" is largely the political creation of tabloid editorials, William Hague's ambitions and Downing Street's electoral worries. In 1996, under the Tories, applications for asylum were 29,000. In 1997, the figure rose to 33,000, in 1998 to 46,000 and in 1999 to 71,000. This is a large increase, but still statistically insignificant given Britain's population of 60 million. If you average the figures over the past four years - 50,000 asylum seeker applications per annum - the British Home Office, under its international obligations, is being asked, in population terms, to consider one refugee case for every 12,000 UK citizens. Given that many applications will be rejected, the true figure for successful applicants is probably 1 per 25,000 native head of population. New Labour's ministers may, in their harsh, tabloid-pleasing rhetoric, be fighting back a "flood", but the asylum seekers "crisis" is actually a trickle. "By heralding measure after measure to stop people entering Britain, the Home Office has given life to racists," says Bill Morris. In the elections for the London Mayor on May 4, the British National Party candidate polled 78,000 first and second preference votes - that is 10% of Ken Livingstone's vote. "The asylum seeker issue has been great for us," says Nick Griffin. "We have had phenomenal growth in membership. It's been quite fun to watch government ministers and the Tories play the race card in far cruder terms than we would ever use, but pretend not to. This issue legitimises us." Griffin is not alone in believing that the racist tide is turning his way. "Race, through the asylum seeker issue, is going to be a big issue in the next election," says Claire Dissington, of the Anti-Nazi League. "If racism is legitimised through the mainstream parties, then the far right can only benefit. Already there has been an increase in attacks. If it continues, we are going to end up with a dead refugee." Britain's would-be fascist leader is, of course, enthralled at the potential political opportunities of increased racial tension. Griffin, who has devoted his adult life to the fascist cause, wants to use a new wave of racial strife to re-unite those far-right fragments. He wants to make the BNP better so he can make things worse. Griffin is worth knowing about because he is the enemy of democratic and human rights. Griffin came down from the hills to meet me in the little town of Welshpool, in mid-Wales, after dropping his four children at school. He was dressed in a neat black polo neck, a well-tailored collarless jacket and a grey wool overcoat. He was polite, friendly and clever enough to have looked me up on the internet and therefore be able to quote my own articles back at me. He has the air of being a cross between a hearty country estate agent and an eager but slightly clumsy novice Conservative candidate. He might live in Wales, but he speaks with an earnest English Home Counties accent.
