It does not have a nationalist outlook in its head. The Conservative problem with immigration is purely reactionary. It's because of black crime, or something like that. Whereas I would be opposed to immigration even if it was from people who, in larger numbers, were more law-abiding than us, more hard-working, cleverer than us and more productive. I would be opposed if it meant they were going to take over the country and change it so we do not have a homeland - which every people needs if it's going to survive." In the past, the first-past-the-post electoral system made it difficult for extremist parties to get elected. The National Front might, in moments of acute racial division over issues such as the Ugandan Asians in the mid-70s, have won up to 10% of the vote, but mostly it barely retained its deposit, never mind won seats. In 25 years, the far right has only ever won one council seat - in 1993 in Tower Hamlets - and promptly lost it five months later. The unremitting message from the British electorate was rejection. Crucially, the electoral system also created mainstream political parties that were informal "broad-church coalitions" with their own internal spectrum of left-right division. This allowed the right of the Conservative Party to expand into the political space the far right hoped to occupy on race or Europe. "Since 1958, every mainstream political party in Europe has been pro-European," says Roger Eatwell, professor of European politics at Bath University, and an expert on the far right. "In Austria, the anti-European alliance, outside the mainstream, was very important for Haider. In Britain, Europe has been a politicised issue, but the NF/BNP has still failed to develop a 'political space'. They are tainted as a Nazi party, and although people might pick up on bits of their programme, they can get many of the same ideas from the Conservative Party. Why vote for a bunch of bumbling incompetents when you can vote for a successful political party?" Devolution, the new English regional assemblies, proportional representation, together with Griffin's "strategy of moderation", may however work in the BNP's favour. Ironically, out of sheer apathy by the legitimate parties, Griffin's BNP managed to get a councillor elected, unopposed, in Bromyard, Herefordshire in this month's council elections. "They are not going to take over the world tomorrow, but they are always there, festering away in the background," said a spokesman from the anti-fascist magazine Searchlight. "Where there is a lot of racism, there is potential for these groups to grow." In 1983, and again in 1986, there were shattering splits in the NF provoked by personal hatreds, but also by an ideological struggle between competing doctrines of violent street fascism or the failed electoral road. Griffin was instrumental in founding one of the more obscure factions, the International Third Position - a fascist cross between socialism and capitalism - which supported Libya's Colonel Gadaffi and Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini. Griffin infamously went to Tripoli in the late 80s to see if the Colonel would come up with some cash, just after the American bombing. Griffin's Libyan trip, and his flirtation with various crackpot dictators, has itself given rise to a number of conspiracy theories about Griffin himself - that he has links with MI6 (something he denies). In the early 80s, a small group of fascists arrived in London, including Roberto Fiore and Massimo Morsello, both of whom were wanted by the Italian police in connection with offences concerning "subversive" association with armed groups. All Italian efforts to extradite the men from London failed. In the late 80s, when a Labour MP asked whether the two Italians had a connection with MI6, he received the standard government response to intelligence matters - that "a reply would not be in the public interest". It was taken as an indicator that Fiore and the others had indeed been recruited by MI6 and offered sanctuary in London. A lawyer for the two men later said that the Home Secretary had specified that extradition was denied because of insufficient evidence and because there are no equivalents in English law of the crimes they were accused of. For years, Fiore and Griffin, as he himself admits, were ideological soul mates on the International Third Position. Fiore was his fascist mentor. And there are other links. Edgar Griffin, Nick Griffin's father, is still listed as the accountant on two charities connected to Fiore. These charities had their bank accounts seized last December by the Charity Commission amid suspicions that the money raised through their charity shops was being channelled to Fiore's fascist political party. The commission has yet to report. By 1989, the National Front was national no longer. It collapsed in on itself and Griffin moved on. In 1990, Griffin had a serious accident that left him blinded in one eye. A shotgun cartridge buried amid burning rubbish exploded in his face. His left eye was badly damaged and had to be surgically removed. The painful injury left him depressed and he dropped out of his brand of politics for two years. He uses a glass eye. In 1994, Griffin was declared bankrupt after a property development project he was involved in went badly wrong. Griffin returned to far-right politics after an offer from the old British Nazi, John Tyndall. After leaving the National Front in 1980, Tyndall had re-founded the British National Party in 1982 to keep the fascist flame alive in an ever tighter vessel. In 1996, Griffin began to edit Tyndall's personal mouthpiece, Spearhead magazine. After 36 issues and various machinations, he stood against Tyndall in a postal ballot for the BNP leadership and won. But, by then, every single household in Britain had already heard from Nick Griffin. He personally wrote the BNP's 1999 Euro manifesto. BNP election campaign leaflets were, under our electoral laws, pushed through 16 million letterboxes. Will we be hearing from Nick Griffin in the future? Will the race issue, in its new guise as the "bogus asylum seekers crisis", dominate the forthcoming General Election, and will the two main political parties continue to use racist rhetoric borrowed from fascism? Or will the latest, and hopefully the last, British fascist leader suffer political oblivion in the Welsh hills. Unlike in France or Austria, the British far right has never managed to re-invent itself as a legitimate political movement. That will not stop Nick Griffin

fields.headline: Changing ruse
fields.standfirst: 'I've come to believe we don't change very much. We're formed by genetics and early experiences, and remain essentially the same throughout life'
fields.trailText: 'I've come to believe we don't change very much. We're formed by genetics and early experiences, and remain essentially the same throughout life'
fields.body:
St David's Day, 1984. A Cardiff Comprehensive Eisteddfod. Here, in front of everyone, I - Freako New English Girl - am about to win that most Welsh of prizes, the annual poetry competition. I am the new 13-year-old school Bard. My name is called and a girl puts a purple robe around my shoulders and leads me up to the stage, where a fourth-year is playing the harp. There I am seated on a throne while a cardboard crown is placed on my head and the headmaster reads out my prize-winning ditty.

I don't know what happened to me. At my previous school in Broadstairs, I was a popular extrovert. But when we moved to Cardiff, I swear I began to mutate. My shoulders hunched, my skin turned pallid and my hair swung down over my eyes in greasy clumps. I became a geeky swot. Freako New Girl.

My coronation was The End. The school bullies set to work on me and I quickly ran out of hiding places. So off I went to another school, where, Dr Who-like, I reinvented myself. Never again would I write a poem. Never would I so much as stick my hand up in class. I exaggerated the Cardiff accent I was acquiring and made out I was Welsh, from across town. I became as bland as possible. Wallpaper Girl.

I think back on 1984 as the year in which my basic ideas about myself were undermined. At the first school, I was shown forcibly that I was not the person I had always thought. At the second school, I became a "yes" girl, eager to do nothing that would make people hate me. I resented it, feeling that the real me was not this anxious, wafer-thin persona. But the transformation had worked. I was wallpaper. I made friends, got myself a perm and maintained my personality like my hair - sprayed firmly in place; brittle. And from this position of blandness, I began to claw back a personality.

A number of years and regenerations later, and another me - adult me (a great deal happier) - is starting a new job at a London literary agency. As I'm walking through the offices for the first time, I can't seem to shake off that Freako New Girl feeling. It's as though someone who knew me Way Back When is about to spring out from behind a partition.

It could be worse: the girl who is about to become one of my new colleagues is from the second school in Cardiff, not the first. But as she calls out my name and we begin our chit-chat about the past, I am shrinking down under the desk. My jacket is evolving into a blazer and my hair is twisting itself into tight corkscrews. My clean slate has been daubed with indelible ink. I imagine my school chum creeping from desk to desk, whispering the truth about me.

After watching the film Fight Club on video, I've been thinking about how we reinvent and transform ourselves. There's something intoxicating about public declarations of change: New Year's resolutions, ITV's Year Of Promise. Perhaps the existence of a plaque on a wall saying, "I promise I'll never sleep with men on the first date again" really can lead to born-again sexual frugality. A public statement can be the way forward. Break it and you show yourself to be spineless.

Even seemingly trivial changes lead to transformation - the makeovers, diets, exercise regimes. You only have to make a brave decision at the hairdressers to acquire an entirely new face (and then, of course, you spend one of those weird evenings sneaking glances into mirrors, and it's like catching sight of an alien).

A friend told me about a self-help technique, in which you smile at yourself in the mirror for a full minute each morning. No matter how lousy you're feeling, if you grin for long enough the smile becomes real. I'm not attracted to self-help. Its quick-fix aspects turn me off. Self-help lacks the appealing gloomy grandeur and labyrinthine vastness of psychotherapy and its cohorts. Yet the transformation I put myself through when I changed schools must be closer to self-help than therapy. And, after all, what's more boring than listening to someone attempting to analyse last night's dream or spouting about the discovery of their inner-child?

Language is a powerful transformer. A friend with a new job told me she listens to herself in meetings babbling a kind of lingo-professional, and feels distant, as though eavesdropping on herself. The more she talks, the more she becomes someone else. She sees the people around her lulled into sympathy and she starts to believe in herself.

Is the notion of fundamental personal transformation anything more than babble? When I think of all the times I have listened to people who believe they have metamorphosed but who seem unchanged, I begin to wonder. I may feel I have regenerated myself, but perhaps it's just a question of which face I present to the world. That seems true when I think of how I slid back into Wallpaper Girl on running into my ex school-mate at the literary agency. Since, I have discovered that she felt as insecure as me - she too was jolted back to a self she thought she'd left behind.

As a tortured 13-year-old, I spent my weekends among my Wham! posters, frantically scribbling a novel called The Loner, the story of a misunderstood teenager (with inner beauty) who falls in love with a thinly-veiled George Michael, and grabs his attention by . . . writing a novel about a girl who falls in love with a pop star. Cinderella fantasies written to transform my life. These days, my writing is more an attempt to get a fix on who I am.

I've come to believe we don't change so very much. We are formed by genetics and early experiences and we remain essentially the same throughout life. I don't believe in fate, though - predestination is a cop-out. We have the power to decide what versions of ourselves we reveal to others and utilise to shape our lives. Remember Silly Putty? A rubbery lump inside a plastic egg? You could stretch it, shape it. If you threw it against a wall, it bounced off. And then you squidged it up and put it away again. We radically morph our behaviour as a creative act, as a kick against boredom, or as a survival tactic, but back inside our individual plastic eggs we are who we are. The rest is Spin.

© Anna Davis, 2000. Anna Davis's new novel, Melting, is published by Sceptre, priced £10. Julie Burchill is away.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
If women are to escape oppression by emulating Zionists and setting up our own nation state, whose country does Andrea Dworkin suggest we steal (Take No Prisoners, May 13)? Or does she believe in that mythical place, 'a land without people for a people without land'? The Palestinians' plight provides but one example of the terrible consequences of that lie; Jews should be free of anti-Semitism and women of misogyny. I thought an anti-racist internationalist feminism had these goals.
Frankie Green
London NW3
fields.body:
If women are to escape oppression by emulating Zionists and setting up our own nation state, whose country does Andrea Dworkin suggest we steal (Take No Prisoners, May 13)? Or does she believe in that mythical place, 'a land without people for a people without land'? The Palestinians' plight provides but one example of the terrible consequences of that lie; Jews should be free of anti-Semitism and women of misogyny. I thought an anti-racist internationalist feminism had these goals.
Frankie Green
London NW3

It seems strange that Andrea Dworkin should have expended so much time and intellectual effort to reach a conclusion that must have already been obvious to many and will come as a surprise to few. 'They to whom evil is done, do evil,' is a principle as old as humanity. All we can do is try to use our knowledge of it to somehow combat its effects. In my view, the state of Israel should never have been founded, but as it has been, let's hope that it will reach some sort of rapprochment and accommodation with its neighbours, and that the same thing happens in the war between men and women, because Dworkin's proposed 'Womanland' sounds to me like a pretty good definition of hell on earth.
Sue Saxby
Wrexham

So men hate women? The world over. It took nine years for Andrea Dworkin to come to this earth-shattering conclusion. (Perhaps her time would have been better spent campaigning to stop the institutionalised slaughter of 'bad' women in the Indian sub-continent.) The fact that the Jews have suffered doesn't mean that inter-gender relations would be any different from anywhere else.
Kathryn Saville
London N8

I was particularly struck by one of Andrea Dworkin's ideas. 'As for feminism, there no longer seems to be any plan at all, no political organisation, no goals, no strategy.' She is right. What happened to the fight?
Catriona MacLeod
ll1g2116@lmu.ac.uk

Andrea Dworkin's belief in the similarity between Jews and women is uncannily reminiscent of the views of Otto Weininger. In his book, Sex And Psychoanalysis, he identified the feminine with all that is weak and corrupt, and the masculine with strength and virtue. The Jew, he argued, was the epitome of the feminine type. Dworkin seems to reverse this thesis, while maintaining its essence. This bizarre identification led the misogynist Weininger to self-loathing, suicide, and the soubriquet of 'Hitler's favourite Jew'. It seems to have led the feminist Dworkin to Zionism, racism and national chauvinism.
Roland Rance
London E17

Are you trying to encourage readers to agree with Andrea Dworkin by showing us models looking like potential child sex-abuse victims (Fashion, May 13)?
Lois Palframan
Sheffield

I laughed at Jean Chapman's favourite joke (May 13), but something disturbed about it, too. Substitute men for women, and the violent fantasy which gives this joke its punchline is suddenly very un-funny, and reminds us how far we are from any collective recognition of equality between the sexes.
Jamie Elliott
London SE15

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

fields.headline: The mighty munchkin
fields.standfirst: With his cocaine-snorting Don Giovanni and Trump Tower Figaro he's the iconoclast traditional opera-goers loathe. Yet, as  John O'Mahony reports, there is a deeply religious purpose behind the diminutive director's assaults on modern American culture
fields.trailText: With his cocaine-snorting Don Giovanni and Trump Tower Figaro he's the iconoclast traditional opera-goers loathe. Yet, as John O'Mahony reports, there is a deeply religious purpose behind the diminutive director's assaults on modern American culture
fields.body:
It's early in the summer of 1987, and Peter Sellars is rehearsing the final scenes of his radical reinterpretation of Mozart's Così Fan Tutte, which the producer has infamously sliced out of da Ponte's 18th-century Naples setting and inserted into the chrome and glitter ambience of a Cape Cod diner. In the rehearsal space at Purchase College, New York, where the work is due to be performed, Sellars spends his days assiduously snipping, tucking and reconnecting the meaning of the work, as the usually jaunty reconciliation of Mozart's wayward lovers is scrapped to make way for a much more edgy, ambiguous conclusion, culminating in an angry brawl. During scheduled breaks, the Sellars road-show continues in front of baying packs of America's top culture journalists, eager for a replay of the now- standard conversational fireworks, all sparkling wit and limber philosophical acrobatics.

In the evening, Sellars would retire with the rest of the cast to the spartan Purchase dormitories to study the score before catching a little sleep. And then, next morning, just as every morning, "he would get up very early and read the Bible for an hour", remembers the conductor Craig Smith, who lived in the dormitory next door - "I'm talking about five in the morning" - and would then go and "do this wild theatrical thing and give interviews and shock all these people".

There are two quite distinct incarnations of opera producer, theatre director, teacher and social activist Peter Sellars. The first is the Sellars we know and love (to hate, in the case of music critics from the Daily Telegraph or the New York Times, circa 1988); the gleeful, spike-haired opera-terrorist running rampage in the citadel of high art with a mallet and a razor-blade. This is the one who has indulged some of the greatest operatic gimmicks of our time: Handel's Orlando set in the Kennedy Space Centre and on Mars, with the unbalanced hero of the opera reborn as a Nasa astronaut; and Giulio Cesare, again by Handel, transported to a semi- constructed but already bombed-out penthouse in the Beirut Hilton.

Most notorious of all is his reworking of the da Ponte Mozart trilogy, with not only a Cosí Fan Tutti in Despina's Diner, but a cor porate Marriage Of Figaro set in the opulence of Trump Tower, and a Don Giovanni set in New York's Spanish Harlem, with a gloriously amoral cocaine-snorting Don who is finally pulled down into the ultimate modern metaphor for hell - the New York sewer system.

It's a role that he plays to perfection. Tiki Davies, press attaché at New York's Kennedy Arts Centre while Sellars, then 27, was head of the ill-fated American National Theatre, remembers how he would lurk by the exits in wait for outraged, fleeing punters: "He would stand there and cackle like a maniac as they were scurrying off. He was just delighted that he had touched them." "He loves it," says singer James Maddelena, who has worked with Sellars for 20 years. "If people really hate it and have a kind of strong reaction, then at least he knows he's got through."

In person, Sellars displays all the traits of the flamboyant, gregarious showman, albeit in a curiously compact form. It is still a jolt to discover that he is just 5ft 6in tall, with an oddly oversized head, and arms that seem barely to reach beyond his waist. There is also that trademark electrostatic burst of hair (he fashions it himself, according to his friend, the librettist Alice Goodman, with an implement resembling garden shears) and the sudden splashes of wild, honking laughter that punctuate his conversation (think Tom Hulce in Amadeus, but shriller).

Sellars's Lilliputian size, however, just seems to amplify the atomic levels of his phenomenal energy. Throughout rehearsals for next month's new ENO production of John Adams's opera Nixon In China, the director fizzed with ideas, bounding around the makeshift stage with the exhausted singers in tow, barking out the arias in his motor-horn baritone. He lives only to work, spending much of his time jetting from one gig to the next, never taking a holiday, never indulging the slightest inkling of a conventional personal life, other than visits to his mother and sister. As for love interests: "It's not really a topic," he replies with another honk of laughter, "I'm just really, really celibate."

Apart from books and records, which he accumulates with extravagant abandon, Sellars has few vices: he doesn't smoke, drink, do drugs, or even eat very much: "Just one meal a day," he says. "It is really good for me to be hungry. That little edge is important. It teaches you to see a little clearer." And with only three or four hours a night, he sleeps even less: "I saw him asleep once," says the choreographer Mark Morris, a friend and collaborator. "I went into his room one morning and saw him asleep for, like, one second before he woke up. I didn't think that he slept at all."

This is the Sellars who bristles with conversational chutzpah, often tossing out contentious declarations: "Opera has the highest stakes of any of the performing arts but it is usually surrounded by the most trivia"; or "I love gimmicks. They are great. They are fun. They are part of life."

But at the same time there is an entirely different, radically unglamorous, acutely unfashionable dimension to the life and work that couldn't be in greater contrast to his public image of opera b te noire. Despite a punishing schedule of international engagements, Sellars finds time to teach one full trimester a year at the University of Los Angeles, overseeing two courses: "Art as moral action" and "Art as social action," both broad examinations of the social, moral and spiritual dimensions of the business of making art. There is also a course option called "The invisible world", devoted entirely to an exploration of the spiritual mechanisms of creativity.

Naturally, Sellars applies the same flamboyant showmanship to this side of his work, often lecturing non-stop for anything up to three hours, mesmerising his 700-800 students (the course is so popular that the university is forced to hire halls normally used as rock venues) while a ghettoblaster on the podium blares out London trance or aboriginal mouth music.

Equally remarkable is his work in the deprived, crime-ridden communities of east LA, where he has so far staged a number of works, including Genet's The Screens and Stravinsky's Soldier's Tale, featuring local Chicano and Latino artists, gang members from the infamous Boyle Heights LA suburb, and unwed mothers. "People are making this art because it is going to help and it has a lot riding on it," he says. Peter Mark Sellars was born on September 27 1957 in Pittsburg, Pennsylvania, the first (and, as it turned out, only) son of Lee Sellars, a radio producer who pioneered the first live phone-in radio shows in the US, and Patricia Palmer, a high-school teacher. The Sellars household was quietly religious, they were Christian Scientists.They disapproved of TV and encouraged the young boy and his sister Juliet to read voraciously and immerse themselves in classical music. From an early age Sellars had an avid interest in natural history: "He was going to be a herpetologist at one time," remembers his mother. "He had a couple of snakes, which sometimes got loose around the house. It distressed him that snakes had such a bad rap. Their image was not, he felt, very fair."

Sellars's 10th year would prove to be one of considerable change. First, his parents got divorced, leaving the fractured family in a less than healthy financial situation. Second, he threw himself into what would become the abiding theatrical passion of his teenage years, taking up an informal apprenticeship at the Lovelace Marionette Theatre: "It was basically a garage in East Pittsburgh painted fuchsia," he recalls. "But there were puppets and masks from all over the world on the walls. My first images of theatre were Javanese shadow puppets and Japanese Bunraku. I was 25 before I knew what a well-made play in a living room was, or saw a kitchen-sink drama."

Every summer, Sellars and his puppets would perform on the streets of Pittsburgh and nearby towns: "We were doing all these shows in department store windows and shopping malls. Working on the street is much more difficult, you really have to work out how to make them stay and how to get them to put money in the hat."

At the age of 14, he was awarded scholarship support to attend the Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, one of America's oldest private boarding schools and the alma mater of former president George Bush. "Even as a ninth grader he displayed total mental concentration, almost superhuman energy and endurance, needing apparently little or no sleep," remembers art teacher Robert Lloyd, who allowed young Sellars, in his final year, to teach a fully credited course in puppetry. "He had listened to an extraordinary amount of music, from classical through contemporary, and his taste was eclectic without being at all shallow. Schumann, Stravinsky, Berio, Stockhausen were equally interesting to him."

After deferring his place at Harvard, Sellars set off with his mother and sister to spend a sabbatical year in Paris, where he saw Giorgio Strehler's Marriage Of Figaro and Patrice Chéreau's Tales Of Hoffman: "my first experience of opera which was critical of its source". Before returning to the US, he joined a puppetry delegation to Moscow, which would ignite a love of Russian theatre that would colour his work for decades.

In autumn 1975, Sellars finally strode onto the campus at Harvard. Almost immediately the teenage whirlwind began to make an impression on the Ivy League consciousness: "The university was divided into those people who thought he was a genius and those who thought he was a mountebank," says Alice Goodman, a college friend who would go on to write librettos for both the John Adams operas Nixon In China and The Death Of Klinghoffer. "He had the kind of impeccably 'nice' manner of the sort of person you would take to tea with your grandfather. And of course he could also be hilariously and devastatingly rude - but never unintentionally. He was always very careful and meticulous in his rudeness."

In the spring of his first year, Sellars became the first freshman in Harvard history to direct a production on the student theatre main-stage, a spectacular bomb that led to Sellars being evicted and told never to return. Instead, he set up a theatre club in the basement of his dormitory, called the Explosives B Cabaret, named after some old signs picked up from an army base. It was here he put on his legendary six-hour version of Wagner's Ring, using human-sized puppets to a recorded accompaniment of the world's classic vocal performances.

The popularity of the Explosives B Cabaret forced the Harvard dramatic society reluctantly to readmit Sellars with a season of his productions, leading to yet another undergrad legend: his King Lear. Set in a Lincoln convertible, which was slowly dismantled as the action progressed, Lear was transformed into a play about a group of amoral young people in a materialist society who were just a little too anxious to take over their father's business. Famously, the lead actor came down with severe stage fright just three days before the premiere, forcing Sellars to take over: "My lines were written everywhere," he recalls. "The rest of the cast knew them - they would be whispering them to me constantly."

The success of this work drew the attention of theatre guru Robert Brustein, who invited Sellars to work at the American Repertory Theatre (or ART) and, more importantly, introduced him to costume designer Dunya Ramicova and set designer Adrianne Lobel, who would become the core of his collaborative team right into the 90s: "I think I loved him immediately," remembers Lobel, "For one thing he was very small. When I first met him he was wearing one of those rain parkas, with a little hood. So he had this sort of troll-like appearance. It was like being Dorothy in the Land of Oz. He was like this munchkin, so full of energy and ideas and ready to take on the world."

The first ART production was a biomechanical version of Gogol's The Government Inspector (Sellars wrote his final-year thesis on the Russian experimental director Meyerhold), featuring a huge transparent plastic curtain separating the rich from the poor. However, Sellars's national breakthrough came with his next ART venture, a radical reinterpretation of Handel's eccentric opera Orlando, set in the Kennedy Space Centre and on Mars, with the lead role now sung by a contralto astronaut, in the process earning a rave from the powerful New Yorker critic Andrew Porter. In 1983, Sellars became the youngest ever recipient of the MacArthur Foundation award, the so-called Genius Award, which came with $136,000. He ploughed most of the money into an ailing and now defunct institution called the Boston Shakespeare Company, where, as artistic director, he staged acclaimed productions of Chekhov's The Seagull, Pericles and the Peter Maxwell Davies opera The Lighthouse. Then, at 26, he was offered the job of setting up an American National Theatre at the Kennedy Centre in Washington. American theatre went into shock.

Lobel sums up the unreal atmosphere of the time: "Suddenly, we seemed to land in all of these highfalutin' giant cultural institutions all over America; the Chicago Lyric Opera, Houston Grand Opera, the Kennedy Centre. And again we felt like really bright children about to turn the world on its ear, taking over these giant toys and being very serious about our work but also incredibly irreverent." The venture at the Kennedy Centre, where Sellars sped through $5m in less than a year, soon turned sour. But he had already turned his attention elsewhere, and in 1985 mounted a production of Handel's Giulio Cesare at the PepsiCo Summerfare festival at Purchase, in which the libretto was transformed into a power struggle in the Beirut Hilton, with the invading Americans becoming embroiled in a messy local love affair (not unlike the real US involvement in the Lebanon, minus the love interest) .

However, it was the next three productions, staged over three subsequent summers at the Purchase event - Così Fan Tutte (1987), The Trump Tower Figaro (1988) and the Spanish Harlem Don Giovanni which was presented in tandem with the other two in 1989 - that polarised reaction to Sellars. As with all of his contemporary transformations, the primary aim was to strip away the frilly accretions and stuffy attitudes that he felt had trivialised the works: "These composers are staking their lives, everything they have got, on the biggest issues in the world. It's hard to think that anything could be more important than Beethoven's Fidelio. In Mussorgsky's Boris Godunov he is the destiny of his country and trying to ask his audience the most important questions about its future. In Figaro, Mozart is taking on a play that had officially been banned. This stuff is so daring!"

In the da Ponte trilogy, Sellars's stated aim is to transform the operas into an examination of three strata of American society. The use of the updated contexts, which he refers to as "surprisingly articulated surfaces", he feels is supported by solid philosophical reasoning: "It is the rationale of the believer," he says. "The crucifixion is depicted through most of the history of art [as being] right in the middle of whatever Dutch burghers are doing. Artists are actually going out of their way to paint it as a normal thing, in the middle of a completely contemporary event, because the crucifixion and the resurrection are completely normal things that are happening at every moment in your life for every human being throughout all time." Unfortunately, some critics saw it rather differently: "It remains a mystery why this once precocious director, ostensibly an avant-gardist," said the rabid Sellars-baiter Donal Henahan in the New York Times, "has not concentrated his energies on staging contemporary operas instead of ravaging and bowdlerising existing ones."

Ironically, Sellars was simultaneously taking the advice of his most outspoken critic almost to the letter. At a convention in the mid-80s, he ran into the minimalist composer John Adams: "He had seen one of my earlier works," says Adams, "and immediately asked me if I wanted to write an opera and suggested this subject. He even, if I remember rightly, came up immediately with the title, Nixon in China. At first I was less than delighted about the idea, Nixon at the time was persona non grata and generally thought of only in satirical terms."

Under Sellars's pressure, however, Adams came around. Sellars then turned to Alice Goodman, then a completely unknown writer attempting to establish herself: "I was living in Cambridge in England and Peter rang and said he wanted me to write an opera called Nixon In China and I immediately said 'yes', because it was a perfect title." The plan was to build a "heroic" work around the disgraced president, one that would present him, as Adams has said, as "a visionary and a poignant character, a man whose vanity and paranoia became an Achilles heel".

The resulting opera is a powerful and enigmatic work, a subtle philosophical comedy propelled along by a score which sweeps gracefully from bloated bombast to wrenching introspection: "A stirring creation, full of charm and wit, and in the end, beauty," wrote John Rockwell in the New York Times. "Unlike so many operas, this one's likely to last."

Immediately afterwards, the trio began work on the next collaboration: "I think it was during a staged rehearsal for Nixon," says Goodman, "someone asked us what we wanted to do next. And without any hesitation, Peter just said: 'The Death of Klinghoffer'. And we all just nodded and said 'Yes, of course.' Everybody in the room thought we were joking." From the onset, however, Sellars's chosen material - the 1985 hijacking of the liner Achille Lauro, in which a disabled Jew named Leon Klinghoffer was murdered by Palestinian terrorists - proved far more contentious. "Even before I had a written a note of the score, I was receiving letters from both sides, from Palestinians and Jews, complaining that I was siding with the other," says Adams. The 1991 premiere at the Thétre Royal del la Monnaie in Brussels, which was in rehearsal as US planes were dropping smart bombs into ventilator shafts in Baghdad, was almost cancelled. In the US, Klinghoffer was greeted by a firestorm of criticism ranging from opportunism to anti-Semitism. Taken on its own merits, however, the opera is musically superior to Nixon and is considered to have mapped out a new direction for the future of minimalism.

Much of the 90s coincided with what might be termed Sellars's Los Angeles period. In 1987, he moved there to take over the artistic directorship of the LA festival. What he found profoundly affected him: "Instead of the usual image of LA as a cultural wasteland, I found that I was dealing with incredible cultural riches." One of the first of his large-scale shows to be affected by the LA ethos was his infamous production of Mozart's The Magic Flute at Glyndebourne in 1990, which produced a vitriolic critical reaction. Set under an LA freeway, with a cast of bums, hippies and an Imelda Marcos lookalike, it precipitated the first outbreak of booing at Glyndebourne and the resignation of its then artistic director, Sir Peter Hall.

Sellars shifted the focus of the 1991 LA festival to showcase local artists such as the late Iranian theatre visionary Reza Abdoh as well as community-based work, often in public spaces, 85% of which was free. The next (and because of funding difficulties, the last) festival in 1993 had an even deeper impact: "It was coming off the LA uprising where people set their own city on fire," he says, "That's a very extreme gesture and needs to be responded to seriously, and the politicians were not capable of that. So, it is up to cultural workers. That was an incredibly powerful experience and all my work for the last 10 years has really been responding to 1992."

Sellars's post-1992 experiments in transplanting the furious conflicts of the riots into classical works took equally daring steps: a Pelléas And Mélisande which set Debussy's work in a beach-front condo, with the disaffected hero lurking in a cavernous no-man's land beneath, and Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress set in an LA maximum security prison. In these works, Sellars's objective is made painfully clear: he is attempting to create a highly politicised, Brechtian model of opera, employing classic works, which, he argues, were highly politically relevant in their day, to comment on contemporary society. In straight theatre it's commonplace. But Sellars feels that the inbuilt "alienation device" of opera is even more suited to the task: "You have critical distance, and at the same time the music is so overwhelming that it involves you completely." He feels too that opera audiences are the perfect recipients of his message: "That's why it's an important place to work. You are addressing the power structure. That's who goes to opera."

The problem for many is Sellars's apocalyptic anti-Americanism, anti-racial-imperialism, anti-corporate message itself. As his critics gleefully point out, his polemic is often deeply contradictory, sometimes gliding neatly into the slipstream of the original libretto, though quite often jarring discordantly with meaning and sense. However, it is these inherent contradictions that make his work so difficult, unwieldy, and ultimately so interesting, and what raises it above arid politics.

Those critics and audiences who insist on finding something more coherent in his work need look no further than the Christian principles that guide his vision. "New England Christianity was all about social justice, and about what it meant to base one's religious beliefs on an idea of social justice and social equity. Those two things, belief and its social implications, are for me tied together so tightly."

All of this might be impossibly pious or complacent if it weren't so inextricably married with the more outrageous, controversial, and overstated aspects of Sellars's work. And the controversy also keeps his argument alive, though not always understood: "A lot of productions are important not because anybody saw them," he says, "but because they heard about them. People's imagination of what happened on stage is even more important than what happened on stage. The most important nights in the theatre were seen by only a tiny fraction of the population and yet they have passed into the history of the world."

Life at a glance : Peter Mark Sellars

Born: September 27 1957, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Education: Phillips Academy, Andover, Massachusetts; Harvard University (BA 1980).

Career: Artistic director: 1983-4 Boston Shakespeare Company; 1984- American National Theatre; 1990 - 93, Los Angeles festival. Professor of world arts and cultures UCLA.

Some productions: 1983 The Mikado, Lyric Opera of Chicago; 1984 Cosi Fan Tutti, Castle Hill Festival Mass.;1987 The Electrification Of The Soviet Union, Glyndebourne Touring Opera; 1987 Nixon In China, Houston Grand Opera; 1990 The Magic Flute, Glyndebourne; 1991 The Death Of Klinghoffer, Thétre Royal del la Monnaie, Brussels; 1994 The Merchant Of Venice, Barbican; 1995 Mathis der Maler, Royal Opera; 1996 Theodora, Glyndebourne; The Rake's Progress, Chtelet, Paris.

 Nixon In China opens at the English National Opera on June 7.

This is the one who has indulged some of the greatest operatic gimmicks of our time: Handel's Orlando set in the Kennedy Space Centre and on Mars, with the unbalanced hero of the opera reborn as a Nasa astronaut; and Giulio Cesare, again by Handel, transported to a semi- constructed but already bombed-out penthouse in the Beirut Hilton. "If people really hate it and have a kind of strong reaction, then at least he knows he's got through." It is still a jolt to discover that he is just 5ft 6in tall, with an oddly oversized head, and arms that seem barely to reach beyond his waist. There is also that trademark electrostatic burst of hair (he fashions it himself, according to his friend, the librettist Alice Goodman, with an implement resembling garden shears) and the sudden splashes of wild, honking laughter that punctuate his conversation (think Tom Hulce in Amadeus, but shriller). Apart from books and records, which he accumulates with extravagant abandon, Sellars has few vices: he doesn't smoke, drink, do drugs, or even eat very much: "Just one meal a day," he says. And with only three or four hours a night, he sleeps even less: "I saw him asleep once," says the choreographer Mark Morris, a friend and collaborator. This is the Sellars who bristles with conversational chutzpah, often tossing out contentious declarations: "Opera has the highest stakes of any of the performing arts but it is usually surrounded by the most trivia"; or "I love gimmicks. Despite a punishing schedule of international engagements, Sellars finds time to teach one full trimester a year at the University of Los Angeles, overseeing two courses: "Art as moral action" and "Art as social action," both broad examinations of the social, moral and spiritual dimensions of the business of making art. There is also a course option called "The invisible world", devoted entirely to an exploration of the spiritual mechanisms of creativity. "The crucifixion is depicted through most of the history of art [as being] right in the middle of whatever Dutch burghers are doing. Artists are actually going out of their way to paint it as a normal thing, in the middle of a completely contemporary event, because the crucifixion and the resurrection are completely normal things that are happening at every moment in your life for every human being throughout all time." Unfortunately, some critics saw it rather differently: "It remains a mystery why this once precocious director, ostensibly an avant-gardist," said the rabid Sellars-baiter Donal Henahan in the New York Times, "has not concentrated his energies on staging contemporary operas instead of ravaging and bowdlerising existing ones." Ironically, Sellars was simultaneously taking the advice of his most outspoken critic almost to the letter. At a convention in the mid-80s, he ran into the minimalist composer John Adams: "He had seen one of my earlier works," says Adams, "and immediately asked me if I wanted to write an opera and suggested this subject. He even, if I remember rightly, came up immediately with the title, Nixon in China. At first I was less than delighted about the idea, Nixon at the time was persona non grata and generally thought of only in satirical terms." Under Sellars's pressure, however, Adams came around. Sellars then turned to Alice Goodman, then a completely unknown writer attempting to establish herself: "I was living in Cambridge in England and Peter rang and said he wanted me to write an opera called Nixon In China and I immediately said 'yes', because it was a perfect title." The plan was to build a "heroic" work around the disgraced president, one that would present him, as Adams has said, as "a visionary and a poignant character, a man whose vanity and paranoia became an Achilles heel". The resulting opera is a powerful and enigmatic work, a subtle philosophical comedy propelled along by a score which sweeps gracefully from bloated bombast to wrenching introspection: "A stirring creation, full of charm and wit, and in the end, beauty," wrote John Rockwell in the New York Times. "Unlike so many operas, this one's likely to last." Immediately afterwards, the trio began work on the next collaboration: "I think it was during a staged rehearsal for Nixon," says Goodman, "someone asked us what we wanted to do next. And without any hesitation, Peter just said: 'The Death of Klinghoffer'. And we all just nodded and said 'Yes, of course.' Everybody in the room thought we were joking." From the onset, however, Sellars's chosen material - the 1985 hijacking of the liner Achille Lauro, in which a disabled Jew named Leon Klinghoffer was murdered by Palestinian terrorists - proved far more contentious. "Even before I had a written a note of the score, I was receiving letters from both sides, from Palestinians and Jews, complaining that I was siding with the other," says Adams. The 1991 premiere at the Thétre Royal del la Monnaie in Brussels, which was in rehearsal as US planes were dropping smart bombs into ventilator shafts in Baghdad, was almost cancelled. In the US, Klinghoffer was greeted by a firestorm of criticism ranging from opportunism to anti-Semitism. Taken on its own merits, however, the opera is musically superior to Nixon and is considered to have mapped out a new direction for the future of minimalism. Much of the 90s coincided with what might be termed Sellars's Los Angeles period. In 1987, he moved there to take over the artistic directorship of the LA festival. What he found profoundly affected him: "Instead of the usual image of LA as a cultural wasteland, I found that I was dealing with incredible cultural riches." One of the first of his large-scale shows to be affected by the LA ethos was his infamous production of Mozart's The Magic Flute at Glyndebourne in 1990, which produced a vitriolic critical reaction. Set under an LA freeway, with a cast of bums, hippies and an Imelda Marcos lookalike, it precipitated the first outbreak of booing at Glyndebourne and the resignation of its then artistic director, Sir Peter Hall. Sellars shifted the focus of the 1991 LA festival to showcase local artists such as the late Iranian theatre visionary Reza Abdoh as well as community-based work, often in public spaces, 85% of which was free. The next (and because of funding difficulties, the last) festival in 1993 had an even deeper impact: "It was coming off the LA uprising where people set their own city on fire," he says, "That's a very extreme gesture and needs to be responded to seriously, and the politicians were not capable of that. So, it is up to cultural workers. That was an incredibly powerful experience and all my work for the last 10 years has really been responding to 1992." Sellars's post-1992 experiments in transplanting the furious conflicts of the riots into classical works took equally daring steps: a Pelléas And Mélisande which set Debussy's work in a beach-front condo, with the disaffected hero lurking in a cavernous no-man's land beneath, and Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress set in an LA maximum security prison. In these works, Sellars's objective is made painfully clear: he is attempting to create a highly politicised, Brechtian model of opera, employing classic works, which, he argues, were highly politically relevant in their day, to comment on contemporary society. In straight theatre it's commonplace. But Sellars feels that the inbuilt "alienation device" of opera is even more suited to the task: "You have critical distance, and at the same time the music is so overwhelming that it involves you completely." He feels too that opera audiences are the perfect recipients of his message: "That's why it's an important place to work. You are addressing the power structure. That's who goes to opera." The problem for many is Sellars's apocalyptic anti-Americanism, anti-racial-imperialism, anti-corporate message itself. As his critics gleefully point out, his polemic is often deeply contradictory, sometimes gliding neatly into the slipstream of the original libretto, though quite often jarring discordantly with meaning and sense. However, it is these inherent contradictions that make his work so difficult, unwieldy, and ultimately so interesting, and what raises it above arid politics. Those critics and audiences who insist on finding something more coherent in his work need look no further than the Christian principles that guide his vision. "New England Christianity was all about social justice, and about what it meant to base one's religious beliefs on an idea of social justice and social equity. Those two things, belief and its social implications, are for me tied together so tightly." All of this might be impossibly pious or complacent if it weren't so inextricably married with the more outrageous, controversial, and overstated aspects of Sellars's work. And the controversy also keeps his argument alive, though not always understood: "A lot of productions are important not because anybody saw them," he says, "but because they heard about them. People's imagination of what happened on stage is even more important than what happened on stage. The most important nights in the theatre were seen by only a tiny fraction of the population and yet they have passed into the history of the world."
